Author: walker.reynolds
Content: Question of the day: Do you have experience working in manufacturing, on the plant floor?  If so, which industry?  What do you think was their biggest hurdles to digital transformation?

Author: walker.reynolds
Content: Pinned a message.

Author: r.pop
Content: Great question today @Walker Reynolds my experience started as a controls integrator, launching assembly lines for mostly Automotive. Spent some time in airpor baggage handling as well and about 5 years in Lithium Ion battery manufacturing as well. I think the biggest hurdle to automotive is fear. There’s such a strong mentality of “if it ain’t broke, don’t fix it”. A lot of legacy systems and software as well that are so heavily intertwined to operations, it would be a massive cost to replace/remove.

Author: .dhess
Content:
Do you have experience working in manufacturing, on the plant floor? 
Yes. I've been in the Semiconductor industry since 79: AMD, Signetics, National Semiconductor, Maxim Integrated Products, Linear Technologies, etc.... My career has been spent performing troubleshooting, repair, death by preventive maintenance procedure, modification, upgrading, keeping the calm, writing / improving procedures and specs, leading teams, and many meetings. I train, mentor, assign tasks, push agendas, and console team mates grieving from life's many hardships. I get my pick of any tough, exotic problems that come up, and I love it.

What do you think was their biggest hurdles to digital transformation? 
First off, a full transformation hasn’t been achieved where I work. Additionally, no one has thrown down from the top of the pyramid I live in, that it is a hardcore mandate, and corporate priority. 
Secondly, if it was a top priority, you already spelled out the primary obstacle: Ignorance. Managers have no idea how. 
And why is that? Hardly anyone knows what digital transformation means. Many have never even heard of Industry 4.0. The term is still young in the collective consciousness. Plus, even if they have heard of it, it's similar to what happens if you ask 500 people what heaven is like, you get 500 answers, and likely none of them are 100% right. The full definition can mean a lot of different things to different people. 
Because the answer can be somewhat nebulous, so is the roadmap to it. 
It's a question that leads people to fantasize, or their pupils to dilate to the size of a pinhead, and stare out the window like a confused chicken. Transformation can be a very long journey. It is a living, moving target, like a piece of software: perhaps never completed.

Author: marioishikawa
Content: I can answer as SI and solution provider as I have never been working as an employee on the shop floor. In my opinion the biggest problem is a wrong understanding of what the technologies on the market do and how they help. I've seen many people saying they need a SCADA or Historian as if it was a magical thing that would automatically solve the problem by working in an autonomous way. I've seen people trying add control logic on SCADA to save on PLC. I've seen people expecting Historian performance on SCADA without being commited to the same price tag. I've seen people require a SCADA and Oracle and then expect the SCADA to be a DBA managing the Oracle with the excuse that PLCs don't need maintenance so the database of OT should also not need.  The possibilities are immense and I could stay here for hours writing, but in short is to not know what to buy, how to specify a RFQ and lack of internal and qualified team to manage projects, use all the system can deliver and maintain it.

Author: spanner.john.720
Content:
Industry: Paper converting. Biggest issue to transformation: initially, lack of vision/understanding from upper management and thus lack of budget.  Later a changing of the guard for some upper management, but then they were tied to former vendors who didn't really understand or have experience with the transformation, or understand well what real-time data could buy them besides a possible "I used to have this phone app at my old plant" - but they didn't see value in things like alerts for changes outside of expected parameters, such as when Joe turns a knob at 3am just because he thinks it helps or his notes suggest that's the right # to run at, despite the fact it's been running great all day.  So lack of Vision and Lack of Understanding, leading to a lack of budget and resources.

As an employee and consultant for other companies in the Industrial space around the world I've been fortunate to work with vendors/companies that were working on improving their business by bringing in more real-time data and/or analytics.

But as it's written elsewhere, it's the same here imo - the largest issue is lack of vision/understanding.  This has been an age old issue.  Here's a quote from long ago "My people are destroyed for a lack of knowledge" (Approx. 720 - 780 BC)

Chose right technology to address your problem.
Change Management, ROI

Author: jeastburn9264
Content: Having worked in a few kinds of manufacturing environments with organizations large and small, I'd say the biggest obstacle is that for decision-makers technology is not truly seen as an enabler of business. It's viewed more like a necessary evil: "We'll only get as much as we absolutely need and no more, and don't expect me to understand what it does or evaluate the trade-offs myself. That's what I have you for. But in the end, I'm not really going to listen to any of that analysis because you aren't high enough in the organization to discuss business strategy." <Pardon the rant> My takeaway is that engineers who want to have sway in these decisions need to understand the business. Similarly, tech vendors need to speak directly to the problems that businesses grapple with, not simply pitch features and benefits.

Author: .dhess
Content: @Josh Eastburn Yes. It is very frustrating to deal with people that simply see your department as a cost center. The magic words are: "It will save money."

Author: marioishikawa
Content:
> @Josh Eastburn Yes. It is very frustrating to deal with people that simply see your department as a cost center. The magic words are: "It will save money."
@EgoNoBueno it is a challenge not only on internal sale, but selling in general. It is harder to convince someone to invest resources to reduce costs than it is to convince someone to invest on something that will increase their gross revenue.

Author: andyott33
Content:
> Question of the day: Do you have experience working in manufacturing, on the plant floor?  If so, which industry?  What do you think was their biggest hurdles to digital transformation?
@Walker Reynolds I don't have experience working in manufacturing, however, I did work as a control systems engineer at a large fulfillment center. I believe the largest hurdle was not training/empowering the team to think in a way that would encourage digital transformation. Just as I was leaving, I did see some encouraging things happening to ensure that the team was properly trained.

Author: jeastburn9264
Content:
> @EgoNoBueno it is a challenge not only on internal sale, but selling in general. It is harder to convince someone to invest resources to reduce costs than it is to convince someone to invest on something that will increase their gross revenue.
@Mario Ishikawa that's an interesting perspective. I was thinking the opposite was true, especially for middle managers responsible for stretching the budget as far as it will go. It feel like the idea of investing in growth almost always comes across as a riskier proposition than saving money on what you are already doing. Tell me more 🤔

Author: marioishikawa
Content:
> @Mario Ishikawa that's an interesting perspective. I was thinking the opposite was true, especially for middle managers responsible for stretching the budget as far as it will go. It feel like the idea of investing in growth almost always comes across as a riskier proposition than saving money on what you are already doing. Tell me more 🤔
@Josh Eastburn yes, it all depends of the kind of customer/plant. If it is a plant with 4 lines and there is no more room for a 5th line, the investment to move or build another building, not to mention the machinery cost, can be prohibitive and it is better to work on cost reduction. On the other hand, what some colleagues mention is that when you sell something that makes your customer to make more money you are their happy agenda. It does not need to be necessarily a new machine but maybe an upgrade on it that will make it produce faster. But to simplify we can think of it as CAPEX. Something they buy to just get started. When you sell something to reduce costs, you are usually on the problem agenda of them, and as it is something already running, it is OPEX, usually with several budget limitations. As a friend of mine selling technology for grocery stores to save on energy, he says: it is hard to convince the customer to invest to save when he can use the same budget to buy more refrigerators and then increase food sales. It is possible, of course. But harder to get on their agenda for active sales, meaning, you want to show by your numbers what they can do but that is not what they are worried about. But if the manager already have this in mind than it is easier as you said. They will look for the vendor.

Author: jeastburn9264
Content: @Mario Ishikawa Thanks for clarifying. That makes sense. I'm sure it depends where they are/what their role is in the organization.

Author: walker.reynolds
Content: Pinned a message.

But to some people they would see that as a benefit or a key differentiator.  The same goes for "IIoT" hardware and software.

Author: andersgustav
Content:
(end users point of view here) - They advertise their stuff as Industrie 4.0, but in reality their just tricking you into a proprietary ecosystem that only support their spesific products, service and solutions. And you become unable to freely choose the best buildingblocks for your system.

Yea.. just what the previous posters said..

Author: marioishikawa
Content:
> Question of the day: What is your biggest frustration with current hardware or software solutions available on the market that advertise using IIoT or Industry 4.0 compatibility?
@Walker Reynolds Lack of focus on the Front-End. By the end of the day the interface is what the user will see and most Front-End tools such as a BI or even SCADA are far from complete.

Author: dewayne_warden
Content:
> Question of the day: What is your biggest frustration with current hardware or software solutions available on the market that advertise using IIoT or Industry 4.0 compatibility?
@Walker Reynolds  Hardware and software are company specific, not entirely open.  Technology is rapidly changing but it takes time to assimilate into society, so no matter the number of products or services, it will take time for the market to reveal the winners and losers.  The best place is here to learn, practice and prepare for the future.  Frustrations?  The learning curve and the amount of time to conquer this subject.

Author: benveenema
Content:
> Question of the day: What is your biggest frustration with current hardware or software solutions available on the market that advertise using IIoT or Industry 4.0 compatibility?
@Walker Reynolds Price point is my biggest sticking point with Industry in general. I can buy a $20 micro that has multiple digital and analog inputs, a wifi card and antenna, and easy to use, built-in libraries for writing programs, including MQTT. To get something like that in PLC form is $500+ for a "low-cost" option. I know my $20 micro isn't industrial hardened and requires a circuit board around it but there's a lot of room between $20 and $500 to make a board and lots of profit.

Author: dewayne_warden
Content: @Ben Veenema Good point.  Just remember, your application needs good hardware to last.  "Pay me now, or pay me later" isn't about being the cheapest.  But I do understand if you are trying to reach customers with limited budgets and $20 will carry a long way to helping them.

Author: walker.reynolds
Content: @Ben Veenema and @dewayne_warden you are both right, imo.  This is why we focus on building eco-systems of software and hardware solutions that are built on a technology stack.  There is a place for ESP32 solutions running micropython or C with low grade sensors AND there is a place for high end PLCs with industrial grade sensors -- both fit in the ecosystem.  Choosing which one to use in a specific application is all dependent on the problem, the value of the process it is running and the minimum requirements for reliability.  You have some end-users that don't use low end hardware because it is 'cheap' or its 'hobbyist' and you have some end-users who want to turn away from high end hardware because its too expensive or its overkill.  The IIoT, I 4.0 professional is in the middle -- put both in their tool box and use the right tool for the job.

Author: walker.reynolds
Content: Smartsheets -- we create from the matrix template and can connect directly to a web report.

Author: .dhess
Content:
I am being asked to help in developing a skills matrix and a technology matrix to understand the current state of technology in our facility.  This will be the basis a roadmap of who we get to a desired state.  Has anyone here been involved with a process like this and have some pointers?  I am really interested in any tools people may have used to develop a technology matrix, I am trying to avoid an excel purgatory at all costs.  Look forward to hearing this groups input.
@Densparker I am going to pretend that you are in a manufacturing environment, since I don't know. So does this study span the breadth of all your people responsible for Process, QA, R&D, Equipment Maintenance and Repair, Operators, carpet dwellers, and professional desk flyers? What is the scope here? Who in the company is included in this survey?  As Walker (I surmise) would say, start with your dream company as your destination / desired state, then inventory your technological assets. At least you will have a better idea of what you are missing.  Compiling your core technological assets across the personnel of your company will be less daunting when you know where you want to wind up.  Number crunching however is inevitable in this process. We use https://www.skills-base.com/

Author: bright_hummingbird_31342
Content:
Regarding a training matrix, have you looked into using what you might already have?  If your org is certified to any industry standards (e.g., quality, environmental, security, financial), there's a good chance you might have something.  These invariable have some component of managing awareness and competence across the work force.

What does your company use for an HCM?  Many HCM suites have training modules.  You can roll this into or synthesize with existing training programs.  This software usually have canned-reports you can leverage.  Additionally, many of these have SQL backends, so you can do quite a bit of customization for reporting.

We use our a training module in our ERP today.  The skills are centered around operations, quality, and product development.  They basically state "Employee X must have Skill Y to perform Process Z."  It works well for the day-to-day and auditors love this.  It helps determine training requirements.  It doesn't necessarily facilitate planning, though.  We're looking to formalize aspects of this into formal workforce planning on an HCM.  A lot of training matrices enable one to take stock of the supply and demand of skills, but not necessarily how to change it.  I think a lot of that is driven by the potential of employees.  Too often, we all think about our workforce in terms of what they're capable of doing today, but not tomorrow.

Author: .dhess
Content:
The 3 Unique Challenges of Digitally Transforming in Life Sciences

I finally had a chance to watch this video. I can easily see how Quality Assurance has put a stranglehold on drug manufacturing. In a discussion with my ER/UC Nurse wife, who piloted COVID-SARS-2 testing in our county, drug companies came by the oversight honestly due to past instances of unsanitary conditions, and cases of corner cutting due to sheer greed. https://www.fda.gov/drugs/news-events-human-drugs/cders-efforts-help-improve-quality-drug-compounding-include-ongoing-focus-insanitary-conditions
That said I can see that QA may have gone overboard in their quest of the Holy QA grail. And it sounds like an area of that got overwhelmed with over- the-top regulation is electrical signal validation. I'm certainly not an expert in this area, but I can see how this could happen. I applaud Walker and Team for trying to cut through the bullshit and wind it back down to something reasonable.

https://youtu.be/ragOnNHmjS0

Author: sqlwalkermj
Content: I am currently working with a client who is in the market for a CMMS / EAM solution. We have looked at Infor -  https://www.infor.com/products/eam and UpKeep - https://www.onupkeep.com/.  Both seem like very solid solutions, in the same ballpark from a cost perspective.  Curious if anyone here as any positive or negative feedback on either solution, or can provide insight into an alternative solution. Thanks in advance!

Author: .dhess
Content: @sqlwalkermj Take a long hard look at the API and your ability to script state notifications to it from other parts of the automation stack. Will the CMMS contribute to your OEE calculation methodology? Can users subscribe to the tool sets they want to be notified about?  Paperless / Mobile PM checklists are critical to go paperless. Can it handle it? Can you graph PM derived data such as cal flow rates, temp, etc? Can you retrieve PM archives with out much fuss? Will it integrate with SAP or stores for developing PM kits? Will it integrate with vendors such as Arrow Electronics  or Grainger? Can it handle pareto analysis for sustaining Equipment Engineers? Will the reports it generates make your customer happy. It is hard to get out of bed with a CMMS once you cuddle up to it. Take your time. @DavidSchultz uses UpKeep - weigh in David. Be advised that floor techs will need training to nav the new CMMS platform. Be sure to include a team from Equipment Maintenance to onboard the techs, or plan on a lot of bitching. A lot of maintenance occurs on weekends during Prod downtime, so make sure that work pushed out can have a work order generated for its  completion separate to normal unplanned maintenance tickets.

Author: .dhess
Content: Different topic: Currently downloaded these IEEE articles for bed time reading. DM me if anyone cares to discuss:

Author: sasanka9171
Content: @Walker Reynolds you have mentioned about Tesla model of manufacturing in couple of your videos.  Could you please throw more light and talk a little bit more about this

Author: thedavidschultz
Content:
@sqlwalkermj I only have experience with UpKeep using its APIs to create work orders from an edge device. They are easy to use and allow you to do just about anything.  To use the APIs you will need a business plus or enterprise license. There is an UpKeep community on Slack that is chock full of the usual suspects in maintenance and reliability. Ryan Chan (CEO) does a lot of work to support M&R activities, even if it is on another platform.

 But before you start picking solutions (I heard this somewhere) I would want to know what problem they are trying to solve? Why do they want a new CMMS? How does it fit within their transformation strategy? My experience is that reliability people don't understand technology and technology people don't understand reliability. When it's time, I would also consider Fiix Software. They have open APIs and the platform is built on .NET.  Downside is they were just acquired by Rockwell 🤣

Author: thedavidschultz
Content: Since we talking maintenance, I though the attached might be helpful to your digital transformation.

Author: sqlwalkermj
Content: Thanks for the feedback @EgoNoBueno  --  Yes we have identified the API available on UpKeep and we already have experience integrating with Infor's web services / API and through the ION middleware. I think we have all the functionality you ask about less the vendor integration, I will be sure to investigate and include that in our design if possible.

Author: sqlwalkermj
Content: Thanks for the feedback @DavidSchultz - After reviewing the UpKeep API I was sold, very open and all the integration points we need with this client are included, at least they seem to be documentation for the API. The problem this customer is trying to solve is the current "maintenance" system they use is obsolete, built on MS Access circa 2006. The plant has grown, 10X since then.  We have digitally transformed most of the plant and supporting operations over the past 2.5 years, the maintenance department is looking to tap into our Unified Namespace  data to drive PM activities over time, incorporate the  maintenance schedule  into the production schedule, receive work requests directly from the MES, and move all the standard maintenance functionality to a modern system. I did look at Fiix, but saw that Rockwell had purchased them so unsure of where that product is going now, I will revisit that with this customer.

Author: .dhess
Content: @sqlwalkermj A couple of other side notes. We live and die by comments made in our CMMS. If it isn't written in a comment, it didn't happen. Historical searches are the real meat and potatoes .  CMMS have drastically matured and changed over the years. Just about every manufacturer out there has dabbled in their own home brewed version.  The ability to perform pareto analysis on equipment failures is the only way an organization can  be easily engaged in continuous improvement. Without that ability, the Maintenance department is crippled. Fiix was well engineered. Our facilities department uses it, but EM didn't adopt it due to subscription cost bleed. I would love it if Intellic wrote their own CMMS, and made it 4.0 friendly. I think that would be an awesome product. @DavidSchultz great comments. TY

Author: thedavidschultz
Content: @sqlwalkermj Excellent! I have talked with Walker about his experience with Infor EAM. I am from the school of thought that a CMMS is best done by CMMS folks. ERP companies tend to apply ERP thinking, which may not be appropriate. I am very interested in how you couple the CMMS with the UNS. Please let me know if there will be an opportunity to take a look at how you do this.

Author: bright_hummingbird_31342
Content:
I'm following this discussion on maintenance software.  Currently using an ERP module.  The integration with the non-maintenance modules (e.g., purchasing, inventory, asset list) is nice, but it has the "afterthoughtness" of many ERP modules.  Functionality and user experience are definitely not best-in-class.  There has been under-investment in this product area and most buyers in the ERP-realm lack domain expertise in maintenance or even an appreciation for it..

Infor EMM and UpKeep are new to me.  Is Infor EMM an evolution of MP2?  Anyone using IBM's Maximo these days?  They seem to brand as something new (e.g., "Watson", "AI"), but I have not cut through the marketing.

There are some less-traditional options I've pondered:  ServiceMax and ServiceNow.  Service Max is a field service SaaS app built on the Salesforce platform and was recently acquired by GE Digital.  ServiceNow is a IT service management platform that has become somewhat of the premier workflow cloud and jack-of-all-trades for service management.  Organizations are beginning to leverage it for HR, field service, maintenance, etc.

Author: walker.reynolds
Content: My message there is referring to specialized hardware like PLCs and Embedded Controllers.  My point is, we should not be controlling equipment (control logic specifically) from software running on a pc or server.  Process control should be running on specialized equipment like a PLC or an Embedded Controller.  They are designed specifically for this purpose.

Author: mikec5454
Content: Walker  finally realized I had not hit that 'JOIN' button!  💯  agree on the need for specialized systems, simply because of the built-for-purpose design.  The system must complete scans deterministically. Can we control with PC's and servers - yes, and APC has run successfully for decades in that space. But real-time control demands 2 qualities - execute on time, and high availability.  On that note - when will high availability VM platforms be enough to address true redundancy on the availability side? Really cool opportunity for continuous improvement in the platform services end of the DCS and high perf PLC world.

Author: alenduranovic
Content: Hello. Are there any CMMS or MES on the market which are completely ISA 95 compliant?

Author: thedavidschultz
Content: What do you mean by ISA-95 compliant? In a CMMS Assets are assigned to a Location, which is a physical address (could be thought of as Site). Within the asset definition you will have an Area and a Parent Asset, which could correlate to an ISA-95 structure (Line/Cell). To my knowledge there is not a specific reference to ISA-95 within a CMMS.

Author: alenduranovic
Content: Sorry, I meant ISA 95 compliant in terms of integration with other nodes.

Author: thedavidschultz
Content: The Sepasoft MES modules use ISA-95 and recommend you use the same structure for physical tags. That way you can use {parentPath} in to connect to your SCADA system.  Sepasoft training vides guide you through this process. I am not aware of a CMMS that builds out assets this way. That said, most CMMS software software will allow you to view data organized in a method similar to "Site/Area/Line/Cell". For instance, I can view open Work Orders based on Assets and Parent Assets. If I want to create a Work Order from another system, that is done purely by Asset ID. Hope this helps although not sure if it answers you question.

Author: john_cindrich
Content: Curious if anyone sees Microsoft PowerBI as something that would be useful as part of a digitally transformed ecosystem. I've done a little work with it but am wondering PowerBI becomes redundant with tools like FactoryStudio

Author: marioishikawa
Content: I see Power BI or any other BI tools as very important and the reason is: with Ignition or FactoryStudio you will usually end up with a powerful back end and engine, with some cool displays and reports, but any new report someone wants will need you, the programmer, again. In a large corporation, different users will need different new reports every day. On the other hand, with Power BI and the right data users can create the report they need on their own, and this correct data can be prepared by FactoryStudio.

Author: marioishikawa
Content: So, I don't see it reduntant to FactoryStudio. It does not collect, transforms and store data. But it gives you an DIY interface flexibility that the SCADA end user does not have.

Content: It is challenging to find the most ideal way to work towards the Industry 4.0 situation. I am very new to it all, so there is a lot to discover. For sake of the future, a good standard needs to be implemented, however something like Unified namespace sounds like a complex situation to realize. It is ideal for a very modern factory where multiple systems are connected. However, when you are at the start of the transformation, like me, it is a very expensive and extensive transformation. Author: zackscriven
Content:
Remember the Minimum Technical Requirements for an IIoT Ecosystem:

1. Edge-Driven
2. Report by Exception
3. Lightweight
4. Open Architecture

To answer your question, OPC-UA doesn't meet these requirements.

Content: Ohh... Erich's response to my comment is making me laugh 😆 he is a 17-year Microsoft employee works for the OPCUA Foundation and thinks MQTT is proprietary... Says I'm locking manufacturers into walled gardens to boot.

Author: matthijsprent
Content: I have been thinking about OPC-UA vs UNS. This might be a dumb question but it was just a thought. Why is OPC-UA not suitable as middleware in order to connect PLC's (edge devices?) to the unified namespace and vise versa? It would not serve the purpose of connecting everything together, but just a small edge part.

Author: zackscriven
Content: It absolutely is. You aren't getting rid of OPC-UA. It's just not suited to be the UNS.  Going forward it will be less and less necessary as edge devices will support Open IIoT Protocols out of the box.

Author: zackscriven
Content: It's really simple. We have the results to prove it... they are part of the OPC-UA foundation. We have no ties to MQTT other than it works for us, our clients, and for the 7.5k subscribers on our YouTube channel that give credit and validation that we are helping the community.... not steering them towards a solution we have a vested interest in succeeding going forward (Unlike the OPC-UA Foundation... or Rockwell Etc Etc)

Author: jon.forbord
Content: I had this same train of thoughts after seeing Walker's OPC UA video. "But... OPC UA IS the future ?!?". At least compared to OPC DA. It eventually occurred to me I was thinking too narrowly on the use case. I was thinking about PLC connectivity and only comparing it to OPC DA and native protocols. As Zack says. OPC UA can absolutely be used to connect to PLCs, but only because a specific PLC doesn't come with an IoT protocol built in (edge driven, report by exception, light weight, open).

Author: thedavidschultz
Content: I have watched the OPC-UA video several times along with passing it along to other people (not in Discord). I have also seen several discussions regarding OPC-UA, MQTT, etc. There have also been discussions around hardware, software and other parts of a technology stack. I am also reminded of the "brain surgeon" video. For every project, as the "brain surgeon", it is our job to pick the technology that is best for the application. There is no one silver bullet on anything.

Author: bright_hummingbird_31342
Content:
And it's worth mentioning that Erich is not just any Microsoft employee.  He heads up Azure's Industrial IoT team.

I don't believe that Microsoft thinks MQTT is proprietary.  They actually leverage MQTT (as well as AMQP) as transport in their own platform.  If I recall correctly, many Azure products even "strip out" OPC-UA along the way and exchange data in simple JSON form.  In general, I believe Microsoft and the OPC Foundation's have the right intentions, but they're not truly addressing the problem.  It feels good to everyone selling, but it's not helping those deploying and using (e.g., manufacturers, machine builders, system integrators).

Personally, I have not had issues with the relative "openness" of OPC-UA or how heavy it is.  I've generally had the luxury of performant networks and don't perceive the barriers to entry as significant or prohibitive.  But, I recognize this is definitely not a universal experience.  My biggest critique is the adoption of the standard.  It tries to be everything to everyone and makes it all optional.  It's like a non-binding UN agreement without any real "teeth" (e.g., substance, accountability).  It's more symbolic than substantive.  We still can't buy assets, applications, or platforms that are intelligently aware of each other.  Specifying OPC-UA does not change this.  The vast majority of OPC-UA implementations are still exchanging information in the same way it has been done for 30 years with OPC Classic.  This is not helping manufacturers digitally transform.

Author: mparris
Content:
Great insight.

OPC-UA has been interesting to explore the non DA functions. For example, in the AutoID spec, there is a tag that represents the LastScanData. A client can also subscribe to the event of the scan coming in, which includes the scan data and other metadata. The tag will give you the data at the negotiated scan rate, whereas the event subscription fires immediately (0 lag in data). I don't know if any Sparkplug client-devices allow this function: segregating some data for publishing immediately and others at a rate. Obviously something like ignition it HighByte could do this, but don't know if devices are set up this way. So OPC has great features.

Author: mparris
Content:
Then, you start dreaming of being able to plug in a piece of equipment and all devices in the ecosystem can detect that addition. It gets complicated in OPC-UA. You need an OPC-UA client/server aggregator, then you need a way for that aggregator to discover the new server, and initiate it's connection, then the aggregator needs to insert the equipment in it's address space so it makes sense (data modeling) then the devices in the ecosystem need to detect the change in the address space of the aggregator and then the devices need to create their subscriptions to the new equipment.

I don't even think this functionality even exists in the market (I've looked) and likely is at least five years out.

Author: mparris
Content: Or you could just use MQTT with SparkplugB: your equipment connects to the broker, devices use the wildcard subscription and instantly see the additional equipment with data, and Dynamic applications will accommodate the addition (HMI screens for example).  This functionality had existed for a couple years now.

Author: thedavidschultz
Content: Haven't used a shipping box, but pretty familiar with a folding chair and 5 gallon bucket (upside down is the preferred orientation).

Author: walker.reynolds
Content: Spot on -- we built a completely self aware SCADA application for a gold plating process using MQTT SPBv1.  You could move sensors around the line, to different cells (rectifiers and ph sensors were the big ones) and the SCADA application would self discover that the sensor was moved in the namespace and it would automatically move to the correct cell in the visualization.  It worked great for deploying new lines with different configurations of sensors... the only limitation was that you needed to integrate a new faceplate or visual object each time you created a new type of sensor... but after that, fully self-aware.  The device drove the visuals, no server side work at all.

Author: mparris
Content:
My colleagues and I knew we wanted self-discovery and I distinctly remember discussing this amongst ourselves in our OPC-UA training class. Spent a year learning the space to see what would be needed to operationalize the idea.

Then tried SparkplugB and the self-discovery vision was instantly operationalized. 

This should always be point #1 in the OPC-UA vs SparkplugB debate. After that question is answered, then other merits can be compared.

Author: bright_hummingbird_31342
Content:
This is somewhat of a broad question.  It would be helpful to obtain some specifics on your system integration projects and the MES applications you work with.

Here's the short, unqualified answer:  .NET, Java, Python, SQL

In general, .NET and Java are the most prevalent languages in enterprise software.  In recent years, the adoption of Python has grown considerably.  These combined with SQL for databases cover many needs.  These tools should be capable of solving most integration problems.

It's worth mentioning that the manufacturing and industrial space is no stranger to legacy technologies.  You will invariably encounter legacy applications that exist because an organization's culture rewards stability and, hence, complacency.  Don't be surprised to see VB or IBM mainframe tech.  You may need to coexist with or migrate from these systems.  While I would not advise directly learning this tech, I believe it's important to be capable of working with people who have.

Ignition and Factory Studio are popular platforms among this community and its founders.  These solutions are built on Java and .NET, respectively.  Both have support for scripting with Python.

Useful technical skills for system integration involving MES:

  -A foundation in object-oriented programming (e.g., .NET, Java)
  -Scripting with a higher-level general purpose language (e.g., Python)
  -Programming relational databases (e.g., T-SQL, PL/pgSQL, PL/SQL, MySQL)
  -Working with APIs (e.g., HTTP/S, REST, SOAP)
  -Working with IoT and field protocols (e.g., MQTT, OPC-UA, EtherNet/IP, PROFINET)

Author: zackscriven
Content:
Complicated: The most common complaint about OPC UA is how complicated it is to implement.  The OPC UA spec is 1250 pages. Many companies don’t implement the full OPC Server, and even if they do it also requires routers, firewalls and VPN.  New devices must be configured and connected rather than auto-discovered.

https://www.manufacturingtomorrow.com/article/2020/07/iiot-protocols-comparing-opc-ua-to-mqtt/15534

Content: Guys, have you seen this open source (Linux, Apache), edge processing ware called FogLamp, and what do you think? Author: benveenema
Content:
I've been asked to write-up a short paragraph for our quarterly customer newsletter about our digital transformation efforts.

Although our customer may be a little interested in how we're changing our process, I think they'd be much more interested in how an I4.0 version of our company will service them better. I've got a few bullet point ideas but I'm interested what others in this community think about: *How does a digitally transformed company effect or better service there customers?*

We're mostly a B2B company that sells widgets in bulk but ideas for any manufacturing strategy are welcome.

Author: benveenema
Content:
My ideas/thoughs so far:
- Higher on-time delivery rate, less delays
- Shorter lead times (possibly)
- Less defects, deeper quality insights, lot tracing capabilities
- Faster order tracking
- Higher predictability

Author: daniel_hirsch
Content: Small lot sizes, pull prodction, Small variant rotation periods, Small setup times. Minimum waste. Basically the lean principles 🤔 depends on products (variants, volumes)

Author: venkyiaf753280
Content:
Product customization
Better UX

Author: Deleted User
Content: Provide them with a real-time status of their current order.

Author: benveenema
Content:
Here's the blurb I came up with.

**Digital Factory**
<Company> has started a pilot program and initiative for digitally transforming the entire way we manufacture our <Widgets>. Over the next few years, every piece of equipment, machinery and process will be plugged into our network, enabling real-time information access and predictive analytics to your products as we produce them.

This process will bring manufacturing information, in real-time:
- To our operators and maintenance staff on plant floor - enabling them to make better, decisions, faster so your parts arrive on-time, and at the highest quality
- To our engineers and planners - so they can design the best possible processes, reducing lead times and predicting issues before they happen
- To our quality department - providing deeper insights for root cause analysis and lot tracing as events occur
- To the environment - by minimizing waste and running our equipment more efficiently
- To our customers - allowing you to plan and better predict your own manufacturing by providing up-to-the-minute status reports and accurate delivery predictions in addition to higher quality

This is an exciting process for us and we look forward to sharing more as we progress.

Author: thedavidschultz
Content: Like the answer to many questions...it depends. From a high level you want to build the technology stack and then select the components that meet minimum technical requirements. Questions to ask are what is the problem I am trying to solve? How does this effort fit into the broader digital transformation strategy? Even a simple application for adding a few sensors and historizing the data can be done in many ways. There is not a one size fits all approach. Author: daniel_hirsch
Content: Distinguish methods for data processing and distribution. For data distribution, use of a message-based middleware that serves as a BACKBONE (UNS) and distributes all data to nodes (Devices, SQL, noSQL DBs) . For historical data, use batch processing to train ML models. For streaming data Stream Processing for applying ML models to real-time data to realize closed loop control. Roughly speaking. But a heavy engineering lift.

Author: zackscriven
Content: No worries! We are in the Mastermind Session right now.

Author: jeff_flow
Content: Hey John.  One thing I have learned in speaking with lots of different end users... reporting means something different to everyone!  Historians and SCADA tend to be great for 'what's happening now' reporting needs.  Some Historian and SCADA options can handle a bit more, including asset condition reports.  BI tools tend to only address reporting needs for large periods of time with processed data rollups.  One tool I like for reporting outside the historian is Flow Software.  They do a great job at combining multiple historians, sql dbs, and scada solutions to a single data bucket that can show resolution down to one minute processed data.  They also do a great job at rolling up data to contextualize it into production or business calenders.  It's like PowerBI but built by process engineers for process engineers.

Author: lukesmaul
Content: Hi All. After 20 years in the Industrial Automation and IIoT space I decided that technology alone was not the answer to "Digital Transformation".  I spent the last number of years helping companies understand how to fundamentally change how they work with their customers so that both parties can realize the benefits of digital. This has meant launching things like product-as-a-service business models. All fun stuff but really only for those companies who are advanced in their  digital strategies. The questions for this group is if you agree that manufactures have to change the conversations they're having with end customers to survive in a digital world? OR, is there just so much value locked up in optimizing existing operations  that focusing inside the four walls of the enterprise is more than enough to satisfy the expectations of a Digital Transformation?

Author: thedavidschultz
Content: The conversation needs to change. DX is not an option unless you just want to sell your business. The second question sounds similar to a bunch of CI efforts. DX is not CI.

Author: lukesmaul
Content: Glad you agree the conversation needs to change and that it needs to be about more than just CI. 👍👍 I didn't understand your comment about selling your business though?

Author: thedavidschultz
Content: Meaning the owners want to sell and plan to go out of business. Then you don’t need to change a thing 🤣

Author: lukesmaul
Content: Ah, yes, or they're riding it out until retirement. 😂😂 - How ready do you think manufactures are to embrace this new conversation with their customers? I keep finding the early adopters who are ready for it but can't tell yet where the rest of the market is.

Author: sherylmccrary
Content:
Hi Luke. Great that you're looking for and finding the early adopters. The rest/majority of the market is confused at this point. We're definitely in agreement here that DT is not the next iteration of CI. 
Zack did a reaction vid to a manufacturing podcast recently in which he/we comment on that very point about what's being presented as a 4.0 solution but is really a 3.0 status quo extension.

It's more radical and exciting.

For manufacturers specifically,  I would say Digital Transformation happens at the intersection of Ind4.0 and shifting market trends being driven by broader digital disruption.
That intersection is where I see the new value we should be chasing being.

Author: sherylmccrary

Author: srihari9539
Content: To add from my experience, I've often viewed digital transformation as the transformation of an entire ecosystem consisting of people, processes and technology. Or rather, the processes that govern the interactions between people and technology... with technology rarely being the bottleneck 😅

Author: lukesmaul
Content: Love this ecosystem definition! Have you found certain industries or functions more receptive to this broader definition?

Author: srihari9539
Content: One industry I’ve had some experience with in this regard has been fabrication of advanced composite aero-structures. You tend to have a mix of automation and manual work all stitched together with stringent process controls imposed by OEMs. Getting sensor-based data from machines is one thing but finding ways to get real time data from people on the production floor is quite another! Also, a lot of these companies usually have well defined standard work procedures that have been in place a long time. This often creates friction and an aversion to experiment with solutions that are perceived as ‘disruptive’ to the status quo (particularly when dealing with manufacturers who are tier 2 / tier 3 in the supply chain)

Author: IIoT#4707
Content: GG @srihari, you just advanced to level 1!

Author: lukesmaul
Content: Oh yes. Aerospace is a fun one! I did a three week onsite with one of the big airframe manufacturers. Our Digital Transformation recommendations challenged the standard work procedures. The response from the executive team “We brought you in to help us change how we build planes. You told us we need to change how we build planes. We can’t change how we build planes”. No joke. End of project 😂

Author: IIoT#4707
Content: GG @Luke Smaul, you just advanced to level 3!

Author: srihari9539
Content: Everyone thinks we do our most fascinating work with our aerospace clients... but honestly I've been having a lot more fun of late with a company that manufactures terry towels...

Author: srihari9539
Content: Industry aside, I've also found it to be more of a challenge when working with manufacturers that carry out a high component of manual work as opposed to those that are highly automated. Connecting workers to the digital ecosystem is challenging and reduces the efficiency of analysis that depends on accurate real time data from all stakeholders..

Author: srihari9539
Content: As an example, in one factory they used to log updates for the shift on a piece of paper and then collate this data at the end of each shift, make reports at the end of the day etc.. HMI's were installed to allow workers to log data at source but the fact that people were used to the old process for so many years meant that they would still often write down what they did on a piece of paper and then update it using the HMI at the end of each shift.

Author: srihari9539
Content: Hence the emphasis early on that technology alone cannot solve the problem (a point btw which you articulated very nicely in your video!) and rather what is needed is a re-imagination of processes that govern the interaction between people and technology....

Author: lukesmaul
Content: Yes! “Re-imagining” captures it so well. It’s why I use Design Thinking in our transformation methodology.

Author: walker.reynolds
Content:
I like to say this... Digitization is not Digital Transformation but they are related.  Digitization (the act of taking something manual or paper and making it digital) is a sub-set of Digital Transformation (a strategy for changing the way manufacturers operate their businesses by leveraging real-time digital data and information to drive decision making).  Digitization is the easy stuff -- there's nothing special about taking a paper traveler and turning it into a digital visualization (it takes hours to do).  Digital Transformation is hard, very hard, because it requires a level of vision and strategy that most organizations are simply not accustomed to exercising.  Digital Transformation is about exponentially increasing the collective knowledge of an organization -- Digitization is simply taking a physical or manual thing and making it digital (something you can make many virtual copies of).  RE: Digital Transformation, if what we want (use case) is a function of what we know, and DT is about exponentially increasing the collective knowledge of an organization, then what we know will change exponentially across the organization as a function of DT.  You must implement a strategy FIRST that accounts for this scaling knowledge -- because what you want will scale at the same rate.  This is why organizations fail in DT -- they start with the wrong strategy, technology or partners... and then they can't scale their digital solutions with their collective knowledge.  

I spend most of my time re-wiring the ways companies think -- so they can implement the right strategy, use the right technology and avoid the wrong partners.  This community is all about creating an army of professionals who take the same approach.

Great convo -- and thanks for the contribution @Luke Smaul and @Venkatesh

Author: walker.reynolds

Content: Omar is right -- Mentorship and Digital Mastermind programs are designed exactly for what you are asking for.  Mentorship is a program for training technology professionals to support digital transformation iterations (projects), Mastermind is a program for training business or technology professionals to lead digital transformation initiatives.  @zackscriven  or @Vaughn Turner can explain more for you if needed.

Author: venkyiaf753280
Content: Can anybody in the group share some use cases of DT in the aerospace industry? Would much appreciate that. Thank you.

Author: lukesmaul
Content: Aerospace is super interesting use case as a whole. You have the engine builders (e.g. GE and Rolls Royce) pioneering outcome based business models and offering Time-On-Wing contracts that rely on connectivity and analytics. You’ve got the airlines using similar IoT-esque infrastructure and analytics to optimize their Maintenance and Repair Operations (MRO): Delta working with startups in the early 2000s created some of the market leaders in the space. In contrast the aircraft manufactures (e.g. Boeing) are somewhat hamstrung by FAA regs to adopt newer systems on the shop floor. Thankfully ind4.0 is paying off in different ways for the manufacturers with additive manufacturing becoming mainstream for light weight and complex parts. Let me know which part of the industry you’re interested in and I can pull up some use cases.

Author: walker.reynolds
Content: The answer is by spending a lot of money to overcome technical debt accrued through a use-case approach.  Delta, fortunately, had the money to spend and an infrastructure wholly owned and maintained by IT.  There are a handful of similar examples in discrete manufacturing -- also in highly regulated environments (Germany and France) but they fall short of the contemporary vision and definition of I 4.0.  Aerospace is a fascinating use-case, indeed... one that can be difficult to bridge over to dissimilar industries.

Not sure on the OT/IT side based on the stuff I had exposure to, but either way I agree on falling short on a contemporary vision of Ind4.0. Author: jameswise8829
Content:
Short notice but I've got a meeting with a group of plant managers today. We've been working on our digital transformation for a little while but this is a group of people I haven't talked to directly before. I'm going to frame what we are trying to do. In addition to other things, I've got a few "general comments" that I thought might help though. If anyone has other thoughts/suggestions, all input is appreciated:  

* Data and Pretty Dashboards don’t provide value. Actions from information that can be unlocked from data we collect is where we see value. Insights provide no value, actions from insights do.

* Our operators, technicians, etc… often know what problems they have and have ideas about what they need to solve those problems. 

* Information NOW, not tomorrow!

* No matter how pretty, I’ve never seen a dashboard run a machine. I have, however, seen dashboards and systems help PEOPLE to run machines more efficiently, decrease costs, improve quality, increase customer satisfaction, help with safety, etc…

* Digital Transformation is about making data collection, and using that data, easier. It is about giving users what they need and letting them act on that instead of spending as much time with collection/processing. Digital Transformation isn’t about eliminating jobs through automation. If anything, it can create jobs by providing more information and improving the business allowing us to create more positions.

This was when travelling existed. There was also a sensor company doing a show and tell to a bunch of plant manufacturers on these new wireless sensors, they bought them lunch and everything. However, I remember how unengaged they were. I feel like people need to be motivated to use technology. How can this technology help me in my career? Help me achieve my goals? Help me make more money? How can this technology help me get promoted or get a raise?

Author: sherylmccrary
Content:
@James Wise Hope it went well for you today.

I love this top-level overview from a CESMII presentation for several reasons. 
1. It's circular, not linear. The nested loops within the bigger one allow you to talk about the levels of DT benefits--- local data to machine, real-time integrated plant status, enterprise level analysis, ML... 

2. It's completely divorced from software, devices, platforms and whether something is done on the edge, on-prem or in the cloud, which are all distractions to the big picture. 

3. It makes it obvious that DT is a strategy for *leveraging data* that requires a data architecture that can enable it.

Author: walker.reynolds
Content:
@James Wise how was your message received?  I've added some thoughts below.

1. Data are the ingredients and information is the meal.  We turn ingredients into meals for sustenance.  Raw data (ingredients) is valuable only to the extent that it can be transformed into information (meal)  that can be analyzed and acted upon.  Most folks agree with this statement -- the piece that most are missing is that what we want to cook (design or develop a capability) is a function of what ingredients we have available to us.  The value we place on a specific ingredient is a function of value we have realized from turning that ingredient into a meal.  Dashboards don't provide value per se, but they do provide an entry-point into the real value... which is turning data into information that we can act on -- over and over again, iteratively.

2. The smartest people in the org are on the plant floor -- they can save us millions if we listen to and enable them.  Digital Transformation is, in part, all about enabling them to unlock potential on the plant floor.

3. Make decisions today based on data we collect today and compare to data we collected yesterday (or last week or last month etc)

4. Dashboards are simply a pane of glass through which we enter in order to turn data into information that we can act on.

5. Digital Transformation is about taking the data all around you, that you likely don't even know is there, and begin to collect it in real-time, in a unified way, in order to turn that data into information to drive decisions in real-time.  I often like to ask plant managers to forget everything they know about technology, about what's possible, about what is practical and ask them to work with me to whiteboard the perfect operation -- what would it look like if EVERYTHING were possible AND we have unlimited time and money?  I then take their dreams and draw a straight line from today to the realization of their perfect operation.  That is DT.

Nice work.

Author: benveenema
Content:
I don't know if it's a broader trend or just my personal bias but I think we are going to see traditional ladder PLCs replaced with structured text or C++ PLCs. These higher level programming languages are going to play better with the digital factory and offer more sophisticated edge computing to take advantage of the additional information a digitized factory will have available.

This will be an effort for the existing maintenance staff to come up to speed  on.

Author: thedavidschultz
Content: Curious if anyone has experience with IOHub. It looks to be an appliance than runs a number of Docker containers. The platform merely facilitates the provisioning of the container. Once provisioned, the Docker can be run anywhere.

Author: mparris
Content:
I hadn't heard of it, thanks for sharing.

Looks to be a version of Balena.io where licenses came with a purchase of their hardware devices.

https://www.ezvpn.online/ioindustry/pricing

Balena has an open source component that is free, but cloud access is an annual subscription. Balena does make a single board computer (raspberry flavored), but they support over 50 other boards, including generic PCs

Author: walker.reynolds
Content: Agreed... We are seeing wide adoption of IEC-1131 and structured text programming across a broad array of industries.  The driving factor is the need for more seamless integration to infrastructure.  We use Wago PLCs with IEC-1131 FB and publish the entire structure of the block and the current state of all parameters via MQTT with a JSON payload.  More and more we are finding others doing the same thing.

Author: sherylmccrary
Content:
@zackscriven Oh, it definitely hit one of my personal rant topics (!) about Product Managers---that they often don’t understand real-world needs of their intended end-users. You don’t get that from business analytics alone. You get it from listening to people where they work or having done their job yourself. (You get info about customer behavior from analytics but not their motivations, pain points for value creation.)

The prevailing MVP approach is a two-edged sword---a way to continuously create value, or pressure to start developing “solutions” without validating what problems are to be solved.  Few companies actually do the work of customer development---creating, demonstrating, verifying real-world value in an operational setting, and testing value propositions in the specific targeted communities. The point is to develop what people need but may not have even envisioned yet, not what your business wants to sell.

There’s a conversation I think is related to this starting here https://discord.com/channels/738470295056416930/738470295056416934/830411769628852226 with @Daniel_H. Daniel’s lament about non-substantive product offerings… 

continuing with @Mario Ishikawa Mario’s comments about empty marketing promises. https://discord.com/channels/738470295056416930/738470295056416934/830411769628852226

This is how those things happen; it’s the result of the disconnect between academia and industry and between product development with the real-world.

Author: daniel_hirsch
Content:
The disconnect in I4.0 topics and DT between science and practice leads to great uncertainty, especially for young engineers like me.

I know from my university, for example, that Siemens supports many industrial research projects at the chairs. Perhaps this disconnect is deliberate or the teaching has a bias because of the funders. That's how you come into contact with these closed systems at an early stage. 

My critical attitude only results from the fact that my father is familiar with this area and knows the dominance of Siemens (as a example), for example on the PLC side, and what problems it brings for the automation landscape in companies.

Speaking of the automation landscape. As a young engineer, you enter the companies and experience this dominance. If you then ask whether there are alternatives that are more open, you very quickly come up against the argument: "Everything in our company is Siemens, that has proven itself, we will continue to use an automation solution from Siemens in the future. Discussion over and so you adapt to this world if you don't want to keep swimming against the tide.

Author: sherylmccrary
Content: Yes, it is almost impossible to innovate from inside a traditional industry.

Author: walker.reynolds
Content: Spot on... which is why we see innovation, typically, from new disruptive companies not the entrenched.  Strategic business and technical debt are very hard to overcome.

Author: benveenema
Content:
As a fellow young engineer, I think this is where we have to be bold and maybe take some risks when opportunities present themselves. Educate ourselves and practice with the Siemens and Rockwell alternatives, and when we get the chance to lead a project, be ready to implement something else that we believe will provide a better outcome.

The only way to win the "Siemens is just what we use" is to demonstrate a better alternative. No one can argue with results.

Author: daniel_hirsch
Content:
I mean, you definitely shouldn't fully fade out Siemens or Rockwell. These companies are also developing. But I wish it were more about technology and methods than about names. It's much more important than recognising trends and their possibilities and weighing them against the problems (there is no free lunch).

That's how I see the role as a technician. Perhaps too idealistic. But you're young...

Author: daniel_hirsch
Content:
Speaking of no free lunch: In the context of event-driven architecture, I keep coming across a statement that concerns me: The asynchronous pub/sub pattern, in contrast to the synchronous req/res pattern, does not expect responses, but rather has the character of a notification rather than a command. The loose coupling ensures that the chains of command from one application to the next are no longer so clearly visible, which makes troubleshooting more difficult.

How serious is this problem in practice? How is it dealt with?

Author: walker.reynolds
Content: It isn’t serious at all when using using QoS 2 and adding the confirmation logic into the node and not expecting it from the protocol.

Author: daniel_hirsch
Content:
Suppose I were to reduce a stock of goods in a storage system and at the same time increase the supermarket of a line, then it is important that in the end both systems consume the message. QoS2 guarantees that.
Assuming this interaction of storage system and line supermarket is preceded by the start of a production order as an event from MES, how do I link this event to the warehouse-event? Are EventIDs useful to track the event from source to sink?

Author: benveenema
Content:
"adding the confirmation logic into the node"

Is this adding poll/response on top of pub/sub? 

An example is a robotic arm gets a published MQTT command to pick up an object and then publishes a "received, understood and acting" response followed by an "action completed" response?

Author: ianskerrett.
Content: There is tooling that is emerging to help with troubleshooting pub/sub message patterns. For instance, with HiveMQ we have trace recordings that can isolate the message pattern with a particulate client.

Author: walker.reynolds
Content: You link them in UNS.  MQTT is stateful, that is, if I have a topic called Production Order and a Topic called Goods Quantity and I want to know which GQ events are related to which Production Orders then I simply read the ‘state’ of the namespace at a specific moment in time (like when Im updated of the new value on my goods quantity topic).

Author: walker.reynolds
Content: The payload of the topic would be your logic states.  Remember, MQTT is stateful — that is, all the values (from the payloads) of all the topics in namespace are their values right now — always.  There are no dark periods between polls, in other words.  The one caveat is... you can set up a node to only publish updates to the broker no faster than n interval, but by default this is not enabled.

Author: walker.reynolds
Content: If QoS is 2 and you are connected then the message got there...

Author: marioishikawa
Content: Not sure how to solve but here it goes: more flexibility for employees. Having a startup, I see tons of people who are interested in this kind of company, usually attracted not only by innovation but a different culture, and a feeling of more control on their tasks and lives. Even with automation, operators have their time dictated by machines. Machines are expensive and if they are available and need operators, operators have to adjust to their time and not the opposite. I once was talking to a plant owner that mentioned he got a coffee machine to make his operator lives better. But then he noticed some people were bringing their own mugs from home. I really did not understand what was the problem with bringing their own mug and he mentioned that the machine could provide a small plastic cup, but with their own mug they would fill with more coffee and stay more time away from the machine. So, this is the type of mentality that in my opinion need to change and it is not only cultural. Technology should be applied to improve that.

Author: marioishikawa
Content: I mean, this is the kind of thing that moves people away from factories to offices. Being an operator is not a trending career.

Author: lukesmaul
Content: Love it @Mario Ishikawa  - what you are referring to, specifically in Manufacturing,  is Taylorism (time and motion studies) versus Lean (self reflection, team work and continuous improvement). Both cultures/management styles rely on technology to be implemented well (a stopwatch is tech after all) and improved upon. Unfortunately, technology is culture-agnostic. Some more reading: https://www.lean.org/balle/DisplayObject.cfm?o=3179#:~:text=Lean%20is%20about%20self%2Dreflection,on%20%E2%80%9Cthose%20who%20do.%E2%80%9D&text=In%20other%20words%2C%20they%20were,describe%20a%20classic%20time%20study.

Author: marioishikawa
Content: Thanks! And the point I bring actually is more on how appealing the shop floor is for the your generations as a workplace. Despite of the effort on Lean and Digital Transformation, there is a lot to be done. The first one is very clear now: the operator cannot work from home, for obvious reasons, but the IT guy can. There is no easy solution, but it can drive a problem similar to what happens to truck driving (there is a shortage of drivers as people are not looking for it, although for this case we see a solution with self driving vehicles).

Author: lukesmaul
Content: I don't know dude, call it micro-manufacturing, stick a tasting room on one end and I think we have a model for how young people want to engage in manufacturing. Highly recommend FutureProof if you want to learn more about craftsmanship, it's link to Lean, and critically it's role in humanizing our experiences (shop floor or otherwise) in the coming decades. We've got to remember we are talking about the post-Facebook, post-Valley generation here too.  https://www.amazon.com/Futureproof-Rules-Humans-Age-Automation/dp/059313334X

Author: walker.reynolds
Content: This is a tad mis-leading (4 legs good, 2 legs bad is a metaphor for demonstrating the dangers of arbitrary contrasts within social groups being leveraged to shift power from one arbitrary group to another).  An organization’s Industry 3.0 mindset, as a function of recruiting and developing the manufacturing employee of the future is a leading indicator that an organization will have greater difficulty in recruiting and developing the technologists needed to build the work force of the future.  This is a measurable fact — one that shows up in every demographic and industry survey and report I have read or worked on in the last decade.  Technologists, especially those from Gen Z, are looking for 2 things in an organization — a common mission that transcends business and society AND a commitment to leveraging and working with bleeding edge technology.  If one is a leader who believes that a full blown commitment to technology, employee enablement, collective knowledge, data collection and information driven, real-time decision making, are not the foundations upon which your organization will be built upon, then one is wrong — and this can be empirically proven.

Author: walker.reynolds
Content: I do not believe that all ideas are created equal and that we should apply the same weight of value to all ideas, simply because someone has that idea.  However, I do believe it is critical that we maintain a culture where we can freely share ideas — even ‘bad’ ones — AND we live up to our commitment to challenge all ideas (both those that will turn out to be both good OR bad) in service of our mission.

Author: walker.reynolds
Content: I’ve given a lot of thought about GE — but have chosen to leave them out of our presentations and content primarily because they simply are not a legitimate player in the Industry 4.0 space.  GE was once the gold-standard in industry and now they are quickly approaching punchline status.  When one considers the power of the brand, the advocacy from Buffett et al within capital markets, and the tribal and formalized industrial knowledge and expertise extending out of the legacy businesses — it it quite difficult to comprehend how GE could have been so wrong.  Luke — you correctly highlight many of the things that GE has done right after 2000 that should have positioned them to take over a market vulnerable to attack (Rockwell is the least respected, appreciated, valued player in the industrial solutions market — one with 75% market share in the U.S.).  At the end of the day, GE simply did not leverage all of their advantages because their strategy was flat-out wrong.  As MP likes to point out, do you want to be stuck in AOLs platform for internet access or would you rather use a web-browser?  GE, as a player in the I 4.0 market, is running out of time... and I see no indication they have even changed tacks, let alone are pointed in the right direction.  For all of the advantages they started with... and the ‘right’ decisions they have actually made... they simply do not have the results to show for it.  Immelt is to blame for that — his hubris passed on down through the organization and it is demonstrated in the products, services and distribution strategies they employ.  I hope GE turns it around, I do... but until such a time, they are an example of what not to do in this space.  (Innovation isn’t continuous improvement — emerging companies don’t start with lean, they start with great ideas and agility).

Author: walker.reynolds
Content: You build a team, one person, one subject, one expertise at a time.  We use a T-Based team building model, and we built wheels out of our teams.  Each team all share something in common (the vertical line in the T) and each member of the team is a subject matter expert in an area that falls under the purview of the team (the horizontal line in the T).  The vertical lines all meet in the middle (the hub of a wheel) and the horizontal lines are the contact points on the road — making a wheel.  You start with the expertise you are looking for first (horizontal), then you find candidates who might fit the commonality of the team (vertical).  Each member of the team interviews all candidates and the goals are: 1. convince the candidate NOT to take the job 2. test that the candidate is right for the team and has the expertise you are looking for.  Each member of the team has a thumbs up or down vote.  All candidates must be unanimous ‘yes’ to get hired.  Measure the progress of the team after, and then identify the next expertise you are looking for.  Its that simple!

Author: walker.reynolds
Content: You scale up by adding more teams (teams are not permitted to grow larger than 20)

Author: konstantinpinegin
Content: If I may, I would like to ask the community about your observations: do you see any software/hardware tools Industry 4.0 is still missing?

Author: mparris
Content:
The biggest gap I see is how to extend the same IIoT behaviors at the infrastructure level.

You'll see a lot of talk here at the application level, but even if the application problem is solved, scalable infrastructure is needed: PCs and network gear.

What systems exist that enable self discovery and provisioning of network gear?

What systems exist that allow self-discovery and provisioning of PCs with their applications?

Author: zackscriven
Content: Great question.

Author: benveenema
Content: Yes, we talked a while back about the dream of having a sensor that, once plugged into the infrastructure, automatically registered itself in the proper place in a UNS and created a display in a dashboard. There would be some security concerns but that really is the way. Sort of like how you don't have to install drivers for a USB mouse and keyboard anymore. You just plug them in and they work. Your PC knows how to interpret them. We need this for everything.

Author: mparris
Content:
I think SparkplugB can do what you outline (application level).

The Automation Stack that has been discussed here is in the application layer.  Walker's diagram (to be more correct) would include a 2nd dimension outlining the network infrastructure and compute infrastructure to allow the applications to execute and connect.

The discussions so far seem to assume that the network infrastructure and compute infrastructure will continue to be manually configured (Industry 3.0 style).

So, how do Network switches and computers handle the self discovery so they can be provisioned without so many touchpoints? 802.1x port-based authentication comes to mind on the network side

Author: Deleted User
Content:
I'm not sure whether this is what you mean by your third paragraph but network automation and orchestration is coming to the OT domain. I've worked on a couple of projects where we used discovery tools (eg Cisco CyberVision) to identify what was connected to the OT network and then push that data into a network admission tool (eg Cisco Identity Services Engine) to define/apply the right policy. That is then pushed back down into the network to provide appropriate segmentation etc. Using OT specific discovery tools allows a far greater level of granularity in that segmentation - for example by manufacturer or device type. This works with network switching and firewalls. We developed pxGrid specifically to enable this and a number of other vendors have enabled the capability. This blogpost is a couple of years old but outlines the intent and lists some of the OT vendors: https://blogs.cisco.com/security/how-alliances-strengthen-your-cybersecurity-defenses. Here is another blog, written before we had CyberVision, based on Industrial Network Director: https://blogs.cisco.com/digital/ot-intent-based-security-policies.

In addition, we are seeing more SDA capabilities being integrated into OT networking kit. 

I will acknowledge that none of this has been without teething troubles but the technology will improve rapidly.

The challenge for anyone wanting to automate plantfloor networks is that it requires a certain level of 'intelligence' in that network. Flat, layer 2 networks, composed of unmanaged switches will need a serious upgrade.

Author: sherylmccrary
Content: Excellent information. Thanks so much for sharing.

Author: sherylmccrary
Content:
In addition to the above, it seems there's a need for unified Data Ops tools for 4.0 Data Infrastructure: change history, change mgmt, data governance (incl. guidelines for UNS structure), auto-updated data model definitions (centralized dictionary), discovery of connection paths and data flows across apps.

At the Canary Roadshow last week, @Jeff@Flow asked for input on functions needed to take the app to the enterprise level and this was my first thought. After watching how to truncate sets of tag names (hiding the hierarchy) and create alias view names in Canary, followed by the Tatsoft demo seamlessly importing object tags, calculated tags, fr disparate sources to build visualizations that may not indicate the data model, quality and rules change history in the UI, and thinking--- with all this exciting flexibility comes the unmanageable complexity. 

Does it not matter to be able to trace or standardize at which level, in what app, what parameters, what rules? Add in Ignition, Flow, OSI PI, BI, analysis tools... to the mix. I don't see that any one historian or control automation software could/should manage the whole fit-for-purpose industrial data structure.  Highbyte may be in a the best position to address it.  We're going to need *One ring to find them, one ring to rule them all.*

Having never built a UNS, I don't know what I don't know here. Fill me in. 
@Ben Veenema , @konstantinpinegin @DavidSchultz @john.harrington  @Omar  @zackscriven

Author: mparris
Content:
Without understanding the full story, my perspective is that GE was building a platform for industrial internet when nothing of the sort existed. At the time, it was the wild west. There were no standards taking hold yet and it was up for grabs. 

It makes sense that GE followed AOL's playbook: be the go-to place for business insight, build it from scratch and leverage its huge amount of industry knowledge.

I remember helping a customer in Boston that was a home contractor. There was an issue with GE circuit breaker nusiance tripping GE Appliances. I, helping the design of the circuit breakers, traveled there with designers of the appliances to troubleshoot on-site.  What other company could provide such end-to-end system service for a customer? Their breadth was unmatched.

I believe that Immelt et al. may have even believed that GE had an obligation to drive this, given how large its influence was and no one else would be able to do it; , and of course profit along the way.

Building a platform when there is nothing is hard enough. Sorting through what technology is going to be accepted by the market is also tough.

The one mistake I will fault them for was any effort to be the AOL of industry.  Building an architecture defined by common, available interfaces is the right architecture. Before those interfaces exist, however, there will always be the forerunners like AOL that build something from nothing.  How proprietary they are is the likelihood they won't last.

Author: mparris
Content:
I took a course on this, and the model makes sense. Getting leaders and team members speaking this language helps quickly set expectations on management style:

"On this assignment, you have never done it before and your are enthusiastic about it. I will match that with directing behaviors"  Treating that same person with delegating behaviors would leave them feeling abandoned. 

Likewise, treating someone well-experienced at a task with directing behaviors leaves them feeling micro-managed.
