Author: ianskerrett.
Content: GE was definitely one of the first to market for IIoT platforms. I believe they tried to do too much, too fast and didn't take time to listen to customers. They grew a development team into the thousands of software developers and spent billions on marketing and sales but I don't think the market was ready. If they tried to do more with less, they might have been successful.

Author: thedavidschultz
Content:
I view a digital transformation strategy (and the DTMA process) within the context of the ISO 55000 standard around asset management. There must be an asset strategy and a plan which guides the decision making around assets and technology. From there it can be incorporated into other aspects of reliability, namely technical activities (engineering, condition management and work execution). It is then incumbent on leadership to ensure compliance with the strategy and plan. This is why the DX strategy is so critical (and nothing should happen until its done).

Taking a page out of the ISO 55000 playbook, the strategy and plan will guide the technical activities. It will help determine how say a UNS will be built and how the various solutions will interact with it. As you note, there are many solutions that will consume and publish data to the UNS, just like there are to manage asset condition. The decision will be a function of the problem to be solved. From there leadership must work to ensure compliance.

Author: sherylmccrary
Content:
Thank you, Dave. I wanted to hear your perspective. And I think spelling this out is important.  To build on that, I'm saying the asset strategy and plan that guides (Ind 4.0) decisions needs to include and regard data as assets---not just the physical ones or other intellectual property---in order to value and address its collection, use and maintenance. 

So in answering the earlier question about what tools are still needed to manage industrial data assets, I see gaps in that (opportunities). The complexity, compliance and governance issues are a big part of the appeal of big name "solutions" that don't deliver the full promise. @zackscriven

Author: rkwadd
Content: Boeing and GE each have several thousand networked machine tools, and they have for many years. So that’s one data point. On the other hand, the ISG report relies very heavily on the World Economic Forum “Global Lighthouse Network” whose own rankings are based on mostly qualitative criteria.

Author: mparris
Content: While at a Mazak training last year, we got to hear about how GE Aviation is requiring their incoming equipment to be MTConnect compliant.

Author: walker.reynolds
Content:
Translation: the ranking's are rigged by setting the qualitative standards in a way that favors the members and partners of members.  Example: Digital thread architectures didn't become the norm in the market because we could measure their value across industry -- they became the norm because Microsoft influenced the standards (qualitative, not quantitative, I might add) to get themselves in the Gartner Magic Quadrant (where the standards are applied) to drive adoption of Microsoft technologies, which are digital thread in nature.

Wide adoption of technology driven architectures are based on measurements against quantitative standards -- eg. they get results.  Microsoft, Rockwell, PTC et al didn't lead in Industry 4.0, they pulled the wool over the market's eyes.

Author: walker.reynolds
Content: Boeing adopted wide connectivity to equipment before they even had a reason to.  Their infrastructure and their machine specs are far ahead of most Industry 3.0 orgs.  That doesn't mean they have done everything right, imo, but they have led in several key areas.

Author: rkwadd
Content: In 2013 the chief economist at GE, Marco Annuziata, gave a TED talk called “Welcome to the Age of the Industrial Internet.” About two years after that was when GE Aviation and what was then Power & Water got really serious about connecting up factory equipment. GE Transportation followed about a year later. It was interesting to see an executive level hype speech as it trickled down into implementation and all the associated hiccups and headaches. https://www.ted.com/talks/marco_annunziata_welcome_to_the_age_of_the_industrial_internet

Author: walker.reynolds
Content:
All part of the bigger GE Digital strategy -- and then the failure of Predix happened.  This article doesn't even touch on the real reason Predix failed, but it does give a great overview.  

https://www.applicoinc.com/blog/ge-digital-failed/

Author: rkwadd
Content: And for Boeing here’s a more recent vid showing an example of how they’re plugging together a bunch of equipment, data models, and standards (Boeing part starts at ~12:00 mark) https://youtu.be/wbsC_qzB8us

Author: rkwadd
Content: What’s the real reason? IMO it was corporate culture.

Author: rkwadd
Content: Holy cow that link is the most succinct, complete, accurate explanation I’ve seen. Great analysis.

Author: walker.reynolds
Content: The real reason was GE didn't even understand the implications of Digital Transformation for Industry and so they approached GE Digital the same way they approached all of their other businesses.  Technology vertically integrates many organizations together, even if they aren't vertically integrated in a business sense.  Technology also speeds up markets through exponential growth of knowledge.  What would normally take the market 10 years to figure out during Industry 3.0, takes but 1 or 2 now.  Lastly, GE failed to recognize that DT is a strategy driven by technology, not a project driven by a solution.  They couldn't have possibly been more wrong with their approach.  Their hubris (led by Immelt) is the gold standard for how one can cripple a 100 year old giant.

Author: rkwadd
Content: Maybe we can all learn from their pain. Or maybe not. Who knows.

Author: Deleted User
Content: @Walker Reynolds  I'd like to follow up on something you said in yesterday's broadcast. You commented that I3.0 started in the late '60s and that I4.0 started around 2000 and will be done by 2030. Most commentators would say that I4.0 really started in 2012 at Hanover Messe and that we might see the first true I4.0 manufacturing between 2025-2030. I'm interested in what you see as being the demarcation point between I3.0 and I4.0? What specific event/s marked that turning point?

Author: bright_hummingbird_31342
Content:
I believe this will always be somewhat murky as the technological possibilities began to open-up in the 2000s, but the awareness really took off in the proceeding 2010s.  The financial crisis in 2008 and its prolonged recovery heightened awareness of myriad long-term trends of de-industrialization and competitiveness in high-wage economies.  There became a bigger appreciation of the economic stability and associated employment that a thriving industrial base provides.

Hannover Messe was, without question, the awareness catalyst in the industrial / tech community.  That show has really grown in popularity.  2016 was a huge year with US as the partner country.  The image of Angela Merkel and Barack Obama in attendance meeting with the automation companies was a pretty big deal.  It became fashionable for all the major heads of state to back high-profile industrial initiatives (e.g., Smart Manufacturing, China Manufacturing 2025, Usine du Futur, Produktion 2030, Innovate UK, Manufacturing Innovation 3.0, Made in India).  Before this, the term "I4.0" arguably could have been written off as a marketing term.  Outside the industrial world, the Klaus Schwab (World Economic Forum) book on the fourth industrial revolution in 2015 really brought the term into the mainstream and investor communities.  For the following year or two, it seemed like every keynote presentation at every conference included a history lesson on the industrial revolution.  At the very least, the world at-large became vaguely familiar with the concept.

Author: bright_hummingbird_31342
Content:
In an official capacity, the term began to carry weight when the German government directed the formation of the Plattform Industrie 4.0 steering group in 2013.  This signified formal policy making and investment in industrial tech under the banner of I4.0.  This is when the high-profile programs in North Rhine-Westphalia really took off.  Some of the most influential applied engineering research of the decade came out of the *Integrative Production Technology for High-Wage Countries* and *Intelligent Technical Systems OstWestfalenLippe (its OWL)* clusters.

Informally, Industry 4.0 is the norm for younger firms (<20 years) – whether they realize it or not.  Organizations that were conceived during the internet age simply do not have the baggage that their elder peers do.  They’re not inhibited by long investment cycles, legacy technology and “old school” culture.  These firms, all these equal, have a considerable advantage.  They are not distracted and spooked by sunk costs.   Their plants never had paper and everything was digitized by default.  Transforming into a smart plant is just a natural extension of this.  For them, Industry 4.0 is just the natural thing to do.  They don’t know anything else.  One could make an argument that these firms were doing Industry 4.0 long before anyone uttered the term in Hannover or Davos.

Content:
I work at a consultant firm that want to break in to the integration  of I4.0 feild. Yesterday my manager asked me if I could set up some sort of simulation so we could visualy show them what happen with the data and where it comes from.

Does anyone have any experience  of doing this typ of simulation in a visual way? What would be good software to use for visualising how I4.0 works?

Author: bert_tb7949
Content: Not sure if it fits with the digital transformation channel but the company i work for is evaluating a DT strategy. Although we have an OT team taking care of some programming, most of the new production lines are sold to us pretty much as a "turn key" solution. We buy a "package" from companies (usually from Germany). They come, set everything up (machines, sensors, plc, scada, etc). But those companies dont seem to have any roadmap to adapt to Industry 4.0 and push back any request from us to open up their solution. I was wondering if others here deal with the same problems and how they were able to work around that.

Author: marioishikawa
Content: This is very common and you can mitigate with specific requirements on your RFQ such as that you want the machine data, which as some OEMs call connectivity kit,. It is basically when they open their PLC database and/or code for you. But you cannot simply rely on them as they are selling only one machine for you. So you need your DT strategy. These machines will come just with a HMI with local storage for like 1 week. What you want is to start collecting data from these machines, add them to historian, analytics and BI tools and so on, and that is where the UNS comes, as the central hub connecting devices and systems in real time.

Author: bert_tb7949
Content: Thank you. Operation is not very willing to fight those guys and impose requirements because of the fear of losing support in case of an issue. Also IT/OT is not involved when a new production line is setup until those guys come in and set up their stuff. Frustrating situation. I guess I'm concerned about a DT strategy that would blocked by partners. They setup their own network, connected to their network in Germany, outdated PLC ("newly" installed S7-300 installed this winter), end of life Desktop PCs. But the apparent lack of competion allows them to do what they want. sorry for the rant 😫

Author: marioishikawa
Content: I understand it. But you still can add a gateway between your UNS and your "new legacy" PLC. Most OEMs are OK to share PLC data for a price. Their PLC is actually just the first layer. Then all the rest is your company's DT strategy.

Author: walker.reynolds
Content: Start with a DTMA (Digital Transformation Maturity Assessment), the output is a document that includes Digital Strategy, Architecture and Minimum Technical Requirements for the IIoT Infrastructure.  These minimum technical requirements (MTR) are what you give your vendors and OEMs.

Author: bright_hummingbird_31342
Content:
This kind of stuff makes my blood boil. 

There exist a ton of machine builders and integrators that are complicit in inhibiting digital transformation. Their whole business model is basically limited to recycling ancient designs because they have no processes to efficiently change anything.

I always find it comical when these machine builders claim that their customers don’t demand new technology, but yet they impose limitations on doing anything different.

I don’t really know how any organization can call themselves a technology company or innovative when they ship products with end-of-life components and 15+ year old firmware. I fully recognize industrial tech can take time to change, but some of these firms have been asleep at the wheel for decades.

Author: mparris
Content: Don't you realize?  The greatness of their firmware is proven by it lasting 15 years.  Why would you ever want new firmware that's not tested as well? 😆

Author: Deleted User
Content: Sometimes there’s (allegedly*) a compliance issue as well. I went to a pharma company that was still using Windows for Workgroups 3.11 on one particular line . Their justification was FDA compliance. If they changed the OS they had to recertify the line. The cost of recertification would wipe out all future profit from that particular product as it was patent-expired. (* I write allegedly as that’s what they told me and I can’t verify it.)

Author: mparris
Content:
Great point; that's a real concern. Working at GE, we certified a few models of circuit breakers for use in nuclear facilities. That certification process occurred at a specific version of firmware on the circuit breakers.

Guess who isn't getting any firmware updates 🙂

For that application, reliability as shown through the certification process is valued infinitely more than future features.

Then what to do if there is a deficiency found in the certified firmware? We never encountered that, but I imagine it would be ugly...

Author: stuxnetza
Content: Hello all, were there any discussions in the past about organization setups for large manufacturing companies undergoing a digital transformation. I have been working for a few companies in a global organization and the same trend is clear... the traditional IT OT organizations and procedures are not being changed and it’s a constant battle between those departments, both from global and local perspectives.... Typical hot topics: who manages Kepserver, IT in one factory, OT in another... Want a change when IT manages?? -> response is open a ticket... this for me is absolutely crazy... Then there are discussions on who should drive DT in manufacturing, IT or OT???? I still feel a dedicated department should be established which is driving the DT home and really bridging the gap between IT and OT and of course the business... would be great to get some feedback on experience of what has worked and what has failed from this group and hopefully @Walker Reynolds  has some input from his side... thanks!!!!!

Author: marc.jaeckle
Content: I'm currently working with a customer who has a setup with a dedicated team that handles the DT platform for the manufacturing process end-2-end from the PLCs to the cloud. They are much closer to the OT side than regular IT but a big problem for them is that the team is currently too small to handle everything from PLC connectivity through production systems to cloud connectivity, data analytics and machine learning. At the same time they need to know IT processes like the procurement process for external software development partners which makes it even more difficult. And we still have the discussion about who manages the KEPServer 🙂 Still there certainly are advantages. For example they are specifying requirements for new machines looking at it from a DT perspective (like the vendor must provide certain documentation on the data the machines produce and what the documentation should include or that the machines must support certain protocols). Also I don't have to think about an OT/IT differentiation anymore 🙂

Going digital in manufacturing requires a big change on the organization, but somehow consulting firms are always trying to push some new AI tool instead of pushing these fundamentals, I guess not much in it for them 😉

Author: misayashaman
Content: Hi folks. I am recently looking into the metrics measurement and as what Walker has mentioned in some of his past videos, OEE is frequently used to compute for the performance. I get the most parts except when it comes to the computation of Performance where we divide 'ideal run rate' by the actual run rate. The question is, whether the ideal run rate can be something subjective, in which case the OEE outcome would rely on the assumption about the ideal run rate and therefore turning the OEE to be something only meaningful for the company itself, and it is incomparable within the industry as the standard can hardly be unified. (A quick example I am thinking of is a coca-cola line to a pepsi line and will there be some 'ideal run rate' as the guardrail for both of them?) The reason I am asking is because I did see some papers talking about the industrial standards for some products. Hope someone can help. If it turns out that ideal run rate can be something deterministic in real life, would love to know the way in computing it. Thanks!

Author: zackscriven
Content: Pinned a message.

Author: zackscriven
Content: Great question! I think some standards for a certain products have an ideal run rate based on a limitation of physics… like pills can literally only be so fast and bottles can only fill so fast. So in theory there is a theoretical Max run wait that goes beyond the OEM… assuming the production machine has everything serialized… but what if the Pepsi bottling line has three fillers in line whereas the Coke bottling line only has two?  Then in theory the Pepsi bottling line should be able to operate 50% faster

Author: misayashaman
Content: Thank you very much for the response Zack! That is really helpful.

Author: zackscriven
Content: I think it makes sense to have an ideal run rate that’s recommended by the OEM and then you actually benchmark against. Adjust for your company based on the product or the settings you are running. This could shift the ideal run rate up or down.

Author: zackscriven
Content: So it’s based on the way the Machine was built and the specific product configuration you are running too

Author: misayashaman
Content: Good to know. It should still be a good metric for any improvements applied to the line/factory, just not as comparable cross companies.

Author: IIoT#4707

Author: zackscriven
Content: The biggest important is if you do it on one machine in your enterprise you should do it the same for all other of that type of machine for that type of product for consistency. Period. But other companies would have a totally different number.

Author: thedavidschultz
Content: To add the @zackscriven response, the ideal run rate may vary with recipe.  Because the goal of OEE is to eliminate inefficiency, the ideal run rate is also something that might increase over time. While there is debate on what should and shouldn't be included in the calculation, it is something that should be measured and utilized consistently across an organization.

Author: jon.forbord
Content: The strategy is twofold: What systems/hardware do you acquire for the new stuff (minimum technical requirements), and how do you integrate the existing. For existing systems you generally put in a gateway (hardware or software). In most cases the existing PLCs don’t support MQTT so you can use gateway from native protocol or OPC UA to MQTT. This is also why your architecture probably need an IoT hub of sorts (the main software you use to build a UNS), like Factory Studio, Ignition, canary labs, Highbyte. They can connect to many different data sources, model/structure the data and connect it all to a UNS. For SCADA/MES layer it may be necessary to replace, but this depends. Mastermind has great case studies. Mentorship is also a great place to start.

Content: Hi John, welcome to the Discord server. Yes, and there's been a lot of discussion here about OSI PI prevalence and the customer confusion around the OSI Asset Framework templates and cloud services namespace structure mimicking a UNS but actually creating hurdles to data use and analysis. The approach taken by Walker and others is not to suggest replacing it but to regard it as the historian that it is and include the PI server as a node in the UNS.

Author: bright_hummingbird_31342
Content:
And this suite does not integrate particularly well with itself either.

Before PTC acquired ThingWorx, most would use Kepware (or similar) to acquire data from Rockwell PLCs (or similar).  They would use OPC-UA or HTTP.  

After PTC acquired ThingWorx in 2013, users still largely relied on third-party industrial driver suites like Kepware.  

After PTC acquired Kepware in 2016, a native ThingWorx "AlwaysOn" protocol interface was added.  ThingWorx had better luck using this WebSocket technology than HTTP and OPC-UA.  It was more performant and stateful over constrained connections (e.g., WAN, internet).  By and large, PTC was still relying on Kepware to expose OPC tags to the ThingWorx platform

After Rockwell invested in PTC in 2018, as I understand it, Rockwell productized its PLC and FactoryTalk software portfolio with PTC's ThingWorx under the "Innovation Suite" bundle.  There are some connectors that expose select FactoryTalk MES objects to ThingWorx.  They do exchange asset structure in ISA95 style fashion.  But, beyond this, Rockwell and PTC still rely on Kepware to more-or-less connect everything.

While there's nothing wrong with Kepware, I do believe the way Rockwell and PTC have opted to integrate their products is quite telling.  After investing a few billion dollars, they're still using the same third-party technology that system integrators would have nearly a decade ago.  It speaks well to the power of Kepware.  It speaks poorly to the integration capabilities and general openness of Rockwell and PTC.  This level of investment and lack of anything to show for it makes it clear that said deal was not about improving product, but marketing and selling.  Apparently, that's good enough for customers and investors.  It's remarkable that one can claim market share by reselling a partners' solution and deploying Kepware.

Author: shaida.eth
Content:
@js  That’s really great information. I see over a hundred success stories on PTC’s website and I know a lot of manufacturers don’t like to be the guinea pigs so PTC gains a level of trust immediately. I think it makes sense as a business to make it hard to integrate into competitors’ automation systems because then Rockwell can easily grow share if it’s easier for the customer to stick to Rockwell.

Also makes sense to have Rockwell stick to what they’re good at, and invest in some other technology provider to fill the gaps so that they can bring the expertise on to their team immediately rather than develop a new solution, hire, and train is this fast-paced environment

Author: walker.reynolds
Content:
@everyone I'm dropping this video in this channel instead of #📺-youtube-links because this is really a digital transformation video.  This video is a discussion on how an emergent company (Xiaomi) is able to compete against and ultimately jump ahead of a legacy company (Samsung) simply because they are unconstrained by many of the elements a legacy company is saddled with.  This is a great illustration, in the consumer space, of what we teach in #mastermind and #mentorship-program -- this goes to a key principles of Digital Transformation (its a strategy for transforming how your business operates, you can't help every company -- especially those who can't get out of their own way).  Hopefully, this clarifies some of the things you hear me say RE: 11/12 manufacturers aren't going to make it.
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=sC3Q1pGHvBI

Author: andymellor
Content: I'm not sure if it is common knowledge on here, but Frameworx has a native OSIsoft PI interface. Frameworx requires standard OSI client tools to be installed and then works like any other native PI client. It can also push data directly in to the PI historian, browse the AF data structure, integrates with event frames.  It's a good way of bringing PI data into the UNS.

Author: andymellor
Content: We work with Auvesy Versiondog which has Claroty built in.  Basically Claroty feeds asset and intruder information that it detects into Versiondog leaving versiondog to do the detailed monitoring of the asset. For instance checking that the PLC code has not been modified, rebuilding the PLC/SCADA should it have been compromised.

Author: _wwerner
Content:
Hey, PLC developers, anyone here willing to share some insights?
I'm very curious about typical challenges you face day to day, especially when developing systems of multiple interacting parties. Say, e.g., any combination of robots, machines, intra-logistics and human operators. I realize this is a broad question, but I'm interested in whether we can spot any patterns. I hope to be able to drill down from there.

Furthermore, coming from an application development background myself, I haven't really understood how people manage the development process in this context. What approaches/tools do you use for version control, collaboration, deployments, monitoring & logging? Especially for software that runs on the edge on PLCs, machine gateways and HMIs. 

Grateful for any experiences/pointers you'd like to share. Thanks.

Author: jon.forbord
Content: Not sure I’m quite onto what you’re asking but I think I need more context before I dive into so many topics regarding my own experiences with this. How experienced are you with PLCs? Are you coming at this from a devops perspective?

Author: _wwerner
Content:
I'm mostly interested in orchestration of (autonomous) processes spanning multiple actors, i.e. multiple PLCs. What are the hard parts when making parties interact?
Following from that, once you have software to deploy and operate on a variety of devices (PLCs, machine gateways / IPCs, mobile devices) I'd like to learn what you use for fleet management, log aggregation, monitoring and alerting etc.
I'm not coming from the automation world but rather from top floor software development. I'm trying to figure out which patterns of modern software development (CI/CD, workflow modelling, resilience patterns in distributed systems, to name arbitrary, wide-ranging examples) are commonly used and whether there are pain points that could be addressed  by adopting such patterns.

Still a pretty broad question, though. Tangible enough to start a discussion?

Author: jon.forbord
Content: Definitely a lot of ground to cover to say the least, but yes, I'll give it a go with my experiences and thoughts on the software version control (and deployment). 1. In general - you'll find that the world of PLCs/HMI and automation are years behind this type of technology and even thinking, compared to the "normal" software development world. My thoughts is that this is partly due to the fact that PLC/HMI software (mostly) operates on vendor specific purpose built hardware and operating systems, not like in IT where it's mostly general purpose hardware and operating systems. PLCs have AT LEAST 15+ years of expected lifetime. This means that in most cases you are dealing with legacy systems. PLC programming languages are also mostly visual and sometimes vendor specific, and even though there exists one standard that most vendors use, it still doesn't mean the source code is kept in an open format that can be used by any other PLC (sometimes even encrypted source code). The PLCs I've come across does have a way to export programs to an open format, but it's still vendor specific, and not very human readable due to the visual nature of the languages. PLCs also come with a vendor specific SDK software you use to interact and program the PLC. This all means that for most cases, using Git or Subversioning or DevOps-platform is not an option. So that's my observations on WHY - in short, long lifetime of components and vendor lock.

Author: jon.forbord
Content: 2. The how do we do it: Some PLC vendors offer software lifecycle management solutions and ways to cooperate, and in Siemens, I believe you just this year got an integration with their Teamcenter PLM solution and their TIA Portal PLC SDK software. This is OK if you only use Siemens PLCs, but unless you are an OEM which controls the market in your segment, this is never the case. There exists third party version control systems that support multiple vendors, although these are 10k$ and upwards, and usually support a select range of common PLC vendors and hardware. I'm not aware that these support automated deployement, but I'm not familiar with the details here. There's a lot of improvement possible in this space. I can't speak to what's common, but perhaps @LuisN has some additional experiences here?

Author: _wwerner
Content:
That's great input, thanks a bunch, @Jon Forbord!

> PLC/HMI software (mostly) operates on vendor specific purpose built hardware and operating systems
I feel that will change in the future due to the advent of RT Linux based PLCs like ctrlX CORE and PLCnext. But I guess it will take years until they are commonly deployed in the field.

> using Git or Subversioning or DevOps-platform is not an option
Especially in the light of regulated environments, I tend to think that hurts, doesn't it? Having a commit history as audit trail and the possibility to address software artefact versions (down to commit level) would come in very handy. Or are these academic concerns? I've noticed start-ups going into that direction recently, like copia.io and auvesy's versiondog, e.g.

I take that vendor lock-in in terms of hardware, languages and tooling is a real concern, right?

Author: jon.forbord
Content: What Walker said in the live-stream today is so true. The time is ticking when you're commissioning the software and testing your code, so you usually have to take the shortcuts necessary. Refactoring is not an option. It's also very true that most PLC programmers use 100% manual process. Which may be something like this if you're doing an update. 1. Arrive at machine, get the current project backup from a file share and "retrieve" (really unzip) in the vendor-SDK. 2. Use vendor-SDK to run a compare with the "live" software. Two possible routes appear. No differences, nice. Continue to step 3. Unexpected differences - go through fileshare for available backups until you find the right one, search, ask SME/colleagues if they forgot a backup last time they were working on the machine. It's nowhere to be found -> gah - analyse differences if possible (sometimes not even possible). Go through one by one, and if necessary merge. plus plus plus.. Go to 5.  3. Aright - you've established that the"offline" copy is the same as the "online" copy. Create a backup, and use filenaming-convention like machine_version_date, and upload to the fileshare. 4. Fetch the update package or update project - either merge from the update package library etc.. Download and test the changes. Fix issues. End of day - create another backup and upload to fileshare. 5. So whoever made the new version, was using an out of date backup to create it - go ahead and apply the same merge operations (can be copy-paste, manual - it depends), to the update package. Once finished, go to 4.

Author: dundo6741
Content:
I remember one time I was in Russia, some beer brewery ...
I, the SCADA guy, and colleague - the PLC guy. Colleague uploaded the code to PLC, which he built on top of our already existing system, we were just adding a couple of units ...
We've completed IO test and were starting things up when some local guy came and complained something about some water treatment unit not working.
We've told him he came to wrong address, we have nothing to do with water.
Few days later we've found that brewery PLC guys added a couple of Profibus nodes and some PLC code to our system and didn't even tell us. 
Stuff in the field is never the same as the stuff in the office.
😄

Author: luisn8316
Content:
My understanding of the use case for Teamcenter (TIA Portal plug-in available since 2016*) is a central data backbone to manage files of a project. It can tie into certain third party software for CAD, however as @Jon Forbord mentioned the automation I believe is limited to just TIA Portal at the moment. There are other 3rd party companies that do a great job of project/file management and version control like Auvesy Versiondog, MDT Autosave and Copia. 
 
Siemens' had made some strides to bring SW Development  practices into automation environment. For example, TIA Portal offers the ability to interface to Git repositories (or other repositories) using version control interface (VCI). You can even graphically compare code between versions using a free and separate comparison tool from Siemens.  There's also a cool video/tutorial that Outlier Automation posted about this (link below).

Teamcenter with TIA Portal: https://youtu.be/MzYR8RBjksY

Outlier Automation VCI/Git demonstration:

Author: osamafouad8649
Content:
Hi everyone,
I'm working on project Automated Storage and Retrieval System (ASRS). We want to create digital twin for our system, but we are struggling with selecting that sensors we need to implement it. Our system contain to 3 Servo Motor (XYZ directions) and other AC motor for production line. So could anyone tells me how can I selecting sensors to create Digital Twin?

Thanks in advance.

Author: benveenema
Content:
This is a big question but I'll see if I can get an answer started.

I'm not as familiar with digital twin as I am with UNS but I believe they are kind of "the same but different". The way I like to think of it is, a digital twin is the digital representation of your device and the UNS is the best way to get the data to build it.

All that said to say, my answer will be mostly about getting your data into a UNS not building a digital twin.

You probably don't need to add any sensors. You just need to unlock the sensors that already exist. The machine already functions without any additional sensors so why should it's digital twin need any more?

1. The controller/PLC. All the data points the PLC creates, state, errors, blocked, starved and so on need to be mapped to an IIoT protocol. If the PLC has MQTT SPb support you win! Otherwise you'll have to add a native driver to MQTT bridge, look into cMT-SVR.

2. The servos are likely connected to a motion controller (unless you're PLC has 3 axis motion control support natively). There will be some communication method (serial, Ethernet/IP, Profinet, etc) on the motion controller that makes all of it's data available. You can either get this directly or you can map all these data points to the PLC and get it out through there.

3. The AC motor is likely driven by a VFD and is similar to the motion controller. Map the data to the PLC and extract it from there.

4. Other sensors. Homing sensors, presence detection sensors, etc. These are probably going directly to the PLC although they could be on some kind of remote io. If directly to the PLC, it's pretty easy to get them, even in the case of remote io, unless you have a DCS, all the data is already on the PLC.

Author: geoffnunan
Content: There is a lot of confusion on terminology when it comes to Digital-Twin. @John Patanian made a good point in looking at the purpose, which helps to clarify the terminology.   For some, Digital-Twin means simulator, for others it means "Live Model" and for others it means some combination of those. Ask 3 people and you will get 4 answers. Having done all of my manufacturing development using TDD against a simulator, and having designed new factories using simulators, there is enormous value in being able to simulate the functions of a machine (both happy state and failure modes) but the effort involved can be huge. The challenge with just using historian data is that you are only looking at what has happened, not what might happen. There are also VR packages which can take CAD drawings of machines and buildings and let you walk through them virtually to check for design issues. That might be called a digital twin.    It might be a little controversial in this forum, but the UNS is simply a canonical message model for integration between systems.  You can quickly get into trouble if you try to use a canonical message model as your entire domain model. That's why knowledge graphs have become a thing.

Author: ajility.dev
Content: I have a question related to this. My application queries tags on the PLC using Python over Ethernet/IP. Is there a benefit to use a device like the cMT-SVR? What is it?

Author: benveenema
Content:
It depends on what you are trying to do and where this application lives.

If this is a standalone system and you'll never expand out. EIP w/ Python is probably fine. EIP is a poll/response protocol, so it has inherent time delays and increased network use.

If you are trying to build a larger system (more PLCs, more applications) EIP w/ Python is going to eventually cause a bottleneck in either compute or network traffic. You can only throw more resources at it for so long. In other words EIP w/ Python won't scale.

If this is just an edge node application (you're doing local storage, HMI, ML, etc) then I think you're in a great space with EIP and Python. Python is a super powerful, simple, and broad language. The data analysis offered by Anaconda/Conda is second to none. You could of course add an MQTT library to your python app and now you have an IIoT ready edge node with compute. Win, win!

In this case you probably don't need cMT-SVR. All that would be doing is reading the same tags over EIP or native protocol and translating it to MQTT/SPb.

Author: benveenema

Author: geoffnunan
Content: Thanks for the question @Ben Veenema, firstly can I state the first law in data modelling: "All models are wrong, some are useful". In short a canonical message model is a term that has been around for the past decade in "Enterprise Application Integration" particularly with Message Bus or Enterprise Service Bus architectures. MQTT is simply a messaging protocol to allow applications to talk to each other, and the UNS is the data model that applications use to talk to each other. This article explains https://teivah.medium.com/why-is-a-canonical-data-model-an-anti-pattern-441b5c4cbff8   A canonical model is supposed to be the superset of all the models used to communicate between applications.  A domain model is specific to a domain. Think QualityManagement versus Inventory Management for example. Domains have specific interests, and so even though they may use similar entities, they may use them for different purposes. This realisation led a guy name Eric Evans to come up with a process called Domain Driven Design (DDD) some 15 years ago. This article discusses SAP's approach and why they have stopped using canonical models. https://blogs.sap.com/2020/07/23/saps-one-domain-model-and-domain-driven-design/ . Finally there is the Knowledge Graph which is the future of manufacturing data as it allows us to infer data based on relationships and then using data science, augment the data set with these inferences. The post that @Kirt Anderson put up explains our take on the Knowledge Graph for Manufacturing

Author: benveenema
Content:
Thanks for the great response! There's a lot to chew on here and the links you and @Kirt Anderson provided have definitely helped me expand my knowledge base.

I think I understand Canonical vs Domain data model. Canonical is one model for all, and Domain is each app/service/unit/etc having its own model.

I think Domain Data model can be achieved with UNS structure, and may even be the recommended way to build it. One of the core ideas of the UNS is "What one node knows, all nodes know" which is why we might publish all current state of any object in the UNS, even if it is domain specific. However, this doesn't mean that all nodes have write access or control over all tags within a model. Some parts of a model may belong only to the ERP, like cost of a purchased part. Only ERP should decide how and where to store that data point and keep it updated. But it may be useful for MES/SCADA to be able to know that so ERP may make that tag read only.

Maybe one would structure the data model for PurchasedPartA as:
- PurchasedPartA
    - ERP
        - Cost: $1.08
        - WhereUsed: {...}
        - StockQTY: 1000
    - LineA
        - Demand: 200

It's not a great example and probably not even how that particular data should get structured. One issue I can see is if the ERP tags and Line A tags were read only outside of their own apps/services. How would we transfer from ERP/StockQTY to LineA/Demand without creating an API interface on ERP or LineA.

These are just my novice thoughts, I'm interested how others would approach a domain data model with UNS structure?

Author: benveenema
Content: I'm still catching up on the Knowledge Graph. I get the base idea but it seems like such a crazy thing to build and maintain! I'm assuming the CS guys have figured out some models for it that work?

Author: kirtanderson
Content:
@Ben Veenema - The Knowledge Graph is definitely a crazy thing to build, but it is necessary and we have done it. The good news is that it isn't something that everyone needs to build.

The ISA laid out the schema roadmap over 30 years with 100s of brilliant minds spending millions of hours to codify the worlds understanding of manufacturing. ISA-88 and ISA-95 contain 98% of everything that any manufacturer will ever encounter in any process, largely distilled into Equipments and Materials and the relationships between them.

Most of the people that we've encountered that like to beat on those standards as being useless fall into one of two categories - 

1. People that have it locked in their head that their process is "different." These folks are headed for a long, dark road of custom development that only they can support. For those in this camp - Good on ya, and Good Luck! When you're done, you may notice that what you built looks a lot like S-95!

2. People that don't understand the standards, which is almost everybody. There are very few people in the world that actually get it from a theoretical standpoint. @GeoffNunan is one of them and is the architect of the worlds only Manufacturing Knowledge Graph.

Author: kirtanderson
Content:
The reason that I point to the standards is in response to your example of ERP and MES and tag read/write. You are correct that in a traditional relational model of a UNS, you are going to have data governance issues when you have 200 APIs tying your model together. The image that comes to mind is of that toothpick bridge that everyone had to build in their HS Physics class...

This is where the concept of a Knowledge Graph and GraphQL Federation Services change the game for Data Infrastructure and MES. By removing relational data structures and moving in the direction of Graph and GraphQL, you remove schema stitching and APIs from your UNS. Federation allows you to use a single API that manages the business rules that define the schema, even if there are actually a dozen data sources in the model.

Sounds crazy, but it's real. Do a bit of digging on Apollo Federation Services.

Author: zackscriven
Content: Can you publish your S95 model back to the UNS for someone to subscribe to via MQTT if they chose to instead of GraphQL?

Author: kirtanderson
Content: Theoretically, yes but I'd have to see the use case. I'm not sure why you would maintain a separate UNS data structure outside of the Knowledge Graph.

Author: zackscriven
Content: It’s one of the requirements we ask all software nodes in the ecosystem, publish your data model back to the UNS for other applications. Enabling self discovery and self aware Scada.  If I’ve got a hit your graph QL interface to check and see if there any new users added then it’s not self-aware. Right?

Author: kirtanderson
Content: Oh, I see. The entire Knowledge Graph and every GraphQL query in the system can be subscribed to so that the result set of any query publishes on change to all subscribers

Author: zackscriven
Content: Excellent. If it can be subscribed to, can it also publish up to another broker? For like tiered plant -> enterprise systems?

Author: kirtanderson
Content: Sure, but again the MKG (manufacturing knowledge graph) IS the enterprise definition of the UNS.  Keep in mind that with Federation Services, any data, on any node anywhere in the system can be queried and updated by subscription provided the proper role-based security is implemented. The entire enterprise data model is wrapped by a single API. It's why this approach is so powerful for data science as well as operations.

Author: walker.reynolds
Content:
Digital Twin == a digital representation of a process, a sensor, a line, or perhaps a business.  It is the virtual representation of a physical object (or groups of objects).  Digital Twin is not a current state of your business and is not real-time (though it generally has some data that was real-time at some point).  A digital twin is used as a testing ground, especially for ML, for business or process improvements.

Unified Namespace == the structure and the events of your business (not just physical objects).  It is built on a common technology and it is always real-time (it is literally current state).  UNS is often used, in real-time, for the nodes in your eco-system to inter-operate with one another.  A digital twin is not used for this purpose.  The UNS is generally built using ISA-95 part 2 for the construction of the the namespace.

The UNS is the single source of truth for your business -- common tech, common structure, common events.

The Digital Twin is merely a virtual copy of a physical thing (or things).

Author: walker.reynolds
Content:
I'm looking forward to our meeting.  I think your product sounds intriguing... but I do not want to temper expectations -- as I see several areas that produce major questions.  I suspect you and Geoff will be able to answer them.  I'd love to test the technology and comment more deeply.

A couple of points -- a manufacturing knowledge graph is not an enterprise definition of a Unified Namespace.  A UNS is the structure and events of your business -- in real time.  A knowledge graph, will create that structure, but not provide current state.  A common use for MKG is to path events to a digital twin, which is also not current state.  Current state is important for ML -- both for learning and for monitoring.  One of the most important roles of the UNS is the normalization and abstraction of non-normalized data points (think OEE that is calculated every 60 seconds and machine counts that can change every 50ms).  A glaring deficiency in knowledge graphs is normalization and abstraction of these data points.  For those unfamiliar with Knowledge Graphs -- think Mind Nodes --> Mind Maps on steroids.

Point two -- GraphQL is not the technology to leverage in the core of an Industry 4.0 solution... and I question the scalability of this approach.  Not only is GraphQL far less efficient than REST (which we would never recommend for Industry 4.0 core tech), it also not edge driven; which is a pre-req for a scalable IIoT infrastructure.  

I'm interested to see how you're leveraging EMQX and where transactions and events are transformed and integrated into a UNS -- what you and @GeoffNunan have outlined so far is intriguing... I hope our discussion gets us over the hump.

Honestly, it sounds a lot like PLC4X with knowledge graphing and edge based end points with GraphQL interfaces.  I'm excited to hear more.

Author: kirtanderson
kirtanderson
Content: @GeoffNunan will give you a much more technically eloquent overview.

Author: walker.reynolds
Content:
Subscriptions are deterministic in GraphQL, knowledge graphs are constructed, not stateful or self-aware beyond what has been constructed.  As your schema is expanded by adding assets or nodes with new data models (not existing digital profiles/models), subscribers must also update their queries.  Yes -- I can set up subscriptions, but my architecture is not self-aware.  I like GraphQL at the cloud platform layer as long as the virtual schema doesn't extend.

I think it is important to focus on Customer Experience and work your way back to the technology.  Amazing tech is of no value if the value can't be explained easily to a 5 year old.

1. I can plug 200 PLCs in and they just 'show' up on the screen
2. I can see a low OEE number in a red box and click on the box to see what the problem is
3. I can add a new production line on the floor, plug it in, turn it on and it is fully integrated into our business
4. I can extend our solutions and those extensions will apply to every machine we have on the floor -- no matter how old it is

I thought I was fairly fluent with Knowledge Graphs -- after building two 1M+ node graphs, one for financials and one in manufacturing -- but its possible I'm missing something.  

As for the UNS -- the architecture was created by me and I coined the term in manufacturing... I hope my knowledge there isn't lacking.  😉

I think your tech sounds very intriguing... but I have questions (as do many members of the community who are messaging me in DMs) that I hope we can get answered.  I think it is very important that we have clarity on definitions, terminology, use cases and expectations when we are 'evaluating' technology.  I know you agree... looking forward to our conversation.

Author: geoffnunan
Content:
The Manufacturing Knowledge Graph (MKG) does not replace the UNS. They are different things with different purposes.
I agree with Walker that focussing on customer experience and working back to tech is important, so lets look at some examples:
1. As a data analyst, I would like to subscribe to a data stream from equipment of brand X, made after 2010. I can't write that query in MQTT unless my UNS has been specifically structured to allow me to do it. I can subscribe to a GraphQL query and receive that data stream.

Author: walker.reynolds
Content: Excellent use case — that highlights some serious synergy between Libre and an MQTT UNS.  Love this, @GeoffNunan

Author: walker.reynolds
Content: We need to get this demonstrated for the community — this question comes up all the time.

Author: geoffnunan
Content: Exactly, the UNS provides the "Plug-and-play" features and self-awareness, particularly in SCADA. But which interface do you use when you want to build apps on top of that UNS? With the rise of low-code app platforms like Tulip, MS Power Apps, OutSystems, Mendix, Salesforce, ServiceNow and more encouraging citizen application development, which interface should these apps be built against? The MKG is a single GraphQL API that allows you to query and subscribe to the UNS for both real-time or historical data using a super simplified query language.

Author: zackscriven
Content: Citizen application development we call “unlocking potential on the plant floor” 😁

Author: geoffnunan
Content: To be clear, Libre uses a UNS in our EMQX broker. The Libre Platform allows you to model your UNS and govern it. The Libre platform then also exposes your model, the MQTT streams and your historian data through the MKG

Author: IIoT#4707
Content: GG @GeoffNunan, you just advanced to level 1!

Author: walker.reynolds
Content: This is a great question… at L2, L3, L4 we are generally using an IIoT platform like Ignition, FactoryStudio, WinCC-OA, Flow etc.  At L5, its the wild west right now.  Our platforms of choice are Sorba IoT, Litmus (on occasion)… but the most common L5 platform is AWS — their suite is impressive and wide open.  Im really interested in seeing Libre 2 in action — from Kubernetes deployment through L5 CI/CD.

Author: geoffnunan
Content:
Another example:
My SCADA system publishes ANDON requests for maintenance to attend my machine. As a Maintenance Technician, I want to subscribe to Maintenance ANDON requests that have not yet been assigned to other technicians and all of the ANDON requests that have been assigned to me, but as a Machine Operator, I want to subscribe to all ANDON calls for my machine. An MQTT topic structure could be designed to handle that, but what if I then want the Quality team to subscribe to Quality ANDON calls for machines that are running particular products?
You can't build every possible use-case into the MQTT Topic structure. That's where the MKG offers a power and flexibility that is needed over and above the UNS.

Author: benveenema

Author: walker.reynolds
Content: We currently do this with MQTT clients… using topic triggers… but this is a use case where ‘subscribing’ to data based on query driven arguments could streamline the request/retrieval.  Up until Libre, this capability would require extensive engineering which is why extending the topic namespace with the results set for quality would make sense.  If Libre can do what u describe, then we still have the value UNS provides with current state and single source of truth… with QL on top for intercepting data based on specific conditions.  Very cool… we need to check off edge driven and self aware a little more clearly and then we have 🔥

Author: walker.reynolds
Content: I look forward to our meeting

Author: geoffnunan
Content: That has always been the headache. Even with topic triggers, you need to add and maintain the triggers to suit the use-case. With a query based approach, there is nothing to maintain. Subscribing to queries is a game changer

Author: walker.reynolds
Content: One of the most important things to note -- is that the vast majority of PLC tags do not change as frequently as once per minute.  That is, about 93% of all tags in a PLC namespace, change less than once per minute (on average, across all PLC applications).  Edge Driven & Report by Exception makes all of the difference.  When you are only pushing changes AND no-one is ever waiting for a response, you can move a massive number of tags.

Author: ashok5983
Content: Hi WR, there is also the 'Digital Shadow' can you please provide some clarity on this term? I have seen people use this and the Digital Twin interchangably...the understanding is that Digital twins can be used for simulations and two way comms with the physical machines whereas DS is just a digital real time representation of the physical attributes measured visualised in a 3D like imagery

Author: jinxmatthews
Content: @Ashok My two cents: If both are used its just because Digital Twin is now as hyped a term as IIoT or Cloud. The Twin runs in parallel with its physical counterpart, and ideally can receive input from and output to the physical equipment or process that it represents/simulates. The shadow would typically be a representation built later, if you had to retrofit old equipment and it usually lacks certain detail/attributes/metadata, its use case is typically specific and singular in nature. The two terms are not interchangable.

Author: pathakchi
Content:
"Digital shadow" is unidirectional flow of data i.e. physical layer to digital layer here only objective is to digitally show the values (normally scada / mes where digital shadow is used).
Whereas, digital twin ideate about both way connectivity means based on real time data and under line design/ engineering equations may be used to creat some value out of it and fed back to physical layer prescriptively.

Author: ashok5983
Content: Thanks Mathis and Pathakchi for the clarifications, so the Digital shadow is perhaps better used for information and exceptional alerts management,  whereas the Twin can be used for simulations to improve the overall performance

Author: pvmagacho
Content:
Thank you for the clarification @MParris . Nothing like a native English speaker to save the day 😃. Codesys is the software, not the hardware. We already use PLCs that are programmed using a software based on Codesys, so that is not the problem. 

What I wanted to point out is that for systems that are heavily regulated and are required to follow many safety and performance standards we are still behind in the Ind4.0 movement, because we are still bound to those OEMs. We need to leverage gateways to unlock the data. Many "manufacturers" in my industry are looking into something that would free the vendor lock-in, for example, Intel's UWC. But we are still far from having a viable product to show.

In contrast, there are many vendors offering very interesting products, that are shown here all the time, but still lack the reliability and safety standards adherence.

That is why I feel the discussions raised in this forum and the videos created by @Walker Reynolds, et al, are so important. To show the strength of these new products and OEMs that are looking into the future and to drive the changes needed (although I feel some might not learn in time and end up like Kodak).

Author: dzimmerman
Content: Thanks for interpreting @MParris I could tell I was missing something. I'm not familiar enough with the regulatory standard but I'm not aware of any real difference between the big three and these devices other than testing to a performance standard. I think we spend a lot time talking past each other. What we need to say is we need a device that meets standard xyz and request vendors to meet the standard. The big three have army's of people tasked with meeting these requirements. The newer vendors are often from a different background that's why their designs are innovative, but like me have no regulatory exposure. So if a customer group inside the regulatory environment could show interest in a design that meets x standard a CTO at these vendors has a business case he can sell. Breaking these barriers is going to take real work on all sides of the buy/sell eco system to make progress

Author: nickn5549
Content: Does anybody have any info/case studies about implementing Digital Transformation and IIOT in EMS (Electronics Manufacturing Services) especially how to connect to legacy Surface Mount Technology (#SMT) equipment? Cheers, Nick

Content: Well, I searched many channels for SMT keywords and nada...I'm the only one from EMS that wants to implement IIOT? or EMS dudes are very secretive...

Author: jon.forbord
Content: What is EMS specifically, what are you manufacturing and why would those dudes be secretive? I mean how is it different from other manufacturing processes, is not PLCs the main form of process control?

Author: kirtanderson
Content:
EMS is essentially high-speed motion control of surface mounted components on PCBs. The older machines are notoriously difficult to interface with because many of them use custom built micro controls. Not that different than really old CNC in terms of data acquisition.

@NickN - someone may have done this before, but with me having tried before to do what you are doing now, I can tell you that you aren't going to find a "standard" for interop with SMT, especially old stuff. Doesn't mean it can't be done. I'd need to know the brand and age of your SMT tooling.

Author: jon.forbord
Content: Thanks for the clarification 🙂 I’ve seen plants where they manufacture PLC components (PCBs?) and I think they used PLCs to control the process.

Author: kirtanderson
Content: PCB = Printed Circuit Board

Author: ryankershaw
Content: Our engineering manager was boasting he hadn't met a system he couldn't connect to (may have been some beer involved), and since then, I've been looking to give him a challenge.  I know we (Litmus) have a ton of drivers, so might even be off the shelf.  The way I see it, we either solve your problem, or I prove my engineering manager wrong.  Win/win from my point of view.

Author: bright_hummingbird_31342
Content:
When you say "connect to" are you referring to simply interpreting the protocol?  Or, do you also mean interpreting what is sent over the protocol?

I'd love to know what your solution can do with Fanuc-based CNC (e.g., Makino, Murata, Robodrill) without memory table documentation.  The protocol is FOCAS Ethernet.  There exist drivers and libraries that speak the protocol and can access some "vanilla" Fanuc registers, but not what the machine builders have implemented on their own.  One must have knowledge of the machine builder's implementation.

Author: ryankershaw
Content: We should be able to interpret much, if not all, of what comes over the protocol.  Also, looks like we already have something built for Fanuc.  Not sure if it's exactly what you're looking for, but it's at least a starting point for us.

Author: nickn5549
Content: @Jon Forbord @Kirt Anderson exactly, all the placement machines are different and locked in their proprietary communication software. I'm still working with Fuji CP6, QP2, IP3 that are ok spit out some of the events on serial port and also Yamaha YV100 that work only with their own SMS software...Printers like DEK Infinity and reflow ovens Speedline, Heller, Soltec are quite mute...just some skimpy log files saved on their internal industrial PCs.... It's the same on Wave Soldering machines, only when you get to PCB routers tou get to PLC and get the info from there...

Author: IIoT#4707
Content: GG @NickN, you just advanced to level 1!

Author: nickn5549
Content: That's the reality for some guys that are building all the electronic PCBAs - printed circuit assemblies that you all play with - from Raspberry Pis, to CPAP machines, sensors, industrial IOT boards, data loggers, automotive cameras, etc

Author: nickn5549
Content: @Kirt Anderson the lack of existing gateways kept EMS away from IIOT. Obviusly, Tier 1 EMS like Flex, Jabil, Sanmina, Foxconn invested already in new generation SMT machines that are coming with more connection options (UML), but some of the Korean, Japanese (Samsung, Fuji) manufacturers are still locking things away....placement programs can't be parsed (proprietary binary files), communication from their machines is possible only using their gateways, etc. Looks like part of SMT OEMs are still in the 20th century when everybody used to charge through the roof for any new connection, for any new bit of data or license to connect any new equipment. Which, for a high mix, medium volume EMS from AU is a bit too much...can't compare with Tier 1 budgets.

Author: nickn5549
Content: Cool. I would like to connect to the whole SMT+WS line, which typically is composed of a Screen Printer (Dek Infinity or Dek Horizon or MPM AccuFlex) + Chip Placement Machine (Fuji CP6 or Yamaha YV100) + Chip Placement Machine (Fuji CP6 or Yamaha YV100) + Fine Pitch Placer (Fuji QP2 or Fuji IP3) + Reflow Oven (Electrovert Onmiflex 7 or Soltec XPM820) + Wave Soldering (Electrovert Vectra Elite). I put OR in between some of the listed equipment because  I have multiple lines with different configurations. So far, I haven't found any of the shelf gateways, only proprietary software that could connect placement machines for example. So, I created my own gateway for Placement machines, but for now, I stopped there... I need all these to be able to calculate a more precise OEE per cell, now I rely on operators to key in the downtime and calculate Availability per line. Performance and Quality info are OK coming from counter sensors and SFDC (Shop Floor Data Collection - aka Quality Control and defect data - part of MES).

Author: ryankershaw
Content: Got a solid "probably" on this one.  We do not have direct drivers for these, but our engineer mentioned that we have done other EMS machines, and usually pull log files, databases, XML, etc. to get the data that's needed.  The one he did ID as potentially problematic was the YV100 since it was released 25 years ago.  That said, he basically figures that one just might take a bit of extra work.

Author: anibalvelarde
Content:
Hello everyone... My experience with IIoT, Industry 4.0 and Industrial Digital Transformation is not very extensive... It goes all the way back to last Friday!  However, in this short time I've been able to consume lots of info from Walker, Zack, the guests on the podcast, the community in general.   

Today, I came across a Q&A session that Steve Jobs was leading where he had to face a "snarky" question.  He handled it like a boss, but what stuck to me that he said that  resonated with me a lot was:  "You have to start with the customer experience, then walk back to the technology."

In a lot of ways, that is what I'm witnessing here on the videos, podcasts, and commentary from the community.   OEM, Distributors, etc. are stuck (in some ways) to the tech and want to push it on the consumer (manufacturers).  Part of the message that Walker, 4.0 Solutions and Intellic (and many in the community) are saying is start with the manufacturer and understand their actual needs, then walk back to the technology that can enable them.

I'm fairly new in this community but I'm learning a lot!
Thank you all!

Author: thedavidschultz

Author: sherylmccrary
Content:
This is Scott Whitlock, Flexware, talking with mfg CIO/IT heads about their digital transformation initiatives and enterprise change-management efforts.

Starts slow. Worth listening at least to the 15-20 minutes starting at 36:05 with the guy from Caterpillar and their (very human) approach:
- communication specific to employees at every level 
- training to get comfortable with digital transformation at large and how it relates to their job
- selecting a team of middle-layer change agents
- pitching OEE and the purpose of data collection

Later, (in the context of ERP/Cloud migrations): "Culture eats strategy for lunch. Also define a deployment strategy and the point at which you burn the ships."

Author: geoffnunan
Content:
1-3 sentences can make a vision statement, but not a strategy. A strategy describes not only the outcomes you are trying to achieve (We make better decisions), but also the outputs you need in order to achieve those outcomes. A good strategy will consider the constraints that your organisation must work within like resources, skills, capital, capacity to adopt change and key people, and outline how the Digital program will work within those constraints to deliver outputs that enable outcomes. A few of the things that a Digital Strategy should consider (there are many more) include:
* Insourcing verus Outsourcing. How much capability should be built and retained within the company, and how much should external providers be leveraged?
* Innovation - Does the company need to simply adopt known solutions, or adapt solutions to new use-cases. I use the test of "If you can't point to a system that does exactly what you want to do, you are developing something new". If you're setting out to develop something new, you had better have a good innovation strategy
* Software Vendors and Service Providers - are you getting both your software and your services from the same place, or different places. How do you build some competitive tension so you retain some negotiating leverage with suppliers?
* How do your digital initiatives help with competitive advantage? If they don't provide a competitive advantage, do you really need to do them?

Author: sherylmccrary
Content: Geoff, Agreed, 3 sentences is a vision not a strategy. It's useful that you spelled it out. Walker tends to oversimplify when speaking to a general audience. For those not familiar with it, the full DTMA/transformation assessment he teaches covers all of these---resources, skills, capital, capacity to adopt change, key people, innovation, competitive advantage, inventory of existing systems and machines---in fact, your post would be a good outline.

Author: zackscriven
Content:

Yes the strategy goes much deeper, but it’s important to know what your digital strategy is. And most mfgs can’t even do that.

Author: bright_hummingbird_31342
Content:
I would say a good place to start is avoid formal support channels.  One does not build an empire through support tickets or emails.  These are typically designed for resolving break-and-fix problems or "MACD" requests at scale.  The personnel involved in this spend 99% of their time troubleshooting basic end user problems (e.g., MS office, printers, AD).  They're not going to be digital transformation agents.  They've been chartered to keep the lights on at lowest cost.  They're there so someone more senior has enough hours in the day to work on other projects like life cycling something that should have been taken care of a long time ago or supporting M&A.

The other thing to look at is what is the leadership's charter of IT.  If the mission is to essentially provide ms office and keep the company out of headlines (e.g., security breaches, compliance, downtime) at absolute lowest possible cost, these unfortunate outcomes shouldn't be a surprise.  For many orgs, there isn't much more of a goal than keeping the cost below a budgeted percentage of sales.  It's not uncommon for some manufacturers to spend less than 1% of their revenue on IT.  This pales in comparison to what is typically budgeted for, say, maintenance or production.  In these environments, service levels and productivity aren't particular important because they were never intended to be.  Most boards view IT as a pure cost center.  This turns IT into a CI-like function.  Providing secure remote access to machine builders to field networks was probably never budgeted.  Nor was standing up infrastructure and providing devops support.  Some of the issues are certainly self-inflicted (e.g., lacking experience/knowledge in operations, managing upwards, responsibility/accountability, allocating funding).  At the end of the day, IT departments are not going to be enabling partners for IIoT if they're expected to be and funded as minders of office appliances.  Only the right leadership can change this.

Author: sherylmccrary
Content:
I'm not sure this guy realizes what he just said.  !

Here's Joe from General Mills Engr Tech Srvcs and CESMII board member speaking on maturity assessments--- The value is to sell digital transformation internally and to educate employees... to roadmap current to desired state for each plant based on business outcomes.

Right, good points.

Then he goes on to talk about DT as a "journey to autonomous, lights out manufacturing," which he's very excited about, and you have to "keep the workforce moving towards."

Ummm, yes, I'm thinking. Maybe that's all it means to Gen. Mills.  You do need to prepare people for the fact that their jobs are changing. But if that's the only outcome you're excited about....
And you're not talking about intermediate, what's-in-it-for-me benefits of digitalization, you're not exactly "selling it" internally. Definitely counterproductive.
https://youtu.be/SNBIr6LKkxA

Author: mikebartlett_nh
Content: While I'm not sure how much better or faster you can make those Cheerios, the promise of autonomous manufacturing is to build more resilient and highly responsive supply chains for higher-margin, higher-risk products.  If using pharmaceutical manufacturing as an example, being able to react more quickly to process upsets based on all available data, where a quick subtle change within the design space of the material being made can help to save an entire batch.  Or at the very least, help get that product out to patients more quickly.  In the case where you have a patient population that requires that product to survive, that resiliency is life or death.   Moving that example earlier into the product lifecycle where you can increase time to market by 2-4x, or build more flexible, multi-product manufacturing assets are other benefits.

Author: bright_hummingbird_31342
Content:
To be honest, it was almost fatiguing to hear about UMATI after sorting out VDMA MT and MTConnect.  While I think the concept of portability is sound, the overlap of information models creates mixed signals to the market. It hinders adoption.  I don't see how plug-n-play is realized better with a handful of data representations instead of one.  It erodes the ROI of developing a products that adopt the standard.

I can already hear the machine builders and application developers asking "If the market is fragmented with multiple machine tool standards, why would adopt any of them?  We should probably wait [forever] until the market improves."

Author: brianpribe

Author: brianpribe
Content: From what I’ve experienced and from what I’ve learned from others is that if the expenditure is less than their cap, then you’ll have a higher likelihood of buy-in. Typical caps for most manufacturers is $10,000 to $25,000 before needing more approvals from higher-level management. The best jobs are the ones where they come to you and don’t care that it’ll cost them +$80k, because the alternative is worse (broken machines, not meeting production). When it comes to DTMA, most manufacturers will have a hard time spending more than their cap, because of what digital transformation will cost for them to do it (not just financial, but completely restructuring their business and educating their employees). A new machine that makes a part 1.5x faster with little to no change in your production process is much easier to sell than making their entire process 5x faster by restructuring the business. Even if it’s the same cost.

Author: brianpribe
Content: To sell DTMA at any scope, you need to remove your customers veil. That veil being “if it ain’t broke don’t fix it”, “this way does it just fine”, “we don’t know how to do that”, “I can’t because of *blank* policy”.

Author: rickbullotta
Content: I think the key question here is are you doing a digital maturity assessment for the business or just for your production operations?  Personally, I think you'd be getting very suboptimal results by just doing it for your production operations.  The biggest transformational value usually comes from the places you interact outside of your company - your customers, partners, suppliers and so on, and from rethinking your product and service and offerings.  OT and production are a part of it - but just a part.

Author: sherylmccrary
Content: Also, are you doing an assessment for the purpose of doing an assessment? or to transform the business? If it's really to effect change then the depth of the inventory, the roadmap, systems evaluation, process, architecture, the PoC identification... matter.

Author: akoscs
Content: No all machine tools can be covered with the same information model, but there is a large overlap. This is the idea behind the machinery information model, which, in theory, should be a common basis upon which many other information models can add their own specifics. E.g. all machine can be queried the same way for e.g. running hours, but to get coolant levels, that is specific only to CNC machines (just a random example). The comparison image you posted is a very skewed way of comparing things. in the SpB image you can still add further columns..like...historical data access? not supported. different underlying transport layers? not supported, client server? not supported (despite all the trends here, client server is extremely useful for all control plane related communications, for the data plane, I agree that PubSub seems in many cases better suited, but ... I do have an idea with a workflow orchestrator like Zeebe that makes client-server gold, but that is a very long topic to discuss). So you know...you have something extremely basic with no option other then at the application layer to add advanced functionality vs. you have something where some (very few I agree) products support advanced features and there is no hard work to be done at the application layer. Why you have the red Xes at the information model, I do not know why, but the same red Xes should be also at SpB, since there is no information model there....

Author: bright_hummingbird_31342
Content:
The point of the diagram is not whether a standard supports functionality, but rather whether a product supports a standard.  Proponents of OPC technology constantly cite features that are basically theoretical.  One does not get source this stuff on the market.  They're either engineering it themselves or requiring a third-party that has never done so to do so on their products.  Either way, it's cost prohibitive.  Anyone that is responsible for building functional systems for real-life industrial firms knows this.  They don't rely on OPC-UA as a sufficiently mature technology to enable outcomes beyond basic data access.

There is no question that OPC-UA is technologically superior.  It can do so much.  But, the question is, can OPC-UA do this in the real world?

When a product supports Sparkplug, the consumer knows what they're getting.  When a product supports OPC-UA, the consumer doesn't know what they're getting.  And when they eventually do, they know what they're not getting.  This is about transparency.

Author: sherylmccrary
Content:
A good laugh about assessments and executive leadership:

 “A Japanese company and a North American company decided to have a canoe race on the St. Lawrence River. Both teams practiced long and hard to reach their peak by performance before the race.
On the big day, the Japanese won by a mile. The North Americans, very discouraged and depressed, decided to investigate the reason for the crushing defeat.
A management team made up of senior management was formed to investigate and recommend appropriate action. Their conclusion was the Japanese had 8 people rowing and 1 person steering, while the North American team had 8 people steering and 1 person rowing. So, North American management hired a consulting company and paid them a large amount of money for a second opinion.
They advised that too many people were steering the boat, while not enough people were rowing.
To prevent another loss to the Japanese, the rowing team’s management structure was totally reorganized to 4 steering supervisors, 3 area steering superintendents and 1 assistant superintendent steering manager. They also implemented a new performance system that would give the 1 person rowing the boat greater incentive to work harder.
It was called the”Rowing Team Quality First Program“, with meetings, dinners and free pens for the rower. There was discussion of getting new paddles, canoes and other equipment, extra vacation days for practices, and bonuses.
The next year the Japanese won by two miles. Humiliated, the North American management laid off the rower for poor performance, halted development of a new canoe, sold the paddles, and canceled all capital investments in new equipment. The money saved was distributed to the Senior Executives as bonuses and the next year’s racing team was outsourced to India.”
