Author: willsobel.
Content:
Regardless of SpB, OPC, etc. I would suggest using some common semantics on top of the standard. MTConnect become protocol and representation agnostic since the greatest value is the information model and the dictionary. Regardless of how you want to send and receive data, it's important that you are speaking some common language and know the meaning and context of you terms.

If we compare MQTT, SpB, OPC-UA, MTConnect, & UMATI on one chart as though we're looking at equivalents it will make no sense. Might as well add turkeys and shoe laces to make the picture complete.

Author: mparris
Content:
What do you think of these diagrams I put together to try and line up different technologies?

I think what you are saying is have a definition at the information layer, and deploy it using whatever communication layer and network infrastructure makes sense?

Author: willsobel.
Content: I used to use this graphic to describe the data enrichment pipeline. (I have other versions as well)

Author: willsobel.
Content:
Different layers of data interpretation come in depending on the level of context and information you have available to you. It is a process of adding context and analytics to try to make something useful out of the data. The protocol, MQTT or a raw UDP packet will get your data someplace (I used to write pub/sub financial protocols before MQTT existed using IP-Multicast and many tricks).

Representations, xml, json, nodeset, or protobufs doesn't matter either in the end. We can work with anything as long as we have sufficient context in the data to drive the analytics.

Author: geoffnunan
Content: Keep in mind that you are only referring to a sub-set of the information model in these diagrams. I.e. only the events and commands that are passed between applications, not the information model of the applications themselves

Author: willsobel.
Content: At each layer in the diagram we have a certain level of context. Each layer add more. At the raw sensor level, we may not even know units. The data layer we assign it a name so we can call it something, but we still don't know what it means. This is an OPC DA level model. Most OPC UA implementations are still using DA semantics.

Author: willsobel.
Content: We did a lot of this work in the industrial AI group at IIC to look at the pipeline from the perspective of information use.

Author: bright_hummingbird_31342
Content:
I don't disagree with the overall spirit of your post.  Semantics are absolutely critical.  I've wanted standard models and to get out of the "mapping business" for a long time.

Theoretically, this diagram makes no sense.  But, in practice, it does.  This is what these technologies mean to a consumer in the vast majority of the market.

The OPC Foundation will constantly market their information modeling capabilities and all the interoperability it enables.  They create the impression that if one simply specs OPC-UA or commits to the technology, they get these things.  But, they don't.  It's the good-old data access from OPC Classic but with modern transport and security.  99% of the time, merely having an OPC-UA seal on a product does not enable the "holy grail" Industry 4.0 outcomes manufacturers desire in a compelling or meaningful way.

The critique that Sparkplug has little-to-no payload definition is absolutely correct.  It doesn't purport to be anything than what it already is.  It's edge-driven UDTs encoded with protobuff.  It solves some, but not all, problems well.  OPC-UA, on the other hand, claims its information models enable plug-n-play.  But, this only exists on paper.  Go ask a machine builder to ship a machine with a full-fledged OPC-UA Server with a companion spec.  In the rare chance that they know what this actually means, they most likely wouldn't know how to do it.  And on the even more rare chance a machine is delivered with this, there will be no client applications to consume it.

I don't know how many times I must reinforce this point:  The market does not care about what something is theoretically capable of, but rather what it's actually capable of.  Taking a Metcalfe's Law view:  if a network does not have nodes in sufficient numbers, it's less valuable as a network to invest in.  Anyone tasked with governing a standard should be laser-focused on this.  Instead, we have people making claims that no one uses Modbus anymore.

Author: bright_hummingbird_31342
Content:
I must give MTConnect credit.  It, like Sparkplug, has done a reasonable job of accomplishing what it claims to be.  It has not boiled the ocean.  Despite some of the poor machine builder implementations with missing information, it's a relatively complete solution in the market.  While it has not solved some unique problems I and others regularly encounter, I can concede that there are good products from reputable firms that have adopted the technology in good-faith.

I would say the greatest strengths of MTConnect is that it's one of the few technologies that actually has client applications that consume the data models.  System Insights / VIMANA, for example, is amazing in this regard.  There are tons of useful things this application can do by simply piping in MTConnect data.

At the end of the day, most consumers are not going to care what data representation standard can be encapsulated in what transport.  They're going to care what nodes they can hook up and what outcomes it can enable as a function of a particular technology in the context of their existing automation investments.  Consumers are not buying frameworks or semantic model standards.  They're buying products.

If we want to go down the path of manufacturers adopting standards and frameworks as highly-customized and highly-engineered deployments (i.e., code on operating systems), we should be prepared to start subsidizing these "mapping" efforts.  Azure, AWS, SAP, Siemens, Rockwell, etc should start paying for the last mile then.  With the current approach, there's no chance of adoption anytime soon.  It's just too cost prohibitive.

In the spirit of "in-practice", I updated the diagram to include MTConnect.  In my experience, when someone says they support MTConnect, it's an standardized representation of machine tool data in XML served up over HTTP.  Yes, MTConnect can be served up in an OPC-UA Server via the companion spec, but I've yet to encounter this done in the real world.

Author: rickbullotta
Content: IMO mapping is virtually always required, and often desired, no matter how awesome device vendor X built their stuff or how comprehensive standard Y is.   I’m also skeptical of libraries of “standard” object models - they sound good in presentations but come up short in practical applications.

Author: rickbullotta
Content: As a way to show best practices for object modeling? Sure. I’ll buy that. Or a “ship the device with a model” approach. Thumbs up.  A “standard” definition of a pump? Not so much.

Author: bright_hummingbird_31342
Content:
A model, any model, is better than no model.  An incomplete model that exists is better than a perfect model that does not exist.

Nothing is ever going to exhaust all use cases.  But, if it products can provide some canned functionality that can provide quick value and can be extended, it's a massive win.  Even if it's a device node is delivered with the wrong model for the application node, it's still better than nothing.  At least there are other things that can consume it or it can be adapted without undertaking a painful process of reverse engineering register-values pairs.

Author: mparris
Content:
I think the idea of digital transformation is to automate the integration of systems.

If equipment can be exposed as an object, then other systems can pull all its properties in. So the "object" enables automating the mapping of individual registers, that normally needs to be done at a higher level.

Next step better, if the object used is well-defined, then systems can automatically consume data from these objects, which is yet another level of automation that would typically require manual mapping/integration at a higher level.

Author: lukesmaul
Content: That automation makes sense - of course that's assuming we have a transformative end goal in mind. Easy access/provisioning of assets in itself will not be transformative.

Author: mparris
Content: Yes...providing data for its own sake is not the goal.  Automating the consumption of data between systems is only one of many pieces for Digital Transformation.

Author: willsobel.
Content:
Thanks for the plug. We are trying not to be everything and just focus on the semantics. 

The direction MTConnect is going, we will not be saying we support MTConnect _or_ OPC-UA _or_ SpB, because there isa companion spec for UA and we are creating one for SpB. Pick your favorite protocol, representation, and modeling framework, and then layer on top semantics (meaning and context) of the data. 

For digital transformation, the hard bit is going to be communicating information between layers. Going from CAD to CAM to Execution with zero loss and complete trace. It is a hard problem in discrete and our thread is broken.

Author: bright_hummingbird_31342
Content:
I appreciate you sharing your vision.  Are there plans to have reference implementations or real products for each of these combinations?

I think it's perfectly fine and probably wise for a standards body to take a protocol/representation/modeling agnostic position.  But, at the same time, market execution is really important.  This makes all the difference to consumers.  For example, what good is an MTConnect OPC-UA Companion Spec if there are no devices or applications that make use of it?  How is it enabling interoperability in the real world?

If I have an OPC-UA and an MTConnect node, I'll put a gateway in between.  Why?  I don't have any applications that can consume OPC-UA information models beyond basic data access.  It all gets flattened into name-value pairs in the end anyways.  Why create a spec if there's virtually no chance that Ignition, Canary, AWS, Azure, SAP, etc will use it?

For example, I could implement Sparkplug to work over a V.92 dial up modem.  But, who cares?  What nodes exist that actually do this or what would this benefit?

Related conversion:
https://discord.com/channels/738470295056416930/738470295056416934/907717980123693146

Author: rkwadd
Content: The standards body is volunteers. That group is going to make the standard. That group does not and will never build product to implement the standard. If there’s a business case to be made for a commercial product that deploys MTConnect over OPC UA, the companion spec already exists and will make that an easier product development effort than it would otherwise be.

Author: rkwadd
Content: I completely agree with your main point though: “standards” aren’t the goal, usable software is.

Content: This is the same power plant that had a bucket for controlling the tripper car. Coal would spill off the conveyor as it filled the silo. When the silo was full, the bucket would have enough weight to close the switch. I must admit, they did upgrade from a plastic bucket to a metal bucket.

Author: ryankershaw
Content: You know it had to go through a change committee before they made the upgrade.

Author: mparris
Content: They must have been ahead of their time. The bucket was simply a pre-cursor to digital twins!

Author: sherylmccrary
Content: Sounds like a scene in an old cartoon.

Author: brianpribe
Content: A true Rube Goldberg machine!!

Author: benveenema
Content:
It actually might be ingenious. Any other sensor to assess that is probably going to be a contamination nightmare.

It can't be any worse than a sequencing drum that triggers a series of relays... FYI, half of my facility still operates that way...🤦‍♂️

Author: lukesmaul
Content: Looking to connect with folks working on smart/connected asset projects. Typically monitoring assets in service at the owner operator but on behalf of the machine builder/OEM.

Author: binyameen_980
Content: **Walker's** Question: Do you have experience working in manufacturing, on the plant floor?  If so, which industry?  **What do you think was their biggest hurdles to digital transformation?**

Author: binyameen_980
Content: How different your answers are after an year?

Author: ryankershaw
Content:
We (Litmus) are starting to see more of those applications.  From what I've been seeing, there's a lower limit as to the size of the equipment that is being monitored.  Most skids usually fit this bill.  Honestly, I think it's an excellent addition to the equipment that is being supplied (yes, I am horribly biased thanks to my position).  It provides the machines builder the ability to provide a complete solution rather than just a piece of equipment by being able to monitor the equipment in real time.  Plus since the manufacturer is doing this at a variety of sites, they're going to start building a good knowledge base about their equipment, which will help them to implement better predictive models, and give them input on future versions.

From a tech standpoint, it's pretty straightforward, the biggest issue is getting the data out from the facility.  There's a few hardware solutions out there that have combo wifi/LTE modems which gets around most of these problems since they can either jump on the local network, or bypass it if the end-user isn't comfortable with the OEM using it.

Author: mriiot
Content: The other challenge (as an integrator) for new custom equipment is having the buyer pay for this functionality up front.  I think it’s time to start a machine builder / integrator union.

Author: rickbullotta
Content: It's a giant security nightmare for customers of those OEMs though, local network or not.

Author: ryankershaw
Content: I don't know if they need to.  I think there's enough value to be gained from the feedback that can be implemented into new designs and identifying potential current design issues.  If a service contract can be worked out, then you definitely have a commercial case for it.  Also, the hardware and software requirements for this aren't prohibitive.

Author: ryankershaw
Content: Yeah, security is always going to be a concern, and the last thing you want to be is the weak point that let a hacker in to the overall system.  I think the LTE route is probably the best way for many people.  You could go the wifi route, but you would have to make sure your (integrator) security protocols were top notch.  If the LTE route is one way (i.e. only setup to send diagnostic data), then the security concerns should be minimized.  That said, look at everyone's favourite example in this server, Tesla, they've got an always on connection to home base and it's been a massive advantage for them.

Author: lukesmaul
Content: That’s definitely been my experience. Focus on the value, work out a new service contract to share that value, data starts to flow.

Author: rickbullotta
Content: yup.  the moment you open up any form of remote control or changing settings, your risk has increased by many orders of magnitude.

Author: lukesmaul
Content: What if it's only one way i.e. not closed loop or remote control, just monitoring?

Author: rickbullotta
Content: Way less risk, but not zero - attaching to any other local networks or devices increases the attack surface exponentially if the device gets compromised.  Thus what Ryan was saying about a dedicated pipe out in some cases.  Also, I personally think you should NEVER EVER initiate connections from outside (nor should it have a publicly accessible IP address). ALL communications should be initiated from the device to the whatever (cloud, data center, etc).

Author: lukesmaul
Content: So dedicated pipe out, monitor only, and comms initiated from the device. And of course, all wrapped in a new service based business model so both parties benefit.

Author: rickbullotta
Content: Like anything in life, some level of risk is essential to achieve results.

Author: rickbullotta
Content: Not always monitor only - but just need to understand the risks.

Author: jon.forbord
Content: How do you make an outcome-based or service-based business model or products that getter better after you buy them, for hardware? Say you're making drive-chains for automotive?

Author: lukesmaul
Content: Very hard for a tier supplier. Ideally you need to partner with the end OEM (the one that owns the customer contract) and move with them to outcome based i.e. your drive train supports the overall reliability of an outcome based contract for the end product.

Author: ryankershaw
Content: Even just being connected to the end-user network can be a potential source of risk: https://www.securityweek.com/target-hvac-contractor-says-it-was-breached-hackers

Author: ryankershaw
Content: Again, it can be done, but you had better make sure you're doing security right.

Author: thedavidschultz
Content: There were a number of articles I referenced about 5 years ago on "non product based revenue streams" for OEMs. It became a chicken/egg in that OEMs didn't do it because no one was asking for it. Customers didn't ask for it because they weren't aware of the benefits. And the added costs. And the clients specs the equipment (talking to OEM) or the OEM specs the equipment (talking to client).

Author: sherylmccrary
Content: I've seen business models in which an OEM collects data from equipment in use at customers' sites in exchange for providing anonymized aggregate data on performance, etc to all participating customers. @Luke Smaul

Author: thedavidschultz
Content: I have pitched these models. At the end of the conversation, they all like the idea, but don't want to lose a project because they were not the low bid.

Author: thedavidschultz
Content: I am only aware of one company that did anything meaningful with it (they were a food company in West Liberty). They required all of their OEMs to provide technology that would provide a "predictive maintenance" capability. Not sure how far they got with it, but last conversation indicated a certain level of success.

Author: sherylmccrary
Content: I think the OEM has to see it as a competitive differentiators. Caterpillar in Tucson offers remote monitoring of mining haul trucks and equipment. Hardware, software is built in and safety benefits drive the willingness/ desire of mining companies to participate.

Author: thedavidschultz
Content: Their sales/business development teams also need to be able to articulate the value. I offered to help develop that for them. Never seemed to go anywhere. It's been a couple of years since I last pursued these. The market landscape may be much different now.

Author: sherylmccrary
Content: Yes, definitely...the need to articulate and demonstrate the value.

Author: mriiot
Content: Ability to guarantee proprietary data will never ever leave

Author: sherylmccrary
Content: It seems to me there's no more risk in a pipe out to the OEM than in a pipe out (edge driven from customer owned device) to customer cloud broker which data could selectively be  shared with OEM, but also used internally.  I'd rather persuade a manufacturer of the benefits of collecting and being in  control of their own data.

Author: sherylmccrary
Content: And part of the challenge here is that it's not just equipment or machine data you're talking about collecting, it's machine data relative to wear and performance in that environment for that level of use, etc. Hard to separate which points are proprietary.

Author: sherylmccrary
Content: Disruptive business opportunities in the making.

https://youtu.be/BOXe5FFkMWg

Author: lukesmaul
Content: I’ve done it once and it took a soup to nuts approach where my firm ended up owning everything from product through to biz dev. Results were great but it was a bear

Author: sherylmccrary
Content:
Concept thru product thru bus dev...sounds like fun, my cup of tea you might say. We don't always get the satisfaction of seeing the results in a corporate environment. 

I think there's a business opportunity to specialize in these IIOT service-product development endeavors---most companies don't have the internal expertise or resources to pull it off and need to subcontract for it, and the ads I've seen for firms that claim to provide it are really only selling a cloud platform or mobile app development or one component of that full soup to nuts process.

Author: martin.brion
Content: Hi! I would like your opinion please. I developed a proof of concept for machine monitoring with a LTE router publishing data to a mqtt broker on the cloud but I was also searching for a way to give remote updates and support so the router is a client of an OpenVpn Server running in my PC. When the server starts running the router connects to the public IP of my office. I have little experiencie in cyber security and would like to know how risky is this solution and what I can do about it. Of course everything is done with TLS and self signed certificates. Thanks in advance!

Author: ryankershaw
Content: Way outside of my area of expertise unfortunately.  As @RickBullotta mentioned, you can definitely reduce your exposure by only allowing the device to initiate connections, but that does create a bit of an issue if you're trying to push security updates down.  @Jermuk wrote a great article going over asymmetric encryption that might give you a few ideas on how to handle this. https://docs.umh.app/docs/concepts/symmetric-asymmetric-encryption/

Author: rickbullotta
Content: At ThingWorx we handled file transfers for updates (as well as log uploads) along with enabling things like remote terminal and RDP sessions over (mostly) the same mechanism.   Once you made the connection, the “cloud” can request that the device perform an update and the device can then request the payload.

Author: chris.demers
Content:
Wanted to get peoples thoughts on the BioPhorum Operations Group Digital Plant Maturity Model (attached). It's extremely popular in Life Sciences. Essentially it defines 5 "levels" of plant maturity ranging from a Level 1 Pre-Digital Plant to a Level 5 Adaptive Plant with characteristic features at each level. Lately I've found it to be more of a nuisance to our digital transformation strategy because corporate IT wants everything mapped back to maturity levels.

At a high level it captures some of the pieces of the Manufacturing Holy Grail i.e. "Level 5" means 'End-to-end value chain integration' but by mapping it out in discreet levels it seems to have the effect of forcing people to think of digital transformation as this linear progression where we bop our way up the maturity levels.

Author: ryankershaw
Content:
Pharma is (for good reason) such an odd and stupidly bureaucratic industry.  One of the biggest hurdles with any technological improvement is trying to explain it to absolutely everyone that has a stake in the process, which is typically everyone.  Many of the process leaders have more of a science background than an engineering background.  Any adjustments have to be signed off on by outside auditors, which may or may not have a technical background.  The risk involved with anything requires significant overview from those on the business side.  And so on and so forth.

While this document may seem simple, I think that's probably it's best quality.  Getting anything done in the pharma industry can be like pulling teeth because change is unknown, and not too many people get in trouble for sticking with the status quo (on the production side of things) in that field.  So, if you can show an overview like this to everyone and say, "here is where we want to go and why", everyone can start developing what they need to develop to get to that point.  Regulators will develop the needed regulations, business will develop the funding models, etc.  Yeah, it does seem like a linear progression, but my experience has always been that slow and steady is the change motto.  That said, I'm sure there are a few place that are skipping steps and just jumping to Level 5.  Resilience Pharma struck me as one of those that would be doing that jump.

Author: lukesmaul
Content: I would want to see value or outcomes at each level to make it meaningful. A Paint-By-Numbers approach with tech alone is very dangerous.

Author: mikebartlett_nh
Content: That's the thing - the primary outcomes are safety and quality, all of which you can achieve at any point on the spectrum.  Surviving and thriving in today's day and age will require you to be closer to the right than the left, where you want to create a culture of agility and adaptability, not only to the current product in commercial manufacturing, but also all of the ones following behind it.

Author: ryankershaw
Content: Whether you can achieve safety and quality isn't the question.  It's whether the method that is being proposed has been signed off on by one of the regulatory bodies.  Until that happens site are going to be twitchy about moving forward on anything.  One example is the real-time release in Level 4.  My last company brought a real-time microbial analyzer to market, which would essentially speed up testing by 1 - 3 weeks and provide the ability to release in real-time.  One finance guy figured the six figure investment would pay off by the time lunch rolled around.  Even with that sort of return and the fact the regulators consider the current method to be "an educated guess", the uptake is slow since there's no hard and firm regulation on it.  There is support, but nothing that says definitively: "yes, you can use that".

Author: chris.demers
Content: I actually think from a regulatory perspective they would like to see that level of innovation. I think it's easy to see them as a barrier but ultimately it's about the patients and if real time release means faster to market then I think the FDA would be supportive. I always go back to the fact that they release their guidance on usage of Process Analytical Technology (to support real-time release or review by exception) in 2004. So nearly two decades ago the FDA was saying hey ya'll should think about this technology because it would bring quality in-line and give a constant readout.

Author: IIoT#4707
Content: GG @chris.demers, you just advanced to level 2!

Author: mikebartlett_nh
Content: I was mostly answering Luke's comment - use of technologies on the right will lead towards better agility to support better outcomes for patients (and/or respond to a pandemic).  But I agree, said elements are cutting edge and a culture change is needed to start using the predictive and prescriptive bits in commercial manufacturing.  That's why we are encouraging customers to start this journey in process development, where it isn't subject to GxP yet.  In reality, if you are using ML to improve yield, as one example, if you can prove through strict controls and documentation that safety and quality are adhered to if/when you adjusted the process, there's no reason the regulatory bodies shouldn't approve it (I know, it's harder than that).  We have a project with regulatory approval coming up that'll hopefully set precedent -> in-line quality measurements feeding ML models to drive closed-loop control of a continuous manufacturing small molecule bioreactor.

Author: ryankershaw
Content: They do support it to a point, and they have been starting to become more progressive in getting new technologies approved, especially thanks to the pandemic, which really showed why advanced manufacturing capabilities were required.  The PAT initiative is starting to take hold, and you are seeing some companies really run with it.  I know Sanofi did massive upgrades to their PA and Toronto facilities that probably put them in Level 4 or 5.  I think that you're going to start to see more of a willingness to implement PAT thanks to the virus that shall not be named, and a changeover from the old guard to those that are used to dealing with high tech on a daily basis.  That said, I've still seen more than a few chart recorders still hanging around those facilities even within the past couple of years!

Author: ryankershaw
Content: Yeah, there is so much potential there, it's not even funny.  I'm hoping that it becomes more and more accepted!  I can definitely see how adding that capability can improve the small molecule applications, but it would be even more interesting to see what impact they could have on the large molecule ones.  The bug applications can be tricky, and thanks to the way they scale up or out, efficiencies would cascade through the process.

Author: chris.demers
Content:
I actually really like @Luke Smaul analogy with “Paint by Numbers” because it’s precisely what Deloitte is attempting to do with their “digital transformation”. Which big “intelligent systems” do we need to “digitally transform” our company. 

I would argue there should be value definitions and that they probably are quite similar to other industry verticals trying to pursue a “connected enterprise” on the far right of the spectrum. 

I think quality and safety are just the boundaries we need to remind ourselves of but that COVID has caused us to take a second look at well how exactly can we innovate and move faster while still maintaining quality.

In the DT process,  you may have develop small pockets of high maturity while overall still being at level 2 or 3.

Author: jbonhage155
Content:
Any tips out there to navigate digital transfomation at large corporations? (even ones they say they are digitally transforming but really just have a few promo videos and slides about it)
Specifally differences from going from the "top"-down.. selling ideas to enterprise IT which pushes down to plants vs the plant cultivating a solution which pushes upwards to corporate.

Author: jbonhage155
Content: Which the ladder is intersting to me because sometimes it seems the enterprise groups can't get out of their own way so plants go their own way driving much better digital transformations.

Author: brianpribe
Content: In mastermind, we learn a lot about digitally transforming a company. Two factors that will determine how difficult a transformation will be is buy-in from C-level officers and IT. You need strong leadership to guide your digital transformation and for IT to allow the plant floor data to interact with IT systems. A third factor is the technology you decide to implement. The wrong technology will increase costs and complexity to your digital transformation.

Author: lukesmaul
Content:
Some tips: 
1) Start with a common understanding of DT. For example, digitization is very different to full DT
2) Know the history of DT; there is a reason we all talk about DT and its thanks to seismic level economic shifts that are happening thanks to digital technology
3) Based on the history determine where the company needs to go to stay/become competitive. 
4) Understand where the company sits today  compared to that desired to-be state 
5) Ask "what needs to be true" to get from as-is to the to-be state. These are your working assumptions that you need to go test in the real world
6) Adjust your strategy as you go based on the results of this assumption testing.
7) It should be top down and bottom up for almost all steps but focus more top down on 3 & 4

Content: Now that I've finished typing you come across as rather genuine.

Author: mikebartlett_nh

Author: nickn5549
Content: It depends from industry to industry what is considered core or must-have functionality for the MES. We've built one in-house - started from core functionality and then, in time, we add modules to it. For us, working in EMS (electronics manufacturing services) core functionality was: materials movement and traceability (license plate for each material reel/box/tray, scanning, linking to the serial number of each product, multi-layer assembly linkage..)  process traceability, enforced routings (must follow the process flow), quality (yields, top defects, etc), reporting.

Author: joshlawson9986
Content:
CFX will only really exist on new machines and most machine vendors charge a fee for interface... 

Old machines could use the CFX SDK .net to make a gateway but issue like Nick stated is does depend on what data you can get or exposed too.

The Electronics Manufacturing Equipment OEMs have been slow to get on train mainly for Vendor Lock-in reasons and sand bag their Ecosystems...

Japanese OEMs seem to be worst at this ...love to lock out any data integration out side of a solution they sell. Often they OEM License other softwares to do some functions but is a closed ecosystem 

CFX is a IPC managed protocol, bit like OPC UA in sense big companies influence it more than small , just nature of these things 

Valor part of Siemens now has the OML or now calles ODB++M protocol for a normalising standard for electronic manufacturing use case , there is alot of implementations of this working globally then any CFX as they developed this before CFX got off ground.

But I think CFX will be a standard offering one day on a machine but only for new machines and when gets more user base. 

Of course if you PO 20 machines they would throw in CFX no doubt...

Author: rkwadd
Content: ^^^most info I’ve ever got on this in one shot and it sounds *identical* to mtconnect 6 years ago

Author: rkwadd
Content: Thanks!

Author: joshlawson9986
Content:
Yes you could say that MTconnect Standard not a expert taking a quick look domain is machining based systems and could be used for some general machine use case..

Electronics Manufacturing is a mix of process like production and automated discrete assembly... As you have paste application , placement then reflow IE soldering , then have THT insertion from manual to automated then wave and selective soldering then have to test from ICT  / FPT and Functional Test.  Then comes the box build system assembly , manual and automated then ship. Can also have cleaning of the PCB and Coating processes

Each equipment domain has its own issues and concerns..

Soldering is a chemical temperature related processes. 

There is QA inspection, manual and AOI , X-ray and the like added in not just Electrical Test Equipment and process.


So is a mixed bag industry if break it down . Standards in terms IIoT has taken some time, adding in the equipment OEMs slowing it down to protect themselves...!!!

Author: bright_hummingbird_31342
Content:
You have just described the state of the CNC Machine Tools industry well.  Again, many of the Japanese OEMs are hostile.  No documentation and the registers are often re-mapped/scrambled.  It's amazing how many field sales/service and engineering channels know next to nothing about the technology.  They know just enough to do the bare minimum.  Anything more, they must request information on case-by-case basis.  I could never imagine working on technology for decades and never learning how it truly works.

I could understand if they were protecting an ecosystem worth protecting, but usually their own solutions are not very good.  They usually have a ton of context missing, poor integration capabilities and few customers actually adopt it.  I wish machine builders would recognize that a majority of their customers are only interested in their machines because they're available, reliable, and economical.  In many cases, they're the only available machines or the only machines that can be serviced in some parts of the world.  Their software and control implementations fall somewhere between garbage and unremarkable.  It's not a differentiator.  No one buys capital equipment based on the unremarkable data collection software it can be paired with.  They buy them based on how productive they are at producing widgets.  I really wish they would give up on this idea that they can succeed in the software business.  The firms are too traditional to be any good at it.  They should either partner with someone who can or just get out of the way.

Author: brianpribe
Content: PREACH!!!

Author: rkwadd
Content:
I had this typed out two days ago and said “eh forget it” but since we’re apparently going to go there…

Every subset of production machines follows the same cycle of interoperability vs proprietary. Welders, robots (mostly arms), CNC, SMT. It was the same in other semiconductor fab equipment. There are of course some technical challenges that hamper progress and these can differ by equipment type/market segment. However, a lot of it comes down to market factors, politics, and culture. 

The best fixes are to:
1) not re-invent the wheel for standards and best practices segment by segment. No matter who you are, you are not the first person to have this problem. 
2) identify segments with favorable conditions and push for progress there first. For example, automated bread slicing machines might be what you’ve always known, but if the market is dominated by two companies who hate each other and will never ever cooperate regardless of what that means for the customer it’s just not a good opportunity to try and take on these challenges.

Author: bright_hummingbird_31342
Content:
Do you ever rate or rank (or perhaps implicitly shame) member adoptions of MTConnect?  I feel like the industry needs some "how much are you apart of the problem" index.  

I honestly believe that machine builders have nothing to gain from their current approach.  They're spending money developing inferior data collection products that most of their customers are not going to purchase.  Their integration services are so expensive and inefficient that it actually induces consumers to look at alternatives.  I've seen entire plants roll out sensors and data collection infrastructure for the same cost that some machine builders quote to install analog input cards on a few machines.  They're not even winning in the market they attempt to wall off for themselves.  How does this help their bottom line?

Author: rkwadd
Content:
You are making a key point. I work for the machine builders association; the MTConnect Institute is a subsidiary. So my underlying objective is to improve the builders’ businesses. The way to do that in my case is to increase the quality and speed to market of what they are able to offer their customers. Pressure from smart, well-informed, hungry customers is critical and it’s why I spend time here.

Direct answer: 
Someone released open source validation tools earlier this year. See https://github.com/TrueAnalyticsSolutions/MtconnectCore

Next up is to build automation against the mtconnect V2 model which is at https://github.com/mtconnect/mtconnect_sysml_model. The open source validation tools should be able 
to self-update whenever a new version of MTConnect standard is released (as a SysML model). Funding for all this is relatively thin but I still think by this Fall there will be people making purchase decisions based on an _actual_ implementation and its objective alignment to the standard as opposed to vague promises and half-informed sales pitches.

Author: rkwadd
Content: This ties straight back to CFX because it seems feasible to hand an approach and basic software tooling over from MTConnect Institute to IPC (their governing body), taking lessons learned from attempting this in CNC machining to speed up CFX development and adoption for SMT lines.

Author: rkwadd
Content: But maybe I’m just an optimist.

Author: joshlawson9986
Content:
CFX will take off I believe as most SMT equipment makers have a approved option for it but generally only on new gear. There are alot more mature machines in place and they will not support CFX adaptors for these. Generating a CFX adaptor is not hard but is if data needed is not easily available for machine due to proprietary IP not shared.
So end up IO scavenging looking at inputs , light towers to get status of a machine. 

Valor Software was first to market with a standard that that still use in there MES related line management systems for the Electronics space ... They did offer this as a Vendor Managed standard ODB++M (OML) to industry but at time was resistance from machine vendors, some signed up but was slow. At the time the push for I4.0 concepts and saw it as a buzz word for machine vendors license to vendor lock in than working to  common communication standards.  

End day CFX will get traction but also end customers have to drive it , demand it will drive it forward also. Siemens Valor is part of CFX IPC group and will support both CFX and their ODB++M .

ODB++M previously OML , has a more mature install base than CFX as of today

Also alot of Valors competition saw as a threat so pushed to diffuse this by banding together at IPC to come up with a standard, aka CFX. Which is good Valor wanted this in end anyway get Industry talking about this.

So two main pushes are CFX ( driven by IPC HQ in USA) JSON payloads on AMQP transport for a vertical comms standard. d Hermes TCPIP XML message exchange ( HQ in EU at start), now assigned a IPC standard , for horizontal coms for PCB data transfer markup between machines. Wish was JSON not XML but who knows why XMl???

To complicate Japanese Electronics Manufacturing wants to have different standards in place and China toying with own standards...IE competitive with Hermes and CFX ... Again reinvent wheel again, but not about Industry control and political issues.

Author: omarazizahmed
Content: I am really really interested in digging into this @NickN Your UNS is alive and well. My question is about the different business groups who are accessing the JSON. Who is subcribing to the payloads? What are their business roles? What departments. This is of signifigant interest to me.

Author: nickn5549
Content: At this stage, the JSONs are for sanity checks before production starts. We have in UNS a TAG PRODUCT_RUNNING and another one QUEUE for each line. Whatever is in the QUEUE we would like to check before it reaches PRODUCT_RUNNING  status. I'm checking if all the products queued are ready for production, by checking ECN status, BOM revision and content from various sources (Official BOM is in ERP, another copy in MES, another copy in PLM - all these aligned by ECN process, but delays and exceptions could occur), programs/recipes ready for that product/line combo and when product is put OnLine if operators working on the line are trained (signed latest rev of the OWIs - Online Work Instructions) for that product and that line.....and of course, I have a backlog of  checks that is growing by the minute. Source of inspiration, DT meetings where people are asked what their known pain points are regarding their day by day job - with a special focus on data access, manipulation, checks, comparisons.

Author: nickn5549
Content: Later on, passed this PoC, the idea is that JSON of processed payloads will be saved in the historian/database and be the starting point for Predictive Scheduling and Predictive Maintenance done using machine learning and AI. For ML and AI, I have a bunch of Jetson Nano's ready to be powered up and configured. They have enough firepower for ML & AI PoC later on.

Author: nickn5549
Content: giving operators and employees a flat structure tiles menu to access all the apps proved to be the best way to get everybody on board - easy to find and open anything you need. Just don't move the tiles around too much coz you get complaints. The idea was, like in web design, what is used more often is at the top and then you follow a F shape down the page and place the most used tiles on that F. The traffic for each app is monitored with Piwik/Matomo.

Author: nickn5549
Content: Why don't they move to Py3? Together with everybody else... Author: rickbullotta
Content: Because there is no released version of Jython that supports Py3.  I suspect there’s a deep dependency on that to get decent performance (no need to invoke external code across an RPC boundary).  But doing that and decoupling it can bring some benefits in a cloud version for scalability.  Maybe someone from Inductive could chime in with an official roadmap statement?

Author: mparris
Content:
All dashboards shown in demos are better as secondary screens when digging into a problem.

The simplest primary screen is a list of issues that need to be addressed, with names of owners and when they were acknowledged. This is hard to do, as keeping the list tidy and manageable it  requires an intelligent alarming engine to combine notifications coming from different equipment but are related to the same root cause.

Author: rickbullotta
Content: I also like the “actions” to be one click away if possible.  Ultimately I think if the SCADA/HMI vendors built out better interactive analytics widgets, added more “forms oriented” capabilities, expanded their connectivity to a broader range of data sources, and doubled down on HTML5 clients, they could be in the best position to deliver here.

Author: benveenema
Content: The most development in UI design in the past 10 years has been in the web/HTML world. In my opinion, it would be silly not to leverage this and take advantage of all the good work that's been done there. Things that HTML/CSS does easily that trad HMIs suck at: scaling to different display resolutions, transitions (not just animations), reconfiguring displays, display state management, code reuse.

Author: rickbullotta
Content: it's a bit more complex in the real world, as you know.  putting up 15 thermocouples and gauges/displays only requires tapping into some power (and sometimes not even that).  if you need to install comms or power wiring and conduit, the cost can go WAAAAAAY up.   to make each of those sensors wireless adds another layer of cost and complexity.  that said, i've seen some cool use of local LPWAN networks with battery powered sensors to make it more cost effective.

Author: jpmoniz
Content: Who said rip and replace?  Was more of deciding what platforms provide long term value and what doesn’t. In my case it was deciding to abondon FT view for ignition. Again best decision made. That decision was made 10 years ago.

Author: rhuisken
Content:
I'm doing this now with PLCnext. 3 PC's on a single cell all running the same HTML5 HMI. And I can access it easily through VPN for remote support. 
The big advantages I see: 
- Reduced programming time because multiple screens do not need to be programmed individually and the PLC hosts the HMI so it's tightly integrated with the PLC program. 
- I/O Components, barcode readers, vision sensors, etc. are growing their HTML5 interface offerings. Instead of having to program my own screens to show as much information from the sensor as possible, just create a link to open the page for that device.

Author: hobbes1069
Content: Cool. What's your opinion (pros and cons) of the PLCnexts? I know they meet the minimum technical requirements but that doesn't mean they're easy to program or work well 🙂

Author: rickbullotta
Content: I’d love to understand how those tasks are isolated and/or partitioned such that HMI load can’t impact or crash control code performance and determinism.

Author: rhuisken
Content:
I do not have much if any experience with the other big names so take my opinion for what it is. I also use it more as a traditional PLC with IOT features than an IOT edge device. For that I am happy with it. 
You can seamlessly mix ladder, function block, and structured text style code- pick the one that works best for you. I will admit, that I do not like it's ladder programming. The function block editor and structured text editors are quite good. It's fully capable as far as being able to create user types, function blocks, and functions for code reusability. It's easy to create your own libraries from that code (including HMI images and symbols) in order to consume in other projects. There are many useful libraries available in the store for features that are not included out of the box. 
As far as the the HTML5 HMI, it does not have much in the way of charts or graphs. But with the tools it does have, you can create your own symbols (like templates in Ignition). There are more than enough tools to create visually appealing graphics and animations.

Author: rhuisken
Content:
That aspect is abstracted away using PLCnext Engineer. For my use cases, it performs well. Running I/O based operations on a 10ms task, data logging and HMI operations in a 50ms task. I see a definite increase in CPU usage when an HMI page with large amounts of data being polled, but less than OPC UA consumes. It handles 5-10 HMI clients polling the REST interface at 250ms intervals without a problem. 
For a sneak peek under the hood, check out the video below. I'm sure you'd understand it better than me. 
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=y38tVUaYoo8&t=4s

Author: jman444
Content: did you pulled the data from DB and aggregated it using Node-Red? or to be a bit more specific, how did you used Node-Red for this?

Author: nickn5549
Content: Yes, used Node-REd as a gateway between MSSQL /MySQL and the MQTT Broker. I connected to SQL Servers using Node-Red and pulled data into the MQTT Broker. Some of the Machines were connected to UNS VIA Raspberry PIs(some RS232, others parsing log files from the machine and spitting out the data to UNS).   Then I used Node-Red to calculate OEE - get data from  UNS, calculate A, P, Q, publish them back in UNS (different topics). The last step, Dashboards were created in Node-Red  too,  reading directly from UNS (all these topics previously calculated and published back to UNS)

Author: nickn5549
Content: Here is a pictogram of a flow that connects to various databases grabs the data, transforms the data and saves it in MQTT. You need 20-30 Flows and maybe as many Subflows (reusable functions) to get everything done for medium size PoC (connect to 4 x SMT  Production Lines ~ 20 machines and 10 + X Dbs from SCADA, MES, ERP layers). Each Flow can be as big as the development space permits....you scroll down and add stuff until Node-Red doesn't scroll down anymore...you've reached the MAX allowed height....happened to me a few times...

Author: nickn5549
Content: To calculate stuff, you take pre-processed data from MQTT, calculate and then publish back to MQTT (different topics)

Author: nickn5549
Content: For Dashboards, you just grab stuff from MQTT and display it nicely...

Author: marioishikawa
Content: I see it like this: OT started way ahead, before personal computers were a thing. But then came a huge gap. People had smartphones costing 1/10 of a PLC with 1/100 of that computing capacity. Big Data and NoSQL empowering tools were started to be used in all markets but it took sometime to arrive in OT and when it arrived it coincided with IIoT becoming a thing. Now people can solve a PoC for a small line with NodeRed and Granafa with a Raspberry Pi. But they also can do many more using other tools like Kafka and the cloud.

Author: rickbullotta
Content: It's just one analyst's take on a term - my point was more that the overarching concept should not focus on technology.  The "OT" and "IT" chasm is just as much about processes as technology.

Author: rickbullotta
Content: I'd even go one step further and suggest that the IT/OT thing really didn't do a great job of bringing the extended supply network/value chain into the mix.  There are lots of "chasms" that need to be spanned, and not all OT integration needs to flow up through enterprise systems, despite what PERA and ISA-95 zombies will claim.

Author: jon.forbord
Content: An effort to condense DT into a few words: There’s some key areas to focus effort for DT/IX/MT. DT is from a 10 000 foot view, about people, business and technology. Focus for tech: Single source of truth and the integration of your business applications. Focus for business. Leadership vision and overall digital strategy, and becoming a data company. Focus for people. Change management, training the employee of a data company and creating the business where talented people want to work. Bringing it home: “DT is about fundamentally redefining an organization’s business operations and customer experience through digital technologies and creating a company that’s actually stronger and more agile than it previously was”. (Last one’s a quote)

Author: thedavidschultz
Content:
IT/OT convergence starts with culture, just like reliability, quality, etc. Similar to how companies ask if an effort will make them safer or more reliable, they should ask if it will enhance convergence. 

It then moves to elimination of politics, silos and turf wars (HT Patrick Lencioni). The people will converge. 

The third step is the application of the best practices with the technology infrastructure (use use of routers, switches, gateways, firewalls, etc.). 

It ends with the convergence of the actual data. 

There is a lot to understand in the term IT/OT convergence.

Author: thedavidschultz

Author: rickbullotta
Content: I think we forget sometimes that the PERA model was formulated in the 1980s and introduced in the early 90s - **before the internet and the web were mainstream**.   Ted Williams work was seminal on not only this topic but many of the approaches we used for process control and automation as well.  He was talking about AI and manufacturing in the 1980s.  He is a pioneer and a true hero of manufacturing (and a war hero too).   I had the honor ans pleasure of meeting him at one of the early ISA95 meetings.  He literally drove from Purdue to Delaware to attend.  That said, many of the higher level concepts of PERA and S95 were and are based on somewhat dated layer cake approaches and command and control techniques that aren’t as applicable today.  We need to evolve them, not take them literally.

Author: thedavidschultz
Content: I agree. But there are people who do not. As far as they are concerned, ISA-95 (and other standards) came down form Mt. Sinai with Moses. But it was never meant to be a guidebook. Only how we are currently doing things today (which was 30 years ago).

Content: What is this group's opinion on the use of RabbitMQ?  Are there any reasons not to or why HiveMQ is better?

Author: jon.forbord
Content: It at least works. Haven’t done any performance testing, just beware if you use spark plug B, there is a setting you have to set, as RabbitMQ will interpret . as topic separators, so Rabbit messes up the spark plug payload.

Author: jon.forbord
Content: RabbitMQ is an AMQP-broker with an MQTT plugin, so in theory it’s less specialized for MQTT than the other more common options here.

Author: jon.forbord
Content: Both RabbitMQ and EMQX are built in Erlang, and support clustering. From what I understand, RabbitMQs mqtt plugin will translate incoming mqtt messages into AMQP to the core, and then translate to MQTT on the outgoing message as well. This adds some overhead compared to EMQX, and EMQX generally is better in performance testing, especially for one to many messaging.

Author: patanj2
Content: I have used RabbitMQ,  but not as an MQTT broker.  An advantage is that it does support more design patterns than just pub sub.  I was using it for distributed, asynchronous processing behind an API call. I would only use for an MQTT broker if I already had RabbitMQ for another purpose.  From what I have seen for benchmarks, it’s mQTT implementation does not scale very well.

Author: rickbullotta
Content: Read the limitations. No MQTT 5 yet, no QoS2 support, limits on retained message storage might come into play in a large UNS, retained messages are not replicated.

Author: venkyiaf753280
Content:
Can the legacy #bombs be made smart?" That was the question asked by then Squadron Leader Krishna Iyengar Ravi, a bright young #squadron technical officer of No. 1 Sqn, on a hot summer afternoon of May 1999 in Gwalior. He went on to successfully #retrofit the dumb 1000 pound bombs with the American Paveway kits, comprising of the #laser guidance nose kit and a tail unit, and converted them into a smart laser guided bomb (LGB). Consequently, the #precision #airstrikes by the Mirage-2000 #aircraft (nicknamed as "Digital Delta") on Muntho Dhalo, Tiger Hill and Point 4388 in the Drass Sector was the turning point of the Kargil #war.

The point proven by then Squadron Leader KI Ravi is a reality in today's world where businesses are trying to transform #digitally. It’s a myth that the adoption of  #industry4point0 means getting rid of #legacy #machines. All #industries that started a decade ago or more have a sizeable population of legacy machines. It’s impractical and prohibitively expensive to replace all legacy machines with smart ones. Hence, it becomes very important to #integrate these machines into #smartmanufacturing systems. It is now possible to convert the legacy machines to smart machines by identifying the #kpis, be it #process KPIs like #conditionmonitoring, #pdm, diagnostics, etc. or #production KPIs like #oee , #loss analysis, etc. to be measured. The #connectivity options most commonly include  installing #sensors, connecting to a #plc or use the #electrical signal outputs of the machine as #digital pulse outputs to get the production #data.

Author: hobbes1069
Content:
Very interesting analogy but I'll make a far simpler and applicable one 🙂
We have a lot of manual finishing equipment controlled by various manufacturers of VFDs. In my IoT pilot project I dug into the manuals and found that there were leads to do things like detect if the equipment was running, external START/STOP, and even analog outputs for speed. I used two Opto 22 groov EPICs and tied into all 41 pieces of equipment. I can detect if it's running (reported through Tulip), what speed it's running at, and remote enable/disable, which could be used to disable the equipment if run outside of the validated parameters. All the state data is pulled in with NodeRed via MQTT to our Kepserver instance in the cloud.

I'm working with the Industry Readiness Technical Committee with ISA (SMIIoT Division), and we've been trying to find programs like this to see if there are any common threads throughout them, but we haven't getting much in the way of feedback.  @Luke Smaul mentioned he might know something, but he never got back to me.  Hint, hint, nudge, nudge Luke.  😁 

We've talked about putting together a guide that could be used, or even a technical report, but definitely need some more source material.  Also as a blatant plug, if anyone wants to join the committee, let me know.

Author: rkwadd
Content: Edgecross was formed specifically around a tech stack/framework; supporting docs like qualification etc came later.

Author: rkwadd
Content: As in the Edgecross framework itself was the first thing that the Edgecross Consortium came into being around https://www.edgecross.org/en/solution/feature.html, and was sort of a Japanese answer to Reference Architecture Model for Industrie 4.0 (German, federally supported), Industrial Internet Reference Architecture (US-led private consortium), and possibly others.

Author: aristotelestn
Content: Forgetting the price question, has anyone ever used or uses this Siemens Xcelerator architecture (Mindsphere + Mendix) for digitizing industrial processes? Is it possible to scale fast and build a light MES?

Author: nickn5549
Content: Sounds interesting. We are using only their PLM (Valor MSS), but nothing yet from their IIoT spectrum... We connected the Valor MSS to MQTT, so we get PLM data (BOMs, Revisions, Product Data) into the UNS. It's all done through plug-ins not out of the box functions of the Siemens software. My problem with Siemens is that they tend to be expensive like sh*t. 10 years ago when I was looking for a PLM their PLM was 3 times more than Valor PLM, now they bought Valor...hope the prices won't start going up like crazy. Also, they tend to break down functions in different licenses and catch users unaware of the total cost if they want to do more with their PLM solution, which is very annoying. I have a simple example, you have multiple machines, each with its own library of parts/shapes. Each time you add a new machine type, for the same parts (read it as ICs, caps, resistors = electronic parts) you have to start from scratch creating the library, which infuriates the sh*t out of any decent engineer. You can't copy parts from Fuji to Viscom for example. Siemens has the solution, which is AG (auto generation) function, which, of course, is priced as a separate license that is costed ridiculously high for what it does... In my opinion, they would win engineers/users' hearts and minds much easier if this smart function would be part of the core PLM instead of an extra somewhere there, waiting for users to bump their heads into problems first and then ...Ta Da...they come to save you if you pay the fee. And to continue about Siemens...they inherited from Valor/Mentor a standard ODB++ (Design, Process, Manufacturing), which in their opinion will be the next big thing in electronics manufacturing from the way you transfer design data, get data from the machines and program the machines AND first thing that they do with it change from 'open standard' to 'internal Siemens data format' and there is no longer an SDK available for download... Smells like a fish....it is a fu**ing fish

Author: tvidonja
Content:
Do IIoT, UNS and MQTT as the elements of the I4.0 architecture help converging OT and IT? I mean people from both sides talking together.
Or there are some other ways to motivate those two groups of people to cooperate and together deliver the visikn of smart factory?

Author: hobbes1069
Content: To some extent. With MQTT (vs OPC/UA) only needing outbound connections makes it more palatable to IT.

Author: jhisw
Content: FWIW, OPC UA defines a Reverse Connect, to enable Servers to reach out to clients and let them connect.

Author: hobbes1069
Content: Is that one of the optional parts that few have implemented? 🙂

Author: rickbullotta
Content: While I'm a fan of edge initiated connections for edge-to-cloud "firewall friendliness" (which was the purpose of this capability), that's usually best when using a cloud proxy/broker for clients to connect to, not having the edge device connect to a "client" that way.  That creates a requirement to alter the configuration on the edge "server" (I hate the OPC terminology, BTW) to be aware of each client.  I don't like that if it can be avoided.

Author: jhisw
Content: I guess 😆

Author: jhisw
Content:
I understand. That felt indeed a bit bumpy, when I looked it up, how it works. The server has to have a list of each client and invite it to connect.
And I haven't yet understood if and how Reverse Connect ties in with the usual concepts of Global and Local Discovery Servers.

Author: sherylmccrary
Content: To an extent. I think "motivating the two groups to cooperate and deliver together" is the reason the DTMA-type assessment is useful when you can do it, as it creates a shared vision of what the goal is.

Author: tvidonja
Content:
Thank you. Excellent idea. We've been doing. DTMA as the first step in our process creating the digital strategy, but we haven't explicitly thought of shared vision "as a tool" to connect IT and OT.
We plan to add shared values and   benefits of the common data (single source of truth) to additionaly motivate them to cooperate. 😊

Author: jon.forbord
Content: I really like OPC UA at the edge with gateway to mqtt to the higher layers. The edge namespace is rarely so well structured you don’t need a gateway anyway and OPC UA gives a level of control you sometimes want on the edge. Reverse connect seems like a giant workaround..

Author: rickbullotta
Content: Well, it’s solving a similar problem as MQTT and other “always on” protocols.

Author: jpmoniz

Author: douga.7429
Content: Experts who have been successful in implementing Digital Transformation often warn against putting SAP at the center of your implementation strategy. They state that failed transformations happen when people don't question this commonly assumed path.  I agree with this, but I am currently faced with making this argument at or near the C-Level.  I believe I am about to convince IT that they need a UNS-based Digital Transformation strategy.  My thinking is that I will find myself talking with the executive leadership again and I would like to be able to articulate why this is true.  If others agree with this, why and how would be your 30-second pitch on it go?

Author: jpmoniz
Content: My biggest push against that would be agility. What space does this company operate in?  Cost would be second concern. SAP consulting isn’t cheap.

Author: mparris
Content:
My response would be:

What are the chances that SAP will contain all functionality that is needed? (Hopefully they would agree that it's 0%).

What are the chances that the other products that are needed within the Enterprise will be able to connect to whatever interfaces SAP offers to consume and product data?

What are the chances that SAP makes all its data available over open data interfaces?

Author: douga.7429
Content:
In this case, the company is publicly traded with a founder who has full control. The founder would be part of the audience and this topic would appear at the board level. The company has been using SAP from early in the company's history, so it would be an extremely huge lift to move away from it.

My question is more about how to weigh the importance of ERP vs. UNS for a successful digital transformation. I have a pitch, at a director level, that it would be impossible to push all data through SAP to create a cloud IoT solution, which would enable the Real-Time-Enterprise they hope to create. I also added that the SQL-based MES system is equally inadequate at moving all that data. I am wondering if others have a different take on this?

Author: hobbes1069

Author: hobbes1069

Author: douga.7429

I should have also added that we assume the founder is onside with an SAP first argument, meaning that if it can be done in SAP, we will. I think the argument would have to be focused more on ROI.

Author: rickbullotta
Content: I think everyone underestimates what SAP actually has to offer in digital manufacturing.  Is it perfect?  No.  Is it fragmented? Yes.  Is it proprietary?  Yes, and so is pretty much every piece of commercial software.  But it does have a very comprehensive offering for some vertical industries.  And if you're a big SAP customer, often an SAP offering only needs to pass the "good enough" test.

Author: hobbes1069
Content: I agree. There are some things SAP does really well. At least for me on when I was on the Mfg Engineering side, BOMs and Routings worked fine for me.

Author: rickbullotta
Content: If you can drive this change from an operations role, and "win" over IT, you would probably be the first person every to accomplish it.  Not saying you shouldn't try if you're passionate about it, but it's a huge uphill climb.

Author: rickbullotta
Content: We also forget that SAP was *very* influential in the concept of Industry 4.0 in the first place...

Author: hobbes1069
Content: Where I got frustrated was trying to get data out of SAP. In fact (10+ years ago) I wrote several Python scripts that would take report output from SAP and reformat it to a CSV file so I could do further processing in Excel.

Author: jon.forbord
Content: Isn’t a «transaction» just the delta of some form of state? Such as a ledger transaction moving money from one location to another, and the resulting balance is the state of the account? Anyway, I don’t see a huge issue with these types of discrete connections (meaning you do them outside mqtt), as they’re very particular to each use case of actual transactional integration between two applications, and a large majority of the data exchange is mostly context and states. One example could be some raw material being moved from the warehouse to the production line and being consumed, and this would be the transaction, while the current warehouse inventory would be the state. Transactions are anyway point to point, unless you have to keep the logic to deduce current state from transactions in every single application consuming the events?? I’m basically just thinking out loud now, but hope I’m making some sense 😅

Author: rickbullotta
Content: Makes sense.  The other area where MQTT as the UNS foundation breaks down is queries.  “Show me all of the orders for material XYZ over 2000 units with a due date within the next two weeks, and no dependence on raw material ABC”…

Author: jon.forbord
Content: Until there comes along something that will do “everything”, it’s bound to be a need for augmenting mqtt with some supplementary tech, be it Apollo graphql or Redis Cache or Apache Scrotum for that matter..

Author: douga.7429
Content: I have been building a star schema over the past two years that can take a log and turn it into a SQL source. I think the issue with transactions would come up with last-minute changes to the scheduling, WO, and related bills of material. True transactions where one thing gets rolled back if another fails and timing. Also, as this video points out, just like a general ledger, you have to close periods so that aggregates don't have to look back over the entire history to calculate.

Author: torije
Content: When you say SQL source, what are you referring to? I might just be slow, but couldn’t quite figure it out from the context 😅

Author: douga.7429
Content: A data lake is a store of events in a log or if you prefer call it a  ledger. The data in the lake is in a raw, unstructured format. To use the data for analysis, it must be transformed into a structured format, such as a star schema. A star schema is an optimized SQL schema for analysis. It is different from a typical SQL DB, which is optimized for data entry. To create a star schema, you need to transform the data from the data lake into a structured format. This schema is what you should be doing in a tool like Power BI when you make a model.

Author: jhisw
Content: That's basically OPC UA. Many things discretely specified (Data Access, Historical Access, Alarms & Conditions, ...) and depending on the needs, things get implemented into a specific software or they don't.

Author: douga.7429
Content: I was the full stack developer for our data warehouse, memory cube, and business intelligence front end that covered the manufacturing execution system. That is why I know how poorly it is counting. So in my mind, the potential issue you described ELT (extract, load, transform) vs. ETL (extract, transform, load). Currently, I have a solution in ETL and would like to make it ELT using a data lake. The Wonderware MES uses MSDTC (Microsoft Distributed Transaction Coordinator) which makes it hard to just suck the data up to a data lake. And the implementation allows the deletion of data. This presents a whole other issue I have with our current architecture.

Author: douga.7429
Content: There may be a more pronounced split between OPC and MQTT in terms of response requirements. I heard Walker say that he would not make an SLA that would promise better than 500ms. With OPC, you would expect responses to be less than 50ms. So, OT stuff should be on OPC, but business integration can be much slower. I think the point of debate would be whether or not SCADA can be handled with MQTT and if HMIs should be on OPC.

Is that right? I’d argue with your definition of a data lake in that statement though. A data lake can hold unstructured logs, but it can also hold structured data, images, etc. If your storage is in fact a ledger, or some kind of specialized store for logs, I don’t think data lake is the most apt description.

Our MES system is not scaling, so taking the utilization log out of the MES and just having the MES do WO transactions would allow it to fit our scale. This is the problem that is pushing on the need for a UNS-type architecture.

Content: Yup, which can get “interesting” to manage. Also have to pass callback/return topic name which is spoofable.  It’s all doable though as you say.  But non trivial.  And then you have to deal with buffering and  QoS if requestor and service provider are out of phase. It could be abstracted away (I can see how I might attack that similar to a protocol I wrote a few years ago)  but it just seems like the broker and MQTT get in the middle while adding more cost than benefit. 100% open to be convinced otherwise!

Author: geoffnunan
Content:
"it" is still a very fluid concept for most people.
"focussing on the data" is a way for service providers and solution providers to cut-through a customers lack of strategy.

True Digital Transformation starts with Management Consultants convincing the executive that without transformative change, the company will suffer from more advanced competitors or changes in the market. A project team can then be formed to implement the strategy.

What most people refer to as DX is just a new name for modernisation of applications. If it doesn't change the products or services that the business offers, or the channels to market available to the business, It's not really a digital transformation, It's a digitalization program. (Taking things that were analog and making them digital) 
 Digitalization focuses on Cost reduction where as Digital Transformation focuses on Revenue increase.

Assuming you are looking at Digitalization, any company needs to be able to answer the following questions before speaking with software providers, service providers or external analysts:
 - What is our current level of Digital Maturity across each function in the business.
- What impact does that level of maturity have on that department's performance?
- What are the barriers to improving the digital maturity of that department?

Once those questions are known the executive must prioritise, in order of importance to the business, the specific areas of digital maturity to improve.

With that input, an application architecture assessment can be made that identifies the capabilities that will be required to improve the maturity, and define a set of business requirements for those capabilities.

Then you are ready to talk to vendors and service providers.

You MAY even find that you need a UNS.

Author: geoffnunan
Content:
I think MQTT needs a name change. It's an acronym for Message Queue Telemetry Transport, but is has nothing resembling a queue. In order to be usefull as a reliable way of managing commands between applications, it is missing some important concepts and really needs to he paired with a propper message queue.
Drop the Q, it's just MTT

Author: rickbullotta
Content: Don’t the QoS concepts, topic naming, subscriptions (shared and multicast) seem a lot like a traditional message queue?  And I think the MQ was originally for IBM MQ, their offering.

Author: geoffnunan
Content:
On the surface, yes, but only if you consider it as a queue with only 1 position in it. If your disconnected, and a publisher publishes more than 1 message, you loose data.
Also if a subscriber receives a message and then dies while trying to process that message, it is very difficult to retry. 
All the reliability concerns, particulalry in horizontally scalled, distributed systems, are exposed when using MQTT for transactional exchanges.
MQTT is great for sending telemetry, but undercooked for transactions.

Author: rickbullotta
Content: That and a lack of proper RPC semantics make it not ideal as a universal pipe for data and services. TBH plain old message queues kinda suck for that too.

Author: ianskerrett.
Content: FWIW, MQTT is no longer considered an acronym, likely for the reason you pointed out. MQTT is just the name.

Content:
Yes, Mario!

After connecting about 120 devices to upstream systems over OPC UA, the next step was to visualize that data.

From home in my spare time, I used Ignition Perspective trial (reset every 2 hours) and built out a dynamic dashboard. Every time I added OPC UA subscriptions to the Ignition tag structure, the dashboard would update.

I demo'd this capability and mentioned all that is needed is to add the perspective license to our already existing Ignition node. Everyone agreed and my project was deployed on the Ignition server and a link made available to others.

Then I got tired of managing the tags in Ignition...every time a tag was added on the device, I had to add a subscription within the Ignition tag structure. I wondered why Ignition didn't include a function that would detect when a new OPC UA tag was available and automatically add it to its own structure. Enter SparkplugB.

I converted one device to Sparkplug and trialed the MQTT Engine add-on within Ignition (reset every 2 hours).  Every change of data structures on the device immediately propagated to Ignition. Anytime new equipment was added to the system, Ignition immediately saw this data within it's Tag Browser.

I demo'd this capability, showing automated integration, where "plugging in the network cable" from the plant floor populated the dashboard all automatically. Everyone agreed to purchase the MQTT Engine add-on.

We converted the original 120 devices from OPC UA to SparkplugB, and have integrated an additional 80 without lifting a finger within Ignition.

And if you only have the Ignition trial license they only get to enjoy it for two hours at a time and then THEY have to come to YOU to reset the trial. 😉

Author: mparris
Content:
@jpmoniz we use industrial PCs running custom software that is controlling the production quality process. Changing devices meant updating our software (add OPC UA server, then add Sparkplug client). 

Each PC connects to several lower level devices: barcodes scanners, IO racks, RFID readers, energy monitoring, etc. These are things that would typically be seen on a local monitor connected to each PC available to personnel watching/operating the production process.

Whenever we updated our software to expose more data, or include more devices, we would need to add those new tags in Ignition... FOR EVERY DEVICE! It only took two times of that for us to know we had to move in a different way.

Along with managing the process on the plant floor, we upgraded the software into a Sparkplug edge gateway, exposing ALL DATA of itself and all devices within it's local control.

Because we publish everything, and that data can be read by other applications dynamically with the MQTT wildcard subscriptions, we plan to replace our Ignition dashboard with another instance of our software that will act as a dynamic client. It will allow us to display a single, central Web GUI with a menu of all the available devices across the business (built through auto discovery on Sparkplug, of course). This will then let a user see the application screen exactly as the plant floor is seeing it in real time.  Basically we are converting the dashboard to include "remote desktop" through SparkplugB with no permissions needed for anyone in the business.

Author: petersorowka
Content:
from our experience such a situation would be handled with the following systematic:

- what's your use case (rather experimenting or an actual business use case) (to understand what effort is it worth)
- how many machines of this types do you have or want to connect (to understand how any solution scales)
- what data do you actually need for your usecase (to understand if it's feasible to find alternative acquistion methods)

Only from these questions answered I think a solution can be designed systematically
