Author: binyameen_980
Content: I have heard Walker talk about digital strategy. What this "Digital Strategy" really is and why is it important?

Author: binyameen_980
Content: I have also heard Walker talk about manufacturers becoming a data company if they want to sustain. What are the implications of this "becoming a data company" for a high tech industry like automobile and semiconductor industry, and for a labor intensive industry like garment, agriculture, and mining industry?

Content: How a company fits in this concept whose end product is cutlery, a jeans, or a sports equipment?

Author: binyameen_980

Author: thedavidschultz
Content:
OEMs are a great example. The data produced by their equipment can be consumed by the end user for asset and process health. Same data can be used by OEM for product improvement and service calls. This is non-product based revenue.

Cummins has monitoring equipment on their OTR trucks. Based on engine status and driver destination, it will automatically schedule service for the driver at a convenient location. Cummins Cloud has been a great source of revenue. There are becoming a data company that makes diesel engines.

Author: binyameen_980
Content: Crystal clear.

Author: binyameen_980
Content: But how a company which buys fabric and makes jeans can become a data company in your opinion?

Author: thedavidschultz
Content:
Internally it is based on real-time production data which is integrated into a digital supply chain. Amazon can predict with 85% confidence that a product will be purchased in the next 60 days. External market data and internal quoting activity can be used to drive raw material and production demands.

Externally there needs to be engagement by the consumer. In Australia the original MyMacca's app was used by consumers that can scan a QR code and get information on the origin of the ingredients in their order. It is now the preferred way to order and pay for food. And there are incentives for the customers to use it. A jeans company could do something similar.

Author: joshuastover
Content: Cutlery, for instance, could be knives that gather their own data on, say, the amount of pressure needed to cut through a steak. Once the knife has determined that too much pressure is needed to cut through a steak, or any other object, you can be notified through an app you register your knife in that it's time to sharpen or replace your knife. There are many ways for companies to become data companies.

Author: joshuastover
Content: In the automotive sector, Tesla gathers data on its own cars and the cars on the road around its vehicles. This data is then used to improve their cars, change the insurance rate of the owner of the Tesla, etc.

They take the data from the cameras and do some cool stuff with GIS mapping and AI. They use it to sell information to municipalities , utilities and others to give them feedback on road conditions, high risk areas, utilities damage.  You name it.  While they make the chips and software for things like Nissan co-pilot. They are also extracting video data to the cloud to augment a whole other revenue stream.  That is the definition of a data company.

Content:
Financials still need to be a critical consideration when it comes to any major decision.  There have been many examples of companies that have ignored that, and have either gone out of business because of an unsustainable business model, or have even succeeded in a way that left them insolvent.  That said, I liked Walker's comment that the ideal leader should have both an MBA and an engineering background.

ROIs are still important, the issue is that many MBAs don't know what is possible, and many of those that know what is possible aren't great at building ROIs that MBAs can understand.  As the saying goes: "What we have here is a failure to communicate."  Both parts are equally important.

Content: It’s just another term invented by a vendor to sell more stuff.  Industrial computing is distributed computing and always has been.  There’s compute up and down the network.  Always has been.  It doesn’t need a marketing term.  And it’s not a fixed three level hierarchy.  Even edge compute is a useless term.

Author: petersorowka
Content:
I have a different definition but a similar conclusion 😄 

if you ask me, Edge Computing is the term invented by the Cloud Hyperscalers "as an excuse" to offload processing back to devices you physically operate (and still charge you for that on an as a service basis sometimes). Fog computing I'd rather use as a term (but actually I would never use it) if you have a more standalone type of on-premise deployment using technologies usually seen in the cloud like containers, kubernetes and infrastructure as code paradigms.

In short: "edge computing" always comes with a cloud; "fog computing" not necessarily.

To confuse more: "Edge computing" has unfortunately diluted as a term and is now too often used whenever you have a workload on a device you physically operate locally

Author: ryankershaw
Content: Latency can be a big one depending on the calculation being run and what is using it afterwards.  Ability to continue to run calculations with a loss of network error is another, but when I talk to people, one of the most attractive pieces is cost.  If you can run calculations and analysis at the edge, then your data transmission costs drop significantly.  For instance, on our demo system, we have an OEE calculation that is composed of about a dozen tags.  In a cloud based system all of these tags would need to be sent, probably at a high frequency so that the cloud system can calculate the OEE value.  If this is done at the edge then only the single value can be sent, and if it is an analysis value, how often do you need to send it over?  Once a minute?  Every five?  If the raw parameters needed to be sent on a second-by-second basis, you're going to realize a 99.8% and a 99.97% reduction in data transmission respectively.  This could also be useful in process applications where real-time data could be (depending on the application) be substituted with min/max/mean/median values from the past minute along with local alarms for excursions.  In this scenario, data transmission would be reduced by 93%.  I would love to talk to someone in an accounting department to see what a 90%+ data transmission drop would mean financially.  I'm guessing it would not be insignificant.

Author: ryankershaw
Content: I've always considered "fog" computing to mean something like an HCI or private cloud that's on prem.  That said, I know the technical committee in the SMIIoT division dropped that term, and is now just using cloud and edge.  Seems like it's going out of style.

Author: ryankershaw
Content:
We've got a SIRI/INCIT guy on the Industry Readiness and Maturity Committee TC in SMIIoT.  He's walked us through the process, and it looks really good.  They approach it from a holistic sense, so they're going to look at stuff like "will your middle managers be on board" sort of thing.  The evaluations are done by independent guys, INCIT is just the licensing and training organization, so there is probably going to be some variation from inspector to inspector, but the framework overall is solid.

The IR&M committee is actually looking to put out a framework for these sorts of programs, get it so that they can be compared.  There are not many of these out there, and we figure that if there was a good framework for this sort of program, it would make it easier to get more going, and since these programs do well at showing companies where they will need to focus their efforts, making that sort of offering better will be helpful.  At least that's our thought on it!  If you're looking for other programs, the DTMA program from Intellic is another one that we're looking at.  Honestly, there aren't many other programs out there, at least not many that we could find.

Author: rkwadd
Content:
SIRI - Smart Industry Readiness Index
INCIT - this is an acronym but doesn’t matter what for; it’s the organization producing and governing SIRI
TC - Technical committee (of International Society of Automation or ISA for short)
SMIIoT - Smart Manufacturing and Industrial Internet of Things division (of International Society of Automation or ISA for short)

Author: rkwadd
Content:
VP - Very Person
VIP - Very Important Person
PC - Person Counter
QT - cutie
VC - Very Counter
MIA - missing in action
KP - kitchen patrol

Content:
I feel like edge has become marketing hype for "we need to find more customers to sell hardware to".  Marketers will crank out tons of "do you have an edge compute strategy?" or "are you edge computing right?" type content.

A good example of this is companies like HPE that show up to industrial automation conferences with hardware running OSI Pi, ThingWorx, etc.  They don't even do a great job of showcasing industrial edge use cases.  Other than maybe the ruggedness and that it could be integrated into a broader commercial relationship for hardware and services, it's just plain-old x86 compute.

More thoughts here:
https://discord.com/channels/738470295056416930/738470295056416934/896059779074633748

Author: andreasbackman
Content:
Definitely true that it's over-hyped. I would rather run the edge nodes in a virtualized environment where you more easily can have hardware failover setups (e.g VMWare HA), backups etc etc
Having physical hardware also requires someone to physically go there in case you can't reach the machine remotely (someone unplugged power/network because reasons..)
Not saying that it's entirely ruled out, but these things must be considered too.

Author: IIoT#4707
Content: GG @AndreasBackman, you just advanced to level 1!

Author: ryankershaw
Content:
I don't know if it's over-hyped, though I am horribly biased.  That said, yes edge nodes are definitely just x86 systems for the most part.  Aside from minimum performance requirements, we (Litmus) only really require 2x ethernet cards to certify a system.  As for running edge nodes in a virtualized environment, that is definitely a way to go and we see a few different approaches being used depending on the company.

Physical or digital, I still see this as the "edge strategy", which essentially boils down to how are you going to connect to your devices in the field and how are you going to handle local functionality, i.e. store and forward capability, local analytics, data normalization, etc.  I see the edge nodes as the big difference between IIoT and IoT.  In IoT, data is sent directly to the cloud, things happen there and results are sent back to the device.  In IIoT, the edge node takes much of the decision making and processing and localizes it.  The cloud is still used and is a critical part of the overall ecosystem, but the edge node can run without it if need be.  This does a couple of things, such as reducing latency and increasing reliability, but one of the biggest is the cost reduction that this can provide.  If much of the analytics can be done locally, only the data summary needs to be transmitted rather than the raw data stream.  In cloud applications, this can be a significant reduction.

Author: yasirtuncer
Content:
As a Certified SIRI Assessor (CSA) who conducted around 40 assessments and compared several digital maturity assessments, here are the pros and cons:
Pros:
- SIRI has a holistic approach and frameworks both for assessment matrix (AM) and prioritisation matrix (PM) consider critical aspects like process, technology, organisation for AM with 8 pillars and 16 dimensions. Cost profile, Essential Business Objectives (KPIs) and Global Benchmark as the difference your current maturity vs your industry's highest score for the corresponding dimensions. 
- SIRI is non-invasive usually the field study is completed in 2 days while the production is running. 

Cons:
- As Walker suggested Acatech model has its flaws, the maturity is assessed on 0-5 scale and pragmatic approach like 80% of the band requirement sustained fire-backs while creating a road-map.  
- The framework gives you a map however your assessors' background changes the experience completely. You can go so deep on any dimension like DLP scenarios, Pen test details for connectivity or go so shallow like have you conducted a Pen test in the last 12 months.
- Detailed road-map with use-cases are not in the scope of SIRI assessment, however we provide a 2-year plan starting with training and UNS as the core architecture

It definitely depends on your business needs, DTMA is more down to earth and in my opinion leads to actual transformation where SIRI assessment with an experienced assessor can catch up to DTMA but this is usually the exception not the rule

Author: nickn5549
Content: Definitely usable. It gives you the proper framework to start and as you said if you have experience you can fill the gaps and split the Shopfloor into areas to be able to access more realistically the level of automation, connectivity and intelligence for the different production areas. The same can be done for Enterprise with a bit of creativity and inside business knowledge. I basically butcher it, or improve it... when I've done our self-assessment using SIRI and created an interactive APP to store the results, chart them and save brainstorming or ideas about what we need to do to improve the scoring for each dimension.

Author: ctown_kyle
Content: 5 years in Aerospace. Post-covid the issue was money. No money to do anything, all efforts were focused on cost savings. I ended up leaving and moving to Pharmaceuticals. Pre-covid (and before I discovered this community) I remember a lot of meetings with vendors (Rockwell, Siemens, McKinsey and large integrators) that would pitch the full stack "MES" solutions, high 7 figure projects that would last many years. I was never impressed but it was hard to get leadership to change their mindsets, but I think I could do it knowing what I know now. It just seems like Aerospace execs have all been in Aerospace for decades AKA they have no idea what is possible nowadays and think throwing money at a well-known company means they're digitially transforming. How's that one quote go? "Nobody ever got fired for choosing IBM"?

Author: nickfenlon
Content: As far as I can see, most places (middle and upper management) don't have a clue about any of this stuff! The term "OT" gets funny looks never mind trying to paint a picture of how integration can help. At some point, the "benefits" pitch has to become technical and you loose so many people at that point. If you're in a position of influence in the manufacturing sector, it's your duty to learn this stuff. Get ahead with where your business needs to go.

Author: loganmoline
Content:
One of the biggest obstacles I’ve seen is fear. Particularly the fear associated with being found out. As companies grow from a mom and pop where everyone is involved with everything to larger scale, and eventually multi-site organizations, generalist are replaced with specialist and those specialist make teams. More to the point they build silos. The amount of effort that goes into keeping outsiders from finding out about any mistakes made in a given silo is obscene. Too many people would rather muddle through, not knowing where real improvements could be made, just so no one else knows too. 

I don’t know whether this is the biggest obstacle, but it’s gotta be up there.

I forgot to mention here that I’m in the wine and beverage business.

Author: nickn5549
Content: 25 years in EMS - electronics manufacturing services - 10 years pushing uphill the Digital Transformation, since last year pushing uphill the UNS. After 60+ Apps and 100+ microservices designed, developed, implemented, validated and added to support that give manufacturing a nice, clean, paper-free one pane of glass way of doing business and  I still find non-believers or indifferent enough to not give a shit... Hard to go around them when these individuals are from the decision-making gang - especially IT and C-suits. The good thing though, daily users appreciate it, and external visitors are impressed...the whole thing made it into the factory PowerPoint presentation, somehow. What else can you do to align all the ducks? Or some ducks are just black and swim in a different pond...

Author: mparris

Author: akoscs
Content: A few years of SI, few years of R&D, few years of architecting few years freelancing. Worked with machine tool mfg, automotive, food and beverage, some agro, some chem and some other non-mfg industries. I think the problem is people do not understand each other well enough. We have IT (as in IT infra), SWE developing software, ML experts making models, managers managing, OT experts programming PLCs and robots and domain experts (for the sake of example, lets call them MfgEng but insert any domain expert here). For a successful digital transformation you kind of need all of these, and maybe even more roles) to work together very efficiently. OT and Mfg.Eng are forced to work together since PLCs entered the factory so they kind of know how to talk to each other in an industry 3.0 setting. IT, SWE and ML kind of knows how to work together, but only if they are managed well otherwise it is just a huge fight. If we throw everybody in the mix (even if we leave out ML) in an ind 4.0 setting it is just a huge fight waiting to happen, because nobody knows how to talk to the others due to the cross disciplinary boundaries. (Simple example, if you say “model” everyone will understand something else by this word). Now let me use an analogy I heard from a prominent researcher to get to the point: Imagine a bowl of fruit. Every fruit is clearly delimited. That bowl of fruit is a multidisciplinary project where each fruit is a different discipline, every discipline is clearly delimited. This is how people are used to working together. Now imagine a fruit salad where everything is chopped up. That is an interdisciplinary project. A few companies are used to working like this. The delimitation of disciplines gets fuzzy, but you can still kind of work out the lines. Imagine that you make a juice out of that fruit bowl. That is a transdiciplinary project, the lines between the disciplines are very fluid.

Author: akoscs
Content: My theory is that digitalisation is in most case a transdiciplinary project and the people involved, in many cases, are used to working in a multidiciplinary setting. This would needs a new level of understanding each other and communicating efficiently with each other. Everyone has to know at least a bit of the other disciplines involved so that the they can work in a setting where the lines dividing the disciplines are blurred. This requires time, practice and the willingness to lear something far out ones comfort zone. Even if people would be willing to do this, they rarly get enough time for this. Successful digitalisation projects have people who, for some reason, already (knowingly or unknowingly) can work in an environment where there is no clear line delimiting IT/OT/ML/Mfg and management supports the right people who can work like this.

Author: nickn5549
Content: that's it 🪄  nothing else is needed. From HQ IT, I can smell envy and absurd competition -anything software has to come from them or be recommended by them. Regarding C-Suits, they just don't spend enough time on the shop floor and don't talk to people from the shop floor. They trust more the opinion of another C-suit or other Tip Top Exec from their HQ offices instead of trusting the Engineering Management and Operations from the plant that pays all their salaries and bills.

Author: rehenley
Content: The tech talk and benefits of DT sounds like a sales pitch to most people.  I have learned  the hard way; and only recently, there is a much better approach. It is a subjective approach and it requires different talking points based on your audience but in general it goes like this. Establish commonality / familiarity with group.  Find out the root cause of there main issues - aka find pain points.  Develop a simple but effective proof of concept and make it happen.   Once you have that it builds confidence in your solutions. It may take 2 or 3 iterations of this same process but eventually you get to the point that they start to listen.  You have to move thru some version of that same process with each group. It can be very time consuming and you will start to doubt it’s worth.   But eventually you will make head way.  The other option is to move on and find people who know they have a problem and are actively in search of a solution.  This scenario also requires a lot of the same steps.  You can just get moving in the right direction quicker.  Or you can just wait 3 - 5 years when everyone will be talking about it and frantically searching for solutions, lol.

Author: regius21k
Content: My company just send an RFP for an IoT platform to AWS, Azure, Siemens and some others. The proposals comply with all the technical requirements, but the pricing is very different from each, so we can not make a fair comparison. One vendor charges by module, another by users, another by connected devices, another by the usage of the different modules (dashboards, alerts, etc.).  Since our company is just starting on this we don´t have an specific usecase to be shared with the vendors.  Also, we do not want to start with what looks like the best option (cost wise) to later find out that the pricing increases as we connect all our factories (around 50). Vendors has asked us how many assets are we going to connect (with its sensors and variables), and even how often are we going to be sending from each point, and how much procesing power we need, but since we are just starting this journey, we don´t have that information.  What would be the best way to get this right from start?  Should we propose an imaginary usecase? Should we let the vendors get into one of our facilities and check out the equipment we have and let them make suggestions? (but in this case, probably each vendor will propose something different and will be the same issue?  Any Ideas?

Author: mattmigchelbrink
Content: Great questions Regius, I'm interested in what replies you get. I'm not going to outline a lot of answers, but throw some more factors you might want to put into the equation From a 10,000 ft view your company needs a digital strategy, but it sounds like you are focused on a pilot project to "prove" your digital strategy. This isn't uncommon, and most everyone has similar pressures. Make sure you realize a good pilot (immediate short-term returns on paper anyways) can incorporate a shitty strategy. As an end-user: More important than the software chosen, is the integrator/consultant/people you work with and their skillset/values. prove me wrong meme These are separate items. You should have unique requirements for each. There's a pretty ridiculous conflict of interest if an integrator can only recommend one solution. If you only have a hammer... Before jumping into bed with a giant waterfall type proposal, I'd highly recommend explore possibilities of some agile-type based proposals. Take the car out for a test drive. You'll get a better understanding of skillsets/values when you get into the muck and past the templated powerpoint introductions.

Author: regius21k
Content: The idea that we have right now is to select a piece of equipment from one facility, lets say equipment 1 with 5 sensors (temperature, vibration, etc.), and have all the vendors connect to the equipment and show us what they can do and their pricing for that specific test. I agree with the test drive approach.

Author: nickfenlon
Content:
Would say IT/OT convergence is very much people-centric: empower the OT folks a bit more (or even create those positions in the first place). Educate the IT folks about the world of OT.
On the other hand, IIoT is more a technology thing: if you're picking a new device for the factory floor, consider network connectivity, does it present a data interface, etc.

Author: zeratall
Content: I would argue it's all a "cultural thing". In a lot of ways, the technology already exists today to drastically mature digitally (I refuse to use the term transform lol), but due to things like steering comittes, biases in the decision makers, the cultural willingness/eagerness to mature digitally, and where a company is currently on a maturity scale can drastically impact the effectivness of any effort. One book I highly recommend is The Technology Fallacy: How People Are the Real Key to Digital Transformation (Management on the Cutting Edge) https://a.co/d/gWuY7Xt regarding the cultural element of DT.

Author: joshuastover
Content: **Question of the Day** Have you ever dealt with a **CAVE** person when working on a project? (*Citizen Against Virtually Everything.*) How did oyu handle that person? What techniques do you use to overcome their barriers or inaction?

Author: hutcheb
Content: I find a lot of the time that people with this view haven't been given enough responsibility, and have difficulty seeing that there is a need to change. One approach to deal with that view is to give them something meaningful and interesting to work on.

Author: niravpatel16
Content: There is one or more of this type of person everywhere. There are lots of obstacles and challenges to working your way through. The way I dealt is Think Big for your digital transformation platform, execute small, show results, and scale. Start with PoC or Pilot for your first use case. Afterward, the rest is up to you to showcase. You will hear a lot of "We have always done this way" this is when you say that is why we are behind in transforming successfully. Our competitors are getting ahead in the game. Tell them that digital transformation is no more the future but the presence and you're too late to catch up.

Author: loganmoline
Content: This describes one of my co-workers (a Millwright) to a T. He is tremendously knowledgeable, but so cantankerous that his ideas are rarely well received from higher ups. It's so bad that when I suggested he try the Costanza method of "just say the opposite of what you're thinking" they actually did what he intended. Even still he didn't see the light. Nevertheless, hear is what I do with him and it works pretty well. Step one. Listen to them. No one is going to listen to you when you don't listen to them. Step two. Reflect and diminish. This is not a fast approach, but if you actually work with someone like this then you know that truth bombs will only alienate you. What's more alienating someone like this is 100% guaranteed to get them to shit on all your ideas and denigrate you to anyone who will listen (behind your back of course). A person like this NEEDS to be able to complain. Nothing is going to change that. If you can take what they are saying and bring it back into the vicinity of the real world. Step three. Solve problems that are not possible for them to solve with the tools at their disposal.

Author: loganmoline
Content: I guess if it were a shorter term project you might have to resort to truth bombing, otherwise you might risk the viability of the project.

Author: nickfenlon
Content:
Cool. Sold! Already in my Amazon basket.
Yeah... Everything is people!

Author: joshuastover
Content: Great take. So many get stuck trying to debate to get people to change, but no one can deny results. This is why winning the results war matters.

Author: karltbraun
Content: There are probably several types of people that fall into this category; but two that come to mind:  (1) Like Josh says, people who haven't been exposed to the necessity of seeing different points of view - they've not been given the responsibility or had an urgent need to do that, and (2) left-brain operators who see things as only black-and-white (see Iain McGilchrist - https://youtu.be/686heq5QFPk) and can't get moved off their position no matter what.  For those in the latter category, if they are in a position of decision making for your project, run away very fast.

Author: mattmigchelbrink
Content:
Don't forget the elusive 3rd species. 

[noun] The Pournelleḉ CAVE people <wərTHləs bjʊəɹəkɹæt> are those dedicated to the organization, not the goals of the organization. They are vested in proving their worthless worth and communicate solely through a dialect of Carnegie descent.

Author: du5tins
Content: There are a lot of CAVE people in the industry vertical I am in. Sometimes we have to build things the way they want and build it the way it should be in parallel to prove the results. Sometimes we find a different project champion to work with. Sometimes we build tons of relationships and communicate with all the staff around the CAVE person to progress things. The strategy for dealing with them depends on if they are critical to the path of the project or if they are approving our invoices. Results matter. Execution matters. If we cannot do our work because someone is holding us back we have to be candid about it and constructive about how we work through them or around them.

Author: jon.forbord
Content: «Every organization needs to understand its “digital DNA” in order to stop “doing digital” and start “being digital»». Really liked this quote, as it speaks to the necessity of the digital mindset! Sidenote: I find the phrase “people, process and technology” to be one of the most obnoxious empty repeated phrases in industry 4.0 context..

Author: zeratall
Content: That is such a good quote! I completely agree, I think that is why I really hate the term "Digital Transformation" Transformation assumes an endpoint. If we are really to adopt a digital mindset, its more of a continuum centered on how can technology facilitate the current needs of the business, but also the future needs of the business that aren't even visible because of where a business is digitally.  Aka as a business matures digitally, they will get new ideas of doing business that they would have never thought of before.

Author: zeratall
Content: Another book I highly recommend talks to this point: https://www.amazon.com/Winning-Right-Game-Changing-Management-ebook/dp/B08MQ4DCYN/ref=sr_1_1?crid=3HWFNVHZG2S8V&keywords=winning+the+right+game&qid=1667426975&qu=eyJxc2MiOiIwLjkxIiwicXNhIjoiMC44MyIsInFzcCI6IjEuMDUifQ%3D%3D&sprefix=winning+the+right+game%2Caps%2C128&sr=8-1

Author: zeratall
Content: In the book it talks about lose couplings of technology and how users interact with technology changes as technology changes, and gives some points on how we can be introspective to understand if we are "winning the right game". One of the analogies in the book talks to Kodak during the Digital Era, Kodak had in its own right a very successful digital transformation from Analog to Digital Photography. They're main focus was to enable customers to now print photos in their home, they developed digital cameras, digital media to save photos to, and digital photo printers consumers could have in their home to print their own photos, vs having to go to the store to get film developed (analog).....In it's own right it was a successful transformation and they had some best in class solutions, but the company ultimately failed........Why? Well because they didn't account for how users might consume and share photos. Instead of printing them in house and sharing with friends, now users with the invention of Instagram and other social media, share photos directly online and don't necessarily need to print photos. I think this also applies to DT for industry, we need to be mindful and introspective of why we are transforming, and not just transforming to be transforming.

Author: joshuastover
Content: Kodak also did not see through their Digital Transformation. They invented the digital camera but they did not think it would take off and opted to not focus on developing digital camera technology to market and aloud their competitors to out compete them early on in that market. Now every time I see a professional photographer they are using Canon or Nikon.

Author: loganmoline
Content: Good question. I work on the floor (in maintenance) in the wine ( and cider/beverage)business. I think one of the biggest hurdles we have faced is getting connected. Most wineries start out as a mom and pop and then expand. I think there have been 5 separate major expansions in this facility in the past 35 years, many of which were either not documented (by which I mean there are no prints anywhere) or the documentation is out of date. Just creating a clear picture of how electricity moves through the facility has been an arduous process. Then add in plant water, hot water, steam, hot water for various processes, compressed air, co2, nitrogen, chilled water for processes, chilled glycol, and on and on. It's taken me about 5 years to get to about the 90-95% mark on how everything gets where it's going and how it's controlled. This is all between calls and other projects. Every project (done by a project manager)to date has been a standalone solution to a particular problem. We also don't have any of the right kind of engineers. In fact we never have. The one we have now is the best yet (mechanical) but just like the last engineer, he just works on projects. The last engineer was geotechnical, and I like to joke that the one before him was a custodial engineer. The five years I spent figuring out the plant were also the first five years after we were bought out, so all the execs from that period have gotten their golden parachutes and moved on. We now have a great new group who actually wants to make improvements. I should note that both engineers are great people and easy to work with, just limited in what they know (with respect to controls).

Author: ryankershaw
Content: Sounds like you guys got bought out recently, which lines up with what you have described.  I've seen this at wineries and breweries before, especially the smaller ones.  The heads of these places are essentially artisans, so they feel like with anything they produce, the quality is going to come down to that person.  In certain situations, it definitely will, like a new type of beer or wine, but for repetitive applications, like larger scale applications, automation is going to provide better consistency each and every time.  Unfortunately, with the artisan approach, there is a feeling that replacing the person with automation will reduce the importance of the person running the operation, when in fact, they can still be there to develop new product, but use automation to improve quality and consistency.  A newer company coming in, especially one that is more corporate focused, will be more disconnected from the process, allowing them to introduce automation and controls without seeing it as turning their baby into a Borg.

Author: rickbullotta
Content: Very different solutions.  Tulip is more "platform" and has deeper technology in areas like AI, machine vision, highly configurable user experiences, hybrid edge/cloud execution, and so on, plus a lot of templates for application use cases.  Redzone seems more "enterprisey" and traditional MES/work instruction stuff to me.  They also offer some interesting professional services around workforce training/empowerment.

Author: thunt.career
Content:
We (end user CPG) have RedZone rolled out to multiple manufacturing sites. 
Positive:
- Increased communications between operators, maintenance and manufacturing engineers. We do not allow phones on the floor. Having the iPad's ability to capture pictures of issues and share it with others is a great improvement in capturing them as they happen.
- Operator training and work instruction modules are better organized and standardized
- Operators increased engagement with quality and performance data
Negative:
- Reduced granularity of downtime reasons. We had a solution that automated reasons based on PLC tags. Now everything is operator input and not always correct especially for compounding issues.
- Distrust in data due to operator input. ("The lbs produced is not accurate because operator does not select product/run correctly") 
- Not real time data. (8 hour production shift reporting 0 lbs/hr until 8th hour when 100,000 lbs were produced for example)
- Does not integrate well with any solutions. It collects its data for its purpose and isn't great to connect in to use the data.
- Enterprise view of data is not available. Each site is its own data source and is difficult to pull. They are working on building this.

Author: jon.forbord
Content: I know one thing for sure about the term digital transformation. Implementing cloud ERP is NOT digital transformation. EVEN if they include the notorious Schmeeple, Schmrossess and Schmechnology. It's JUST one solution in an ecosystem of solutions in a digital transformation. Digital transformation is about leveraging digital technology to fundamentally change how you operate your business. Almost 0 legacy organizations are truly capable of doing it. At best they manage a Digital «gradual-adjustment-over-a-10-to-20-year-period».

Author: urukhai69420
Content:
I'm a large scale process chemist in the specialty chemicals space. I write and manage over 120 chemical processes run on the shop floor, as well as am responsible for their safety, optimization, yield, quality control and approval, equipment transfers etc. Basically I do everything except for the transactional side of sales and purchasing, the physical synthesis on the floor, and testing the material in the lab.

The company I work for is a legacy company and has been making many of these chemicals for 25-50 years. Their largest hurdle is the belief that "Adding more systems controls just get in the way, and you will never be able to collect enough data to account for all of the variables involved in manufacturing to draw statistically significant conclusions using a computer because a computer can't account for the operator working the job that day". 

This comes from a team of multiple Lean six sigma black belts and green belts... They might see the idea of a unified namespace as a "good idea" but believe that it is impossible to account for all of the variables involved in manufacturing even a single run... mind you these people also can't figure out why their computer won't work when they have 14 updates pending...

They also say that "you could gather all of that data but you won't have any data as a baseline so it would be useless for the next 3 (or as many as 30 years in some cases for processes that run once every 2-3 years) until you have enough data points to determine where the process normally runs with any reasonable confidence.

Author: rehenley
Content: Has anyone done research into the 2-wire Ethernet solutions and their implementation in the sensors/instrumentation arena?  Using SPE and Ethernet-APL?  I have heard E&H is working on solutions.  I have used E&H's ethernet/IP flow meters and they are wonderful.  They allow for massive increases in the customization of instrument operations/interaction.  If we could get entire classes of sensors and instruments to run off 2-wire Ethernet and interact with those devices via Ethernet/IP it would completely change the way a controls engineer can control and monitor processes.  I would like to hear if anyone else is tracking this and get links to information related to it.  I have an opportunity to set up a greenfield manufacturing facility and would like to take advantage of this tech as much as possible in the buildout: scheduled to start mid-2023.

Author: bright_hummingbird_31342
Content:
I have not really seen it take off personally, but it's super interesting.  It will be useful for the process industry with it's ability to carry power.  A lot of serial fieldbuses have stuck around for this reason.  By bringing Ethernet deeper into the field layer, it's not just bringing protocols TCP/IP and UDP/IP.  Firms like E+H envision using SPE for long-distance IO-Link implementations.

I've been curious about these decentralized concepts like Ethernet-APL and field power supllies (e.g., PULS FIEPOS).

Author: joshuastover
Content: **Question of the Day:** What are you thoughts on the term Industry 4.0? Why are people confused/hate the term? Why has Industry 4.0 become a spot for great contention?

Author: atechmu
Content: I think for most leadership it's become a buzz word that's not readily understood. Every manager I've spoke with doesn't think at the technical level. Which makes explaining concepts and benefits very difficult. They value proposition is much harder to convey, compared to new machines that cost this much, generates this value, and has a payback in this many years.

Author: seamoss
Content:
IMO 4.0 is a loaded term and draws arbitrary lines that (arguably) can hamper discussion. Two primary downsides and one upside, firstly there’s a lot of negative sentiment attached to the techbro numbered naming scheme mostly from the crypto community’s adoption of “web 3.0” a lot of people who hear industry 4.0 for the first time tangentially associate the terminology with techbro culture. 

Secondly, the majority of concepts in industry 4.0 are extremely applicable to consumer IoT devices which is the field I’m in. The industry has constructed this arbitrary “wall” between industrial and consumer IoT devices and this wall does more harm than good in a lot of cases. Things that are considered industry standard in industry 4.0 I’ve never even heard of in the devices world but we really need to adopt (things like basic MBSE practices). 

Finally, the good part about industry 4.0 term, we need a word that classifies industrial application of smart devices and IoT engineering separate from consumer applications and other subsets. The messiness of language will always cause problems, lines are never clear cut on anything. I get _why_ the term is used but my only concern is it going the way of something like “web 3.0” where it falls down the buzzword valley so badly the term becomes unusable in describing anything meaningful.

Caveat: I could be completely wrong on all of this. I come from a devices background and not an industry 4.0 background so this is my current understanding of industry 4.0 and how I feel about it as an outsider looking in.

Author: zeratall

Author: rickbullotta
Content:
"I'm sorry, but my knowledge is limited to what was known as of 2021, and I am not able to browse the internet for updated information."

Yikes.

Author: zeratall
Content:
Hahaha I problly don't want to even ask this questions, but I'll go ahead and bite, why do you think that that is a "yikes", that's how all language models work, they are trained on a fixed data set (typically a very large one), and to my knowledge none currently out there publicly avaliable have the ability to retrain themselves real time as the ability to evaluate it's effectiveness and update it's training set would require an additional and totally seperate type of model to aid the language model.

The point of a language models isn't to provide correctness, they are trained to provide text responses that can put context together to generate a response thst looks similar to a human aka a fancy text generator. The fact that people are able to in some cases generate code with it speaks to how well it can contextualize this information, and how mind blowing the technology is getting, but language model at the end of the day are not capable of "technical thinking", you can test this by asking it to provide you a list of books on xyz, most of the time it'll produce a list of books that don't exist lol. The main use case for a language model is language based hence the name aka in my current work flow when I'm writing a paper I might capture the main idea but not like the wording or Grammar. You  can provide thst text to ChatGPT and tell it to clean it up for you, it'll keep the main points you give it in your write up but in a lot of times it'll make the flow of the writeup better. These are what these type of models are designed for

Author: seamoss
Content:
Think of it like a mirror that reflects your own thoughts back to you and distorts them. The construction of the mirror (training set) distorts the reflection (output) of your own thoughts (prompt).

It's more complex than a grammatical tool, but it is not capable of understanding meaning in any capacity.

You should use this as a tool to better articulate the thoughts of areas you already know. It's not an education tool.

Author: seamoss
Content: The more information your prompt contains, the more it has to work with. Any _additional_ information chatgpt adds outside of the prompt is not useful since it is likely wrong. This is why detailed prompt crafting is so important and harder than people think

Author: seamoss
Content: So yes, it is presentation over substance but that's kind of the point

Author: seamoss
Content: I'll be a little spicy here and go so far as to say a complete rejection of a tool as "bad" and disregarding it entirely makes for a poor engineer. It's literally our job to have a deep understanding into one field and a wide breadth of awareness on others. You might not need it now, but maybe someday you will. So just be aware of what it can and can't do then file it into your mental toolbox

Author: autopsias
Content:
*** Sorry a bit of a long one ***

Would love to get the community’s views on a frequently forgotten theme.

User experience of the solutions we are creating in our digital transformations.

2 areas which are interesting to me and I think deserve reflection:

1 - one of the keys for unlocking digital transformation (within the famous 3 areas of failure, Strategy, partners and technology) is how easy our solutions are, to be used by the end user. This seems trivial but it’s far from it. We are trying to create the “mobile phone” of the enterprise where the worker of the future can access all the data and solve its own problems. But we forget one little detail. No one ever needed training to be able to use his/her mobile phone!
Without proper care in terms of User Experience it’s likely that your change management will very quickly become hell, and all the value we would be getting rapidly evaporates. Nobody uses whatever solution you’re developing and if they are obliged to, they will hate your guts and sabotage it right left and centre. 

This serves to illustrate that UX is a key element in any Digital Transformation.

Author: autopsias
Content:
2- Having the above cleared out, in other words, its importance, I would like to think about how we go about this typically.
Typically we (the client)  put in our SOWs that we want the solution “User friendly”. No kpi’s , nothing, just hiding on its subjectivity.
What usually happens? Less than ideal UX is created because no meaningful resources are put to it, since you cannot really measure it and evaluate it properly. This way of managing it also denotes a lack of importance, to whatever integrator you’re using.

What do I usually do?

I like to insert in my SOWs some clear kpis to evaluate UX. Are they perfect? Hell no, but are better than nothing!

Author: autopsias
Content:
Here is a bit of a generic micro sample:

- define about 10-20 main tasks for your solution that your target users will need to fulfill.

- from the above select the top 3-5 and the bottom 2. These are the tasks to be tested. Bear with me…

- those selected tasks to be tested above, you will request and plan to execute usability testing on them and the metrics you will want to achieve are roughly:

Author: autopsias
Content:
- successful execution of tasks with a minimum success rate of 80%, yeap that’s what you need as minimum.
- why the top 3-5 and the bottom 2? Because you want to make sure that even the bottom 2 can be found and executed even though they are not as important. That will make the whole solution a lot more robust and free from “expert user syndrome” vis a vis training.

What you obviously want to do as well is make sure your project allows for usability testing during some project sprints rather than only at the end.

This way by inserting simple but measurable kpis on your SOWs you can bring focus and some control to UX which is normally very lacking, and indirectly fixing some important aspects of change management which in my experience are also one of the big reasons for digital transformation to fail.

Would love to hear your thoughts on this subject!!




Disclaimer: in college I specialised in Cognitive Ergonomics and my first career path was indeed UX. So I’m a bit more sensitive to this subject than the regular joe.

Author: douga.7429
Content:
In my journey in an organization advocating for DT, this is my current perspective.  I have seen expensive, poor outcomes and heard many a tail of woes from outside our organization of foolish approaches we repeated. 

Data is like gold in empowering people in their daily efforts.  If Digital Transformation becomes a battle for who hoards the gold, a battle will break out.  It will be like pirate captains fighting on the decks of each other's ships. And I strongly agree that users will come up with designs for themselves, so it is best to let them keep their gold.  The key is to give them a suitable space/architecture to build a good solution.  Eventually, unlike gold, the data can be copied but is only valuable if it is of good quality. They are terrified that you will steal their ability to have insight, correct their issues, and write your narrative for them based on the data they create. The key is to let these fears and desires motivate them to build the solution and be accountable for the data quality.

Digital Transformation efforts often fail because middle managers are responsible for the detailed design of business processes. Often they go behind closed doors and focus on centrally managing things to a plan.  Once all events must fit into a schema of a defined plan, no unplanned activities can be adequately reported.  Alternatively, plans and activities need to be sourced separately and pivoted into a comparison of planned vs. actual activities. Ignoring the wisdom, time, and attention of the people doing the work leads to failure, and the effort is scuttled by users who were not labeled for their experience.  The Toyota model is the best argument against central management, an ERP-first approach that gets socialized and fails. This prevalent DT failure happens because it is so easily socialized in middle management to align with finance, focus on planning activities, and make an imaginary world where they solve all the problems.

Author: douga.7429
Content:
Kimball Star Schema can provide an almost magical experience for users. The product's value is clear by allowing access to data and KPIs across relevant dimensions. This idea of avoiding monolithic solutions and using decoupled smaller solutions can reduce the cost of digitally threading between domains and building reports on and between them. Visualizations can be built on data warehouses or other nodes, such as graphing databases. These can sit on top of event-sourced history, real-time state, and edge data from IIoT.  But, if you are tempted to take their data insights and spend their data capital, they will revolt.  As companies digitally mature, the role of building these products shifts toward the business domains vs. IT.

For example, the assets and items are named the same across the activities in MES, CMS, LIMS, WMS, and EPR. Users can quickly relate to these domains and gain insight without having to coordinate communications and systems integrations between groups.  So KPIs like  OEE can be compared to delivered-on-time-in-full.  Allowing focusing on higher-level concerns like JIT delivery vs. domain objectives and assessing how planned vs. actual activities impact results.  When attributes are applied in tools like power BI these KPIs can be sliced instantly by product attributes like Size, Brands Family, and Date periods hierarchies month, day, year, and quarter. 

One obstacle that also needs to be overcome is how to empower users to make corrections to data that can be audited and traceable.  This is not only needed due to tracking accountability but changed events point us toward what needs to be improved with the system. If they can't do this, they will export to a spreadsheet to edit the data as needed.  All systems have exceptions, and demanding perfection and not providing a way to handle the exceptions is a recipe for failure.  This is often ignored because accommodating this is often more challenging to implement than the base solution.

Author: douga.7429
Content:
I am helping architect a framework to support a Digital Transformation initiative.  This framework is IIoT based with a central hub, an MQTT-based message broker.  I have spent a lot of time making star schema-based data warehouses with memory models that use MS Tabular over the years.  My assumption is that these start schema solutions will likely be made by domain in a Data Mesh approach by business domain.  A peer suggested that graphing databases are needed and not data warehousing.  Can you elaborate on how they relate to each other and what solution would lead to more efficient analytical results?  Also, list the pros and cons of each approach. And keep in mind this is for supporting manufacturing production operations, and MES, LIMS CMS, AND ERP are the predominant sources.

-------------Ai Response--------------

Data warehouses and graph databases are two different approaches to data management and analysis. A data warehouse is a centralized repository that stores data from multiple sources, usually in a star schema format, which makes it easy to query and analyze. This type of database is ideal for OLAP tasks, such as generating reports and performing analytics on a large set of data.

A graph database, on the other hand, stores data in the form of nodes and relationships. This makes it easier to represent complex data sets with many interrelated relationships, such as social networks. This type of database is ideal for OLTP tasks such as transaction processing, as it allows for rapid traversal of the data to find the shortest path between two nodes.

Author: douga.7429
Content:
In the context of your Digital Transformation initiative, both data warehouses and graph databases could be useful. A data warehouse could be used to store and analyze the data from MES, LIMS, CMS, and ERP systems, while a graph database could be used to represent more complex relationships between components of the system.

To decide which approach will lead to more efficient analytical results, it depends on the specific requirements of the system and the types of queries you need to perform. If you are mostly interested in analytics and reporting, then a data warehouse could be the better approach. If you need to traverse the data quickly to find relationships between nodes, then a graph database could be the better approach.

Pros of a Data Warehouse:
- Good for analytics and reporting
- Easily queryable
- Centralized repository for data

Cons of a Data Warehouse:
- Not ideal for complex relationships
- Bulkier than a graph database

Pros of a Graph Database:
- Good for traversing complex relationships
- Faster than a data warehouse
- Easier to represent complex data sets

Cons of a Graph Database:
- Not ideal for analytics and reporting
- Not as easily queryable as a data warehouse

Author: geoffnunan
Content:
I like the event-sourcing pattern, but like every pattern, it's not a silver bullet that should be used everywhere.
We use event sourcing in our Warehouse Management module. Effectively there is a ledger of inventory transactions that is append-only, and is the source of all queries and reports for stock-on-hand.
The beauty of the approach is that it makes point-in-time queries really easy, like 'how much stock did I have last Tuesday?'
You do need the right database for it though. We actually store the events as a time-series in InfluxDB to make them easy to roll up.

Author: rickbullotta
Content:
It sure did "throw it off".  LOL.  That thing is so full of sh*t.

Question: Does a start schema make sense for iot applications?

Response: A start schema can be useful in IoT (Internet of Things) applications as a way to define the structure and relationships of the data that is being transmitted between devices in the IoT system. A start schema is a formal way to describe the data that is being exchanged and can help ensure that the data is organized and consistent across different devices and systems.

Using a start schema can help to improve the interoperability and reliability of an IoT system by providing a clear, standardized way for devices to communicate with each other. It can also help with data management and analysis, as it allows data to be easily organized and queried.

There are several different types of start schemas that can be used in IoT applications, including JSON-LD, RDF, and XML. The specific start schema that is best for a particular IoT application will depend on the specific needs and requirements of the system.

Is the Wonderware System Platform a good architecture for a Digital Transformation strategy to use?

Yes, the Wonderware System Platform can be a great architecture for Digital Transformation strategy. Author: douga.7429
Content:
What is a DataHub for Manufacturing and why would I use one?

A DataHub for Manufacturing is a central platform for collecting, managing and sharing data across an entire manufacturing enterprise. This platform allows for the integration of disparate systems and technologies to create an enterprise-wide data hub that allows for the exchange of data between different stakeholders within the organization. DataHubs for Manufacturing can help increase operational efficiency, reduce costs, and improve the overall performance of the manufacturing business. By having a centralized data hub, manufacturers can quickly and accurately access data to make informed decisions, gain insights into production processes, and identify trends in the market.

Author: rickbullotta
Content:
You're not going to convince me... here's another gem from the bullshit machine.  It sounds reasonable and feasible.  But there's generally no such thing.  It basically paraphrased the use of a data hub for *fisheries* and misappropriated it.  

Question: What is a data hub for fishing boats and why would I use one?

Response: A data hub for fishing boats is a system that allows fishing boats to share and access data related to their operations. This can include information about the location and movements of the boats, as well as details about the catch being made, the types of fish being caught, and the conditions of the fishing grounds. Data hubs for fishing boats can be used by individual fishermen, fishing fleet operators, and other stakeholders in the fishing industry, such as regulators, researchers, and buyers of fish.

There are several potential benefits to using a data hub for fishing boats:

Improved efficiency: By having access to real-time data about the location and movements of fishing boats, fleet operators can make more informed decisions about where to send their boats and how to optimize their fishing operations.

Enhanced safety: Data hubs can help to improve safety by providing fishermen with access to real-time weather and ocean conditions, as well as allowing them to communicate with other boats and shore-based personnel.

Enhanced sustainability: Data hubs can help to support sustainable fishing practices by providing information about the health of fish populations and the impacts of fishing on the marine environment. This can help fishermen to make more sustainable decisions about where and how to fish.

Increased transparency: Data hubs can help to increase transparency in the fishing industry by providing a clear record of fishing activity and catch data, which can be used to monitor compliance with regulations and support traceability of seafood products.

Author: andersgustav
Content:
There have been several ways of sharing information between vessels in fisheries for many years. One of the early ones was Olex, a navigation chart system that stored bottom data and the occurrence of fish from sonar and trawl hauls in such a way that it could be shared with other ships in the fishing company's fleet or partners.

This data has been handled and shared between vessels via a hub run by the shipping companies.

The authorities have now decided that catches must be reported electronically, and that all commercial fishing vessels must use a Vessel Monitoring System (VMS) together with an Electronic Reporting System (ERS). Several suppliers have taken advantage of this, and for example http://www.apollolofoten.no (sorry, the site is only in Norwegian) has developed services and modules that largely cover the functions that the stupid AI has listed in your example.

*The fact that they are unfortunately not (yet) compatible with UNS is another matter, but you are well on your way with domains and things. So now you have the opportunity. The market is there (it is even required by the fisheries authorities)* 🙂

Author: sachin_k22
Content: I recently came across a report 'IoT Signals - Manufacturing Spotlight' jointly published by MS, Intel and IoT Analytics. While, the premise is about digital transformation, it talks completely about Smart Factory as a sort of 'silver bullet' as the solution to digital transformation. Though I don't intend to belittel the views published, there seem to be quite a few contradictions e.g. the authors say that to suceed manufacturers need to be more agile, resilient and sustainable, but the survey results published give a higher priority to OEE as a KPI than to increased supply chain resiliency. This is inspite of 75% of respondents being from NA and EU that were the most affected by the pandemic induced SC challenges. It would be interesting to understand from this ocmmunity, what in their opinion are the top 10 KPI's when it comes to digital transformation. P.S - I am fully aware the OEE is an operational KPI and that digital transformation happens across the entire value chain of the business not just the plant floor.

Author: joshuastover
Content: **Question of the Day:** Since it's the beginning of the year... If today you were given full ability to start digitally transforming your organization, where would you start? What would you do?

Author: seamoss
Content: First we’d have to start decoupling systems from each other. The most success we’ve had with digital transformation was sectioning off product areas and creating referential interfaces between the areas we plan on refactoring then building against those references. Digital twins help a _ton_ here. Think of it like remodeling a house, we’ll do a room at a time instead of burning the house to the ground haha

Author: hobbes1069
Content: Pulling all the data from all the "smart" things on the shop floor and integrating "dumb" things to get what data I can and storing it in a historian and/or data lake. Having a good baseline will make it trivial to measure improvement. That's where I'm struggling right now. Trying to measure the improvement of my projects. The noise in the signal is greater than the measurable improvement.

Author: dan2ther
Content: First answering one of these. Ironically enough, I'm currently working this out for our little chemical mixing shop. We are running an old Microsoft Access monolith and I've been taking an inventory of not just digital assets but physically ones on the product floor to get an understanding of what data parameters we need to be gathering for each process throughout the organization. Once we have it all consolidated and inventoried we will be migrating to a more robust and open ERP system that can handle UNS integration with open IIoT protocols. With any luck we'll get there without breaking the bank because I'm a HUGE advocate for Open source software and architect 🖤🐧🤍.

Author: jeff.rankinen
Content: At Penn College where I teach, I would start with the 4.0 Solutions Digital Transformation Maturity Assessment (DTMA) modified for use at a technical college.  The digital strategy would likely be something like - "Use real-time learning data to customize content and delivery to increase learning efficiency". Then I would identify Proof of Concept (POC) projects that can be performed in four weeks or less. I would develop an MES-style learning management system to manage each POC and to provide students and teachers with a real-time learning dashboard.

Author: sherylmccrary
Content: Great podcast, thanks. So in Walker Reynolds terms: digitization = connect-collect, digitilisation = contextualize-visualize. (I've learned a great deal being a lurker is some places.)

Author: katyot
Content: I agree with a lot of the responses I have read here in regards to user experience, but I feel one key component wasn't addressed that I think is critical: **User** Experience. I see digital solutions most often created for groups of users reduced down to a single "user", but what I have learned over time is that every individual user has a non-shared experience. How can a user customize his or her own experience to use the data as information to make decisions? If I as a user can both easily create and edit my experience in real time as my needs change, I own the quality of my experience.

Author: IIoT#4707
Content: GG @Katy O-T, you just advanced to level 1!

Author: jpmoniz
Content: I think DT in my view needs to be better defined. Connecting things and moving data is not it. It part of the evolution but not the end goal. To me it’s more about eliminating waste in business processes and business operations.  To me true transformation is still a long way off. Too much competition in the software industry for competing OEMs to provide true solutions that support a goal of allowing industry to optimize business processes in an truly integrated fashion. May be off my rocker on this but the next 10 years are going to be very interesting from a software point of view.

Author: brianpribe
Content: Definitely agree with u and @Katy O-T. The most important aspect IMO is the master data model. For users to customize their own experience, there needs to be a well documented and organized structure for users to intuitively “connect the dots”. Graphical programming tools (node-red, graphana), will become more prevalent for users to create their own experience, but without a solid MDM for users to plug-in, the data won’t integrate with the rest of your system.

Author: jmckeon
Content:
Starting from the bottom up, we audit the target asset and apply technology to ensure that data can be extracted from it ...in otherwords we digitise as in the act of digitisation....

Digitalisation is in simple form convert of paper based into the ecosystem...

Cultural digital transformation is the combination of these two with people to provide a digital transformation heading and the elements for the business to operate digitally

Author: brianpribe
Content: This is why in the front-end space GraphQL has become popular, because once the data structure has been discussed and settled between the front-end and the back-end, they then go off on their own

Author: jpmoniz
Content: Yes but think of the complexity of a simple concept of user/identity data and management. If we are truly transformed. Then I only manage and admin in one location and all apps would look there to get an answer. Sounds simple. Now overlay reality, very different story. Still going to be a while before we really get there. That was one simple concept. Add in all of the other pertinent concepts relative to an industry and you start to see how true transformation is a fair bit off for most.

Author: brianpribe
Content: Oh it takes a long time for a company to digitally transform. The concepts are immensely complex especially starting off. That’s why there are so many failed DT projects.

Author: brianpribe
Content: You won’t get true company-wide adoption until it becomes subjectively easier than any alternatives

Author: jpmoniz
Content: Yes. And I am suggesting we are only scratching the surface in the thought of what can be.

Author: brianpribe
Content: 2023 is going to be even more groundbreaking with the software to come. The name of the game now is who can successfully implement a multi-site digital company

Author: jpmoniz
Content: I’m thinking a bit differently than that. Ask yourself this. Why do you design control panels in a cad package and what is the resulting output of that process?  Is there a more efficient process.  Is there a better output that can be universally provided?  True transformation should impact everyone and every process. To me the goal needs to be focused on the elimination of waste regardless of boundaries.

Author: brianpribe
Content: Letting team leads design HMIs for example?

Author: jpmoniz
Content: Not sure what you mean by that. What I am thinking is the following. We only use Ecad to generate schematics and provide users 2D representation to build/diagnose. The output of those packages are generally proprietary outputs.  What if you could do the same but the output was a universally recognized data format? Would you need to have drawings anymore?  Forget about DWG/DXF and other drawing based formats. Could platforms like scada and HMIs just import the data and derive graphical rendering. Does the design data you generated just become a part of the equipment’s data model available for other nodes to consume based on it’s published schema?

Author: brianpribe
Content: Now I’m catching what ur saying. It’s much more efficient to utilize universal standards and methods than a verbose method to get to the same output. But, as you mention, to get to that point we need to create these universal standards and methods, and this is where the real challenge is

Author: IIoT#4707
Content: GG @Brian Pribe, you just advanced to level 22!

Author: jpmoniz
Content: Exactly.  Lot of opportunities on the table.  Like you said the challenge becomes globally herding cats. No different then talking about climate change.

Author: brianpribe
Content: Hahaha true

Author: jpmoniz
Content: Yep. Thus my mindset of build what works for you vs buying

Content: I wasn’t thinking the actual schematics are stored. More like a data structure you could read and generate a schematic from. At the end of the day a schematic is just a network of devices with underlying meta data. If we represented that network in data schemas then you can build whatever you need around that schema.

Content: Schematics is the first thing to design in electronics, i guess what you call schematics is more a block diagram.

Author: zeratall

Author: zeratall
Content: Yeah as an enterprise architecture im a huge advocate for being Model Based. You can do a lot of cool things with it, even infrastructure as code using a model definition for a system.

Author: zeratall
Content: Getting non technical adoption is hard though, I think a lot of modeling tools such as Camoe have poor UI/UX, people take one look and immediately want to go back to developing block diagrams in visio just because it looks "CoNfUsInG"

Author: jpmoniz
Content: I think design tools like CAD/ECAD/BIM and integrating control platform software.  Will ultimately end up heading that way. Just see so much duplication of effort.
