Content: Yeah absolutely!

Author: mriiot
Content: Do you have any examples you can share and explain ?  I would like to learn this.

Author: zeratall
Content: Model Based is a pretty broad subject and there's a lot of. different aspects of the architecture (operational, logical/functional, physical) thst being said this video is an pretty good high level view, skip to the 7:00 min mark https://youtu.be/gmcezrHfRuA

Author: zeratall
Content: Most cameo models are going to be for physical systems aka a product but it can be applied to any kind of system such as an IIOT Architecture etc

Author: nickn5549
Content: Siemens MBSE is based on Capella, I guess https://www.eclipse.org/capella/

Author: zeratall
Content: Yeah there's quite a few different MBSE modeling tools out their. I'd say the industry standard is cameo.

Author: nickn5549
Content: Cameo from Dassault Systems?

Author: zeratall
Content: Yep

Author: seamoss
Content: My company is actually working on building an internal MBSE SaaS for digital systems (mostly to autogenerate tests / simulators for our software developers). Does anything like this exist? I really want to save us the time from building that if it exists already 😂

Author: seamoss
Content: Primary use case is for our mobile app devs, they just need a behavioral reference to build their app against while the hardware devs are working on the device and comms boards

Author: seamoss
Content: Currently we're able to autogenerate BLE simulators based on models and messaging structure then determine states based on workflows. Saves a ton of time but surely someone has done this already

Author: akoscs
Content: MechatronicsML, Modelica, OpenModelica, Simulink

Author: seamoss
Content: Didn't know simulink could autogenerate bluetooth simulators from models for mobile app developers to use instead of device in hand. When I checked it seemed pretty closed off? Like I can't just generate a dashboard for our devs to use as a test reference afaik. I'll look into the others though

Author: seamoss
Content: The ultimate goal being we want to create a complete operational digital twin of any device for our app devs

Author: akoscs
Content: It can generate code for (Almost) anything you model in simulink using Simulink Coder. It can be surpsizingly good, look at the demos i used it only for robotics realted stuff, but there are plenty of other toolboxes to chose from

Author: akoscs
Content: Also look at stateflow for a more flow based modelling

Author: seamoss
Content: oh neat, I'll see if that works for our usecase. Long term we want to tie these into appium tests that run against our CI/CD pipeline so we can automate app testing without a device lab. A lot of our QA process is manual right now with the exception of HIL testing but I'd say 90% of the issue caught in HIL testing is just from people not following the spec haha. So if we can just verify bluetooth packets against a virtualized behavioral simulator that can check spec compliance well before it gets to HIL that'll save us a ton of time

Author: sammysevens777
Content: Big fan of Siemens' products - they are top class, but Master Class really stunk.....is this how companies manage their engineering and product life cycles? What a terrible visual, all those lines, check boxes.......the concepts are good, but not so sure about the tool itself.

Author: seamoss
Content: Agreed tbh, feels like the tools for this stuff have been stuck in the 90s and are too obtuse to really use in a real world setting. Not to mention these tools are entirely inaccessible to younger startups who are pushing into the IoT space

Author: IIoT#4707
Content: GG @seamoss, you just advanced to level 5!

Author: zeratall
Content: Siemens is not top in class in terms of modeling lol. Like I said Cameo is the industry standard. And yes this is how major engineering companies do modeling and SE. If you think MBSE is a bad visual you should see how traditional systems engineering is done. This is a huge step up in capability.

Author: zeratall
Content: Modeling can be useful for smaller projects but it's really a MUST  for large enterprises where you need to model relationships (dependencies, realizations, satisfy, etc) otherwise the project fails. At the end of the day most sysml modeling tools are just visualizations of a graph database

Author: seamoss
Content: Why do you think a lot of organizations just choose not to use modeling? Even billion dollar companies I've been with that are doing IoT stuff haven't even heard of Cameo

Author: zeratall
Content: MBSE is relatively new to actually being used in industry that being said most organizations are problly modeling in some form or the other just you might not be aware of it. With most contracts now a day with the gov you HAVE to deliver a model it's not even optional anymore.

Author: zeratall
Content: Read any Systems Engineering textbook or INCOSE course MBSE is mentioned in one way or another

Author: seamoss
Content: oh yeah I've read the nasa handbook cover to cover and a textbook I use for reference all the time. I've been trying to push it more in our org. Companies will do it without really knowing the theory or terminology behind it. I see this more software side than hardware side though, where the hardware guys will have simulink models but the software engineers are just winging it with a pdf ICD spec they're passing around through email or on confluence if they're lucky haha

Author: seamoss
Content: I wonder if the learning curve plays a part in cameo's slow adoption

Author: seamoss
Content: A lot of places don't have systems engineers those duties will fall onto tech leads who basically have to learn an entirely new field of study

Author: zeratall
Content: IMHO as a EA that's consults and mentors a lot of models. I don't think it's cameo UX. Sure cameo is a bit dated, but again it's an engineering tool. The real lack of knowledge is fundamental knowledge of Systems Engineering.

Author: zeratall
Content: So many companies have developed command media that tell System Engineers they need to produce some system spec or produce some diagram, and because they are use to generating those artifacts a lot of understanding of why those artifacts are needed aka what questions they answer about the system are lost. Aka if I ask a lot of system engineers why it's important to define the operational domain, the logical domain, and the physical domain. You always get crickets.

Author: seamoss
Content: What do you see when a company makes that first step into understanding systems engineering? Is it usually one of the engineers stepping into that role or do you see they usually build a systems engineering / integration test team from the ground up?

Author: seamoss
Content: I'd imagine it starts with the problems: why are all my subsystems not working together, why are we two years behind schedule, why does no one know what's broken, etc

Author: seamoss
Content: But just thinking that first step in the right direction, not sure what that looks like

Author: zeratall
Content: I work in DoD space where every org has hordes of Systems Engineering. But systems thinking is the art of exploring the problem space and the solution space. I think a lot of orgs just do "buisness as usual" instead of exploring all the options.

Author: seamoss
Content: I'm client facing in our org and we're an engineering firm, so I'm mostly brainstorming ways to evangelize systems engineering internally to these companies. The problem is these companies want the _benefits_ without knowing that first step. "We're a large ship to steer" is always the excuse for why they can't change

Author: seamoss
Content: They'd rather be $25M overbudget on a $5M project than address the problems that get them there in the first place

Author: zeratall
Content: That is a very common problem aka justifying why flushing out the entire problem space and then solution space is valuable. Most would rather a good enough solution that's quick to market then doing proper SE.

Author: seamoss
Content: Do you think that has more to do with stubbornness or the complexity of SE?

Author: zeratall
Content: A little bit of both haha

Author: seamoss
Content: Just wondering if the solution here is making SE more accessible to the industry (maybe simplifying some aspects of it to make it easier to digest even if it loses some completeness). Just something that's been on my mind a lot lately

Author: zeratall
Content: Like @RickBullotta had in his slides, the world is not as structureed as most engineers would like to believe. Most would prefer a top down or bottom up approach but when it comes to system design much of it is parallel aka a bottom up, top down and inside out

Author: zeratall
Content: Which is why a model can be very valuable

Author: zeratall
Content: Yeah I totally agree, we need to have more understanding of the value that SE provides and how organizations can do enough SE that makes sense rather then just abandojing  it all together

Author: seamoss
Content: Oh yeah for sure, building software before device is in hand requires proper models. But... a lot of companies I've seen try to build software against benchtops and the mobile app developers end up having to troubleshoot prototype boards when the hardware fails

Author: seamoss
Content: While it's funny to watch mobile app devs troubleshoot hardware.. it's not good for a product roadmap 🙃

Author: zeratall
Content: Maybe I'll make some youtuve videos showing some examples of why a model is valuable and how we use SE, and how I utilize SE and a model in IIoT architecture,  but I'll have to be careful because I built the methodology a lot of our company uses lol but I think I can abstract it enough. Sometimes seeing examples is more consumable then writing about it

Author: seamoss
Content: I've been wanting to make content about this too, from the software engineer's perspective. Everything SE related I've seen has been mostly hardware centric

Author: seamoss
Content: I don't think I've met many software engineers who even know what SE is

Author: zeratall
Content: Hahah that doesn't surprise me, I think a lot of software architects do the same kinds of things traditional SE do

Author: zeratall
Content: I bet if you ask those software engineers about UML a lot more will know what your talking abour

Author: zeratall
Content: That being said sysml is a specialization that extends UML

Author: seamoss
Content:
The pipeline is like this architect creates diagrams on a PDF spec -> emails it to software team lead -> they make a simulator in another repo -> build their code against the simulator 

Then, when they inevitably miss the redlined state flow diagram on page 487 of the pdf and code the simulator wrong, their feature gets a false positive on the actual product in QA. Then, when it comes time to do full integration, the system "doesn't work" and no one knows why

Author: seamoss
Content: Cue the two weeks of troubleshooting and 30 person zoom call

Author: zeratall
Content: Most of the sysml concepts such as object oriented, generalization, etc are all concepts that stem from software design. Aka if you were to explain what the model actually reprents a lot of software guys would know it

Author: zeratall
Content: So we have a very similar issue with traditional systems engineering so like you most diagrams would've done in visio and then exported to pdf

Author: seamoss
Content: One of the tools I'm working on is to take sysml and message libraries to autogenerate simulators so we can skip two of those steps, which is why I've been diving deeper into this lately

Author: zeratall
Content: Let's say we have a complex assembly and of thst assembly we have 100 different views done in visio

Author: zeratall
Content: Ome view might represent the physical interfaces such as ethernet, analog etc. Another view might talk to the logical signals aka MQTT etc. Aka each view represents the assembly in a way to speaks to a specific stakeholder

Author: zeratall
Content: Now like you let's say we make a swap a component out in thag assembly. Now we have to tell everyone on the team of thst change. Each team member will have to go and update their visio diagram. Which Isa lot of rework and what if someone doesn't get the memo and we miss one? Happens a lot!

Author: seamoss
Content: Yup! It's a huge issue for us software side especially at integration testing

Author: seamoss
Content: So moving our source of truth to models instead of pdfs haha

Author: zeratall
Content: Contrast that to a MBSE approach where the assembly is represented in the model. Each view points to a definition of thst component. Aka if we make a change to that definition every view update automatically

Author: zeratall
Content: That's the object orientness of MBSE which is just one benefit but yeah great example

Author: zeratall
Content: That's exactly what we do. The  model becomes the source of truth for the configuration of the system if thst makes sense

Author: seamoss
Content: Software devs really only need the operational and logical model, so there's some simplifications that can be made from their perspective. As long as I get the correct messages over UART / BLE / ETH etc then the device is indistinguishable from production as far as I'm concerned

Author: zeratall
Content: We still have other sources of truth that feed the model thoufj the model shoild capture all the engineering rational for example

Author: zeratall
Content: All of our requirements from our customer or ones we have developed the source of truth is in doors

Author: seamoss
Content: Now full integration testing needs HIL where physical models matter but you shouldn't ever fail HIL testing because someone isn't following spec software side

Author: zeratall
Content: However we establish the relationship for the requirements in doors to elements in the model for example a analysis.

Author: zeratall
Content: Let's say we have a functional requirement that mandates some sort of behavior

Author: zeratall
Content: We link that to a functional analysis in the model which helps us understand that requirement and to allow us to decompose that requirement to lower level requirements

Author: zeratall
Content: With those lower level requirements we can then allocate them to lower level pieces of the architecture

Author: zeratall
Content: The beauty of this

Author: zeratall
Content: Let's say a customer changes the requirement

Author: zeratall
Content: Because we have all of those relationships we understand impact pretty quickly

Author: zeratall

Author: mariano.beracochea
Content:
Hello, i work as an on plant control engineer, my plant starting to have a digital infraestructure, we use multiple OPCs to collect data, influx db for time series, grafana for visualizations and node red to handle which data of the OPC put in which influx table and some processing. 
I think that in a way we got digital because now everyone on the plant use grafana to analises and make decisions, even the managers.

How do you automatically collect all the data of PLCs? we have S7 400 and S7 300 we have to manually collect the data with OPC and with node red send it to influx for historization, and it would be a lot of work to map all the data "just in case we need it"

Author: patanj2
Content: It is not expensive to use ignition to do the tag mapping.  At scale,  I use built in python scripting to import and export tags into Ignition platform.  Ignition could consume your OPC tags and map them into a new namespace.  For historizing,  you can either use external InfluxDB history module for ignition,  or use transmission module to publish the new namespace back to broker and then use another tool such as node read to write to InfluxDB

Author: joshuastover
Content: **Question of the Day: **How do you ensure the scalability and flexibility to accommodate future growth and changes in your organization when digitally transforming?

Author: ryankershaw
Content: Good infrastructure and culture.  Good infrastructure, like a UNS, provides the ability to scale and flex.  Good culture provides the willingness to scale and flex.

Not to say you shouldn't have people who ask lot's of questions, or push back against things that don't seem right, but an unwillingness to move away from "what we've been doing" because "we've always done it that way."

If your intent is to truly digitally transform at the enterprise level, @Ryan Kershaw, how do you propose that your infrastructure will provide the context, API access and iterative application development to do that at scale?

Author: joshuastover
Content: UNS is not deterministic... is Omniscient and Omnipresent. It is layered and distributed, creating a mesh across an organization with many entry and consumption points, all on common access technology. UNS is not theory, it is practice. It is reality. It is the architecture that the largest organizations in the world use to digitally transform, we have hundreds of examples.

Author: brianpribe
Content: Eliminating infrastructure bottlenecks is the first step. You can’t have a scalable and flexible system without first solving how to have a HA infrastructure. You could develop your own IT/OT infrastructure to be HA on-prem, but for the smaller enterprises this isn’t a feasible option. Going with a IaaS provider (AWS, Azure, GCP) is the defacto option.

Author: jon.forbord
Content: There seems to be a misunderstanding that a UNS can solve all your problems, and there seems to be a misunderstanding that a UNS is all you need. You’re right that a UNS alone doesn’t solve all problems. But saying it only provides scale for SCADA systems is either lacking in understanding, experience or imagination on the topic of UNS. I suspect that neither of these are true for you, so I assume you’re being poignant to make a point. Why does it only provide scale for SCADA, or would you otherwise want to clarify your point? To paraphrase @Michael Brown , there’s two types of data, the “right now data”, and the “not right now data”, and you need a strategy for both. I’d argue the foundation for the latter is the former, and using UNS as the strategy for the first is a prettttty darn good way to go about this and probably where you should start your DT journey.

Author: dvy___

Author: mariano.beracochea
Content: for the 400 we have SCADA, but is PCS7 7.2, is through OPC DA, we use OPC Expert as a bricht to the OPC UA, but it maps a lot of structure data and meta data from the blocks on de CFC that are used, on the PCS7, the DBs are generated automatically when the program is compiled, so i cant read directly from the PLC all the DBs(there are some i created to collect the data for OPC. But there are more than 10 000 tags on OPC Expert, a great deal of thar us is useless data, but the manual mapping will be a lot of rework, we are already collecting those data

Author: dvy___
Content: Indeed with PCS7 the db numbers can change, need to be careful with that. First of all a big part of the data that you want should be on the control modules. You're probably using the standard APL library. There's much more data on those blocks than you want to collect. Best for each control module type list what is useful. For example for an AI at least you want the measured value. Possibly also some alarm states and settings. Similar for the PID you want the SP, PV and output. You won't have more than 10-20 CM Types in a typical project. Next you need to collect the list of the CM instances. One approach can be from the process object view. Another approach could be to open WinCC and collect the instances from there. I think there might be an export available there. The WinCC approach might also work for the S7-300's. The other kind of data you might want to collect is what's on the sequences. For example the actual stepnumber. This approach should already cover more than 80%/90% of the data.  Then try to automate the whole process as much as possible. I would avoid mapping data manually to separate data blocks. It's not very scalable.

Author: kirtanderson
Content:
@Jon Forbord - The larger point here is that of Digital Transformation for an entire organization. Manufacturing, as a whole, is not doing a very good job of it; I suspect that most people reading this will agree. But, the interesting thing is that very few of the other industries out there are struggling the way that Mfg is. Why is that?  Finance, Banking,  Retail don't have that same complexity in their  data model, nonetheless there are things that they consistently do that Mfg does not:.

1. Democratize Application Development 
2. Use Bottom-up Design Principles
3. Implement CI/CD Processes that allow for iterative development, rapid deployments and proper change management
4. Standardize on Cloud native / cloud agnostic technologies
5. Maintain a fundamental understanding of value vs cost for large tech projects (i.e. MES)

There's more but listing them is overkill. The point is that I don't think that a reasonable person could argue that, in todays tech stack and dev environments, that these things aren't critical.

The reason that I list these is because I am interested in hearing from the community on how the UNS, as an enterprise construct, helps to promote these things within the manufacturing industry and how the products that are embraced by this community are architecting and developing themselves to help their user base achieve them. 

My reasonably-well educated opinion is that if you aren't doing everything in that list in your DT strategy, you're going to hit a wall for capability and scalability. If a UNS is your strategy and you haven't found a way to make it operate within a strategy that includes these things, you've built a SCADA extension that provides you a vision of a point in time, which is great if that's what you set out to do.

Author: brianpribe
Content:
I think these are the growing pains our industry is still having to figure out. While it took accounting, IT, support, etc to figure out how to interoperate with each other, at scale, and reliably, we have to do the same, but at the same pace those industries are at NOW. Some manufacturers are  discovering the benefits of excel!! It also doesn’t help that our industry has created such a poor environment for digital innovation that we outright sue those who are giving away their IP for free. 

Right now, there is no software that is ready to be mass adopted to meet those demands. However, the demand is there and it is strong. Small improvements in aggregating and acting on manufacturing data, generates an astonishing amount of value, and return on investment. 

So can the current UNS tech stack meet all enterprise demands, no. But 10 years ago were you able to connect, aggregate, and structure that data into a cohesive model for other services to consume in real-time with millions of devices? I think everyone knows that answer.

Author: kirtanderson
Content:
"Small improvements in aggregating and acting on manufacturing data, generates an astonishing amount of value, and return on investment."

@Brian Pribe - you are correct. You also very eloquently defined the wall that I'm speaking of. When your low hanging fruit is gone and you actually need to DO something with any degree of complexity for the enterprise, you're probably going to find that you don't have an architecture or an infrastructure to be successful.

Author: zeratall
Content: I love the well articulated stance that you have, I agree there needs to be some pretty fundamental paradigm shifts before we truly see innovation that we see in other industries. I am curious for those things you listed what is your rational for why those things are needed. As an enterprise architect I have seen just as many issues with some of those things as well as pros. For example with democratized software development you often have competing interests between stakeholders and often that interferes with the technical solution as well as cause undue delay in schedule. (The unicorn/phoenix project Is an excellent book that speaks in volumes to that). Another example is bottom up design. Because of constraints and  different stakeholders often architecture development is more top down, bottom up, inside out. That's architecture in general especially for a complex distributed system where different stakeholders own different parts of the stack such as many enterprise IT/OT architectures. What I'm getting at is its often not a one solution fits all with architecture and that includes UNS, it's just another tool that "could" be used. It's up to the architect to evaluate the pros and cons of any design pattern and determine if it's a good fit. Just my two cents.

Author: kirtanderson

Author: kirtanderson
Content:
Yeah, fair points and certainly valid questions. Both of the cases that you pose are mostly "people" problems caused, in my opinion, my folks either needing to be the smartest person in the room or feeling like they need to defend their fiefdom.

My opinion? Top-down design is the single leading cause of data silos and lakes, poor quality data, poorly thought out and even more poorly implemented middleware, "API hell" and "rip and replace" implementations in Layer 3. If the design always came from the back end and was always predicated upon a standard (i don't care which one, just pick one and stick with it), it wouldn't take all that long before any use case design became an exercise in iterating on the definition of the entities in the model, not designing a new data model to serve the UI that someone already built 60% of without even thinking about the DB or API.

This also helps to alleviate some of the democratized dev problem that you describe in that the backend is controlled and standardized and so the use case starts with "What backend iteration is required and is it part of the standard or is it an extension of the DB not covered in the standard?" Once the data model for the use case is defined to cover all interested parties, who cares what the UI looks like, right? Build 4 four them for four different sites and then throw them all away and build another until you get it right. It's just a UI - it should absolutely be the dumbest thing in the stack.

But, @Zach E - you make fair points that don't have easy solutions...

Author: zeratall
Content: Yeah I totally agree with your response and yeah in my personal opinion (especially at my company) the cultural aspect is the greatest risk to any successful effort. The thing I always try to articulate is with any proper engineering decision there needs to be some sort of analysis that supports that decision. That not only helps you arrive at the appropriate solution, but If that rational is documented (which it should) such as in a model. It provides a point of reference in the future when ultimately the architecture will need to be refactored  (which it most definitly will at some point) to understand if the assumptions or rational the architecture is built on is still valid.

Author: dvy___
Content:
Nice architecture in this first use case:
- Multi-site (totally about 50?)
- Local historian at each site
- Local MQTT broker at each site
- Local relational db for the track&tracing
- Enterprise MQTT broker
- Kafka for streaming data into a data-lake
- Power BI for dashboarding (not sure where they connect to)
- not yet containerized, but they mentioned that they had that in another use case
- as I understand common namespace in the historian, brokers and I guess same for the data-lake. Not sure about the relational db but since they managed to make it scalable you can also see the data there as an extension of the namespace.

Author: brianpribe
Content:
Here would be my functional stack:
Cloud services for level 3, 4+ (MES, ERP, CMMS)
On-Prem services for 2, 1, 0
(SCADA, WMS, PLC)
Pub/Sub service for events, iot
API service for transaction data
DB with time series capabilities 
UI for visualization, user data
^thats for cloud and on-prem^
I would also use a digital infrastructure scripting service to automate the installation and configuration of new digital infrastructure agnostic to any cloud provider.

Author: mparris
Content: Could you spend some time explaining how "being the ecosystem" is good with LibreMfg, when many in this community may still be licking their wounds from previous applications that presented themselves as " the ecosystem."

Author: rickbullotta
Content: A wise man once told me “you’re not a platform/ecosystem because you say so - it’s because others say so”. Words to live by. ☝🏼

Author: rickbullotta
Content: I think a workflow engine and rules engine are important, as are AI applications for vision/metasensing, analytic insights, and predictive/prescriptive guidance. Critical to all of this is a unified access control and authorization layer.

Author: kirtanderson
Content: Completely agree. You'll notice the words "closer to" and that I did not describe Libre as an ecosystem...

Author: IIoT#4707
Content: GG @Kirt Anderson, you just advanced to level 7!

Author: rickbullotta
Content: And don’t misunderstand me - building an ecosystem is a virtuous, valuable (and often difficult) undertaking - but well worth the effort.  It starts with open APIs for virtually everything and good docs/training/support. You’re well on your way on the architecture front!

Author: kirtanderson
Content:
In theory, the "ecosystem" is always a better approach because, if it's done right, it removes many of the integration problems. In practice, it mostly gets screwed up because RA, AVEVA, Siemens, etc. are actually marketing and sales engines cleverly disguised as software companies and have chosen the "growth by acquisition" strategy that will never work for Mfg.

Is Libre a better approach than what's been there in the past? Probably. Am I going to get on a soapbox and pound my chest about it? Nope. There is no point. One of the things that I've learned in my 25 years in this industry is that it is often more constructive to watch somebody fail, so that they are properly motivated to understand what they "could have" done to be successful, than it is to try to argue against a point that is being self-reinforced through confirmation bias.

Libre is a massively open Data Hub based on it's protocols and standards. That can be very clearly demonstrated. I'm sure that there is a time and place to debate the the term "ecosystem" and it's application, I just don't see the value in doing it now. If observers care to see Libre as a "node" in a UNS, **that's OK** - it doesn't change what we do or how we do it.

Author: rickbullotta
Content: The challenge is that a  “marketing and sales engine” is an essential component for startups too. Lots of great ideas and tech never achieve their potential due to a focus too much on product.  Gotta work both sides.  And in some ways it’s getting harder - to get above the noise level.

Author: kirtanderson

Author: dvy___

The pub/sub? Still that's an addition for many architectures, not a replacement for what's currently there.

Author: brianpribe
Content: How many architectures with a namespace are event-driven instead of poll/response? How many architectures are graph based, instead of purdue?

Author: dvy___
Content: My point about the pub sub is that for many architectures pub-sub is actually not the limiting factor for making them scalable. Which is what the original question was about. Additionally pub-sub can't replace many of the existing connections. To be clear, I agree that pub-sub has it's place in a scalable architecture, obviously for removing bottlenecks in communication.

Author: akoscs
Content:
Scaling is the issue. The IT solution to cost effective scaling and breaking up a monolithic application is messaging (event driven architectures) and microservices which allow a much more cost effective scaling then monolithic approaches. In OT we already have a distribiuted system, so the logical thing is to use the current best practice for distribuited systems in IT. Could we use a monolith? Sure but it would not scale cost effectively. Could we use a non event driven architecture? Sure, but it would not scale cost effectively. So the simplest answer to why pub sub? Why event driven? Is that these are the most cost effective ways to scaling and as such have a solid tooling coming directly from IT.

What is the limiting factor to scaling if not communication and compute, in your opinion? Also what are those many architectures you mentioned, for which pub sub is not the issue?

Author: dvy___
Content:
Yes agree scaling is the main issue, but the biggest limiting factor in many industries is not the scaling of the messaging. And when it becomes an issue it's relatively easy to set up some event driven messaging to reduce the communication workload at the place where it's a bottleneck.

A couple of things that will unlock bigger scaling possibilities:
- ability to deploy/manage everthing by scripting (containerization, open API's, ...)
- decoupling of the software and hardware on the edge (barely mentioned here, but there's a huge pressure building to decouple SW and HW by end users, see OPAF from the DCS side and Universal Automation/ IEC61499 from the PLC side, both initiatives converging.
- text-based engineering (Simatic AX would indeed be really disruptive)

Author: dvy___
Content:
Just look at pharma for example. Everything needs to be documented first. We have list and lists and list of design data before anyone can even start to program or configure a system. Everything after that is just a translation of the data of the design into another form. (programming, configuration, installing, ...)  And after all the actual programming work everything needs to be valuated again against that design. (multiple times even if you're not smart about your validation strategy ...) Don't even mention changes that need to happen afterwards. People try to optimize but there's not much we can do today because most of our applications are closed/proprietary formats/no API's/...

Once we unlock above things we can finally optimize an entire process like that: design/model the plant, run a couple of (validated 🙂 ) scripts to set everything up, run automated tests, run automated deployment, some more tests and production is ready to go.
You want a common namespace? Well it comes along with the design.
You want an MQTT broker that forwards into the historian? Well take this (pre-validated) script to add it to the architecture.
You want to set up another production line, or 50? Just copy and adjust the design, run the same scripts, done...

Author: akoscs
Content:
Not scaling of the messaging, but messaging is one of the most important enablers of scaling. Take your example. Deployment and containerisation. Ok, you have everything in containers. Do you start managing all of your container IP adresses manually? No. Do you use an mDNS? You can and you should. Now you know how to reach a container with a string instead of an IP.  You can do direct connections to the containers but now, when you chance any data source or data sink you habe to change something in every data source that uses the changed container as a sink. Message brokers allow you to be more productive and make changes o ly in one place. Also do not get me started on config management for testing without a broker. 

Decoupling: well with decoupling your sw can run anywhere. Also can run anywhere dynamically, as in today it runs on this node tomorrow on the next node. So you need to handle communication. Again, most productive solution is a middleman how takes care of this for you. Are there other solutions to this problem then brokers? Sure! Are they as popular? Nope.

Text based engineering. Well this sounds cool but it is kind of orthogonal to scaling.

Author: jon.forbord
Content: The definition of UNS isn't really up for debate. You can debate whether the name is misleading, but the concept has a clear lineage and origination. UNS is the structure, the events and current state of your business. A UNS adheres to the following minimal technical requirements, edge driven, report by exception, open architecture and lightweight. Edge driven and report by exception means generally pub/sub. You can "call" your poll-response architecture with a common naming convention and namespace a unified namespace, but it doesn't make it a Unified Namespace. We make no assumptions about how data will be consumed, and this means that we try to collect everything (in principle, often not practically possible). When we collect a lot more data, you'll quickly find that you need pub/sub and report by exception to EVEN make this possible at a small scale. The nice thing about pub/sub and RBE is that network load is of minimal concern, plus the fact that you can drive configuration from the source, and don't have to set up text-based deployments on tag lists and shit just to get the implementation part. Gallarus has done Life sciences projects based on UNS, and are able to scale efforts by making the validation process FAR more efficient using pub/sub than traditional poll/response. So yes, Scaling matters, but it may be in other dimensions than purely on network load.

Author: dvy___
Content:
- Scaling of messaging: again yes important, but we're running against other bottlenecks. Like I said the architectures we work with (process industries for medium to bigger companies) don't quickly run against bottlenecks for the messaging. And the times we did it was quick to fix.
- Decoupling of HW and SW: The main point here is that you don't need to use a different computer language to program another piece of HW. Like the Siemens 300 and 400 in an earlier question were already programmed with different platforms. And their 1500's are again different. Multiply over many vendors. It's like you would have to program a Dell with their proprietary language, in their proprietary IDE. And another dell with another of their proprietary IDE's. And the same story for HP and so on.

And yes all these things are orthogonal to each other, and will actually even benifit/multiply the overall scaling. Just pointing out there's a lot of other powerful changes coming that might have more impact.

Author: akoscs
Content: How do you propose HW/SW decoupling without messaging? With a Discovery service?

Author: dvy___
Content: Is that reply for me? I didn't say we don't need messaging.

Author: akoscs
Content: You say that HW/SW decoupling is a bigger problem then pub sub. Well, I think pub sub messaging is the enabler for efficien HW/SW decoupling. If you do not agree, could you elaborate on how you envision HW/SW decoupling without pub sub messaging? You can use a discovery service instead, but the more dynamic your deployment is the more you run inti problems with a discovery service.

Author: dvy___
Content: Ok wait let me try to clarify the concept. It's not about letting the software running anywhere. It's about letting software run on any type of hardware, but you still know exactly where it is running.

Author: akoscs
Content: I would not call this HW/SW decoupling. This is just cross compatibility. Ok, so this enables a more productive engineering apporach. Agreed. But scaling your production IT  infra is not improved by this.

Author: dvy___
Content:
The original question was about what will enable scaling of an organisation in general, not only focused on the production IT infra.
This concept will mainly enable scaling of the applications, which is what actually controlling the factory. And not having this capability today is one of the biggest limiting factors in scaling the digitisation of at least some types of production facilities. 
Indeed, orthogonal to pub/sub.

Author: rickbullotta
Content: I think where I differ on this is in the implementation of how you expose the “current state of your business”.  For simple telemetry and sensor/state data across a relatively static namespace (eg assets or machines or sites), the approach suggested here works well (assuming you break apart things like  Sparkplug into a more consumable namespace).  Where I think a different approach is needed is accessing data from systems like MES, ERP, and historians.  I prefer a model where data can be pulled “on demand” from the source system in some of those cases. Polling and pushing guarantees latency, inaccuracy, and can overburden the source system with unnecessary queries. “Pull with cache” is also an option.

Author: mariano.beracochea
Content: Which is the process of normalicing data for a time series db? if everything is report by exception, everything have a different timestamp, so you cant add things because data doesnt aline. i thought about rewriting last value of existing data when a value change, but that lost the purpuse of pub/sub... so how is it done?

Author: hobbes1069
Content: With the caveat that I haven't done it yet (at scale), you basically have to replicate values for your slow changing signals to match your fastest signal. And to be precise you would do this normalization either virtually or into another data set, not rewrite into your source database. If you're doing this in Python then PANDAS would be the first place I looked.

Author: mariano.beracochea
Content: With just one fast changing signal, wouldnt that make it replicate everything a lot and make it almost a polling system? i havent dont either, Im trying to understand

Author: nickn5549
Content: I'm slowly modifying my apps to publish to MQTT when users add info in DB, but for Apps where i don't have access to the source code i'm still polling the databases and send to MQTT.

Author: hobbes1069
Content: You're thinking about it the wrong way. As I said, you don't modify the incoming signal, you "re-align" your dataset after the fact. Basically you re-bucketize your data.

Author: hobbes1069
Content: So in my case I can at best have 1s resolution polling a bunch of CNCs via Kepserver, but many of the signals last minutes to hours. I would re-bucketize the data to 1s intervals where the slow signals would have the same value for longish periods of time. This not only makes the data "aligned" (and normalized) for analysis for tools like PowerBI, but also for AI/ML uses.

Author: dvy___
Content: I also don' t understand where the inflexibility of the UNS with capital 'U' is coming from. It's clear it doesn't cover everything, and it's leading to a lot of confusion of people being told that you best send everything over the broker, and then finding out that in reality it's not really so clean. And that's actually quite ok in most cases. Is that the stance that the definition of UNS is 'not up for debate'? Ok then double down on it. Fix it in a white paper, put up a website or a wiki or something so it can be referred to properly. And then if we have an architecture that implements a namespace that doesn't 100% fit the UNS definition then we just call it a common or coordinated namespace. And for the people who like capitals we call it a CNS: Coordinated NameSpace with a recommendation not to poll your networks into oblivion.

Author: mikebartlett_nh
Content: Those systems have exception bands, compression (archiving) bands, exception and compression timeouts, and when time aligning for slow-moving and fast moving roll-ups there are functions that will interpolate.

Author: jon.forbord
Content: Context: my perspective is usually about what you can do NOW, with technology today, not what would be optimal or what if technology did X. Having seen actual implementations of this, I can try to paint a picture of how things have been done.  In practice, because most systems don’t “talk” an IIoT protocol, UNS implementations use an IIoT platform (Ignition/Highbyte) that sits on top of the namespace. This is usually at the site or area level. To query the namespace or add context from transactional data into the namespace you use the the IIoT platform to query the databases or call APIs based on topics that essentially make up the where-clause of the query, and publish the result into the namespace. One example is a work order on a machine, the IIoT platform queries the database to get the information about that work order from the ERP based on the current work order pulled from the machine. Status on the progress on a work order would go back from the machine and through the IIoT platform to perform an update (could be an API-call, whatever). There are tons of examples like this where you use the current state (triggered by an event) to query/poll transactional or other historical data. Some are just querying at a set interval as well. All of this makes up the unified namespace at the site level, a mix of transactional data, current state of equipment, current state of KPI’s, etc. This namespace is then published to a broker that sits at the enterprise level. If you need to query the process historian to perform aggregations, same approach,

Author: jon.forbord
Content: through the IIoT platform. You plug in a Historian to be the “memory” of the namespace and sometimes do streaming to a data lake for advanced analytics. You can essentially take the Libre architecture diagram, and put Ignition in its place (with say Canary Historian and SQL backend), and there you have the bulk of pre-2020 UNSes as implemented by Walker’s Intellic Integration (at least the ones I’ve seen). Am I making ANY sense? Are there times when using MQTT to do things is suboptimal, for sure, 100%, but with the right approach and mindset, you can achieve a ton of value in relatively short time, with solutions and technology that exists today. Now is the UNS really the IIoT platform and the broker together, or is it just the broker? In some level, I don’t care, I just want to solve problems, and do it as efficiently as possible. In others I see these as two mental mappings that people use to understand something that is essentially an abstract concept.

Author: walker.reynolds
Content: We mostly achieve this through platforms that support MTR -- MQTT with SPb or the like -- plus support for SQL, API or some other connector.  What's important to note is that we use data ops tools to merge queried and/or transactional data into information and data models that are 'current state' in the UNS.  There are plenty of examples of MES that are full on nodes that support MTR out of the box and publish as a device or device nodes into the UNS, ERP is a different story -- we are almost always merging into UNS with platforms that support UNS MTR and API, SQL or other.  I'll paste an example below.

Author: walker.reynolds
Content: Namespaces are built like this -- MES and ERP fall under 'functional'

Author: walker.reynolds
Content: Sketch of an actual asset with namespaces highlighted

Author: walker.reynolds
Content: Looks like this

Author: walker.reynolds
Content: 'MachineSchedule' is an ERP Function and is an aggregation of transactional and real-time data/info with abstraction

Author: walker.reynolds
Content: 'Line' is an Asset Function and aggregates ERP transactions, MES state and transactions, along with real-time events from the asset

Author: walker.reynolds
Content: Together, along with other namespaces above in the original screenshot, they make up a 'UNS' for the asset that is a child of the 'Area' and is unified at a higher level using transmission via the MTR protocol, MQTT SPb.  This aggregation is done as data ops, at the asset level (in this case) and is unified at the broker.

Author: walker.reynolds
Content: In this example -- 'Press 103' is the Node in SPb.  There is a transmitter for this asset that publishes the entire namespace (which is many namespaces aggregated into one) to an Area 'Group' at a higher level.  This is a unique approach -- asset is not generally a node, much more common for the 'Area' to be treated as a node, but this is a very large UNS.  There are topics within this namespace that are shared outside of the organization -- both up and downstream in the supply chain.  For this client, treating the asset as the node makes the most sense.  FWIW, the 'MQTT' namespace is actually raw edge and contains the namespace from the Siemens D445 motion controller, all blocks, all tags.  If there is a datapoint needed by a new function in the Asset Namespace, it is pulled from here and abstracted.  Once the function is completed, its namespace shows up in the full UNS at every broker entrypoint.

Author: dvy___
Content:
Thanks for the explanation Walker.

Could you elaborate a bit further about @RickBullotta 's question about the access to the Historian and MES systems?
I believe in your case study about the tier-3 automotive supplier you have three main sources of data (at plant level) that can be queried by other systems:
- the broker
- the historian
- the MES database with a.o. tracking & genealogy information
So depending on what kind of data an application needs it can either subscribe to the broker, make a query to the historian, or make a query to the MES database. Or even a combination of these three.
Did I understand that correctly?

Author: walker.reynolds
Content: In the Tier 1 example, there are 4 connectors -- OPC-UA to Mitsu and Omron PLCs, MQTT to Broker, JDBC to Historian, SQL to MES.  The IIoT Platform brings them altogether to create a single namespace that is transmitted to a higher level broker for consumers outside of the production Area to consume data, info and data models.  The IIoT Platform also consumes from the broker, new functional data, info and data models from other nodes that use the Area data to create new info, or ingest non-Area data and info that is useful in the production Area.

Author: walker.reynolds
Content: OPC-UA is transformation of native Mitsu and Omron drivers

Author: dvy___
Content:
Ok I guess basically something like this.

So the three main sources of data at the area level:
- Historical Time series in the Historian
- Current state in the broker
- Relational data like the tracking & genealogy in the MES
Applications can connect to one or more of them.
And devices are connected to the broker through the native - OPC UA - MQTT transform.

Then the site brokers transmit to the enterprise broker from where in this case it streams into Kafka and then into the data lake.
At that level there's enterprise applications, probably also where something like Microsoft BI ties in to.

Author: walker.reynolds
Content:
Kirt -- every single client of ours, since 2015, has been transformed on UNS infrastructure.  Parallel approach, one for legacy devices, one for future state.  Digital Strategy is crafted, architecture designed (including settling on a technology -- in most cases, MQTT 3.1.1, MQTT 5, SPb for Nodes, IIoT Platform for Legacy Data Ops to MTR) and Minimum Technical Requirements for smart things written.  UNS is built out via ISA-95 Part 2, functions are defined and namespaces built with integrations to MTR compliant smart nodes or through the IIoT platform.  Business problems are solved iteratively.  Internal resources are trained on digital transformation, an internal team is built, more problems are solved -- at some point 18 months into the engagement we scale.

Whether we are transforming 100 plants in the connectivity space, 300 plants in soda water production, 40 bakeries, Tier 1 Automotive, Life Sciences -- or we are doing a mom and pop plant down the street -- the approach is the same.  

This isn't theory, its practice.  You know as well as I do that we can't publicly share customers and sites without permission.  We get that permission for Mastermind sessions, we have sanitized documents and architectures -- we have presented on architecture and use cases over and over again.  There are hundreds of mentees and mastermind members who have spent two years delving into this, we have dozens of partners who use this architecture and approach.  UNS is the structure and state of a business -- it absolutely scales, it is the mechanism upon which hundreds of companies are built on.  Many of the biggest names in Industry.

Author: walker.reynolds
Content: The biggest challenge we have is closing the information gap on ERP to UNS integration -- I think @Jon Forbord hits the nail on the head in nearly all of his posts -- there's a lot of confusion out there, right now.  Especially when it comes to UNS capabilities at enterprise scale or with integration to ERP.

Author: learner0756
Content: I am looking for suggestions on how to connect files generated on a Windows 10 PC into an MQTT ecosystem.  I need a gateway to collect a series of files as a transaction event, contextualize the data and broadcast out the payload for consumption by various endpoints.  Currently considering tools such as Kepware, Ignition or HighByte for the job, but would love to hear everyones thoughts on an ideal configuration, or the pro's and con's of each platform.

Author: hobbes1069
Content: HighByte would work, it can ingest CSV files, etc. But if you want to PUSH the data off the computer, I would just install Node Red on it and have it watch a folder for files being written to it.

Author: learner0756
Content: I am looking to send and receive (Publish and subscribe) via MQTT Sparkplug

Author: hobbes1069
Content: I've only done MQTT 3.1.1 and 5 with Node Red but there are Sparkplug nodes.

Author: jon.forbord
Content: Why would you want to use Sparkplug?

Content: Well I think the main reason is to make the systems discoverable.   LWaT seems to be good as well, but i am definitely here to learn as this is my first attempt.

Author: bright_hummingbird_31342
Content:
**Kepware**
Kepware, to my knowledge, does not ingest file data.  There might be some file-based drivers (e.g., EUROMAP 63) you might be able to hack a solution together with, but it won't be pretty.

**Ignition**
Ignition can ingest text file data.  The string reader function and the Python CSV library in its scripting engine can be employed.  The data would get read into a table or tag values.  Ignition, in turn, can publish this data over MQTT.

More info here:
https://docs.inductiveautomation.com/display/DOC79/Exporting+and+Importing+a+CSV

**HighByte**
HighByte has a file connector.  It can ingest csv, parquet, etc.  A file, or a variety of files, can be consumed and transformed into a  defined model.  A flow can be established to take this modeled source data and target an MQTT connection for publishing.

More info here:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=xi_zSuqDXmU&t=815s

It's worth mentioning that the upcoming release of version 3, most notably, adds the 'pipeline manager' functionality.  This includes buffering, transformation, and monitoring capabilities for shaping more complex integrations.  This addresses many use cases involving the processing of files and other "bulk" data.

Author: jon.forbord
Content: I’d say it depends on the scale of this effort and if you’re going to do more than read files in the future? Do you send the files themselves or do you want to parse them into tags / UDTs?

Author: jon.forbord
Content: Using the tahu-library with Python (or another language if you prefer), you can build this yourself to a PoC-ish level in a day if you’ve got the chops and the fileparsing isn’t overly complex.

Author: jon.forbord
Content: You don’t have to decide the platform you use yet. I’ve had a good experience starting with Ignition to get a hang on the technology, and because you can download it without talking to anyone and reset the trial ad infinitum (so you can develop at your own pace). In my experience highbyte needs some scale to the implementation before the benefits will manifest. Sounds like you may want to check out highbyte.

Author: hobbes1069
Content:
More generically from this situation, I've been giving this a fair bit of thought, and I think standardizing on MQTT 5 as much as possible and using the user properties is the way to go, but as you mentioned, what's the best practice? In the HiveMQ article they show an example using "schema:<file type>", but I was thinking more literally using "mime" or "mimeType".

Author: hobbes1069

Author: markpitout
Content:
Right. I checked with @Joshua Stover , and was advised that this is the right channel to post the following VERY long post. Please bear with me.

Hi. First time posting in this discord. But I have been following 4.0 solutions on YouTube for a while. I want to ventilate Walker's comments on last month's podcast video entitled "Siemens has a long way to go..". Specifically, I want to explore the comment he made about Schneider Electric.

See, I work for Schneider - for just over 8 years, now. The first four years I was a projects engineer executing PLC / SCADA projects in a typical 3.0 way. Now I am a pre-sales technical consultant - my job is to help our customers find the best fit solutions for their projects. Obviously, what I propose is made up of Schneider's products. But I am not shy to include 3d party products in my solutions, when Schneider has no equivalent option or when I know that the Schneider option is inferior. That being said, my experience is largely around Motor Control, PLC, HMI/SCADA, and Ethernet networks. When it comes to full stack integration and the software that live higher up in the stack, I am a total noob.

Slight caveat before I continue: I am not mandated by Schneider Electric to represent them on this forum. So, please don't take my words here as an official statement from Schneider Electric. Rather, my views are my own, based on the experience I've had working at Schneider Electric. Walker has also said in his video's that he repeatedly invites anyone from the big OEMs to come and defend themselves on the podcast. A live debate with Walker is a bit of a scary prospect (I'm not such an eloquent speaker). But I am willing to stick my neck out here, on the discord. Maybe I get some backlash from Schneider management for speaking out of turn, but I'm willing to risk it.

Now on to Walker's comments in the video:

Author: IIoT#4707
Content: GG @DaftWullie, you just advanced to level 1!

Author: markpitout
Content:
Video entitled "Siemens has a long way to go.." At around 6 minutes (https://youtu.be/NL-ubFbwStc?t=386) Walker says this:
"Siemens has accepted that they are never going to have 100% coverage in an organization and that there has to be mechanisms to easily integrate 3rd party / non-Siemens partners into a Siemens infrastructure. That is not Rockwell's philosophy. It's also not Schneider's philosophy, weirdly enough, and I'm not sure why."

As the Michael Jordan meme goes: “I took that personally”.

I take exception with the view that Schneider/Aveva's philosophy is to force our customers to only use our products. EcoStruxure is marketed as being open and interoperable. One of the guiding principles at Schneider is that our products only use industry standard, open protocols. In all the sales training I've had at Schneider the underlying theme was consultative selling - help the customer find the best solution. I've NEVER heard of an approach from any of my colleagues that tries to ensnare end-users in our ecosystem. I've NEVER heard of anyone trying to convince a customer that they have to replace or avoid someone else’s products at one layer, in order to gain access to our products on another layer. While you might hold the view that Schneider's implementation of an open and interoperable stack is not the best in the world, saying that our PHILOSOPHY is one that tries to lock users into our ecosystem is patently false.

Author: akoscs
Content: * grabs popcorn *

Author: markpitout
Content:
I will admit that our adoption of MQTT, and more specifically Sparkplug, has been slow. But, it has not been zero either.
MQTT Sparkplug is supported by the following products in our stable:
•    EcoStruxure Geo SCADA 
•    EcoStruxure Machine SCADA
•    Aveva System Platform
•    Aveva Edge
•    At the end of Q1 this year Schneider is releasing the SCADAPack 47xi controller. This is an IEC61131 PLC, DNP3 RTU, and Linux edge computing device, which will support MQTT Sparkplug, via EcoStruxure RTU Operation Expert software and through 3rd party apps on the Linux OS.
•    R&D of the Modicon M580 PAC have told me that towards the end of this year they hope to release an in-rack edge computing module, which will also support MQTT.
•    For years, we have had a range of Linux and Windows based edge computing products that could be used as MQTT gateways (see part reference HMIBSCEA53D1L0T).

At around 7 minutes 45 seconds (https://youtu.be/NL-ubFbwStc?t=462) Walker also says this:
"When you ask the Mindsphere group about consumption of data into Mindsphere from non-siemens datapoints, they're going to give you a pretty generic OPC response. And if you ask them, how are you leveraging MQTT or other IoT protocols they are pretty stand-offish about it."
I've recently come across Aveva Datahub. I don't know much about it, but it seems like it might be Aveva's answer to Mindsphere. And as far as I can see, it also supports MQTT Sparkplug.

Author: markpitout
Content:
•    I acknowledge that Schneider has not made MQTT the foundation for its EcoStruxure stack (none of the big automation OEMs have).
•    I acknowledge that only some of Schneider's products will directly integrate with a UNS, without middleware or gateways (just like all the other large OEMs).
•    I acknowledge that Schneider has put a lot of focus on OPC-UA (just like all the other large OEMs).
Compared to emerging automation OEMs, we are not leading when it comes to MQTT. But we are making strides towards adopting MQTT Sparkplug. As time goes on you will see more and more of it in Schneider's offers.

So, I don't know why Walker holds such a negative view of Schneider compared to Siemens. Am I just a brainwashed Schneider employee? Am I just to naive/inexperienced about the higher levels in a digital stack? Or am I missing the bigger picture?

Content:

This is the type of participation we want from the large OEMs. I believe the reason why the community (more specifically Walker) has a negative view, is because of association with the other large OEMs and zero attempt to discern themselves and state it to the community. Marketing can publicly say whatever they want (Open, Bleeding Edge, IT/OT), but nobody gives a shit because marketing inherently lies. 

For the two years I've been a part of this community, this is the FIRST time Schneider (or Rockwell and Siemen's included) has stood up for themselves. Even more impressive, it came from one of their project engineers. Someone who actually implements their products.

Without it, they're just unsupported claims.

Author: dvy___
Content:
First of all openness and interoperability are not black or white, it's a gradation. And it is also has different facets: not only about the supported communication protocols, but also for example if it has open API's, open access to the data, open/standardised programming languages, open docs, open pricing, ...
(Walker's preaching is mainly about the communication protocols and architectures)

Secondly companies like Siemens, Schneider and Rockwell are highly complex organisations with multiple product lines and teams.

Mapping all the facets of openness and interoperability against these companies would give a very complex and nuanced view. 

An additional example (surprised you didn't mention it?) of the philosophy of Schneider is their efforts around Universal Automation (https://universalautomation.org/) promoting an open and shared runtime on edge devices of different vendors.
On the other hand there's also Aveva. The portfolio of Schneider/Aveva has become so big over the last years that it's even difficult to have interoperability between their own products.

From Siemens there seem to be different philosophies depending on where you look in their organisation. Factory Automation is moving towards more openness and interoperability. The Software division seems to go the opposite direction (at least for their MES strategy). Process Automation ... well similar level of openness as the other vendors, which is quite low. At least no clear communication from them of moving towards the OPAF concept.

Author: rickbullotta
Content: Aveva Data Hub isn’t what you think it is. There are (confusingly) two products with that name - one is a third party product and one is the evolution of OSISoft’s cloud services.  Aveva/Schneider BADLY need to go through a product rationalization and unification process.  Years overdue.

Author: nickn5549
Content: ...it is a hotch-potch...

Author: markpitout
Content:
Thanks for the correction. Admittedly I only gave DataHub(s) a surface level viewing. And yes, the brand names confused me. 

Schneider's (and Aveva's) strategy to grow through acquisition has caused many challenges with rationalization and unification. In my opinion, some of those challenges are insurmountable. And the unification challenge not only applies to products, but also to business units and strategy in the organization.

Author: markpitout
Content:
Thanks for your input. Your mention of Universal Automation is valid - my only hesitation is that Schneider's implemention of IEC61499 is still very young and applications for it are limited. 

Having open API's, documentation, protocols, etc. are one thing. But the effort required to engineer, maintain and scale a system, even when all the components are open, is another. Edge-driven protocols publishing and subscribing in and out of a UNS promise to simplify engineering. Right now MQTT Sparkplug appears to be the (only) standard for edge-driven coms in industrial automation. This is why my post was so focussed on this one protocol.

If I had my way, adoption of MQTT in Schneider products would be widespread. I would even argue we should develop our own broker (or partner with / buy out someone like HiveMQ)

Author: dvy___
Content:
Well the systems have to be engineered and maintained anyway. A common runtime should in the end reduce the overall effort. Of course this would be a net benefit for Schneider if successful. 
One thing I've been wondering though is why codesys isn't looking into this?

However important and future oriented we think these IT/OT convergence featurese are, we currently represent a small percentage of the market. Will that change? Yes! Should the decisionmakers be ballsy and look into the future instead of current market analysis? Yes, and they kind of do, but they take veeery small steps forwards and are much more cautions then we (?) think they should be.

Author: markpitout
Content:
I had a bit more of a think. About the "Siemens has a long way to go" video. If you start with the premise that no single OEM will have the best in class hardware and software for every layer of a full stack, then comparing the full stacks of various OEMs against each other is a moot point. 

Rather, one would considder the individual products of the OEMs at each layer, and pick the ones that best suit your needs. The starting criteria is  "How well does this product at this layer integrate with my UNS." After that, the other criteria follow: feature set, price, ease of configuration, service and support.

In 3.0 there was value in sticking to a single vendor for multiple layers, because integration of discrete connections between layers was normally easier. If a UNS is used and every product complies with the minimum technical requirements to interface with it, then having vendor A at one layer and vendor B at another makes no difference to the engineering effort.

BUT, maintaining relationships and getting support from multiple vendors is more complex than sticking to one vendor.

Author: jbonhage155
Content: Hi all... was doing some googling but thought I'd bring it up here. We are in arch design reviews for future state, our MES vendor is pushing OPC-UA (with our middleware Ignition) vs a our preferred pub-sub architecture. (via Ignition/HiveMQ combo) I'd like some ammo to defend pub/sub vs going with OPC-UA (client/server?)... I haven't gotten into the details of why the vendors prefers OPC-UA (I'm assuming familiarity) so just want to have my ducks in a row before I go to battle for pub/sub.

Author: jbonhage155
Content: are there valid points that OPC-UA can be more reliable than MQTT?

Author: hobbes1069
Content:
NOTE: This is what I've learned here but not yet been able to apply 🙂
OPC-UA is great on the plant floor up to the SCADA layer because it's much more deterministic. Once you're trying to "export" data off the floor and into the cloud the lightweight nature of MQTT is far more scalable, not to mention Azure and AWS have ways of ingesting MQTT messages directly or if that get's to be too much, you can use Kafka.

Author: hobbes1069
Content: Part 2: I'm unaware of any OPC-UA server that can scale like MQTT, when you're talking about publishing ALL of the events potentially across multiple sites globally. Kepserver certainly isn't the answer.

Author: hobbes1069
Content: We're currently working with Highbyte as a PoC, assuming that goes well we're considering using their internal broker at the plant/site level and then pushing all that to an Enterprise level broker with something like HiveMQ.

Author: jbonhage155
Content: Excellent. determinism might be good from PLC/SCADA/middleware but for MES ? Hmm. I think our MES vendors wants to connect directly to the equipment (vendor lock) so us putting Ignition/HiveMQ give us more flexibility.

Author: jbonhage155
Content: Though my biggest concern (only because I don’t know exactly how it’s done) is how a broker (HiveMQ) subscribes and transforms the data it’s consuming from a middle layer. (Reads Ignition tags via OPC-UA and converts) I do know Ignition has SpB built into its transmission module so maybe it’s as easy as dropping tags into that module.

Author: hobbes1069
Content: The short answer is HiveMQ doesn't really do anything with your data except accept it from publishers and send it to subscribers. You can contextualize/model the data using tools like Ignition/Highbyte/etc.

Author: dep05d
Content: Another factor is who else may want access to this data in the future.  As Richard said, MQTT will scale better to get that data to an enterprise layer, where 3rd parties, AI/ML, reporting etc systems can access that data without you revisiting the integrations over and over by adding additional opc clients (and risking overloading the opc server and impacting production).

Author: akoscs
Content: However large an OPC UA fanboy I am, I have to say, (time) determinism has not much to do with OPC UA.

Author: jbonhage155
Content: Interesting! So you would say OPC-UA does not have an advantage of MQTT for determinism?

Author: IIoT#4707
Content: GG @Joe Bonhage, you just advanced to level 10!

Author: akoscs
Content: I very much subscribe to the idea that time determinism is not a yes or no question it is a scale. Fieldbuses like CanOpen, EtherCat, Profinet, sercos are what I would use in applications where time deterministic behaviour matters most (eg. Motion control). Here we are talking about sub microsecond jitter and a cycle time (package roundtrip) of 10s os microseconds. This are one end of the spectrum. OPC UA has a round trip time of 10s or low hundreds of milliseconds and a jitter usually around 10-20 milliseconds or larger.  MQTT is arguably worse, but as it is pub sub there is no round trip of the package, but publisher-broker-subscriber comms are used instead of a round trip. Jitter and cycle time might be worse than OPC UA, but OPC UA is already so bad, that I would not use them anywhere where time determinism matters.

Author: geoffnunan
Content:
In my opinion, the advantages of OPCUA over MQTT (Basic MQTT, not sparkplugB) are string typing. 
MQTT payloads are not forced to conform to a schema, so when integrating systems you need to consider how to make sure the publisher and subscriber expect the same payload structure.
SparkplugB addresses this to a level, but introduces a bunch of new headaches.
The other benefit of OPCUA over MQTT are OPCUA Methods, and the ability to retrieve history. 
All of these can be addressed with MQTT though.
The next question may just be native support. If the systems your company has selected have native support for OPCUA and not MQTT, it can be hard to justify the expense of moving it over.

Author: donpancoe
Content: Isn't there also a matter of polling vs report-by-exception here? While the latter is far more bandwidth efficient, bandwidth is *cheap* over a wired and switched Ethernet network within a single physical site. Is polling inherently more deterministic, all else being equal?

Author: walker.reynolds
Content: We are pre-recording the podcast for next week, premiering 2/21.  I will answer this question directly in that podcast.  @Richard Shaw great response, fyi.

Author: walker.reynolds
Content:
Mark, I will be giving a full, comprehensive response today when we pre-record the podcast for next week.  The podcast streams next Tuesday at 12pm CST.  Let me say three things.

1. This is exactly the kind of engagement the large OEMS need to be doing -- you are the very first from a large OEM to have a real technical discussion in good faith
2. My position on Schneider isn't as hard as it seems.  They are doing a lot right -- I put them behind Siemens because of Siemens choice to extract IIoT from the legacy business to encourage innovation unencumbered by existing thinking.  If you look at the IIoT Stack at Siemens and then look at EcoStruxture at Schneider, you can see what I mean.  IA/IE/Mindsphere/Mendix all connected on hub and spoke via Siemens and Open protocols.  EcoStruxture is more convoluted BUT it is a step in the right direction.  I will reference what I mean in the podcast we are about to shoot.
3. I am incredibly grateful for your contribution on this topic -- Schneider is doing a lot of great things.  My position, however, is that Siemens has pivoted more toward open in practice than Schneider (even if Schneider is preaching open in their marketing) -- it is the practice of integrating to open where Siemens has the slight advantage and it is because of how they organized their IIoT business.

I've attached a couple of images that I operate off of when discussing Schneider.

Author: akoscs
Content: No, determinism refers to repearting the same action again and again and getting the same results. Time determinism is again, same results, but refers to the communication time, not the content. MQTT is not inherently report by exception, and report by exception has nothing to do with the time determinism of the communication. I  can publish every second or I can publish whenever the value changes (only the latter is report by exception). No matter if I repeat the request-responce every second for OPC UA the latency will be roughly the same, the variation of the latency will be the jitter. Same for MQTT. Bandwith another way to characterize communications. Obviously all of this is related, but we can still compare latency and jitter fo OPC UA and MQTT while having the same network maximum bandwidth.

Author: rickbullotta
Content: Isn’t OPC UA over TSN intended to address this?

Author: akoscs
Content: TSN addresses this, regardless of what over TSN (profinet over TSN, OPC UA over TSN, X over TSN it could even be modbus TCP over TSN, but not MQTT over TSN :)). To my knowledge of mid 2022 TSN standard for configuring your CNC (Central Network Controller in this case, not the other thing) was not ready yet. CUC (central user configuration) is also not ready. So even if you can have a running TSN network you do not really have a standard way of reserving your timeslots. (knowing when your timeslot to send on the application side is is again somewhat an open issue). It is a work in progress, but hopefully it will end up solving time determinism for ethernet IP-based communications (not Ethernet/IP, just ethernet IP soo many naming collisions....)

Author: akoscs
Content: Here some more ifor on CUC and CNC https://www.ieee802.org/1/files/public/docs2021/dj-ademaj-cnc-cuc-roles-0121-v01.pdf

Author: akoscs
Content: Yep. I do see adoption. I do not agree that it is not an open protocol (kind of implied in the i40 Solutions videos, but you register for free and you get the standards and there is a lot of open source software available from the foundation). I do not agree that the OPC UA foundation is as evil or malice as depicted in some videos. I do think that the companies working on the Comp Specs do actually intend to implement it to their products. I think the comp specs are not perfect, could be improved, but I do not think we will get anything better in the next 10 years and I do think that we do waste a huge amount of workload always developing our own data models for every different application and even an OKish standardized data model is better then reinveinting the wheel every time.  ISE 95 and Sparkplug B is far from an alternative to the Comp Specs. This will probably start a discussion again, but I will keep defending OPC UA not because it is perfect, but because we will not get anything better. It is not the hero we need it is the hero we deserve (or something like that:)) )

If it will ever be ready, I think it will be great but really hard to use until the right tooling comes along, but there are problems for which the solutiosn are are probly 3-5 years away (e.g. re-configuring a running TSN network). My understanding from product managers was that it will never be a large scale thing, as in you will never have TSN straight to the azure data center, maybe DetNet but I know almost nothing about that.

Author: mparris
Content:
@Joe Bonhage Start with asking how many devices or applications do you plan to consume the data.

OPC UA Data Access Client/Server (whew... I'm tired already) architectures will be limited by the capability of the Server such as how many connections can it support.

To avoid heavy integration costs across many devices/application when using OPC UA Data Access Client/Server (this is really getting old...), you will need to evaluate the clients and whether they include an ability to detect when the server's namespace is updated so the client can update is subscription to include the new items. Otherwise, someone will be on the hook to go on every client and manually browse the server and drag the new tags into the client's namespace, which will be a big pain.

With an architecture like Sparkplug (ahh... that's better), a client will typically allow subscribing to the whole namespace, or a group of nodes, a single node, or a device within a node. In each of these cases, the client will automatically receive any update to the publisher's namespace, then it's just a question of can the application do something with new types of data once it arrives. But the point is that Sparkplug is solving the data plumbing problem.

You could consider OPC UA Pub/Sub MQTT JSON (😩) but after all the hoopla over the past year, there are only two products listed as supporting PubSub MQTT, so it's not looking promising...

Author: mparris
Content:
As a comparison, the Sparkplug certification spec was released in December 2022.  While the compatibility list is short, it's way bigger than the two products listed for OPC UA PubSub MQTT...

https://sparkplug.eclipse.org/compatibility/compatible-software/
