Author: markpitout
Content:
Plant SCADA has a long legacy and in my view is getting a bit long in the tooth.(at least in it's current format).  If you have a greenfields project feel free to use your SCADA of choice. If you have a brownfields project feel free to convince the customer to replace and completely reengineer their existing SCADA.

But, aggressively phasing software products out would be pulling the rug out from under a massive install base.  Schneider/Aveva try very hard to provide smooth migration paths when phasing out old products. The backlash I saw at customers when Aveva decided to retire Vijeo Historian in favor of Wonderware historian was massive.

In the case of Plant SCADA, I don't see Aveva phasing it out any time soon, because of install base. It is also used as the base for other products like EcoStruxure Power SCADA and EcoStruxure Process Expert.

Author: akoscs
Content: In theory, could you have a topic structure for SpB and on the same broker a topic structure for nonSpB. You creata a service wich subscribe to all SpB which you need on the non SpB side, decode the SpB message, serialize it to JSOn and publish on the nonSpB side? If I understand SpB correctly, this could work, right? You van even creata a pool and have more of the same services and use them as a consumer group (shared su scription?) so they get load balanced. The broker will have increased load, but otherwise this could work, right?

Author: markpitout
Content:
Okay. That will leave all our customers in the lurch in terms of support. Even if I shared your view that none of those products have a future, simply cancelling further developmemt and support is not only suicide for us reputation wise, but it puts the operations of our customers in danger as well. 

Perhaps you should not speak on behalf of @RickBullotta - I am geniunely interrested to hear his thoughts in more detail. 

Rick previously stated that Aveva/Schneider is in dire need of unification and rationalisation. I agree with him there. But I don't see any quick or easy fixes for that without hurting our customers. So if anyone has any geniune proposals for Aveva/Scheider to unify and rationalise its offer I would be happy to hear it. I would even be willing to try and promote it at Schneider. 

Pointing out a problem is very easy. Proposing a pratical solution that also makes business sense is something completely different. I'm open to good faith debate, but simplistic "Aveva bad" comments don't add any value.

On another note: I think this discussion has strayed away from the topic of Digital Transformation. Perhaps it should rather continue on a different thread dedicated to  OEM related topics.

Author: markpitout
Content:
Thankfully the SCADAPack range has been significantly rationalised, essentially there are only two choices:
SCADAPack 570 / 575 for large applications and 
SCADAPack 470 / 474 for smaller applications.
End of March a third option will be released: SCADAPack 470i / 474i which is the same device as standard 470 / 474, but with an additional CPU, memory and storage for edge  computing applications.

Author: markpitout
Content: And if you are using SCADAPack then I reccomend Geo SCADA (formerly ClearSCADA) every day of the week. Geo SCADA has natively integrated objects for managing the configuration, logic and firmware deployment of SCADAPack controllers over DNP3.

Author: markpitout
Content:
Aside from attending some training and workshops, I don't have much experience with System Plaform. Here I would rather defer to @Loris.
I was raised on Citect, and I am comfortable using it, but in my opinion it is past its prime and has become a bit of a Frankenstein's monster. Citect's current version has inherrited some components from System Platform and Geo SCADA, and other components are old and dated. 

If you compare Citect to any other popular SCADA, it does not have a lot counting in its favour. BUT, Aveva continues to develop it and releasing new versions, so they must see something in it that I do not.

By far my favourite SCADA from our stable is Geo SCADA. It is 100% object oriented. It supported mobile and HTML5 much sooner than our other SCADAs. It is fantastic in telemetry applications. It has a fully fledged integrated historian (for free). It is also IT developer friendly through it's API. 
And, Geo SCADA now also has an MQTT sparkplug driver that supports auto-creation of data objects from birth certificate metrics.
I used to deliver training on Geo SCADA - the full training course that teaches you how to do pretty much everthing, takes only 3 days.  System Platform and Citect require several training courses over multiple weeks each.

Author: markpitout
Content:
Just a slight correction: Aveva does still see a future for Citect (or Plant SCADA as it is now known).
It is also the basis for two other Schneider products: EcoStruxure Power Scada and EcoStruxure Process Expert. So if Aveva retire Citect, they take two other products down with it. Lastly the exisiting install base is so large that they cannot simply retire Citect.

I think Aveva will rather continue to update Plant SCADA - Hopefully they improve it significantly, but that is a massive mountain to climb.

Author: markpitout
Content: Apologies, replied to the wrong post.

Author: paul_o_s
Content:
@Julia Szprengiel  and I are wondering if anyone in the community has a lot of experience with digital transformation on the business side of things.  We are in the process of trying to digitally transform our System Integrator company, Skellig Automation.
For context, we’ve grown over the past 3 or 4 years from about 30 people to 130 people (100 staff and about 30 contractors).  Our systems are manually managed and we have data silos in every area, in short we grew fast and just made it work.
We use Zoho to manage invoices and timesheets, we use Monday as a CRM and office 365 for our IT needs.  
We have engaged a consultant that specializes in technology solutions for business problems.  They are a Microsoft partner.  So far we’ve completed the workshops, and the gap assessment points to overly manual use of Zoho and our CRM, which means we’d get a poor ROI at this point from a warehouse integration.
As part of the community we are full believers in the 4.0 solutions strategy and we thought we could apply the UNS approach to our own SI business data, however we now feel like we need to strongly consider an off the shelf eco system like Microsoft because of the integrations.

Can you successfully apply the UNS model to business operations or do I think about business operations as just API’s and a warehouse? A digital thread approach.   
Is the UNS actually possible for business data? For example, can we safely adopt a Microsoft dynamics platform where we can see the benefits of integration ‘off the shelf’ for MS project being integrated with timesheets and invoicing.  We are already committed to adding a data warehouse and we want to build API’s as needed to connect our systems and historize our data sets but I don’t know how to apply the UNS concept because there is no UNS broker and I’m struggling to argue my case for it.  

I understand why the UNS helps with large scale data from equipment but this feels more like an MES project to me where we are stitching together a quilt of functionality.  Should we nix the option of UNS from our brains for this problem of business data? OR are there business systems out there that meet the 4.0 minimum technical requirements (open arc, report by exception, light weight, edge driven).  Thank you!

Author: jpmoniz
Content: I think there is a huge benefit of trying to capture current state of all business functions regardless of hierarchy or position within your four walls. One of my  commentary on “death by 1000 apps”. Is the inherent schizophrenia businesss are creating by proliferation of technology within an organization.   I think there is undiscovered value by doing so. There has to be some sort of fabric to tie it all together and create a unified view. I think there is a role to play for a concept like the UNS. Nothing wrong with using off the shelf stuff I would worry more about things having sound API that can be leveraged. At some points there has to be integrations.  It’s just where the state of things are today.

Author: sparkylarks
Content: Will you keep the community in the loop. I think it would be a really great help.

Author: brianpribe
Content: I second JPs comment.

Author: sammysevens777
Content:
D365 is an excellent platform - highly extensible with Power platform - which can manage external API calls to interface with applications relatively easy. Automating processes, developing apps etc. One of the reasons we went with the SMB ERP - business central. They do have CRM and lots of other solutions, but it depends on your business needs, accounting requirements etc. I will say this, that regardless of Microsoft or not, you will 100% need to customize your erp, and have an ongoing cadence of doing so, but the tools are all there and it's relatively easy to do.

As for the OT side of the house, there are so many connectors and clever ways to get data from different systems, and whether you want to write to SQL, use JSON/MongoDB etc....the tools are all there and operate on the same principles as the IT side of the house.

The digital thread is more than just data....it really should manage the whole lifecycle of your project - from design to deployment, and the levels of digitization are up to you.

If your challenges are business focused, I'd say call out the KPIs that you need to focus on, and do a time study of your business process. What takes longer time than it should (is it procurement, AP/AR, developing new designs, manufacturing or QC). That will help you level set on your immediate & long term needs. CRM and accounting are important, but as a SI there is a ton more.....get a virtual FAT (real, but collect data digitally) on your roadmap and have that close out manufacturing order automatically...lots of neat ideas here. 

As for a UNS, from what I understand on thjs discord....you may want to roadmap that instead of make it the next goal....once you get your operation and system architecture outlined and in order, you will connect the dots rather than filling the blanks.

Author: jsenquiz
Content: We have a very similar set of challenges, I will be very interested on the advise we can get!!!!!

Author: rickbullotta
Content: Square peg, round hole.

Author: sparkylarks
Content:
I was thinking about this and 
When I started work a lot of the information I needed was in paper. 

We then started using computers and lots.of data got silo'd in people computer( a lot in email).
So then we used file servers so all the information was in the same place but normally unstructured. I have worked places with a really good file structure and discipline but then you still need to know the project that the information you need was in.

MS Teams, gives us a place to collaborate, but really has the same problem.

So the Digitialisation hasn't really helped break.down the information and make it availible. 

Really a great example of how lots of technology applied wrongly doesn't help.

So I think you need to look at software that fits the requirements. But maybe redefine what open means. Consider a node open if you can get the data out, and transform it into you base technology(is MQQT ideal?)

What you really need is a cmt-svr equivalent for Zoho and Monday. And then make sure any other nodes can do the same.

I'm just starting the move from a contractor to an scalable project business. So I need to apply the same requirements. But I need to find open source versions.

Author: nickn5549
Content: I would add the UNS to the roadmap, otherwise, you will end up struggling to connect various silos. In my case, I went on the road of developing apps for all the functions that were critical and on paper and then (5 years later) realised that are too many silos and point-to-point connections to manage.  The UNS/middleman helped link all these silos together and transfer seamlessly information from one App to another. And when I say App - I mean applications like MES, CMMS, QMS tools, NCMR, eIQC, Production Schedule, OWI, Projects, various SCADA, Training, eMSDS....lots of stuff used in manufacturing and business processes.

Author: paul_o_s
Content: Of course @Mark O'Donovan.  we can share everything, including an architecture as things evolve.  As @jpmoniz points out, @Julia Szprengiel is mapping our business, and that's where we need to go back to again to get more clarity.  Even something as simple as a bill rate or an engineer's name is a challenge to track and connect across systems, for example 'O'Sullivan, Paul' in Zoho could be the same person as 'Paul OSullivan' in the CRM or Microsoft 365.  so getting the basics clear and a data model for all our key info seems daunting on going it our own.  As a business it's critical that we have this data mapped and we understand how our business works, everything must be integrated.  The Microsoft Dynamics seems like an attractive easy answer potentially in terms of some out of the box functionality.  We do see the value of the UNS and it's the only thing that will scale in terms of interconnectivity long term.  SO I guess our real question now is to dig into Dynamics to see if we can publish to a UNS.

Author: paul_o_s
Content: I think that is well articulated Mark and we have the exact same hopes.  I think we've made great strides understanding our business at this scale, but our ability to learn and see patterns is piss poor because we don't have a data model like the UNS.  We can make Silo'd improvements with out of the box interconnectivity and if I was advising me on here I'd say 'Oh don't do that, go with open packages and do the hard work of building from scratch without technical debt.' In practice, its a little more daunting because we must know and learn our business.  We will talk through the moving to Microsoft option and we can circle back.  However just asking the question and seeing all your responses has helped solidify that there are no silver bullets or off the shelf solutions.  1. Our digital strategy is simply to be a learning organization that makes data driven decisions to improve the support and experience of our engineers. We believe in putting the engineer first, so they in turn can put our client first.  2. We need to tighten up our minimum technical requirements and stick to our guns on a UNS architecture that will help us scale and learn our business long term.  I know this is where things get shitty for engineers because if we don't have a coherent data driven understand of each engineer and what's next for them, what kind of projects are fulfilling etc we wont hold up our end of the bargain as a company, and we'll be the next SI that, 'well they were good to work for until they got big, then they got sloppy'.  Caring needs understanding and understanding needs data.

Author: rickbullotta
Content: Just that the architectural model for a UNS as generally described here is not ideal for enterprise app to app integration - that is usually as much of a process integration challenge as a data integration challenge, along with the master data challenges and more transient nature of entities such as shipments, orders, etc.

Author: paul_o_s
Content: On @RickBullotta I assume you mean Microsoft dynamics and making those kinds of choices are not fit for purpose if the purpose is an efficient and scalable business.

Author: IIoT#4707
Content: GG @paul osullivan, you just advanced to level 4!

Author: paul_o_s
Content: Oh not what I expected you to think Rick.  Would you agree though that the UNS represents one data model for an entire business and the goal of a business with coherent data needs one data model.  Hence the ideal business has an end to end integration via a UNS?

Author: paul_o_s
Content: The hard work inside each area of the business needs to be able to reference a single data model for efficiency.  I'm formerly a process control guy, with no real understanding of MES but one of the reasons it seems MES is such a challenge is because of the lack of a coherent data model, such as the UNS.  So MES has silos and work arounds that compound complexity.  I feel I'm falling into the same trap but at a business level because I just want stuff that's out of the box integrated or just has the functionality I need. But without the discipline to insist it pulls and pushes data in and out so we have don't have a bill rate for an engineer in the CRM that's a copy of the one in Zoho people and possibly different again in Zoho analytics or project.  I think I'm falling into building an enterprise MES type solution (to put it in OT terms).

Author: rickbullotta
Content: I know from life experience that this is impractical for a business of any significant size. Not just for technical reasons but for practicality and data ownership/fiefdom reasons.  There are also business integrity/security risks to consider with “one UNS to rule them all”. A virtuous goal in the abstract, but largely unachievable in the real world for large, diverse businesses.

Author: paul_o_s
Content: @RickBullotta  ah.  OK.  And yes, I see the challenges you see.  There has to be a way though? Is there a way you could see this work?  Just so I understand... So at scale, you'd recommend a patch work quilt of API's (MES style) that do what they need to do and digital thread to key info outside the app as needed because that gives you security advantages?  In your experience how do you consolidate key information across API's? By the way, @RickBullotta  I really respect all you've achieved and I really value your input on this

Author: rickbullotta
Content: “It depends”.  If the objective is to create a data Lake from the historical exhaust of OT and IT systems, I think there are best practices taking shape. If you’re talking about cross-business-boundary or cross-application process integration, another set of tools and best practices. And if you’re talking near-real time event driven integration of OT stuff, the best practices discussed here are proven to work well.

Author: sparkylarks
Content: Even just taking names, what happens when people change their name. Without Integration you get two systems with two different names , and noone realizes that they are the same person. I do know this is a big problem with HR systems in Excel, things like marriages and children get missed and you can find someone's child isn't on the Medical Plan. And the employee has no way to check.  But you really don't want a name change to end up with the wrong bill rate going on a customers invoice.

Author: jon.forbord
Content: In short Rick is right, but he’s also wrong. You’re thinking of the UNS as an integration layer purely, and in that case you’re right, mqtt is not natively built to support transactions in that way, and there are other tools that are easier to use for these types of integrations. I believe this is a perfectly valid approach, but I’d keep the UNS as a place for shared events and state. That being said, there is a case to be made for «do as I say, not as I do”. If you’re an integrator professing the “industry 4.0 approach”, you better be willing to use the same approach to your own business. I would strongly hesitate to hire an integrator who clearly is not digitally transformed to digitally transform our business.

Author: jpmoniz
Content: This is the problem when viewing things from an application approach vs data centric approach. Utopians say there should only one definition of a person and build api around that definition for applications to interact with. The reality of that means an entirely custom ecosystem. Not something any business would be willing to take on.

Author: jpmoniz

Author: sparkylarks
Content: General Question. My LinkedIn is full of Digital Transformation colleagues. I I regularly see the claim that Digital Transformation plans fail because people focus on Technology and not enough on People and Process.  That statement is really starting to annoy me. I'm not saying that people and process are not important. My issues are

Author: sparkylarks
Content: 1. How do we  measure focus

Author: sparkylarks
Content: 2. Is it true. Is there evidence to support this?

Author: sparkylarks
Content: It seam to me to be a circular argument. DT fails because of not enough focus on people and processes. So if a project fails it must be because there was not enough focus on peoples and processes. So if those projects all failed becuase of not enough focus on peopls and process we can say DT fails because of not enough focus on People and Processes.

Author: sparkylarks
Content: 3. Even if it is true. How do I track the "focus" on people and processes on my Digital Transformation to make sure I am focusing enough on People and processes. What is my KPI? Is there a focusometer I can use

Author: sparkylarks
Content: Rant Over

Author: sammysevens777
Content: It is annoying because it's a truism....i think the intent of that statement is that technology is not the issue

Author: sammysevens777
Content:
1: measure focus by progress, if you're not moving the needle, then no focus

2: i think proof is in the pudding here....we have better robots than ever, PLCs are more flexible than ever, ERP is cloud ready, analytics are easier to perform, more comm. available, etc....so we dont have tech problems, we have people problems

3: I think (and credit to walker here), but from my anecdotal experience as well ,it s all about education....if the people owning the process today arent a part of digitally transforming it, then thats a bad thing....however if they are educated and are now proponents, leading change.....then the magic happens

Author: sparkylarks
Content: Management of change is a huge piece of any project and eve more so any transformation. But that is a bit like saying Finanacial reform is not about banks it;s about people because ultimetly people use banks and we need those people to lead the change and we need to engage to understand their need.

Author: sparkylarks
Content: And a lot is how do we define focus on Technology

Author: sparkylarks
Content: If I engae with Intellic, to bring  on resoursces, to build a UNS, Is that focusing on People. I put that as Technology. Even more so when doing a DTMA type exercise and building a strategy, of course people are at the Center but that is tech focused too.

Author: sparkylarks
Content: If DT was building great products using great technology, and people were not using them because of lack of engagement and education. I would agree we need to focus on people and education. But any DT failures I have seen is because poor technological choices were made. mostly being solution centered, or using legacy technology.

Author: sparkylarks
Content: I did once discuss a project that had more change champions than developers. I point that as a lack of focus on technology, but the claim was that was a resourcing and thus people problem.

Author: sparkylarks
Content: My analogy is that , If I am building a house, and I focus on the clients and make sure they are engages and excited. but I use poor building technology, so I build my house out of mud and reed instead of concrete blocks etc. The house will probably fall down. If I over focus on the technology and build a technologically superior house, with lots of useful features, great insulation, soundproof bedroom's ..... but I missed some engagement with the clients as to their desire, then they are more likely to come around.

Author: sammysevens777
Content:
To the point about banks - i think that is different....that is about govt. policy reform, bureaucracy etc. somewhat different than digital transformation for a business 

As for making poor technology choices, that is a problem. However, on the inverse, you can also choose the best tech, but have no buy-in, and no users = failed transformation

Author: sparkylarks
Content: I agree, but I would argue that if you fail because of no buy in but have the right tech you have some hope of getting the buy in and saving the process

Author: sammysevens777
Content: Lack of the right personnel is also an issue, and if that is the case, then was the right tech stack selected? Maybe needed more ots solutions vs. develop (buy instead of make)....

Author: sparkylarks
Content: If you have the wrong technology and load of buy in , the solution won't work and you will lose the users, and can't save the transformation

Author: sammysevens777
Content: Yes both are true

Author: sammysevens777
Content: I will say it is a truism, so its true because it is true....but you are clearly more aware of the nuances of that statement...most people on LI talking digital transformation just talk sh** and regurgitate

Author: sparkylarks
Content: People and Processes are  key in any Transformation.  If I am doing a canteen Menu transformation, I need to engage with the staff and customers to find a the right menu for those customers, and engaging with the staff to make sure that the menu can be delivered. Depending on the canteen location , Tech company/manufacturing plant/mine/building site, the menu composition may change and rightly so.

Author: sparkylarks
Content: One of my favorite sayings is " There are two types of questions, easy ones and ones you don't know the answer to". OF course it is easy if you know how. But if you don't know and you don't focus on technology and don't investigate the technological options, you can use OPC UA to gather you information then have a Wonderware or Rockwell MES, with a few custom add ons. The statefull representation of the business, is incomplete and stored in Databases which makes it difficult to convert the data into information or actionable intelligence, and building to the higher functions in DT such as ML, AI or a digital supply chain is not possible. I consider my self a reasonably intelligent and reasonably competent engineer, and I did. I am sure lots of others here did too. What I am gaining on the discord and in mastermind and mentor ship and by watching all the videos of Walker I have is mainly technical knowledge. Some knowledge of how to capture processes and a good dollop of how to bring people along with the vision . But I see that as more focus on Technology. Classifying it in the people bucket as not my future DT team can have the right skill set seams disingenuous to me.

Author: sparkylarks
Content: Ultimately I think the people calling for more focus on people and process are non technical people, trying to increase their own Pie. We need Engineers not Consultants. ( Taking the view that Engineers are people who build things of value and Consultant are people who take your watch and charge your for telling you the time)

Author: marioishikawa
Content: Do you know the main differences that came on Sparkplug v 3.0.0? Or is it just document format as mentioned on the changelog?

Author: rickbullotta
Content:
I just entered a pull request on the roadmap, adding the following items:
* Expand Sparkplug Aware MQTT Server definition to include automatic expansion of DATA and BIRTH metric content into individual topics
* Expand Sparkplug Aware MQTT Server definition to a REST API for querying metadata
* Expand Sparkplug Aware MQTT Server definition to a REST API for querying most recent data and for connectionless publishing of DATA and BIRTH messages
* Add strong data typing for inputs and output to commands as part of BIRTH or METADATA
* Implement a reliable request/response mechanism so that commands can return data, error codes, or other result content
* Consider eliminating group/node/edge IDs altogether and allowing a flexible hiearchy using namespace/message_type/any_hiearchy (note that this would not break existing apps given a new namespace for the next version of SpB)
* Add new primitive types for location and generic JSON
* Separate data and metadata in BIRTH messages and leverage the MQTT retain flag to optimize/minimize load on edge nodes and to enable application tooling to discover metadata even if an edge node is offline
* Clarify which components of a Sparkplug metric are mandatory and which are optional

Author: thedavidschultz
Content: The goal was to create a proper specification. The previous was similar to a white paper. It also added support for MQTT 5. The focus now is adding features for what will become 4.0.0 with a SpC topic.

Author: marioishikawa
Content: Thank you!

Author: jon.forbord
Content: Upvote from me on eliminating group/node/device altogether! And really also most of the rest!

Author: rickbullotta
Content: Any you’d change/have other suggestions?

Author: jon.forbord
Content: Ow.. where to begin.. nah, they’re pretty much covered, but on the top my list has been get rid of the whole node/device-thing and allow any hierarchy of topics, and don’t even know if this is possible, but allow several nodes to publish within a topic so you can create aggregated namespaces from multiple nodes (like you can with flat mqtt), and a bunch of the ones on your list. I’m not too high on the SpB aware broker requirements, but I also don’t oppose to them.

Author: jon.forbord
Content: TVQ should be required, and Q codes should be limited to Bad, uncertain or good. Sub codes can be a separate non-required property..

Author: rickbullotta
Content: The enhanced broker stuff is to make it MUCH easier for other enterprise apps to publish and consume data without the complexity of connections and subscriptions.

Author: jon.forbord
Content: Some of the optimization suggestions I don’t necessarily agree with if the come at increased complexity cost, but that’s on a more general level. Don’t fall into the trap of over-optimization at the cost of increased complexity.

Author: dep05d
Content: Can someone please explain the reasoning of the sparkplug-aware feature to retain birth messages on $sparkplug/certificates/namespace/group_id/DBIRTH/edge_node_id/device_id, vs just retaining the DBIRTH message itself?

Author: mparris
Content:
The DBIRTH payload itself is retained. It is then stored at that topic path.

So if there is a DBIRTH published at:

spBv1.0/my equipment/DBIRTH/bestNodeEva/slowDevice

Then that device birth certificate can be retrieved later by subscribing to:

$sparkplug/certificates/spBv1.0/my equipment/DBIRTH/bestNodeEva/slowDevice

Author: mparris
Content: Keeping the original topic path intact allows clients to specify which DBIRTHs they want to retrieve, rather than all of them.

Author: rickbullotta
Content: Are you sure? I was under the impression that by definition (with the current spec) it should NOT be retained but instead re-requested by each client/subscriber when they connect.

Author: mparris
Content: I'm speaking specifically about the Sparkplug aware server that the spec calls out, which stores birth certificates in $sparkplug/certificates/#

Author: geoffnunan
Content:
I've seen the difference that people can make to performance without revolutionary technology. One of our customers has over 60 manufacturing sites spread around the world. Many of the sites are exactly the same. Make the same products, use exactly the same machines, and have exactly the same data.
These sites consistently run around 50 - 60 % OEE, except one of them, which consistently runs in the high 80s. That one (in Poland) actually drive continual improvement through management discipline, and the others do not.
People still hold the keys to 90% of the potential improvement opportunity in operations.

Author: geoffnunan
Content:
The reality is that even with the best analytic engine, a lack of management discipline and accountability will prevent improvement.
The vice-versa is not true. Management with discipline and accountability can improve even without a fancy analytics engine. They can and do manage with paper and clipboards when required.
The critical factor is not the analytics engine.
I'm not saying you should not have one, I am saying that you need both, and we as the technology people tend to forget about the people side

Author: benjaminsynsor
Content:
@Walker Reynolds  i am currently trying to understand, how our vision AI fits into a "future proof" technology stack and what that means for us. You mentioned that the digital thread as an approach has issues (one-way communication mainly) that UNS does not have. But you also mention Boeing as a company that is at the forefront of "getting it right" - they use digital thread. What I do see is that Boeings digital thread (see image) goes way beyond the production process (which UNS seems to be focused around in my eyes) both before and after production (from design to flight tests). Does that hint to a future in which production centric data (from CRM to WMS) generally lives in the UNS, while other data lives in a digital thread that "surrounds" the UNS (and the UNS is a data producer for the digital thread)? As we want to help control the behaviour of PLCs based on analytics results generated elsewhere (cloud etc.), oneway like digital thread would literally prevent our approach from functioning if not everything is done on-prem (and noone wants 15 boxes from 15 vendors sitting next to every line/cell). Then again, how do we sell to a company like Boeing then, if they use digital thread in production? Their case-calculation would never turn positive because of the engineering effort involved i would assume?
Sorry if my metaphors might be a bit off, I'm still fairly new to all of this.

Content:
I'm pushing a few topics at Tulip that I really think they need to add/improve to the platform:

- The ability to display "other people's data" from other apps, integrated into Tulip workflows

Author: douga.7429
Content:
I recently left my position as an MES expert building front end information systems over this question of what is a connected or real-time solution at the OT layer.  I interest of answering your question I think we first have to acknowledge that MES was meant to connect the enterprise planning around what was needed to support manufacturing and reporting on the actual manufacturing was a strategy to make a manufacturing "connected". So it technically can't just be OT.

This group and myself needed OT solutions to create this and exploring this topic made me realize I was not going to be able to influence the organization I was in without an intervention and that is why the DTMA should be the approach for creating shared information on this subject.

If I was influencing for the right OT approach, I would focus on IoT and get the infrastructure that supports it. The resistance comes often in that 3.0 approach has was to make it all work it is just to hard.  So an OT piolet should establish results and meet the changed expectations that come with IoT.  This is that like a Nest thermostat or Ring doorbell you expect that out of the box you will be able to seamlessly integrate and control it with your phone and have data for analytics by default.  And adding additional devices will be effortless and scale to infinity.

I think we need a new standard and alliteration like MES that rejects MES and starts anew. When MES was made the "Connected" enterprise at best would run planning once a week.  Now we want to react to demand signals within minutes.  I have been exploring this subject and been kicking around a concept I called Enterprise Manufacturing Unification(EMU) to try to bring many of the learnings that have come from Walker and the community together.  It is good to have this time to work with GPT-4 and consolidate theses thoughts while  industry 5.0 seems to be the next driving wave upon us now.

Author: sammysevens777
Content:
Its the legacy stuff in OT that makes it hard for IoT (i think)....otherwise, i think MES is fine, so long as we recognize it is as much a "system" as an ERP, in that it is not just a database, or even workflows, but an entire platform that orchestrates mfg. process from ERP...hence why  Walker says MES is built.

If we allow MES to focus on planning, orchestration and work order assignment, then we can focus on the more machine-to-machine and connectivity tasks (iot etc.) which probably should be handled in lower layers (PLC, SCADA etc.). 

If the main bottleneck is recalculating plan, especially for larger orgs. - then i still think this is an MES task, but perhaps there are clever ways to recalculate only based on the specific updates required at this time, rather than recalculate the entire plan (e.g. optimize for a window of time - based on new inputs). That could affect downstream for sure, but i understand the pain you are acknowledging, which is constant replanning which is time consuming and waste of compute....

Author: douga.7429
Content:
The idea that Enterprise planning should dictate to the plant floor has been an issue for some time, and this has only been exacerbated by the integration of computer automation solutions such as the Toyota model. The ISA-95 semantic model and other universal definitions for manufacturing make sense, but the subsequent idea that Manufacturing Execution Systems (MES) should be the center of the enterprise integration has created SQL implementations of MES that lack the ability to dynamically determine what transpired and why a Work Order (WO) took more time or varied from its expectations.

Planning is now expected to change in real time, and multiple plans and forecasts must be evaluated in the same timeframe. With companies increasingly turning to GPT like models to build smart systems, these "intelligent" perspectives are able to act in near-real-time. This tight coupling of plans and reporting actions creates a need to know not only what happened, but also the reasoning behind it, as this data can be used to monitor actions as well as the model itself. As such, a new paradigm has emerged where data creates programs instead of programs creating data.

Author: douga.7429
Content:
This is how ChatGPT thinks of POMS does it sound right?

The POMS MES approach was developed by POMS Corporation, a company founded in 1987 that specialized in providing software solutions for production operations management. POMS Corporation was headquartered in California, USA, and had offices in Europe and Asia.

POMS Corporation offered a range of software products and services, including the POMS MES platform, which was designed to help manufacturing companies optimize their production processes and improve their overall operational efficiency.

In 2017, POMS Corporation was acquired by Werum IT Solutions, a German-based company that specializes in providing software solutions for the pharmaceutical and biotech industries. The POMS MES platform is now marketed under the name "Werum PAS-X MES" and is part of Werum's suite of manufacturing execution systems.

Author: douga.7429
Content:
did GPT-4 get it right

"POMS Corporation was founded in 1987 and was an early pioneer in Manufacturing Execution Systems (MES) technology. The POMS MES platform was indeed ahead of its time, offering a comprehensive solution for managing and optimizing manufacturing processes in industries such as pharmaceuticals, biotechnology, and consumer goods.

The POMS MES platform provided a low-code environment, which allowed users to develop and deploy applications with minimal coding effort. This made it easier for non-technical staff to customize and adapt the system to their specific needs.

Some key features of the POMS MES platform included:

Form/UX Builder: This feature enabled users to design and customize user interfaces and forms, allowing for a better and more efficient user experience.
Scripting and Rules: The platform supported scripting and rule-based logic, which allowed users to define and automate workflows and processes based on their specific requirements.
Real-time Integration with SCADA and PLCs: The POMS MES platform integrated seamlessly with Supervisory Control and Data Acquisition (SCADA) systems and Programmable Logic Controllers (PLCs), enabling real-time communication and data exchange between the MES and the plant floor.
The POMS MES platform was widely recognized for its innovative approach and played a significant role in shaping the evolution of MES technology. However, as with many early technology pioneers, POMS Corporation faced challenges in the rapidly evolving MES market. Over time, several other MES platforms emerged, offering new features, improved functionality, and modern technology stacks.

Although the POMS MES platform may not be as widely used today, it is important to acknowledge its contributions to the development of modern MES solutions. POMS Corporation's innovative approach laid the groundwork for many of the features and capabilities that are now considered standard in contemporary MES platforms."

Author: douga.7429
Content:
Several MES systems offer more flexibility to accommodate deviations from planned routing, asset use, and item consumption. Some of the leading MES solutions known for their adaptability and advanced features include:

Siemens Simatic IT: Siemens' Simatic IT is a scalable MES solution that supports a wide range of manufacturing processes and industries. Its modular architecture and comprehensive feature set make it highly adaptable, allowing it to address complex and dynamic manufacturing scenarios.

Rockwell Automation FactoryTalk: FactoryTalk is an MES solution provided by Rockwell Automation that offers real-time visibility, control, and synchronization across manufacturing operations. Its customizable features and integration capabilities enable it to handle a variety of manufacturing challenges, including deviations from planned routing and asset allocation.

GE Digital Plant Applications: GE Digital's Plant Applications is an MES solution that provides advanced capabilities for production, quality, maintenance, and process management. Its configurable modules and extensive integration capabilities make it suitable for addressing complex manufacturing scenarios.

Author: douga.7429
Content:
AVEVA Manufacturing Execution System (formerly Wonderware MES): AVEVA's MES solution is known for its adaptability and configurability. It offers extensive features, such as workflow management, performance monitoring, and integration with various automation and business systems, enabling it to handle a wide range of manufacturing challenges.

SAP Manufacturing Execution: SAP's Manufacturing Execution system provides end-to-end visibility, control, and optimization of manufacturing processes. Its integration with SAP's ERP system and other business applications allows for better communication and adaptability in managing deviations from planned routing and asset utilization.

These MES solutions are known for their flexibility and adaptability, which can help address the issues you mentioned. However, it is essential to evaluate each solution based on your specific requirements, industry, and manufacturing environment to determine the most suitable MES system for your needs.

Content: If the AI doesn't work, that probably needs to be the first thing to focus on. I think "not working" is a bad foot to start off on. But, assuming it works then the biggest cost in automation is integration. The less expensive you make it to integrate and work with the customers' tech stacks, the better. I'll pay more for a system that integrates into my ecosystem well over something that is nominally "better" but I can't use the data coming off of it without hundreds of hours of integration work.

Author: stollaker
Content: I would appreciate input about how systems/historians handle data from an IOT sensor. In particular I'm interested in sensors on LoRaWAN. I work for a company that manufactures and sells self-powered, wireless (LoRa), revenue grade, hot-installed current sensors. All data (amps, amp-hours, etc) comes in with a timestamp. However, packets may get lost because of network loading etc. Do all of the modern systems/historians handle data like this? How is the missing data handled?

Author: sammysevens777
Content:
I think this issue comes down to how you want to handle it:
- if no new data, persist last data point with "last updated" timestamp....know your average message stats

- from data science perspective, there are a variety of "imputation" techniques to fill in missing data (and keep in mind statisticslly relevant metrics as to wby data is missing)

- add some more SW checks to handshake data has been received

If your data is mission critical, maybe LoRa is not the best approach? I setup a facility with LoRa WAN - it was excessive and we didnt need LoRa (some exec had a LoRa IoT device they sponsored, so we had to use it )

Author: rickbullotta
Content: You could also partner up with someone like MyDevices and leverage their backend/infrastructure and also sell your sensors through their channels and online prescence.

Author: stollaker
Content: We use myDevices and they are a great partner. However, there are a lot of customers that don't want their data to leave their facility. My question above is based on a number of people stating that customers won't be able to handle typical LoRaWAN data because the customer won't have the ability to cleanse the data - i.e. fill in missing packets, etc. I'm used to DCS and PLC systems where historians are designed to read the data. IOT is a little different where the data may or may not be received and the timestamp is sent with the packets. This may be easily handled. I don't have experience in this area and know that a lot of companies are moving to LoRaWAN devices and I'm curious how they're handling the data.

Content: *grabs popcorn*

Author: akoscs
Content: This is not an easy topic. There is a OPC UA which in many cases refers to a server - client architecture based communication protocol. This is fairly well established with some lesser known subvariants and possible compatibility issues. PbSub exists in some open source libraries but is not yet adopted by equipment manufacturers on a larger scale.

Author: asthomas
Content: We have a SCADA-in-the-cloud managed service available on Microsoft Azure.  Choose "create a resource" and search for Skkynet DataHub.  You can send data to it using MQTT or DHTP (DataHub Tunnelling Protocol) from machines or plants.  If you just have I/O gateways like Red Lion routers, you can connect directly from the I/O to the cloud.  If your system is distributed already, like a pipeline monitoring system, then this is not much different from running your own aggregation server. For larger systems you probably want to run a hybrid model - run a local DataHub in the plant and then tunnel the data to the Azure instance.  The idea is that if you lose the connection to the cloud your plant will still run just fine, and if you have the connection to the cloud then you will have (optionally restricted) access from anywhere.  The Youtube video you linked touches on several important issues, but many of them are well addressed by a hybrid system.  That video is 11 years old and was created to cast doubt on the use of cloud.  Since then that same vendor now promotes a cloud SCADA service.

Author: asthomas
Content: I've never quite worked out the use case for OPC UA Pub/Sub.  AFIK it was designed to deal with the problem of keeping plant networks isolated while still being able to see the data outside the plant.  Pub/Sub isn't really a publish/subscribe model at all - it's a broadcast model. The server in the isolated network blindly sends a UA-encoded packet either to an MQTT broker or a UDP broadcast address (though I guess it could be unicast, too), and hopes that some listener will pick it up.  The only case I see for it is implementing dashboards or external historians where the information is allowed to be inconsistent with the source some of the time.  Have you run into other uses for it?

Author: akoscs
Content: MQTT is pub/sub not broadcast. OPC UA over MQTT or AMQP is also pub/sub not broadcast.

Author: asthomas
Content: That depends on your perspective.  Yes, MQTT is pub/sub from the point of view of the receiver, but it is broadcast from the point of view of the transmitter.  OPC UA pub/sub is intended to be agnostic to the transport layer, so the MQTT and UDP versions have the same semantics from the point of view of the transmitter.  The primary point is that the OPC UA transmitter has no idea whether its message was received by anybody.  In a client-server pub/sub arrangement the publisher is aware of who is subscribed, and knows whether the subscriber has received a message.

Author: akoscs
Content: What do you mean by a client server pub sub arrangement? Do you mean a brokerless pub sub?

Author: asthomas
Content: The publish/subscribe pattern consists of a source of data (the publisher) managing a data set that might consist of multiple tags, points, topics, whatever you want to call them.  Consumers of data connect to that source and express an interest in one or more topics.  Subsequently, the publisher will notify the consumer that a significant event, like a data change, has occurred on one of the subscribed topics.  That's the way OPC DA, OPC UA, MQTT brokers and other tools work.  We used to call that report-by-exception, but publish/subscribe is a more understandable term.  Publish/subscribe systems do not require a broker.  It just describes the communication between the client and the server, whether the server is a broker or a direct source of data.

Author: akoscs
Content: The publish subscribe pattern makes no underlying architectural assumptions. It is a communications pattern, not an arch pattern.   It also does not make any assumptions about the contetn of the message. By specifying report by exception you make an assumption that the message content is an event or it a value change. You can publish the same value thousands of times, pub sub is not inherently report by exception, report by exception is just one way to use a pub sub pattern These are all irrelevant for the pub sub communications pattern and so is the existence of a broker or not. If a broker is used or not is an architectural choice of implementing the comms pattern.

Author: karltbraun
Content: Question for the group:  Do you think the current trends in Generative AI is going to knock manufacturers (and others) off of the Digital Transformation game?  I can see business leaders focusing on 'retooling' their work force and not moving forward with DT strategies.

Author: douga.7429
Content:
I have been thinking about this too.  I was thinking of pitching an idea for a reoccurring video series.  Typically, Industry 4.0 solutions focus on DT methods they succeeded with; however, with the rapid pace of AI advancement, it seems like just keeping up is overwhelming.  I hope the community can be leveraged to discern significant advances and integration methods and consolidate thinking.  This would require more collaborative engagement because reference implementations are now emerging.  

I imagined the AGI would be described as a criminal investigation, borrowing a concept from detective movies and using a "Link Analysis Board" to visualize connections between different research domains.  For the 4.0 solutions community, AIG should be considered achieved when AI can be relied on to schedule daily work activities, planned activities, and assignments.  The measure should be AIG based on results, not philosophical arguments about consciousness or emotional awareness.

This would help innovative companies adapt to capabilities and understand how close we are to this AGI capability and who will be displaced by what and when—for example, the capabilities of AI agents, Vector Databases for extended memory, Stanford models that are open source, licensing, and user agreements, extending and training models, new more capable models.

Content: From what I see, it's always a game of returns and actual value created. Business Leaders (from my experience) are hesitant to get too much in the weeds, and while digital transformation sounds exciting, my guess is only a subset of those people in that "space", are actually equipped to drive these initiatives (breadth more than depth). However, Chat GPT has broken that 4th wall - its value is immediately understood, and honestly it works quite well. There isn't a day that goes by now that I don't use Chat GPT to generate code for me, write a prompt, or discuss an idea/concept. For this reason....yes, I agree that Generative AI will be a distractor to Digital Transformation. However I think the hardest part about DT is the breadth - and for this reason, I think the guys that can integrate Generative AI into DT - will come out with the "winning" strategies.

Author: sparkylarks
Content:
Yes. Sort of. For major programs, the effect will be less, and the spend will need to be justified by predicted value.
But for proof of concept or R&D type expenditure, AIG is more Zeitgeisty so it is more likely to win a funding round if the values is less defined.
OF course the predicted value can be hard to quantify, and if I can claim a 10X productivity for AIG against a Digital Transformation where some initiatives have failed to deliver against the predicted value .

In some companies there will be leadership people who decide to back the AI horse because they think it can win and if they are seen as the backer and AI delivers value then they are seen as hot stuff.
And many companies won't do the investigative planning that might lead to a strategy to incorporate AI into the Digital Transformation and only look to leverage it after a certain amount of Transformation has been achieved

Author: douga.7429
Content: I have been considering Conway's Law and how data architects love to refer to it.  When models gain perspectives that are much wider than what a human can absorb across and organization the need for communications across domains will decrees.  The UNS also decreased the need to communicate as well and that has value to when applied to Conway's law.  My prediction is that we will soon want to work more closely with AI so we don't have to deal with all these folks in the middle, trying to prove their value.  The AI will always be working always be attentive and always be professional and we will quick lose tolerance for normal human weaknesses.

Author: mparris
Content:
There can be confusion based on what part of the system is in scope for the discussion.

In an MQTT architecture, from the top-level perspective (ignore the broker in the middle), the source of the data publishes and interested consumers subscribe. This is commonly understood as a publish/subscribe architecture.

Now diving down a level to the MQTT broker... There are technically two client/server relationships: 1) the publisher to the broker and 2) the consumer to the broker.

You are correct that the source of the data is blindly sending to the broker, even if no consumers are listening. Even worse, as @akos stated, an MQTT publisher can send out values that are duplicates. Or worse yet, the publisher is sending out data faster than anyone wants it. The combinations can continue at nauseum.

Now, compare this MQTT setup to a hypothetical system where a subscriber says they want data and the broker blindly polls all the clients asking if they have that data. Is this any better than the typical MQTT broker scenario?

So, if you don't like those two systems, you want the broker to know what data is available so the consumers can browse the data and subscribe to only the data that is available, and the broker knows exactly what sources to poll for the data. The benefit of this scenario is that nothing is being sent from the data source to the broker until a subscriber says that they want it. A subscriber could even specify the max publish rate, the % change required before sending, etc.

This is exactly the description of an OPC UA Aggregating Data Broker, which I outlined the concept in the section "Building Communication Infrastructure" in my article here:
https://iebmedia.com/technology/iiot/how-all-protocols-fail-at-data-access-interoperability/

Pure OPC Aggregation servers include Matrikon Data Broker and Softing Secure Integration Server. Products with more diverse connectivity include HighByte Intelligence Hub, OPC Router, and Cogent DataHub.

Author: mparris
Content:
It sounds nice, but there are challenges:

1) while MQTT publishers send data blindly, there is simplicity for the consumers... They get all data within a topic of interest, even as new publisher come online that the consumer didn't know about before. With an OPC UA Aggregating server, the consumer needs to be notified everytime new topics are available, the consumer would then browse the broker to see if it cares about the data, and if it does, it would then subscribe. This is a heavy lift for applications, and there is zero market standardization around that function (what would a software datasheet say to tell me it supports that concept?)

2) the Aggregating servers are clients to the sources of data (servers) which is against the grain of firewalls. OPC UA offers reverse connect, but again, low market availability.

3) OPC UA Aggregating servers are super specialized, getting real-world usage in obscure industrial use-cases. Compare that to MQTT brokers that get hammered by the market from all kinds of use-cases making the product more resilient.

Author: mparris
Content:
It sounds like your definition of publish/subscribe hinges on the location of the data source filter function.

For example, the "publisher" in your example (typical OPC UA Data Access mechanisms, by the way) only sends changed data. Well, how does the publisher get the data to begin with? Very likely a polling mechanism on some cyclic frequency, then the publisher application looks at every value coming in, sees if it meets the filter criteria to be considered "changed" and, if so, sends it out. So, the filter function in your example, resides inside the publisher.


Now consider MQTT... Here, the filter function moves from inside the publisher to within the subscriber's application. Does that make it less publish/subscribe? I don't think so... Maybe less efficient for some use-cases, but it's still publish subscribe in the end.

Author: mparris
Content:
Depends what you mean by "exist"

Some food for thought:

1) The OPC Foundation president says they "love MQTT".

2) a year ago, the OPC Foundation stated in a press release that six major IOT Vendors support or will support OPC over MQTT.

3) the OPC Foundation released the Product Marketplace to help end-users and Integrators find products. Today, two products are listed as supporting OPC UA via MQTT:
https://opcfoundation.org/products/?filter=31

Author: sammysevens777
Content: Can I ask a question about #1 (excellent posts btw - going to read the article too). You mention *With an OPC UA Aggregating server, the consumer needs to be notified everytime new topics are available the consumer would then browse the broker to see if it cares about the data, and if it does, it would then subscribe *. This is a great observation, and do you have a solution in mind? Could the consumer configure which topic notifications they're interested in, or is that like a bandaid to the problem?

Author: asthomas
Content: I think we are saying the same thing here.  Pub/sub in a broad sense is simply this:  the subscriber tells the publisher what it is interested in, and the publisher sends messages when it decides they are relevant to that subscription.  That could be a data change, or the same message thousands of times, as you point out.  The determination of what is relevant is left to the publisher.  We used to call that report-by-exception, but some people have a narrower definition of "relevant" that only considers data value changes.

Author: asthomas
Content: Comparing OPC UA and MQTT in general terms is tricky.  In UA there are two actors - the server and the client.  In MQTT there are three - the broker, a source client and a consumer client.  Yes, the connection between the UA client and server is pub/sub.  It happens to use long polling under the hood, but that is hair-splitting.  In MQTT, the connection between the consumer and broker is pub/sub, analogous to UA.  However, in MQTT the connection between the source client and the broker is broadcast.  The source has no idea whether its message has reached zero, one or many subscribers. If you expand your view of the system to include the PLC, the chain of certainty between the PLC and the consumer client in UA is preserved.  The server and client can both know whether a value from the PLC has arrived at the client, and whether a write from the client has arrived at the PLC.  In MQTT, that chain of certainty is broken by the broadcast behavior inherent in the source-to-broker connection.  When OPC UA uses MQTT for its "pub/sub" implementation, it loses its chain of certainty and takes on the behavior of a broadcast system.

Author: rickbullotta
Content: Absolutely nothing stops an MQTT publisher from also applying deadbands and change rules prior to publishing though.  We shouldn't blame supposed technical "purity" for not implementing best practices.

Author: rickbullotta
Content: Also, there's no reason that notification rules need to be asymmetric (e.g. put all the burden on the client) - all three participants (publisher, broker, subscriber) could conceivably manage this.  This is a GREAT example of why lack of topic metadata, and particularly durable topic metadata, is a FATAL FLAW in MQTT today. Sparkplug DOES NOT ADDRESS THIS in a good or complete way.

Author: jermuk
Content:
In general, there are two approaches for failover:
1. Primary/secondary like a lot of OT solutions have. "Send everything to primary, if it's offline for x seconds, send it to secondary instead"
2. Clustering. "Connect to one of these three IPs, if it fails, Connect to any of those" or "Connect to this DNS name (and the DNS resolver will always provide you with an online instance)". The nodes in the cluster will then exchange the data with each other, so it does not matter where you Connect to.

Author: jermuk
Content: HiveMQ is option 2

Author: douga.7429
Content: Yes, This sounds right.  In the bigger picture, I wondered how this is configured on the device side with option #1. A side thought I had was about deployment pipelines for change management.  You could swap over to the QA namespace and deprecate the Prod namespace.  I wondered if there would be an opportunity to handle failover and this need for a failback during deployments in similar ways.  Then there are the issues with cost and all the redundancy, that came to my mind too.

Author: jermuk
Content:
With option #2 (clustering), rolling upgrades are indeed a common approach, allowing for updates to be applied to each node gradually, helping to maintain availability during deployments.

As for costs and complexity, you're spot-on. It's essential to carefully evaluate whether high availability (HA) is truly necessary for your specific use case. Implementing HA can be resource-intensive, and sometimes the trade-off might not be worth it.

Author: sparkylarks
Content:
Looking at redundancy, and assuming that we are not considering redundant network paths, and diesel generators to backup our UPS on site, I would take a simple approach to say:

Option 1 - No redundancy: If resources are not available, data is lost.

Option 2 - No redundancy, but implement strategies to minimize data loss:
e.g. Store and forward, buffering at the PLC level, stopping when buffers are full, and preventing machines from starting if the MES information is not available.

Option 3 - Redundancy: Implement a redundant Ignition Gateway and communicate to a redundant MQTT cluster, but data may be lost during changeover.

Option 4 - Redundancy and measures to minimize data loss.

Just like you cannot have a zero-risk machine, you cannot have 100% uptime or no data loss. It becomes a question of time and money.

I would normally look at Option 4 with the following considerations:

    All machines can continue a work order for 15 minutes and not lose data.
    If communication from the line to the MES is lost, then a new work order cannot be started.
    The customer can decide if they want to stop or lose data.
        I have done implementations where the machine would continue to run and would lose good production records, but if we got to a point where we lost data on any reject or rework, the line would stop.

As you move up to MES and ERP levels, the impact of loss of communication can become less impactful. I would say this because if you have a 1-minute downtime, there may be no new information being published from the MES and ERP. You could argue that the MES is continually calculating and publishing an OEE figure; however, I would contend that if the data is being published to the UNS from the equipment to calculate the OEE, assuming that the downtime is of reasonable duration (i.e., 10 minutes or so), it becomes less important to focus on data loss and better to focus on redundancy and Mean Time To Repair (MTTR).

Author: akoscs
Content: You are always at risk of data loss, but you can have a storage near the machine to make sure to store historical data until comms are restored, so you do not completely loose data, you just sync with a delay. This way you at least keep historical data even if your UNS is down, you can continue manufacturing active work orders. If you go down a fully digital route you need to invest in an infrastructure which is on par with you manufacturing availability needs.

Author: rickbullotta
Content: To a point, but with some clustering solutions and HA approaches, as long as the client(s) participate, data loss can be minimized with consensus protocols, transactions, and such.  But that's a lot of overhead.

Author: akoscs
Content: Exactly. Additionally to HA you can cache locally to avoid loosing logged data during a comms outage.

Author: kiwimalice
sparkylarks
Content:
This solution didn't utilize MQTT. Instead, every quality record had a set of data tags, and we created a 100x data tag array. The Programmable Logic Controller (PLC) would place data into the next available empty array, usually Array[0]. The Manufacturing Execution System (MES) would read the data and, upon successful reading, set a bit in the PLC to 1 to acknowledge it. This action would move all data in the buffer up. Then the Acknowledge bit would be set to 0. The MES would trigger a read of the buffer if the index value in the PLC was not equal to 0. A "read" was essentially running a script to insert the data into a Database.

We did encounter some memory issues, and some machines required an upgrade from ControlLogix L81 to L83. For some CompactLogix machines, we had to limit the buffers to 30 or even 10. With MicroLogix, we communicated with CompactLogix in the same panel, if possible, and buffered from there. We aimed to ensure that a 15-minute network downtime event wouldn't result in data loss, so the array size was related to the run rate.

Ultimately, it depends on your budget. A 10-buffer system might prevent 90% of data loss, while 100 buffers could achieve 99% prevention, and 1000 buffers could reach 99.9%. However, diminishing returns set in after a while.

Although I haven't tried using MQTT, you could potentially have the PLC subscribe to the value it publishes to the broker and set the PLC code to increment the buffer each time. There may be simpler methods to address the issue.

Author: douga.7429
Content:
Your query about store forward approaches in PLCs and the choice between RAM or SD card storage caught my attention. I've been exploring a similar concept using an Arduino OPTA WIFI for an edge-driven MES IoT device.

My vision involves creating 1440 elements in an array, with each element aggregating counts for every second of the day. This would provide comprehensive coverage for assessing availability and production. It's similar to the auto-aggregating feature of a historian but implemented in PLC structured text local to the device.

The array data would be sent to a Universal Naming System (UNS) with 1440 elements, and its history would be stored in a schema-less data lake or equivalent. This event-sourced store would be immutable and used for analysis, with an MES analysis frontend built on top.

Regarding storage, using an SD card in PLCs poses challenges. PLCs aren't PCs where files can be easily accessed, so a reliable file transfer protocol would be necessary. My approach involves creating 24 arrays with 60 elements each, and implementing store-forward operations on an hourly basis. If resources permit, I'd consider maintaining a day or two of previous records.

The motivation for this project stems from MES count validation issues I've encountered, where latency in high-speed operations led to inaccurate counts being applied to the wrong jobs and work shifts. An edge-based counter addressing real-time issues seems to be the solution.

As for whether the Arduino can handle these arrays, I've received conflicting feedback. I've decided to proceed with a trial-and-error approach instead of assessing the issue too deeply. I'm more of an analyst than a PLC edge expert.

I hope this information is helpful to you. If you come across any relevant references or insights from the Mentorship program, please share them. I'd appreciate the opportunity to learn more and refine my approach.

Author: thunt.career
Content: For standard OPC-UA, the client initiates and maintains the connection to the server. On a stateful firewall, you'd need your ports opened inbound from the MES OPC-UA client to the edge OPC-UA server. OPC-UA PubSub is different but I doubt that's what they are referring to.

Author: jbonhage155
Content: Thanks. So for standard OPC-UA it's only 1 direction the firewall needs to be opened? Or we need both directions due to it's client/server relationship? (even if it's read-only from MES to edge)

Author: IIoT#4707

Author: thunt.career
Content: Should only need one direction but it's not the one you want (less trusted private cloud to on-prem edge server). Client requests and polls the server. Server responds so a stateful firewall will recognize the connection. Most modern firewalls are stateful.

Author: thunt.career
Content: I just moved an OPC client from the OT DMZ to the OT network for this reason.

ok this is where I get confused on the firewall statefulness.

One of my arguments again OPC-UA is that we have to open the associated port for both directions (since client needs outbound to request and server inbound to reply), MQTT we can simply open a single direction.

But what you're saying is the bi-directional traffic of OPC-UA doesn't matter as much because of the stateful features that needs firewall provide?

Author: mattmigchelbrink
Content: I've seen you post AWS before. In that sense NACL are stateless, security groups are stateful.

Author: thunt.career
Content: On a stateful firewall, it will know that the OPC client created a session and will allow the server to reply without needing a separate rule since it caches the TCP connection info and will let it pass. Depending on the OPC server, there may be other things such as discovery services that require additional ports. The important thing to understand is that most if not all traffic is initiated by the client so the firewall must allow traffic from the client to the server. In the case of a cloud MES software using OPC-UA. The MES software would be the client. The port must be open from the outside interface into the inside interface. POTENTIALLY, this could open an attack vector if a separate OPC-UA client was able to learn about the server and provide proper authentication (up to server configuration and certificates).

Author: rickbullotta
Content: I don't think any of the options you listed allow data entry, buttons to trigger logic, etc...but if you add Zoho Creator to Zoho Analytics you can.  Microsoft Power Platform would also be a viable option.

Author: thunt.career
Content: Here's another OPC-UA example using the Kewpare IoT Gateway as a REST Client to POST values to the Cloud API REST Server. Note https[443] is documented here but it would be whatever port is defined by the Cloud API REST Server. The key take away to note is the inbound traffic rules required from the OPC-UA Client in the Mfg DMZ to the OPC-UA server in the Manufacturing Zone network. For these examples, ignore the network Zones and just understand where the traffic is initiated from. This doesn't mean that packets/data aren't flowing the other direction, just that the connection is established (and thus the rule is made for stateful firewalls) in that specific direction.

Author: sammysevens777
Content: That's a trick question - it's probably more of a dial of "how much" digitization, vs. Yes/No to digitize.....I will say this....in my previous industry (electronic mfg.) we spent a tremendous amount of time trying to integrate our SMT line equipment from different vendors, all lacking modern communication (screen printing, PnP, oven, inspection machines)  so that we can feed a model into end of line inspection, and using RCA - determine where in the process something failed....the only problem is....there is no way to actually rework a board automatically (at least with a traditional SMT line). So, even though we digitized, collected a ton of data, it's not something that can be immediately acted upon.....furthermore, SMT as a process can be virtually defect free. It is very reliable, robust, and works very well, not a lot of value if you're taking 99.5% yield, up a fraction of a point....for millions of dollars of investment. This is where open platforms can really help drive value here....so you're not hodge podging a bunch of broken communication standards into a data swamp!

Author: joshuastover
Content: Good point. Choosing where to invest, especially in the beginning of Digital Transformation is important. You have to be able to show a return, where costs are being saved.

Author: nickn5549
Content: Yes, but when SMT machines are getting older the errors creep up if you are not investing millions again to get new tech....I have found that monitoring placement machines gives you great insights, especially detecting feeders issues - bad pickup, dropped parts, indexing issues, etc. At least you know real-time the feeder that is creating issues and you can change it on the spot.

WOE    Good day.

Author: rickbullotta
Content:
OK.  It uses video analytics, not bluetooth.  You'd need camera coverage throughout the facility.  Oh, and you'd be amazed the insights that some people get from analyzing people movement (it's a foundation of work analysis for industrial engineers)!

Bluetooth positioning isn't very good BTW.  In fact, most indoor positioning systems aren't very good and can be quite expensive.

Author: runeston3

Author: rickbullotta
Content: Could be.  I would not count on bluetooth positioning devices though.  The number of sensor locations (and power/communications backhaul) could get quite expensive too, and the accuracy will never be great.

Author: runeston3
Content: ok. we have wifi coverage in the whole factory, is there any way to triangulate position from that?

Author: rickbullotta
Content: There is, but it's only accurate to about +/- 10 meters in real world use cases.  There are UWB systems as well (Ubisense is a popular one) that can get below a meter, but that would require installing an array of sensors in a grid (100 meters or so between sensors) and tags on each forklift.

Author: rickbullotta
Content: Interesting idea, but probably not nearly as simple as it seems. Would almost certainly be very prone to drift and would require a frequent re-reference/calibration (known location and orientation).  It would work great on that initial 10 foot test though.  Likely that the wheel would occasionally slide throwing everything off.

Hey guys
