Author: sawartz
Content:
He pitched for ChatGPT a lot in his presentation. 

Then, I have decided to talk with ChatGPT about digital maturity assessment.

Here is my ChatGPT link: https://chat.openai.com/share/aa852b75-4079-46ce-aa89-ecada1af8955

Author: sawartz
Content:
For those who want to see some results, here is my last prompt:

Then, what should be 20 beginning questions for the factory to ask for at the start of digital maturity assessment?

Author: sawartz
Content:
Here are 20 beginning questions for a digital maturity assessment in a factory setting:

1. How would you describe the current level of awareness and understanding of digital technologies among employees in the factory?
2. Are there any existing digital tools or systems implemented in the factory's operations?
3. What are the main challenges or barriers you have encountered when it comes to digitalization in the factory?
4. How effectively does the factory capture and utilize data in its processes?
5. Are there any automated systems or machinery currently used in the factory? If yes, can you provide examples?

Author: sawartz
Content:
6. How well do different systems and equipment integrate with each other in the factory?
7. Are there any initiatives or projects aimed at optimizing processes using digital technologies in the factory?
8. How is training and skill development provided to employees to enhance their digital competencies?
9. Are there any digital communication channels and collaboration tools used within the factory?
10. How are equipment performance and maintenance needs monitored and managed digitally in the factory?

Author: sawartz
Content:
11. What is the level of involvement and engagement of employees in suggesting improvements using digital solutions?
12. Are there any specific digital goals or objectives outlined in the factory's overall strategy?
13. How does the factory stay updated about emerging digital trends and technologies in the industry?
14. How are digital initiatives and projects prioritized and funded in the factory?
15. What mechanisms are in place to measure the effectiveness and impact of digital initiatives?

Author: sawartz
Content:
16. How do employees from different departments and levels collaborate and share information digitally?
17. Are there any challenges or concerns related to data security and protection in the digital environment?
18. How scalable and flexible are the factory's current digital systems to accommodate future growth or changes?
19. How does the factory gather and utilize customer feedback or insights using digital channels?
20. Are there any industry standards or best practices followed by the factory in terms of digital maturity?

These questions should serve as a starting point for your digital maturity assessment in the factory. You can tailor and expand upon them based on your specific objectives and areas of focus.

Author: boss1519.
Content: Why worry about MQTT broker? Why not use AWS IOT Core directly? Example, Ignition Edge publishes directly to AWS. AWS could then unlock a lot more power than HiveMQ or Ignition broker..

Author: benveenema
Content: Certainly an option but you may want to look into the costs of putting all your data there.

Author: mparris
Content: Following up... Have you been interested with Fortinet?  If so, how has the interaction been?

Author: asthomas
Content: One reason would be your network security stance.  OT systems should not have direct connections to the Internet, including no forward proxies.  That makes a direct connection to AWS IoT Core impossible.  In that case you could run an MQTT broker in a DMZ and then forward the data to your cloud system.  That also means you don't need to use MQTT end-to-end, as the DMZ broker could also support UA, DA, etc.

Author: rickbullotta
Content: Why not connections to the "internet" if initiated from an edge device that proxies the OT devices/systems?  That seems a fairly common approach, with appropriate firewall setup.  Curious what the issues would be.

Author: asthomas
Content: The primary concern is to avoid a) data exfiltration, and b) compromise of the OT network.  If a malicious application makes its way into the OT network via other means, like an infected USB stick or a trojan, then a connection to the Internet, even via a forward proxy, is sufficient for it to steal information, download further instructions and programs, or provide shell access to a remote attacker.  So the safest security posture is to ensure that no machine in the OT network can make a connection to any machine on the Internet, even if it is outbound-only through a firewall.  That means proxying data (but not the connection) through a second machine, ideally in a DMZ.  An application in the DMZ that is both a server (for the OT devices) and a client (for the cloud service) will work.

Author: bartwybouw
Content: You don't want to lose any data when you get disconnected for a longer time, so a local MQTT instance will buffer that, and then move it into something like AWS IoT core (maybe as a centralised instance over multiple sites)., would be my take.

Author: asthomas
Content: That's what we do with Cogent DataHub.  We run an instance in the plant to collect data from multiple sources, and store that locally for forwarding in case of loss of connection to the DMZ.  A second instance in the DMZ acts as a server, and also stores its data locally before forwarding to the cloud service.  This satisfies the OT network isolation requirement and provides store-and-forward at each network hop, so no matter which network connection fails, you don't lose data.

Author: simen13
Content:
Something Walker often talks about for doing digital transformation, is the focus on strategy. He emphasizes the question, "why does a business want to become digital organization?"
To have a data-driven business where data is the primary commodity makes very much sense in manufacture. 
When it comes to engineering firms that service and implement solutions for the industry, how would being data-driven work for such a company?
I would assume that being digital and data-driven is crucial for an engineering firm that work for the industry, but without collecting data directly from the industry, what data would be the commodity?
How would a data-driven engineering firm work?

Author: bartwybouw
Content: Are you saying we need to assume we cannot collect data from the machines at the customer?

Author: simen13
Content:
I would guess that collecting data from machines at the customer would be down to what kind of contract you have.

What I am after, is how a data-driven engineering company work, internally - would you use how people work and how projects are executed as data to become data driven?

Author: bartwybouw
Content: IMHO, there is a lot of value in making the data/information available in formats which are easy to consume for the users. Going from the technical information over machine settings and work instructions. If my assumption is correct, you will typically build a very limited series of products. So the challenge is to be efficient as possible in everything you do as you don't get a lot of chances to learn and correct (like in typical manufacturing). Hence capturing data or feedback from production is critical (both machine and human). And being able to feed that back to engineering and product design, so the next product gets the benefits from the previous one as much as possible. e.g. being able to monitor how long a step takes(and compare to what was foreseen or planned), makes for better resource planning, more accurate prediction of shipment/delivery date of your project and more accurate pricing to just name a few. Being able to accurately measure material usage, waste produced, energy consumption etc. also helps in better pricing capabilities (leading to better profitability or better competitiveness).

Author: sparkylarks
Content:
I think what Walker is saying is the data becomes the most important thing in your business. You might not be selling that data on. Lots of businesses consume commodities, and then use those commodities to make something else.

So for the Engineering firm the data is the data you create as you work.
Most Engineering firms have a CRM and also track hours, but can you correlate how  the man hour estimated across three proposals, to the people-hours and the cost associated with them. Most firms I have worked for as an engineer you have x hours in the budget . but how does that actually affect the profitability of the project.

Can you compare the manhours spend in refining proposals for a customer with the effect that has on the final project.
Can you break down the projects by phase or by deliverable to see which areas are causing problems. - Do you hire based on that data?
Can you look at the projects you have worked on and  see which customers are pushing boundaries, and after a successful implementation f new technology know from data that company B will not look to implement a similar project for 2 years, but Company C will be eager to follow up?
Can you tie into your suppliers ecosystem to see the real-time delivery time changes of components you often order.
Can your customers look at your system to understand the available capacity that you have or will have in the next few months.
Does your AI look at the current global supply chain to highlight future problems in key components to your engineering?

So often analysis of project success or failure is based on intuition , feeling, without the data to back them up.

To me that is a data driven Engineering firm. Of course that will tie into producing products that are data driven., but the focus is about
1. Understanding the Engineering Process at the firm
2. Collecting the relevant data along that process into a single source of truth that firm
3. Contextualise that Data
4. Analyse that Data

Author: simen13
Content:
Thanks, this is very helpful for understanding.
Would you use a UNS and a historian for tracking this data as well?

Author: sparkylarks
Content:
A UNS certainly
A historian, let me put it this way. If you want to store historical data why would you chose a historian over a SQL or even a NoSQL DB.

I'm not saying I wouldn't use a historian if I see an advantage. I just can't see a reason to.

Author: jermuk
Content: if you want to deep dive into the topic of Historians vs Open-Source Databases, feel free to check out this: https://learn.umh.app/blog/the-high-compression-deception-a-reality-check-on-historians-vs-open-source-databases/

Author: rickbullotta
Content: Two reasons: supportability (you have someone to call to get support, upgrade guidance, etc) and connectivity (many historians offer hundreds of connectors to end devices and sensors).

Author: sammysevens777
Content:
Since you're posting this in the digital transformation thread - then I think it's also important to consider that digitization does not only impact deployments. Digitization for an engineering service provider should be more focused on the concept of the "digital thread" to help your organization operate more efficiently, driving down your design costs, while otherwise improving customer experience which means:

- Integrating PLM systems to manage the entire product lifecycle - revision control, collaborative design, etc.

- Integrating simulation into your designers toolset, so that when they propose a solution to a customer, they can demonstrate that it should work, and in turn save your business money by avoiding fabrication first, and also engaging your customer with more digital tools

- Integrating controls into the design phase, allowing your designers to simulate process control with their new designs (one product in particular is Siemens' mechatronic concept designer)

- Get yourself a VR headset and a gaming station, and virtualize parts of your FAT. Allow your customer to virtually tour the facility/machine you're designing

The point is - I would argue that in your business, and based on your question, where your firm is today, that you need to build foundational digital infrastructure....remember these wise words from Arlen Nipper:  *"....decouple wherever possible, we've gotta look at connecting devices to infrastructure and not to applications"*. Although he is referring to MQTT / UNS, the infrastructure is a good place to start

Author: joshuastover
Content: It's my understanding that LIDAR doesn't work in imperfect conditions (IE. Rain, snow, sleet, etc.) and that this has been a major pitfall for the technology being used in autonomous driving of all forms.

Author: joshuastover
Content:
Not every company is gathering data, and/or using it. For instance, GM and Ford don't look at their cars and trucks being more than just a car or truck. They're dumb vehicles. Sure they have done ota software updates in the past, but it's always something along the lines of updating the SiriusXM Radio firmware or similar. Tesla updates their cars like you update your phone, with firmware fixes, new features, etc.

Like @DavidSchultz pointed out, Tesla is able to sell their data to improve infrastructure, to provide consumer data, etc. This is what makes them a data company, as compared to their competitors in the automative market.

Author: rickbullotta
Content: Not true.  Ford is definitely viewing their commercial vehicles as massive sources of data.  And with their EV's, the consumer vehicles also.  Even the "dumber" vehicles (like my F-150) send data to Ford's servers to improve navigation and stuff like that.

Author: sparkylarks
Content:
Does gathering and using data make you a data company?
Or do you need to sell data to be a data company?

If it is the first, does it matter how we gather the data?  

Does it matter how you use the data?

Do you need to do both?

And again assuming that more and more companies will become more and more digitally integrated and will collect and use that data does that mean all companies will be data companies regardless of what then sell?

Author: rickbullotta
Content: Tesla DOES NOT sell their data to third parties.

Author: joshuastover
Content:
Tesla doesn't just gather data for improvement of it's own navigation, they've been doing it to improve their own cars. Does Tesla currently sell it's data to 3rd parties? No, not that I'm aware, my point is that they are already gathering the data to be able to do so, unlike their automotive competitors.

The hopes for Ford and GM are higher, in my opinion, now that they are entering Tesla's ecosystem (this is what makes them adopting the NACS plug and using Tesla's superchargers so significant.)

Author: rickbullotta
Content: I’m doubtful they’d sell it. The backlash would be extreme.

Author: joshuastover
Content:
I'm unsure if they would get huge backlash, particularly if they used anonymized data for things such as infrastructure improvements. The cars would be able to look for things like potholes, where road layouts can be improved, etc. If they go an extreme route with selling personalized data for consumer purposes (where they are visiting and for how long, similar to Google) then there would almost certainly be huge backlash, and rightfully so.

If the backlash on TikTok, FaceBook, etc. says anything, it's less that people's data is being sold, and more that it's THEIR data being sold. We know Facebook sells are data, with our names attached, to companies for targeted marketing. This is the part people get upset about.

Author: rickbullotta
Content: The issue is when you commit to privacy, then violate that trust, you will have issues.  Social media companies never made true commitments to privacy and were transparent about whoring your data out to anyone wanted it!

Author: walker.reynolds
Content:
I don't understand how this can be true -- I use FSD everyday.  There are only two conditions where it gets wonky -- the first is construction diversions where they don't replace lines on the road with reflectors on barriers (like they are supposed to do)... and the second is on the highway where the material used for the road changes -- say from concrete to asphalt -- and the sun is low in the sky.  I would say there's a 5% chance the car will slow down for no reason because it is having trouble seeing the road in these conditions.  FSD absolutely, 100% works.  I probably have 200 hours driving with it under my belt -- out of 20 days per month driving to and from the office using FSD, I will intervene once -- and almost always for an outlier like a construction barrier that has no reflectors on it.

The bigger point that I think most people don't understand is that Tesla is not a car company and is not interested in selling as many cars to as many people as possible.  They are a data company who happens to manufacture cars right now -- Elon knows he is changing the way other car companies approach the market (every day, car companies become more like Tesla and less like GM or Ford) and that means that Tesla will be relied upon less and less to produce the vehicles.

Giga will be manufacturing something else altogether, at some point, and there are already grumblings that its going to be trialed in Austin.

Author: sparkylarks
Content:
I had a very long response written on this, and then in a flash of blinding clarity decided
"I think it is possible to be both a car company and data company."

I am sure at one point in time, people discussed how "Ford was not really a Car company they were a manufacturing company" To try to capture what set Ford apart was that it made automobiles in a completely different way to other companies.  

Maybe people also claimed that Henry Ford was going to take the same manufacturing techniques to other industries next 😉 

And I think it is fair to compare Henry Ford's company to Elon Musk's in the game changing nature of the innovation. What I like to call "Fosberry flop" innovation. Something that is completely new that forces everyone else to adopt it to the point where people almost don't believe that it was ever done the old way.

So while I am willing to accept the "Tesla is a data company", taking that to mean that data is a tthe core of what they do. I will always struggle to accept that they are not a car company, at least until they stop making and selling over a million cars each year. Or get more revenue from another product.

Author: walker.reynolds
Content:
What I mean, Mark -- is that Tesla is not what we have traditionally defined as a 'car' company.  Yet, we continue to apply standards of quality, features, market, sales on Tesla -- when they simply do not apply.

Tesla doesn't build what people request -- they improve their vehicles based on what the data tells them to do.

Modern Day Disney -- Walt Disney didn't ask civil engineers or customers where to put sidewalks at Disney World.  He collected data on where they walked when there was free range and no sidewalks -- and then put the sidewalks there.

Tesla does the same thing with their cars -- but on a whole different level.

Content:
I'm going to limit my posts to 1 a day from now on but.

I love the concept of "desire paths" where people find and use the most efficient route. And I have heard of universities paving the routes that people were taking the other way around. And that is a great analogy for how operators will find the most efficient way of working regardless of that the plan says and how whatever digital system we build has to be able accommodate and capture what actually occurs.

But also , like sidewalks, try to make the prescribed way, the most efficient way.

Author: willemrs
Content:
Speaking in terms of efficiency.  I had an instructor a while back in a completely different field give an excellent statement about taking shortcuts vs doing things the correct way.

I can’t remember the exact wording but the gist was.. “We don’t take shortcuts.  There is only the right way and the wrong way. We’re teaching the right way.  If you find a better way to do the things that doesn’t violate the standard principles(different per field…).  It isn’t a shortcut, we will make it the way.”  

In manufacturing, I see digital transformation as a way to speed up this process and give the operators more power to effect change.

Author: Deleted User
Content:
Hello everyone,

I'm currently writing my Master's thesis and I'm looking for people who I can invite for expert interviews. The core of my thesis is to analyse the specific challenges of implementing Industrie 4.0 use cases although enabling technologies might suggest a high TRL and, based on this, to derive a "Industry 4.0 Use Case Maturity Model". Exemplarily challenges could be: Limited Data availability (according to the criteria of 5V) or an Unsuitable Manufacturing Environment (e.g., light conditions during Computer Vision based inspections).

In total, I have identified 3 example use cases that I would like to analyse. I have already analysed corresponding case studies and now want to use the interviews to verify whether the challenges of these case studies I have identified correspond with current manufacturing expertise.

I am therefore looking for experts who have or had touch-points with the implementation of one of the following 3 use cases:
Condition Based Monitoring & Predictive Maintenance for Manufacturing Equipment.
Autonomous Material Handling Systems (can be e.g. the autonomous recognition of products so that a robot such as a Celluveyor knows where to move the respective product)
Autonomous Defect Recognition and Inspection

I would be very happy to hear some feedback and am looking forward to an informative exchange. :ismile: 
If you are interested, you are welcome to contact me via Discord or Linked In: www.linkedin.com/in/tinus-veltel

Best regards,

Tinus
MSc Student in Intelligent Manufacturing Systems (University of Warwick)

Author: m_r_mccormick
Content: @Deleted User This might provide some insights on the academic side of the fence with regard to case studies, and might or might not be applicable to your direction: https://www.researchgate.net/publication/372051816_Challenges_for_Smart_Manufacturing_and_Industry_40_Research_in_Academia_A_Case_Study

Author: m_r_mccormick
Content: @Deleted User Also, I believe that industry 4.0 maturity models (for organizations at least) have been heavily discussed, so a thorough literature might be necessary to ensure you aren't reinventing the wheel and are identifying a niche are where value is delivered. Given what I've run into so far from the academic side of the fence, and assuming I understand what you are shooting for, I think you might have a hard time distinguishing between the maturity of use cases and the willingness of industry to share detailed information. Example regarding maturity models: https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/abs/pii/S0278612518301341

Author: Deleted User
Content:
@M. R. McCormick You are completely right. There are a lot of maturity models. However, as you also mentioned, they only refer to the company maturity or readiness to adapt Industry 4.0 solutions and not on the use case itself whether it fits to company requirements. Examples that I have found here are IMPULS Readiness Check (https://www.industrie40-readiness.de/?lang=en) or an Article by Fraunhofer "A maturity model for assessing Industry 4.0 readiness and maturity of
manufacturing enterprises " (https://publica-rest.fraunhofer.de/server/api/core/bitstreams/da6860cf-5a33-4d79-82c8-1cf6b53dc3fb/content). 

With my thesis I am aiming to create something like a catalogue or a checkbox list for manufacturing companies to evaluate how difficult it is to really implement that use case. The check boxes are appropriately derived from the challenges I have previously identified. 

I have skimmed through the article that you have send me (https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/abs/pii/S0278612518301341; great Input for me, thanks a lot) and I have seen some of the models that I have identified in my thesis as well. There was 1 interesting idea in the article as well: Each of the models do not build up on each other. For example it would be interesting as well to analyse the Compatibility of my model with for example the IMPULS Industry 4.0 Model. Just a short example to make that idea a little bit more clear: For example Company X have identified with IMPULS that they have a very low level of maturity regarding data usage. However, use case x requires experienced data usage know how. As a result for company x that specific use case becomes hard to implement. The idea now is to give the identified complexity here a specific score, comparing the level of IMPULS with my catalogue level.

Author: Deleted User
Content: So my catalogue or use case complexity evaluation model serves as a basis to see how complex it is for manufacturing companies with a certain maturity to implement specific use cases.

Author: sammysevens777
Content:
Question for the group - when i personally started my journey on I4.0. (~2017) the focus was on defining business cases for applications that would benefit from IT/OT convergence. We focused on analytics in operations, simulation with digital twins, ml to learn processes...

However, during my time in this community I see the overwhelming focus of digital transformation focusing on the infrastructure and systems/data modelling pushed heavily as the approach vs. defining specific use cases.

While I dont think thats wrong, as once the architecture and systems are in place, a lot of business cases can be pursued.....i wonder how that approach really pans out in the "real world" which deals with brownfield operations, layers of system integration, and a desire to prove out ROIs before taking the big leap (like a UNS implementation).

Only playing devils advocate - i genuinely think UNS is brilliant and was a fan of pub sub brokers as a means to connect disparate systems, just wonder how others see it

Author: akoscs
Content: It is all about solving problems. The problems are usually specific, but their solutions are generic and require a lot of intricate details which are widely discussed here. It is not much value in discussing this company needs to see their OEE on a dashboard, yes me too, the otherone too, yes we need that too, we need it mor badly (discuss the problem, their contexts and their urgency). These are business problems not engineering problems. It is much more value in discussing how to put up a dashboard so that you can display  whatever you want on it . As you progress with the solution implementation it is of interest to discuss intricate data modelling problems, compatibility issues, other toolchains which does the same thing. It is also fun to bash OPC UA (just joking) or the other *insert other protocol name here* which did not deliver the expected reults, was harder to use then expected. I think the technical details discussed here are not/should not be the drivers of digitalisation, these are just symptoms.

Author: plarochelle
Content: Understood how you could see that but do some searching on DTMA - you'll find more information on strategy and leadership here.  The architecture is a means to the end - up front companies should set a digital strategy, interview stakeholders to identify problems, pick a problem to solve, and then build a solution using the architecture.

Author: sammysevens777
Content: I did DTMA at my previous company, and conducted it against 6 pillars of industry 4.0 across 50 factories (arbitrary, but we had additive manufacturing , machine communication, smart automation....etc. etc.). What i saw from factories was a focus on descriptive data....while at the time our view was that the goal was to prescribe outcomes. But additive manufacturing has little in that realm, and AR was another pillar which was more application focused....so just interesting to see different perspectives here.

Author: sherylmccrary
Content:
I agree our focus here is less about the applications and more about how to get there, as the use cases are becoming more widely acknowledged. Another way of saying it is that one of the *results* of digital transformation is to be able to predict outcomes based on real-time state at any moment, and the use of AR, analytics/ML are what's possible when a company transitions from paper to data-driven. 

The goal is to become data-driven.  The 4.0 Solutions DTMA pillars assess where a company is on that journey in 5 functional areas: Operations, Engineering, IT, Quality and Leadership plus the infrastructure, network, connectivity, etc. to enable it. Machine communication, which you mention, is part of those. If by "prescribe outcomes" you mean your goal for the assessment itself was to define the outcome of what the transformed company would look like and do, that's also a 4.0 DTMA goal.

How forward thinking you were to lead the company in that assessment. What were the results and how would your perspective change  if you did it again?

Author: sammysevens777
Content:
I was fortunate to be part of the business excellence organization at my company, so maturity assessments were an established process using a grading scale (0-5). It was an eye opening experience for sure...and humbling as I met so many talented people across our company WW. 
What we found was:
- most sites had POCs and great proto deployments, but few had robust processes to take the lab/one off systems, and deploy them factory wide/across other customers
- by descriptive/predictive/prescriptive, we were looking at how sites used data. Descriptive analytics is generally the baseline (dashboards, reports, etc.) But the top tier of data analytics is to prescribe outcomes....most sites captured data across every machine....very few fed them back into the process and used that data to automatically improve the process.
- lighthouse facilities tend to drive the org. forward, once a facility proved out a concept/solution and ROI, neighboring sites tended to adopt them more quickly
- Augmented reality was more successful as a mobile app on phones vs. a hololens....although sites would demo hololens for us....most headgear is too bulky and costly. 
- most sites evolved one project at a time, more advanced (and high capital) factories believed that developing infra across the whole factory was step 1. I agree with the latter in principle, but the former was more common

In terms of what we could do differently....i think trying to partner facilities with one another could have been an interesting approach. Take a more advanced operation, and have them work with a less advanced one, and incentivize the higher scoring facility as well.

Author: jon.forbord
Content: Its hard to «sell» infrastructure, so what you can do, is build the infrastructure in steps as necessary to support use-cases. In other words, you think of each project as a part of a bigger whole building the infrastructure as you go, with the overall plan/strategy and target architecture in mind.

Author: vaughnturner
Content: Hey Kaleb, great question. The DTMA can still be very useful in a digitally immature organization/facility. The need for a Digital Strategy is still the first step, why do we want to be digital? You will still need to assess the business, and the intelligence, and lay out your MTR (Minimum Technical Requirements). In an operation that is still in the building process, those critical first steps are key, Digital Strategy, and Minimum Technical Requirements. What to do in the meantime? This is where the education comes in to play, you take this opportunity to educate your core groups and key stakeholders in the business. Then your knowledge base is ahead of the curve when it comes time to making the rubber meet the road per se. I'd be happy to chat with you more about your situation, I'm always happy to assist.

Author: hiptopjones
Content: In the podcasts, Walker talks a lot about the importance of having a digital transformation strategy before other things.  I can imagine a strategy being something along the lines of "improve decision making by enabling democratized realtime access to contextualized data from across the business", but I really struggle with whether that's too general, too trite, or even too narrow.  I am curious if there are some good examples and some bad examples of digital strategies that I could use to calibrate my thinking on this.  On one hand, strategy (in general) needs to be tailored and meaningful to our business, but I also wonder if our strategy in this area shouldn't basically be the same as the next guy?  Again, using Walker's words, couldn't we all be shooting for the same target of "having data be the primary commodity of our busines"?  Another question I have on defining strategy up front relates to how what you want changes relative to what you know.  So the strategy, if specific to us, should be expected to change as we learn along the journey?  Curious how others think about this--I often overthink topics like this and don't have much strategy-setting experience to fall back on.

Author: geoffnunan
Content:
Strategy, when done well, guides the tactical decisions. It should outline your WHY.
Strategy is about choices. What choices do you have, what choices are your competitors making. How will your business leverage it's strengths to gain an advantage.
In my opinion, a strategy of "having data be the primary commodity of the business" is far too general because it does not say why. Focusing on data is the HOW, not the WHY.
I have worked with some great companies to help set out the why, and gain broad agreement from executives on the why.
Use design-thinking methods to work with your executive team to identify strategic opportunities, and then rank those opportunities in order of their value to your business. This part can be tricky and it's important to get input from the executive team because financial value is not the only measure.

Author: hiptopjones
Content: Great feedback.  Thank you!

Author: sherylmccrary
Content: Agree, great summary @GeoffNunan . Peter, your digital transformation strategy is part of your business strategy and answers WHY you want to digitally transform/ be data driven, usually to be positioned to take advantage of those strategic opportunities identified. With the companies undergoing our DTMA, there *is* often a HOW element or part to that statement, but it can be as general as "We will leverage data and  digital processes for the purpose of..." As you go through the transformation journey, the information you want may change but the business strategy, the why, does not.

Author: nickn5549
Content: to get it started you need more than the WHY?...even if you won't detail all the 5Ws and the How in the Strategy, you will need to detail them in depth in your RoadMap. In Digital Strategy you should clarify Why? How? What? and then When, Where and Who  can be detailed in the RoadMap.

Author: sparkylarks
Content:
@Indiecat I know I initially struggled, when writing strategies with the problem that I expected the Strategy to be some keen insight, and maybe pages long. And the  format @SherylM gives always seamed obvious to me, so when I wrote a strategy of "We use real-time data and information to drive decision making quickly and in real-time" I though it too simple and obvious, but over time as project or technical decision were made we could refer back and see if that decision supported the strategy , was neutral , or actually worked against the strategy.

@NickN I like to state the Why simply as the headline of a strategy. A motto or creed everyone can know word for word,  and then outline the What and the How, in the next half page. Because the how and what might change and update as technology changes, but the Why should be a bit more durable.

I think of it like this. Imagine a Soccer Coach who has a strategy of ***really solid defence and counterattack***. 
That is the Why, the How becomes Play long ball out of defence and into the oppositions goal area, and pick off a goal or two. 
The What might be to use tall attacking forwards who can compete in the air long balls kicked in from defence.

If you get an opportunity to sign a great midfielder who is able to create and control a passing game, then you don't really want to chase them. It doesn't align with your strategy. 
 Or a short striker despite his abilities might not be as good a fit as a tall one who can react to high ball into the opposition goal area.

But we might keep the same Strategy of ***really solid defence and counterattack*** but change 
the how to use fast wingers to deliver the ball into the opposition goal area. 
The what of the  Tall strikers needs to change and I need the shorter ground based attacker.  Swap out a Peter crouch for a Gary Lineker.

Author: akoscs
Content: You are exactly right that a digital transformation strategy can be so high level that it would fit most companies, not just yours and may not include any tailor made elements. But is that a problem? Is your financial strategy tailored to your organization and only to your organization? is your customer acqisition strategy so unique that it only fits you and no other organization? The question is why do you want to digitalize, what is the value you are trying to extract form digitalization? If you are making let's say ... doorknobs. You most probably have the same type of CNC machines then many other organisations. Your doorknobs might be unique, you might have 1-2 unique tools, but not everything is unique. You are using digitalization as tool it is not the USP of the company. It might have some unique aspects at the operational level but overall it does not have to be unique.

Author: jon.forbord
Content: I really like this one from Harvard business review on strategy in general: https://youtu.be/iuYlGRnC7J8

Author: geoffnunan
Content:
An example:
I worked with a Bio Pharma company recently on strategy. Through a workshop over a few days that covered most of the departments within the company, we identified over 20 different "Pain-Points" ranging from the obvious (They still run paper batch records), to the not so obvious.
After identifying the pain-points, we analysed and categorised them, and then worked with the executive group to rank them according to their relative value to the business.
With this customer, the outcome was counter intuitive. Even though digitalising the paper batch records would add significant value to the business, It did not add significant competitive advantage. their main competitors were also implementing MES solutions to digitalise the batch record. One of the items that was lower ranked in terms of financial value was ranked highest by the executive team as it was something that their competitors could not currently do.
What I like about this approach is that it engages the whole team. The worst strategy you can have is "Lets just collect all the data because some magic will happen if we do"
Strategy means knowing your process, knowing your competitors, understanding your strengths and weaknesses, knowing your options, and then making some choices on where to focus your efforts.
The inputs to strategy do change. They rarely change quickly except in times like COVID, but they do change. Therefore your strategy will also change as the inputs to your choices change. It's important to review your strategy at least every 2 years, or whenever a global pandemic occurs.

Author: hiptopjones
Content: I think understand the concept of "Digital Supply Chain", in that being able to see further along the chain in either direction would be game-changing.  Gaining continuous visibility into what my customers' customers forecasts are, or the suppliers of my suppliers, would help everyone avoid shockwaves and bullwhip effects.  However, to be useful in decision making, it seems like the amount of information shared between businesses would need to be pretty detailed, and that leads me to wonder how this collaboration might be done in a way that avoids detailed and out-of-cycle sharing of business results, loss of competitive advantage through sharing of customer and supplier lists, risks of insider trading, etc.  It is one thing for me to pull a forecast from my primary customers, but gaining visibility into one more level (their primary customers) begins an exponential growth in the numbers of companies I have detail about, and doing this in both directions (suppliers and customers) doubles the effect.  That's obviously beneficial to my business, but how are people thinking the risks would be mitigated here?  Am I over-thinking the problem?  (I am obviously making some assumptions about how this would be implemented.)

Content:
Oh man....do i resonate with your experiences ... You know whats the hard truth....2 options: you learn to work within the system and how to navigate the social politics you call out (and btw - sometimes if you cant build it, join em), or you venture out and find a new org that *may* be better

Not sure if this helps....but one thing i noticed is that outside of bubbles like this discord....most people

A: dont care about digital transformation

B: dont understand digital transformation (the way that we here do)

Your level of competence is probably super intimidating - EVEN if you are not intending it to be.

I reported to our CTO for over a year....you know what i did? PPTS...lots and lots of PPTs. Why? Because my CTO was a mech. Eng who grew in Ops and managed factories.....and had a hard time using his laptop some days.

So coming in with a tech driven approach....was a recipe for disaster, everything flew right over his head

BUT - he loved assessments, reporting, and data....so thats what i molded my I4.0 program to focus on....maturity assessments for factories to conduct whose scores were shared with company execs, and he could discuss with confidence. 

So....all im saying is....recognize you are a trailblazer...and as a boss of mine once said...."sometimes, you dont get to pick your team. Make the best of it"

Author: geoffnunan
Content:
Access Controls take on a whole new level of importance.
A couple of our customers are working on digital supply-chain integrations, across sites but also across businesses. Contract Outsourced manufacturing of pharmaceuticals is an example. The outsourced manufacturer is making products for a range of customers, so sharing data needs to be managed specifically for the customer, not for the line or business.
This is where Graph-Based-Access-Control (GBAC) come in. We can set up access controls that are based on the relationships in the data ensuring that only the data that is intended to be shared is shared.

Author: hiptopjones
Content:
Access controls make a lot of sense, but I'm thinking about what the data itself tells an authorized entity.

In an episode of the comedy series "Silicon Valley," a VC determines that sesame seeds are mainly grown in a handful of locations around the world, and that cicada cycles will be aligning in an upcoming year to decimate the crops in all of those locations, leading to a very lucrative futures bet on the sesame seed commodity.

Thinking of this particular situation different way, if I'm McDonald's and I learn that my supplier will be unable to produce buns with sesame seeds on them (or that those buns will incur a premium) I have a problem to solve in my business.  I will inquire to them about why this is, and may or may not receive a useful answer--the supplier may not yet be aware of the underlying reason themselves.  However, in the digital supply chain world, I can see up the chain, and can see that it's the sesame seed producers that are projecting scarcity.  I might intuit that there is a problem with seed production, and now be in possession of valuable information about any business that depends on sesame seeds as well useful information about the commodity futures market.

There would be similar "spilling the tea" happening down the chain as well.  Perhaps a customer who makes machines cuts their forecast in half for our widgets.  Looking further along the chain, I can see that it is the end-systems those machines going into are the bottleneck.  This tells me my customer is maybe in trouble , but I can also make some calculated bets that other suppliers to the end-systems will be affected and also predict that the end-system producer is experiencing a strong downturn in their business.  Certainly, they could have pivoted to another vendor, but I still have a lot more information about the entities in the chain than I would have had before.

Author: willemrs
Content: Given a 15 min timeslot to present on digital transformation to an executive level crowd,  what would you cover?

Author: geoffnunan
Content:
The only thing an executive is interested in.
How this transformation impacts profitability.

Author: sparkylarks
Content:
I would have three points.
1. What is DT really (very quick)
2. What problems  can DT solve for each exec.
3. What you are going to do and what you need from them.


Who on the executive level do you report to? 
You need an hour session with them where you discuss the execs pain points. Imagine DT was a magic wand what pain point would each exec solve?

But the best advice I can say is lay out how DT can solve their pain points.

Taking thr last Board I presented to the pain points 
CEO.  Couldn't see the business in real time

CFO. Wanted to be able to understand if Capex was really needed. 

OPS. Wanted schedule adherence. Less third shift overtime.

Quality and Engineering.
Wanted to be able to verify if returns from customers were on spec when they left

Planning and supply chain.
Lots of thier issues were with supplier but knowing real life capabilities helped here.

HR.(&EHS) 
Better metrics for reporting. E.g. if someone smells something from the factory they want figures before the press call.

Author: sparkylarks
Content: P.s. who is giving you the money. Double down on their problem

Author: sparkylarks
Content:
P.p.s forgot the CTO. Who was not a CNO at all but wanted to take over OT and bend it to his will.

But he was terrified that he had no way to know hiw stable the OT stuff and did not like how we were reliant on the knowledge in peoples heads and tow of them, one staff and one a contractor on site for 40 years had left in the last year

Author: akoscs
Content: In my expeerience, even if it is a 15 min time slot, the attention span at C level is only about 5 min, so make sure to not waste time with a lenghtly into, straight to the pooint and benefits, leeave any explanations, technnical stuff to the end (or skip these).  I would start with huge problems that we are solving as a list and what exactly is needed from the C site. Somethig like, here are the problems we are solving. In order to solve these, this, this and this and this is needed from you. Then go on about solutions and whatnot. Repeat at the end: if you do/allow/enable/aprove this and this and this, these problems will get fixed. Make it actionnable for them (also).

Author: akoscs
Content: Also, if you can quantify the loss, in terms of money, the problems are causing it is a huge plus. even if it is a guesstimate. Put an ROI on the measures to solve the problems and you have a much better chance.

Author: sparkylarks
Content:
To follow on from @akos if you are trying to get money and finance have the key. Follow this 
1. This is the cost
2. This is the annual savings.
3. This is the payback 

If payback for the POC is less than 12 months they will give you the money very quickly( and always give it in months not years. Unless you can claim weeks. I.e. a 15 week playback 

A lot of engineers ask finance for funding and tell them all the cool technical details. They neither care nor understand. 

6 months payback and as long as you have due dillegence they will.find you the money.

Author: akoscs
Content: For some companies a 36 month return was the threshold of approval or rejection.

Author: geoffnunan
Content:
A digital transformation, if considered as a product, should be profitable. It should have a return on investment.
The product needs to be profitable over it's lifetime.
That means that the use-cases that you choose to implement as part of the digital transformation need to have an ROI that justifies the digital transformation.
The profit from the initial use-cases can then be invested into expanding the use-cases, which creates the transformation.

The argument that you should just do it because you have to in order to stay in business is lazy. It means that you have not yet identified how the digital transformation will actually transform the business, and what the impact of that transofrmation will be.

Author: im_glib
Content:
> The argument that you should just do it because you have to in order to stay in business is lazy. It means that you have not yet identified how the digital transformation will actually transform the business, and what the impact of that transformation will be.

This is true. It is lazy argument. Furthermore,  I don't know the full impact of what the transformation will be. Its almost straight from the Wolf of Wall Street "You mailed in my company a postcard a few weeks back requesting information on penny stocks that had huge upside potential with very little downside risk."

As an integrator I honestly don't know how to quantify the impact in 1mo, 6 mo, 1 year, 5 years... There are so many variables - one being, companies often don't have access to the data to even be able to justify a statement like "you will do X 30% better." A component of DT is putting in the framework to actually be ABLE to do that with data driven decisions.

Author: geoffnunan
Content:
It's very difficult to 'Sell' a Digital Transformation as an integrator.
You need to understand the customer's business, financials and competitive position. That's why consulting companies like KPMG, EY, PWC etc charge so much for this.
I've done it before several times through an initial paid consultancy engagement where the objective is to get an agreed position from the customers executive group on prioritised opportunities that will transform the business, with indicative ROI for each opportunity.
The DT comes out of the use-cases not the other way around

Author: akoscs
Content: It is a journey, I give you that, but you do not do this because you can, you are solving problems along the way. You can see how much budget you are spending on the features solving a specific problem. Then you go on to the next problem and repeat. As you progress, the problems you solve get more complex and the solution more cost effective because you can build on earlier solutions. So select the low hanging fruits to make a good start. If you cannot estimate a budget for a project you are doing it wrong. I get it that digital transformation is a program not a project, but it is made up of a sequence of project solving problems. The digital transformation just because we believe in it does not work with most companies, and if you are not an engineer, but an economist you are definetly right to ask for an ROI.

Author: akoscs
Content: I‘d say it is a program composed of a sequence of projects solving defined problems.

Author: nickn5549

Author: im_glib

Sure, I guess. But I suppose mid-flight isn't before starting any work when you are still trying to convince a company to go through digital transformation process, yeah?

Also, are you calculating the expected profit of each of your sprints/iterations prior to starting them? Or is it more like "We expect these features that we delivered will provide the following benefits over the next 6 months, therefore the ROI of the iteration is 3x"? Would be interested to hear your thoughts.

Author: nickn5549
Content: You estimate at the beginning and then calculate after each Iteration. If you get sucked in the total ROI of the total 'project' saga... you will never do anything other than talk about the 'project'. If the customer is not convinced, maybe they haven't reached the level where they recognise that they have a problem (or many). Not everybody can be helped...

This is a strategy, driven by products that need to provide savings for the business for sure, but how would it look like after enabled by digital. Some leaders may not be prepared for that and sometimes just having a leap of faith and give money would not be easy, but this has been a topic being discussed internally here

Author: nickn5549

Author: nickn5549
Content: Do DTMA first. Many things will be clearer after that and also makes it easier to spot the cave men.

Author: jon.forbord
Content: Saying you know the ROI on anything in advance is always a game of guestimation and assumptions and has some uncertainty or unmeasurable quantity. Saying you know the ROI of digital transformation before starting, is like saying know the ROI of LEAN. And I’m guessing people started implementing LEAN because Toyota and the likes had shown there was tremendous value to be gained, even if it’s hard to quantify in advance. So you can calculate ROI for an isolated DT subproject, as everyone does for a LEAN project.. But still not quite. For a given LEAN project, you measure the current losses, implement improvements, and measure how much less you loose from the improvement and extrapolate to some ROI, and you can estimate this in advance as well, to justify the cost of implementing the improvement. But.. doesn’t LEAN projects have a much lower potential for unmeasurable effects and synergies, compared to digital transformation projects. You can still estimate an ROI for a given DT project in advance and calculate after the fact or in flight, but isn’t the hypothesis that the uncertainty and unmeasurable quantity for any ROI calculation related to DT is much higher than we are used to?

Author: geoffnunan
Content: No. I dont think it is

Author: sparkylarks
Content:
This is a great conversation thanks @Will S .
But I think the responses are very much dependant on where on the DT journey they are. and I'l come back to that but
Every initiative, regardless of its nature, can and should have a calculated ROI. While certain endeavors might require leveraging assumptions and industry benchmarks, having an ROI is non-negotiable.  I wouldn't entertain a substantial investment request unless it's backed by a tangible, quantifiable return. It's not just about fiscal responsibility but ensuring each dollar spent contributes to our strategic goals.

you could claim that you cannot calculate a return on going to a Yoga class every week as the benefits of health and wellbing cannot be calcualted.  Cost:
$20 per class x 52 weeks = $1,040/year

Tangible Benefits:

    Reduced Medical Bills: Potential savings if yoga eliminates certain ailments: $100/year.
    Decreased Therapeutic Interventions: Reducing therapy sessions can lead to significant savings, say $3,200/year.
    Enhanced Work Productivity: Increased focus might lead to more projects and a hypothetical extra earning of $1,000/year.

Intangible Benefits:

    Mental Well-being: Yoga aids in mental clarity, reducing stress, and enhancing overall peace of mind.
    Improved Flexibility & Posture: Regular practice can enhance physical flexibility and improve posture.
    Community & Connection: Classes offer the chance to connect with like-minded individuals.

ROI Calculation:
Potential Savings: $100 (medical) + $3,200 (therapy) + $1,000 (productivity) = $4,300/year.
Net ROI: $4,300 - $1,040 = $3,260/year.

And that doesnt include the Intangible Benefits:

    Well-being: Yoga provides relaxation, mental clarity, and an uplifted mood.
    Community: Classes foster connections and new friendships.
    Personal Growth: Discipline and resilience from yoga can positively influence life.
    Spirituality: For some, yoga offers a deeper inner connection and peace.

Author: sparkylarks
Content:
I see it as a parallel to fitness. I cannot say if you do this you will lose X pounds, but I can show how investing in a personal Trainer is proven to help people lose weight and the loss is somewhere between X and Y. 

One I example I love to use was where we put in a Graph of TOC form the Wastewater plan into every Control room and even the reception, The amount of TOC dropped by about 30% just by showing the figures. Did we know it was 30% before no, but we showed that 
1- Studies showed that a 15% improvement could be expected based on behavioural studies
2. with an improvement of just 7% the payback would be 2 years

Author: jon.forbord
Content: I guess there are other things that are much harder to calculate ROI than DT, such as training and free coffee at work.. I guess the point is anyway that asking for ROI on digital transformation, is like asking for ROI on Lean, because it’s a strategy, not a project. You can however estimate to some degree of uncertainty for isolated projects within DT and Lean. But I’d argue that DT projects has more uncertainty and unmeasurable quantity than Lean for example.

Author: sparkylarks
Content:
I actually looked at the cost benefit of getting a free coffee machine in work. A small three wheeler coffee van called daily and about 40 of the 120 staff would head out get a coffee every day and with the queues you could be out there for 30 minutes. It was a great social engagement

we estimated that 25% would still go every day, 25% would not go at all. 25 % would go 1 day a week and 25% woudl go 3 days. That would reduce the number but also the average queuing time from 30 mins to 15 mins, ......

Author: sparkylarks
Content:
I think there is some conflation of different approaches needed  at different stages of DT 
    Vision Pitching: Laying out the transformative prospects of digital tech. Here the ROI is 
    Project Roll-out: Tactical implementations from foundational groundwork to ROI-centric projects.
    Full Integration: Where digital technology is an ingrained business norm.

@SherylM Perhaps the outcome of the meeting the executive is to get funding to get 4.0Solutions to do a DTMA and develop strategy.

Author: jon.forbord

I was thinking more of the reduced/increased productivity of each worker jacked up on cafeen, and lost time due to walking to the coffee machine etc. But I’m not saying you can’t throw together some estimate, but the estimates are going to rely on more and more assumptions and uncertainty and hence have a degree of uncertainty.

Author: jon.forbord
Content: I’m assuming this is a known fact about budgeting in finance, that some numbers you put in your budget have more or less uncertainty. With the latest disturbances in the economy, banks and finance institutions has had to increase their numbers on the error vector of interest and inflation and etc..

Author: jon.forbord
Content: So while buying another CNC has an estimated 10-20% error vector on the ROI, investing in an OEE engine has an error vector of 10-3000% on the ROI. (I’m exaggerating for effect here).

Author: sparkylarks
Content:
Engineers place too much emphasis on the numbers being correct.

Imagine we are marketing pitching a new direction or campaign. 

They have sales forecast and market gains etc.but their inputs are waaayyyy less certain.

For me get the best data you have, be able to stand over you calculations and trust the results.

Author: sparkylarks
Content:
And to totally kill the coffee machine analogy.

We can go to a local distributer and hire a machine. And then return it and get a bigger one as we need. An different models and manufacturers form different offices.

Or we can go to.a consultancy pay 250k on a report into the correct machine, what options it should have and then get a reccommended solution of machine that is way over speced and overpriced but from the consultants strategic partner.

And they are so complicated they need to supply a barrista.and a machinist to support.

Author: sparkylarks
Content: And companies who take the second approach don't see the benefit and say it is too expansive to supply coffee machines.

Author: ted.garrison
Content: Agree.   And ROI in my opinion lots of times get's overworked.  Engineers will try to calculate exactly what the ROI is going to be, when it doesn't actually matter.   I just implemented (as a contract service) a maching monitoring system.  6 figure yearly cost.  I figured out how much downtime I'm seeing yearly, and how much downtime I'd have to save to pay that cost.  It basically worked out that if I saved one failure in our bottleneck system, I'd pay for the entire year.   Done. I didn't bother trying to guesstimate what the actual ROI was going to be.  Good enough to have it fully approved by all PO approvers that day.

Author: yasirtuncer
Content:
Business generate reports for fiscal years, can you give the ROI of the business for the founders? At which time?
What is misunderstood is Digital Transformation is a strategy it is not a program it is not a set of projects. It is like saying we will be more customer-centric we will improve our NPS score. 
Can you quantify the return for investing to this strategy? 
Let me ask you this Geoff what is the ROI of the training the company provides for their employees?

Author: yasirtuncer
Content:
Unfortunately it is not a set of projects, digital transformation is changing the way you do business. You can have more return from your investments in a further time horizon.  Digital Transformation is not just buying hardware, software, you train your people and they become more potent on what they do, you put data as your primary commodity and decisions are made not with experience but with data. You foster an environment where people are collaborating to solve business problems. You can say OK I invested in a machinery now I save on labor cost X amount, on cost of poor quality Y amount. Moreover you can say implementing digital work instructions we improved the operator efficiency by x% which yields to Z amount of dollars in the bottom line. 
However you cannot neither quantify nor put a time bound for executing a strategy because it is not projects

Author: yasirtuncer
Content:
@Mark O'Donovan you are still calculating the ROI for an isolated initiative. Digital Transformation according to your example is living a healthy life, this includes better nutrition, better exercise, better sleep, quitting bad habits etc. 
I have been in both sides of this table and for the last 5 years on the selling side.

Here is what I tell to C-Suite when I get the question of what is the ROI of Digital Transformation? 
First of all let's build a common language, Digital Transformation is a strategy it is not a project or initiative. It is changing the way you do business, like any change management you need to answer 3 questions?
* Do you need to change?  - Urgency
* Will you change? - Commitment
* Can you change? - Capability

You might said yes to all 3 however the success depends on a lot of factors, can you tell me why you need to become digital? 
If they cannot answer Sheryl shared Walker's highlights like survival, attraction of talent. 
Moreover I might argue that the aim of the DTMA is to give the company why they need to transform.

I never go into the details of how much it will cost? Even for a specific project the cost differs completely as well as the returns

The punchline is you will save more than you invest, the break even might be at 6 months or 36 months that depends on a lot of factors, how much budget do you have?

Author: yasirtuncer
Content:
This is where we have different opinions, I believe it is an indefinite game and the rules of the game, competitors are changing. The rules of the new era are faster delivery & product introduction, mass-customization, sustainable production while reducing costs. 

Now how will you achieve that is a set of projects? Moreover the execution of strategy is a function of your resources, every year consultancy companies publish the failure rate of digital transformation. If it were just projects, we were not even discussing the ROI. 

There is no end goal, top of the mountain you achieve with Digital Transformation. You train your body so you can run faster than your competition. You might argue each project is like an exercise like push-ups, squat etc. and you can calculate your muscle increase and burned calories. I am %100 with you on this, you can calculate the ROI of projects and training your body requires those exercises however you also need nutrition, repetition, discipline, sleep to have that body. (commitment from management as well as from shop floor, behavioral change, upskilling, agile working)

Author: akoscs

It is a transformation, so you have a current state. What are the concrete steps you are taking towars the infinte goal and how do you measure progress/success, how to you reflect on how much you progressed, how do you know if you are actually heading in the right direction, manage the steps, even if you have no budget limit?

Author: akoscs
Content: You can create FOMO all you want, that works at a strategy level, you get a nice strategy statement, when it comes to implementation, there is always a buget approval meeting. If there is no buget approval meeting, there is no implementation (if we are talking about brown field projects). Even if the c suits decide we will spend X bilion on digital transformation that money will be distributed smaller entities ask (!) for chunks of it, buget approval meetings take place.

Author: yasirtuncer
Content:
I actually shared on a few linkedin posts how to find improvement opportunities in terms of KPI, cost and current maturity as a series and possible use cases. I was a consultant for 5 years so I am good with frameworks, similar to Walker's approach connect, collect, visualize, analyze, predict. 

Now you need to measure your progress in terms of these steps and your dimensions are:

* Machine
* Process
* Operator
* Product 

You will burn money during the connect phase without any return there is no discussion around that, this is hygiene factor if you need data then you need to extract it from the source and publish it to common infrastructure. 

Organization should solve problems based on the analyzed data, if they don't act upon it no projects will help them and let's be realistic the prescriptive projects where AI has the control does not even %0.01 of total projects. 

https://www.linkedin.com/posts/yasirtun%C3%A7er_%3F%3F%3F-%3F%3F-%3F%3F%3F%3F-%3F%3F%3F%3F-%3F%3F%3F%3F%3F%3F-activity-7087187079759077376-rYFQ?utm_source=share&utm_medium=member_desktop

You can find the costs and how to reduce them on this post

Author: yasirtuncer
Content: Me and my team built the world's biggest digital transformation and capability building center, saved millions of dollars for companies with implementation projects. It is not FOMO, you are still looking from a project perspective and I agree with you there you need money for those projects. However when we talk about Digital Transformation which is a strategy, I am repeating myself you cannot calculate the ROI. You will ask the management we will need X amount $ for switches, cables, cabinet etc. and I will continue like when you are building a new factory do you calculate the ROI of you use for cement, steel, pipes, cables? No, but you know you need those.

Author: yasirtuncer
Content:
We can go forever with this ROI, that was my world while I was employed. Then I learned management who are actually people with emotions do not always act based on ROI. If they were looking everything from the ROI perspective they would have invested in their human capital which has the highest return on investment potential. You give them a 2000$ training and they can save you 100,000$.

My analogy for factory is for the infrastructure investment, you can always look for total cost of ownership and alternatives but you need some elements to hold the roof on top of you whether it is from steel or from titanium. 

Why don't the companies buy mentorship training for their engineers or mastermind training for their leaders like crazy? 4.0 Solutions provide so much value with these.

Author: willemrs
Content:
I agree, I think there is a similar sliding scale to basic human actions for most things.  Take trying to stop bad behavior in a child.  When they choose to do something bad the consequences can be immediate and certain, Immediate and uncertain, delayed and certain, then delayed uncertain.  In order of impact. 

DT is already off in the delayed area so its depreciated vs other spending, IE a new piece of equipment which could have an immediate ROI impact.  
What I keep trying to figure out is how to quantify a fundamental change in the way a business operates.  Then again, maybe this isn't even necessary as it can be done iteratively, but it would be nice to not have to beg for initial funding... 😀

Content:

If it is the first great let's talk about implantation strategies. and @SherylM nail it here.

But if someone is I  the second camp 
I think you need inaddation the the intangible benefits you mention to be able to list tangible bemefits and quantify them in some way e.g. companies that measure their OEE see a between 5 and 30% improvement. Taking a 10% improvement improvement that could mean a 10% saving on overtime, 2% reduction in Raw Materials and and give us enough capacity so we don't have to buy machine X for 300k

I don't think you can convert hearts and minds with fear of the negative.

But I do get that the breakeven depends on soo much and especially how much we spend in the project 

But I have a number of times offered to do the project for the first 18 months of savings and noone has ever considered saying yes

Author: walker.reynolds
Content:
I'll respond to this today in Mastermind -- Digital Transformation is not a product and should never be considered one.  Digital Transformation is a strategy -- and ROI cannot be calculated on it, ever.  Its easy to prove -- show me one example of accurate ROI calculation before or post-facto.  ROI can be calculated on iterations, on solutions, on use cases.  

I'll take it one step further -- if you're the client, and you have a vendor who is giving you an ROI calculation before you break ground -- simply ask them to modify their compensation terms to be solely dependent on the ROI and you'll see just how confident they are in their number (hint: they are not).

Digital Transformation isn't for everyone -- BUT, the companies who remain viable in our economy will be emerging companies OR legacy companies who digitally transformed -- that's an empirical certainty.

Commercial and Industrial DT has lagged behind Consumer DT -- we know the significance of DT for industry by reviewing the significance of DT for consumers.  Show me someone without a smartphone and internet, and I'll show you someone who doesn't partake in our economy.

Author: walker.reynolds
Content: The profitability of Digital Transformation Strategies are measured on the macro level -- generally in the P&L and stock price.  Why?  Because efficiency, capacity and yields are all positively effected by DT and produce exponential returns (n efficiency increase in line, area or site A often times return n2 or n3 across the org).  It is these permutations that we cannot quantify before we break ground -- if we could, we'd be at a black jack table counting cards.  The best example of ROI on strategy is in this image.  2012 is when this client launched their DT initiative -- and nearly all of the stock gains can be tied back to profit captured from operational efficiency improvements and, later, innovations.

Author: t.vesa
Content:
I would like to chime in about strategy, not as a renowned strategist myself, but more like casual strategy enjoyer for just a couple rows and cup of coffee. Or a wall of text perhaps, for which I apologize. 

Strategy involves setting goals, determining actions to achieve the goals, and mobilizing resources to execute the actions. Due to it´s metaphorical and somewhat formless nature I will approach strategy trough the well tested and concrete realm of warfare as it was the venue into strategy in generally for me due to curiosity not by trade. In example in Japanese business culture Miamoto Mushashi' is highly regarded strategist and he is  studied in the of Japanese business world. Mushashi started as a tactician, which was the term for a swordsman  in Japan and became a strategist when he grew into a warrior by understanding deeper levels, motives and meanings behind battles of armies or dueling men alike. He won over 60 duels with some of the best swordsmen of Japan and he  fought in many wars in feudal Japan and walked out alive, talking about a proof of concept here.
For keeping even a distant connection into our field, a parallel to draw here could be a person who starts as a automation technician and grows into position of a system architect.

Carl von Clausewitz (1780-1831) is the best known and the most highly regarded western strategist who argued that war could not be quantified or reduced to mapwork, geometry, and graphs. Just like a group of bean counters can not successfully run a company for an extended period of time as we have seen it and as many will learn it in the future.
Like Mushashi, Clausewitz was a professional combat soldier who was involved in numerous military campaigns.  Clausewitz introduced systematic philosophical contemplation into Western military thinking, with powerful implications not only for historical and analytical writing but also for practical policy, military instruction, and operational planning.

Author: t.vesa
Content:
- "Strategy belongs primarily to the realm of art."
- "Tactics belongs primarily to the realm of science."

Clausewitz argued that war theory cannot be a strict operational advice for generals. Instead, he wanted to highlight general principles that would result from the study of history and logical thinking. He contended that military campaigns could be planned only to a very small degree because incalculable influences or events, so-called friction, would quickly make any too detailed planning in advance obsolete. Military leaders must be capable to make decisions under time pressure with incomplete information since in his opinion "three quarters of the things on which action is built in war" are concealed and distorted by the fog of war.

- "Simplicity: Everything is very simple in war, but the simplest thing is difficult. These difficulties accumulate. The strength of any strategy lies in its simplicity."

I personally see strategy as a part of a waterfall. Strategy itself is formless and immaterial and excists just below the spiritual realm and above action with thought, concepts and raw potentiality. The Spirit forms into thoughts and thoughts form into actions. From there we can draw the what and why in a moral framework to define our strategic cornerstones i.e a business does not operate purely based on profits, but contains a moral element and goals. The Spirit makes any strategy to a force of destruction or a source of life thus dictating the broad nature of actions by anything involved in this system. A Strategy is a system within a system existing with interactive overlapping more influecial or lesser, friendly or hostile systems that born and die, they mature or degenerate as the time goes on. Creating digital strategy is the last drop in the waterfall before it reaches the river below, the basics has to excist before a reactive, fruitful and robust operatingsystem can take form. Is it easy? No. Is it simple? Yes. We are on the right path. Onwards.

Author: geoffnunan
Content:
Yes. Strategy is art. Tactics is science.
Digital Transformation is but a tactic used to deliver on a strategy

Author: jon.forbord
Content: Ok, I understand. We operate on different understanding/definitions of strategy. There is no one definition of strategy, but a common denominator is that uncertainty is key, meaning it’s to a degree of making an educated guess (call it art or a theory if you like) on the rules/principles you will apply in order to achieve a goal under uncertainty. Nobody knows if the strategy will be a success. It also needs to be fairly simple in its formulation, it can’t be a book, and it should be easy/concise enough that the subjects/people/executors can make judgements on their own from the strategy, when faced with a conundrum or problem.

Author: geoffnunan
Content: It all starts with WHY

Author: walker.reynolds
Content: ‘Agreed — if you don’t know why you want to make data the primary commodity in your business, stop — don’t spend a penny on digital initiatives and shift your focus to finding new leadership, one that can define your digital future — and then answer the why.’

Author: geoffnunan
Content:
Or do the work to define the why WITH your executive.
Your leadership are smart people, they must be to have gotten to leadership roles. They may not see things through the same lens as you.
Working with them to understand their priorities, working across the organisation to identify the real problems ( Use-cases ), and working to prioritise those use-cases and get the leadership's buy-in on what they see are the most important moves the business can make, will get you a whole lot further than just saying "It worked for Amazon, Tesla, etc..." 
A digital transformation is NOT a strategy, it's a tool you can use to achieve your strategy. 
The WHY comes first, then the HOW. Digital transformation is a HOW, is should not be the WHY.
The difference in semantics is important, but we can agree on the WHY comes first.

Author: patanj2
Content: I think in terms of semantics,  a strategy is not something you “achieve”,  but rather something you execute to achieve a goal.  I do think that a strategy makes no sense without a target or the “Why” as you have described.    Where I disagree is that a strategy is not a WHY.
