Author: sparkylarks
Content:
🍂 "O chestnut tree, great rooted blossomer,
Are you the leaf, the blossom or the bole?
O body swayed to music, O brightening glance,
How can we know the dancer from the dance?" 🍂
- William Butler Yeats, "Among School Children"

After the mastermind session and the latest youtube video I recalled the above quote from the William Butler Yeats Poem " Among School Children". Yeats beautifully contemplate the indivisibility of essence from existence, form from function, and in our  context — strategy from execution.  

Much like the dancer cannot exist without the dance and vice versa, a strategy, no matter how brilliant, is merely a thought or plan until it's executed. It's in the act of execution that a strategy comes to life, gets tested, and evolves

Honestly, I've seen quite a bit of banter here about Strategy vs. Tactics, projects vs. programmes, and I can't help but feel like we're just splitting hairs at times. Isn't Strategy basically a fancy term for our big-picture goal? And when we chat about tactics, projects, or programmes, aren't we really talking about the steps we're taking to hit that bullseye?

Here's how I see it: We start with a singular, monumental goal (or Aim). As we dissect that goal, we identify smaller targets (or Aims) that feed into the big one. At some point, these targets transform into actionable steps. These steps then morph into tasks, grouped into projects, all bundled into programs that cascade to serve departmental and organizational ambitions, all pushing us towards that ultimate goal.

In simpler terms: Aim big, break it down, act on it, and keep the rhythm going. After all, it's hard to tell the dancer from the dance, and maybe we shouldn't try too hard. Just enjoy the rhythm. 🎵🕺💃

Author: dapomeranz
Content: Can anyone enlighten me on the recent obsession with the term "data lake"? Why are we fighting so hard against relational databases that are tried and true? Why would we spend money on new engines and new query languages instead of working backwards and figuring out how to make nested data structures into relationalized tables? Or a way to query them using SQL-esque syntax?

Author: sammysevens777
Content: Its not a recent term....in fact it is a little dated - databricks has changed the game with the "lakehouse" (data lake + data warehouse). A lot of data is not structured (images, video, audio) and a data lake is a combination of structured + unstructured data (sql, nosql, object storage, files). So a datalake is "one spot" for everything

Author: patanj2
Content: Scale and cost ( by separating compute from storage and using cheap storage),  querying across data from different source data sets to name a few….and by the way a data lake  query engines support ANSI sql

Author: patanj2
Content: If you don’t need the scale and your coats are low,  by all means use a dab

Author: dapomeranz
Content: ^^ exactly. Why would ERP and MES data ever hit the scale that requires all this?

Author: sammysevens777
Content: Well ERP and MES data tends to be structured and relational, so in general SQL based. The scale is a different topic - relational databases can be very large as well....a data lake is more about accommodating different types of data in one place

Author: sammysevens777
Content: And if you mess it up....you end up with a data swamp!

Author: dapomeranz
Content: What types of data are average Manufacturing companies centralizing at large scale? I have always seen historian data totally separate and varying plant to plant.

Author: sammysevens777
Content:
supply chain data was one of the first to move to the cloud....integrating globally across many regions is really helpful when making logistics / planning decisions.

Production metrics were also aggregated for utilization rates (NA, SA, EU, Asia, etc.)...to help manage equipment inventories

Author: dapomeranz

Author: yasirtuncer
Content:
When AI  teams share their topology like this I love to ask this simple example. You have a temperature sensor and its history is 55 mean with 1 degree standard deviation, now your data started to be published around 132 and standard deviation changed to 2. Do you know what happened, you know something is off but what is the reason? With a few meetings you identified the maintenance team changed the sensor and prior sensor was publishing in Celcius now it is Fahrenheit. This is why context matters, Walker covers this in functional namespace in Mastermind. You cannot just act upon the values, you need context from other data sources, context from definition, context from how the function changed. 

Graph DB's importance will be more visible in UNS and manufacturers will realize the true cost of not having a scalable architecture with very harsh consequences.

Author: douglasalbright
Content:
I have been exploring the data vault approach, firstly assuring good event sourcing. There are ways to handle the variant types in a JSON payload in MS SQL and Snowflake; however, there are processing costs, data handling and potential latency issues. I have been firstly identifying how to from object around universal structure like handling an event's occurrence and resolution.

This way the first ingestion layer is strongly types and efficient. By making it an Event Sourced architecture it can be highly optimized for inserts. Then I am looking to use a Data Vault approach to support the ingestion of custom attributes. This way I can take the payload defined data types and transform them into strongly type attributes in the Data Vault defined attributes.

Data vault has been around for over ten years. I think what has changed to make it more viable is LLM coding assistance. I can give a LLM the source tables and talk about the final star schema model I want, and it does most of the work in a carefully guided conversation. Before, this augmented coding experience building such an advanced data abstraction would have been overwhelming.

Author: sherylmccrary
Content: *worth the cost to get the data immediately and make it available for use vs waiting on other parts of the business to decide on proper data structures.* Relatable to a lot of people, I'm sure.

Author: douglasalbright
Content: In a more agile/lean approach, focusing first on capturing from the event source, then moving onto data molding can be beneficial. Often, people assume that time series databases are sufficient, but molding data from this isn't sustainable. Cloud solutions promote the concept of remote storage along with best practices for data warehousing, but flexible data warehousing architectures can also be implemented on-site. This explains why purchasing Azure doesn't simply provide MS SQL in the cloud.

Author: jared.comer35
Content: What is your biggest rebuttal to customers who are hesitant to do cloud and SAAS based solutions. As some solutions that require lots of compute power or benefit from a unified architecture simply don't make sense on prem

Author: yasirtuncer
Content:
Even though most of our customers prefer on-prem solutions at MaestroHub, I faced many objections about the cloud during my consultancy years.
* We don't want to share our most valuable asset with others. 
* It is not secure
* It costs a lot of money

The best way to overcome the hesitation is to plant a seed that will grow over time in their mind and they will revisit their thinking

* I just asked them are you using MS365? If yes, is it hosted on your private cloud or public. Between the lines, the message is you are sharing more valuable information on e-mails
* I love the security aspect, do you think your network is more secure than Azure or AWS? They are getting attacked thousands of times more than yours and implementing countermeasures at least 10 times of yours.
* I am 100% with you on the costs if you send raw data and process everything in the cloud. Use it for storage or setting up VMs other than that be careful on the number of transactions you do. Optimize and TCO will be less than setting up an on-premise solution. The hidden costs are overheads, maintenance etc.

Author: suran23.
Content: Complete rubuttal of cloud tech is no way to data maturity and digital transformation at full scale. But an equally legit and strong edge strategy is required because a lot more can be done at the edge than what is currently the approach. From data fragmentation to sub optimal on prem solutions to confusion added by outdated systems, end users find themselves in this terrible conundrum. To that effect a unified architecture that is scalable, repeatable, and secure is what can deliver the best at the edge and send enriched data to cloud for better cloud roi. Sending raw data to cloud is not THE MOST efficient way to get on a fast track to digital tx. As mych is harped upon about bridging ot and it, it is really bridging the it and ot gap. Sounds the same until it is not. And to do that, the edge processing is equally significant as the cloud.

Author: geoffnunan
Content:
The best rebuttal is no rebuttal.
Why give up the cost and control benefits of on-prem? 
We run our fully cloud-native application stack on-prem by bringing to cloud on-prem. 
Why force a choice?

Author: nickn5549
Content: Hybrid is the way to go - use on-prem when it makes sense and cloud when it is needed... if you push for too much infrastructure change from the beginning...you get...nothing

Author: karltbraun
Content:
Just saw this posted in ISA Connect, in case anyone is interested:

After the COVID-19 pandemic, several measures have been discussed with the aim of strengthening health systems around the world. The application of Artificial Intelligence (AI) in Advanced Pharmaceutical Manufacturing based on Industry 4.0 concepts is essential for the API context and overall optimization of the Health System. This project presents the application of Artificial Intelligence (AI) in Advanced Pharmaceutical Manufacturing based on Industry 4.0 concepts. Implementing advanced manufacturing and optimizing process controls can provide pharmaceutical industry tools to respond to new public health emergencies of global importance adequately. This project started on June 25 and the initial purpose is to define the potentialities and opportunities of the application of AI in Advanced Pharmaceutical Manufacturing. In the second moment (next 2 weeks), we will start to develop, simulate and implement IA in pharmaceutical process control.  The group of researchers is initially composed of two researchers Ph.D. Ricardo de Almeida as an independent researcher and AI coordinator, and Ph. D. Kleber Barros from the Brazil Health Ministry as a researcher and pharmaceutical coordinator.  Together we working on the Virtual Laboratory of Advanced Process Control and Automation a private virtual environment developed and running since June 2021. We are open a suggestions and collaboration, best regards Ricardo De Almeida.


#Chemical
#ContinuousandBatchProcessing
#IndustrialInternetofThings(IIOT)
#Pharmaceutical
#scadaandRTU
#SmartManufacturing

------------------------------
Ph. D. Ricardo De Almeida
New Westminster BC
ISA Vancouver

Author: jrtzincovery_75026
Content: Whats the consensus on IEC 62264-1:2013 and how does it relate to ISA95? Do the described architectures support a UNS?

Author: rickbullotta
Content: Same thing as ISA95, more or less

Author: geoffnunan
Content:
IEC 62264-1:2023 is the international version of ISA95. It is the same as the 2013 version of the ISA95 standard.
There are a number of important updates that have been made in the ISA95:2018 standard which is currently being submitted to the IEC committee. My team have contributed an additional 5 improvements to the standard, which have in-principle agreement from both the ISA95 committee and the IEC Committee

Author: godsxidis
Content:
Hello everyone! I am software engineer working at a factory's IT dept. I got the task of digitalizing the production process, by capturing some data, generating reports etc. The data that is going to be captured are some barcodes that are placed on the items, some temperature sensors, as well as the conveyor's speed and inactivity times. There is no need for real-time data, but only "snapshots" of these values in certain time periods. 
The architecture that I came up with is setting up a new PLC that connects with all these inputs, and running a SCADA software that connects with the PLC, and saves the values and the business logic into a database. From there, I will build or use a template Web app, so that the factory's management can login and see the information visualized etc. The app will also integrate with the businesses' existing ERP, in order to correlate some data in greater detail.

Is there something I am missing or can be done easier? I know this probably is not the best solution when having to do with constant stream of data, but this is not the case in this scenario.

Any advice will be appreciated. Thank you!

Author: ted.garrison
Content: "There is no need for real-time data, but only "snapshots" of these values in certain time periods."  <- today. not tommorow. never assume.  capture it all.

Author: godsxidis
Content: Ok, I see that this is a more future proof solution. Provided that I go in this direction, is there something you would change or advise that I do ?

Author: ted.garrison
Content: assuming the conveyor already has a PLC, you may just be able to add the inputs to it.  Otherwise, a "simple" plc is probably all you need - say a Groov Epic, or EasyRack.  Or maybe just a Groov Rio if you don't actually need PLC capability, and just need I/O.

Author: ted.garrison
Content: key thing - plan for future proofing it.  The "standard" way around here is UNS.  Set that up from the get-go, even if it's just using Ignition as your SCADA and getting the Cirruslink MQTT modules.

Author: godsxidis
Content: Thank you very much for the detailed answer. I will surely use these concepts on the project

Author: sparkylarks
Content:
1. Project Title:

Real-time Monitoring and AI-driven Process Optimization for Higher Productivity
Project Summary:

The project aims to design and simulate an IIoT system in a cloud-based environment, using AWS services. The focus will be on real-time data monitoring and AI algorithms to optimize manufacturing processes in a discrete manufacturing setting, with an emphasis on achieving higher productivity.

2.Project Title:

Machine Vision for Automated Counting of Irregularly Shaped Parts in Discrete Manufacturing
Project Summary:

The project aims to develop a machine vision system using machine learning algorithms to automatically count irregularly shaped parts in a discrete manufacturing environment. The focus will be on leveraging AWS cloud services to create a real-time, scalable, and efficient solution to streamline inventory and enhance productivity.

Author: sparkylarks
Content:
Just to share.
I was at a spinning class last week and talking with my trainer who asked what I do. I mentioned Digital Transformation and got a complete blank.
I said, imagine as an athlete connecting sensors on every part,24/7 recording, collecting all that data and Visualising the output. Then starting to use AI to adapt traingin schedules and adjust technique.  
I said, well I'm doing that for manufacturing businesses, and she got it in 1. Understood the importance and the value it could bring.

When we look for examples of successful digitalisation, should sports teams who collect huge amounts of data to chase a 1% improvement, and have been doing so for years, the shining beacon of digitilization that manufacturing should look to.

Author: rickbullotta
Content: I more or less do that - between my Apple Watch, Oura Ring, Withings Scale/Body Composition, Kardia Monitor, Omron BP device, and related performance data from rides.  Lots of data that usually just tells me that I'm overtraining, not sleeping enough, or eating/drinking too late at night.  Which brings up a topic that is front of mind for me with data/AI - the difference between using data and AI for "eureka moments" (e.g. don't eat after 8pm, don't do a hard ride when dehydrated or after a 95% effort day, etc) versus using data and AI for "real-time optimizations" (at this moment, bring your cadence up to get your HR down to conserve some for the last part of the event).  I think you get the idea -they're two very different things and one lends itself more to "edge" processing.

Author: learner0756
Content:
I am looking for input on how to resource a digital transformation activity.
I am in the fail/recover quickly phase of experimentation and trying to win the results war 😃 
How would you estimate the effort/resources required to execute discreet integration activities?
For example, I am looking at a line with 11 discreet HMI's all with OPC UA.  What should i anticipate the time and effort required to publish out all tags to an MQTT broker?
1 week/machine?
1 month?
How long would it take to setup a historian that can publish from a broker to a azure db?
Any other watchouts for the initial connect/collect/store phase?
I am not looking for IT hurdles, mgmt buy in effort, just the enginneering effort to do the work, once a resource is trained on the task.

Author: ravil1
Content:
I think most time will be spent on designing your MQTT topic structure, and figure out what variables should be published to what topics.
If it is possible to use some generailized approach, common pattern on mapping from OPC UA to MQTT, this can be done very quickly.
With our ogamma Visual Logger for OPC you can map OPC UA variable attributes/properties such as browse path, display name, node Id to MQTT topics using Python scripts, or just using templates in simpler cases. So if your data is organized well in OPC UA servers, no way for it to take weeks or even days. Including some learning path it can be hours though I guess, not just minutes.

Author: vaughnturner
Content:
Hi Learner, from Alex Klein, one of our Solutions Architects at Intellic Integration. 

Alex Klein
A typical timeframe for a UNS PoC that puts those things in place is 1-3 months. Without knowing anything else about the environment (infrastructure, devices, company culture, etc) its impossible to give anything more accurate than that.

Author: learner0756

Author: vaughnturner
Content: You would need an experienced Architect for sure, obviously the more limited the skillsets of the team, the longer the timeline to completion.

Author: sparkylarks
Content:
@Learner  I agree with @Vaughn Turner , especially on the value of a good Architect, though even then depending on company Culture it might take 1 to 12 Months. 
If you are planning to do something a bit under the radar don't skimp on the planning. Even with an under the radar 

1 Calendar month to create a Digital Strategy, Review the current State of Business, Define you MTR and sketch a target Architecture.
you don't need to cover everything in this and it can certainly change but the idea is to minimise technical debt 

Another Calendar Month to Connect to the HMI's, Publish to the Broker and Store in your DB.
But you really need to include some Visualisation and Analysis, so you Can spot a Pattern and Solve Problems if you want to win the results war.

And I would probably recommend focusing on 1 Machine first getting some valuable Analysis, instead of having 11 machines connected and no Analysis or Problems Solved

Author: kskblr07
Content:
Hi, Has anyone used ServiceNow as the data repository with MidServer deployed in the data center to capture:
- sensor data that arrive at IT systems in the data center
- and also capture logs written by these IT systems

My client already uses ServiceNow for ITSM/ITOM. ServiceNow has plugins to capture logs from disparate log systems, MidServer plugins have the ability to filter out noise and propagate useful data to ServiceNow instance, and within ServiceNow we can combine this data with data from enterprise systems and use it for ITSM, ITOM & HLA. MidServer is also used for auto-discovery within the data-centers.

The problem i have with the above approach is data is held captive within ServiceNow and is available for further exploitation with ServiceNow tools only. I cannot use less expensive/more scalable cloud tools such as AWS/Azure storage/data/AI services. In order to do this I have to perform one more hop that costs: propagate data from ServiceNow into Data Lake. The other option is land all data in the less expensive Lake (using mqtt, kafka or Data Factory on prem), cleanse/enrich it and then propagate this to ServiceNow for ITSM/ITOM. The downside is i lose MidServer plugins/auto-discovery. Does anyone have any experience with these two approaches – pros/cons, life-cycle  & costs? Thanks!

Author: kskblr07

So we need to connect dots across system logs (i am simplifying this) to identify where performance degradation happened. And therefore the need to centralize logs and perform analytics.

Author: rickbullotta
Content: At a high level, be sure to design your MES using an event-driven model.  Expose every event you can think of in a pub-sub approach - work and process state changes, machine state changes, data collection activities, CRUD operations, and so on.

Author: busch1974
Content: I am having an internal debate with control engineers and IT.  We are an ignition shop with ignition (both edge panel & IIoT,  Kepware) at each plant and a full ignition gateway at our data center (distributor, historian, SQL).  We also use edge panel for any non OEM custom HMI's in the plants.  Controls engineers want to use remote tags  to communicate to the datacenter gateway in order to re-use plant machine UDT's.  IT is insisting transmitting the plant namespace containing related UDT's via MQTT to our data center.   Each plant publishes to a specific plant namespace in our data center distributor.    For the enterprise UNS at the datacenter we then use reference tags to the plant MQTT namespace and bring in context MES, SAP and other IT data.  We cannot reference a UDT only individual tags in the UDT> Any machine UDT  in the enterprise UNS currently has to be recreated  with reference tags back to the plant namespace related tags.  Controls are saying  creating enterprise UNS  machine UDT's is doubling the work.  IT is saying MQTT is less bandwidth, more secure, IIoT / Industry 4.0 standard, open and agnostic.   Looking for options and advice.. thanks in advance.

Author: geoffnunan
Content: My advice would be to consider yourself lucky that IT are even willing to consider MQTT. Its rare.

Author: sim_sam3
Content:
I just did a presentation on opc v mqtt for a trade show. Mqtt with json (no protobufs or spb compression) is generally less efficient than opc ua client/server after around 70 tags with 70 bytes per tag used for json and 26 bytes used for UA-DA. 

If you have spotty connections and need to reestablish a lot, opcua becomes less efficient (initial connection penalty bytes transmitted is big).

Other things to keep in mind are inbound port for UA, outbound only for mqtt and publish queue depth per ua item should be configured to 1 unless your ua client can consume the additional samples. If it can, and you don’t need a constant stream of quick value changes, then configure desired sample rate and use a slow publish rate.

If doing control/writes back to devices over mqtt it becomes an issue due to lack of determinism, but for non-critical I do see it used (with kepware receiving mqtt command to write and our drivers writing)

last piece if dynamic data selection - easier to make new requests for data with client/server OPC UA; with MQTT, have to RDP or call APIs or program enviro to reconfigure what's published.

Author: ravil1
Content:
Hi @Sam.E, is it possible to share the presentation? So far this is the only case when somebody from Discord community other than Walker really tried himself to compare bytes transferred over OPC UA vs MQTT and publsihed it here. These observations are expected, nothing surprising to me, but for others probably can be something new. Thank you for sharing this!
But to me this does not reduce value of MQTT anyway, because for modern network these loads are nothing, it needs to be maybe 100xs times more before really becoming  issue. Each of them have pros and cons and their place in IIoT infrastructure, not mutually exclusive.

Author: rickbullotta
Content: If it's a microcontroller over a satellite link or LoRaWAN, maybe.

Author: rickbullotta
Content: I would say the key is PERFORMANT and EFFICIENT.  When we were designing the wire protocol for Thingworx, we spent a lot of time on this.  It's much more than just bytes on the wire. It's how much compute and memory is required to serialize and deserialize, garbage collection, whether the protocol can be consumed as a stream or must the entire payload be received first, and things like this.

Author: rickbullotta
Content: I generally stayed out of that world because (this may be controversial), I don't care.   I don't think that's where value creation happens.  It starts at the layer above.  Obviously there are functional capabilities around discovery and metadata that matter just as much as the plumbing too.

Author: sim_sam3
Content:
@Ravil i went back to your posts from 2021; i ran the same tests as you (UA binary with default behaviors of typical OPC UA clients (subscriptions) v MQTT ASCII)

[from MParris]: Best I could tell, Ravil didn't do anything special on the OPC side. He just didn't have access to a sparkplug implementation. So his comparison was OPC UA TCP BINARY to MQTT JSON. Given the compression that OPC UA can do, I'm not surprised that Ravil proved OPC less bandwidth. Based on my tests, I found OPC UA TCP BINARY to require 2.5x the bandwidth of MQTT SPARKPLUG, which makes use of the Google ProtoBuf compression

Author: sim_sam3
Content: maybe the only net-new thing i add to the community once i post results is comparison of initialization penalty of UA binary v MQTT JSON and a few measures as tag count increases to help round out decisionmaking

Author: sim_sam3
Content: both are quite important

Author: patanj2
Content: I actually think that pub/sub with RBE is probably more important than the binary compression. RBE with reasonable deadbands on floating point values can easily save 80-90% of traffic.  I also want to add that it should not be only network capacity,  but sending lots of extraneous data (I.e). A temperature changing by 0.0001 Degrees) makes many  downstream consumers of data either more expensive, resource intensive,  or both.

Author: jpmoniz
Content: 100%. Exactly why that behaviour capability is needed more in the device than in a software abstraction layer above the device. But I guess that will take some time for some OEMs to figure that out.

Author: sim_sam3
Content: quite standard to use deadbanding with client/server protocols as well. i think in general deadbanding is impt for data reduction but certainly not exclusive to RBE protocols.

Author: ravil1
Content:
Agree 100%.
In this regard, additionally to deadbands, I tried to understand how RBE is used in specific use case discord members has experience, but could not get clear anwers. 
My question is: how do you handle "report when a value is changed"? If you don't apply deadband at all, there might be cases when every new measurement can result to different value. Like 1.0000012, 1.0000032, etc. That is just noice caused by the precision / accuracy of the measurent system. So if you scan  every millisecond, you will get "changed" value every millisecond. If you scan every minute, you will get "changed" value every minute. If deadband is not applied or maybe set to too small value, you can easily get your bandwidth used too high.
If OPC UA is used, it is all clearly can be controlled by the client. But if values are published by the MQTT client, it is all controlled at this client/publisher application. 
So, the question is - if you need to change scan rate for example from 1 second to 0.5 second, how do you change it all data sources quickly? I guess this again can be done by delivering configuration settings over MQTT, which perhaps I would to it. But it is interesting how this is actually done by you Discord members on your projects?

Author: rickbullotta
Content: There can also be a tiering of those deadbands/scan rates. You could have one set of thresholds for publishing changes from the device, one set of thresholds for firing events to subscribers/running scripts and another set of thresholds for historizing data.

Author: onlylyon
Content: Is there any discussion on QC here or mostly manufacturing less on the lab side?

Author: jpmoniz
Content: There can be from time to time. Just depends on what problems others are trying to solve but QC applications are fair game for sure.

Author: onlylyon
Content: Makes sense

Author: IIoT#4707
Content: GG @Lyon, you just advanced to level 1!

Author: patanj2
Content: In my setup,  i set a scan rate,publish rate and a deadband at software that serves as device driver/publisher.  Scan rate and publish rate are independent so you can scan at 100ms and publish every 5s, for example.  Subscriber software, such as HighByte and Ignition both can be used to republish the data at a lower periodic rate,  instead of at the publish rate.  There is a system risk in this setup of a rogue client publishing too rapidly and potentially overwhelming subscribers.  That is one reason an Enterprise class broker like HiveMQ has ability to configure throttling on throughput and other operational parameters.

There are 4 layers of materials that end up in the finished goods-- the intermediate layers being stocked parts. Some of which I already have plenty of in inventory. I have X number of available machine hours. I have all my BOM and Route times. Maybe for some added complexity some machines have minimum production quantities and/or fixed yield quantities. Generate a list of work orders.

Content: Nah - there are plenty of scheduling apps that can deal with this.  Check out Simio.com as an example of one.  It does a lot more than that as well.

Author: vaughnturner
Content:
.. There are Advanced Planning and Scheduling (APS) and Manufacturing Resource Planning (MRP) "modules" that can be leveraged at both the ERP, MES and stand-alone as part of a companies architecture. 
 
... First thing would be to better understand current state of the system(s), what is lacking from a capability and potentially integration standpoint and from there evaluate the buy vs. build question's being asked.

Author: bright_hummingbird_31342
Content:
Nice answers, as always, from Rick and Vaughn.

Often, to achieve those scheduling outcomes, there are a series of ERP modules that work together.  The modules and their underlying master data model is sufficiently detailed with the inputs and constraints the scheduling engine will need.  For example, the CRM and order management module provide demand signals or releases to a level ("buckers") that can be broken down to plan production and shipments.  Engineering modules will have BOM and Process Routings to define the product's production process (e.g., order of operations, materials) and how it utilizes capacity (e.g., standard rate, cycle times, parallel process streams, labor utilization).  Production modules will define the resources that make up capacity (e.g., assets, processes).  Sometimes the production module will take inputs from the maintenance module to define planned downtime that isn't available for scheduling production.  Inventory modules will show what's for available for producing, shipping, etc.  MRP and Purchasing modules can help with supply chain.

At a high level, you'll probably want to begin researching "Finite Scheduling" solutions.  Because of complexity of inputs and constraints to model, ERPs generally do this decently because the modules are integrated.  But, it can take quite a bit of working implementing all the modules and all the associated business processes.  Also, ERPs can be rigid.  They may not work well with every production process or modality.  Some give up on formal scheduling for this reason.

I've seen some use more generalized scheduling or supply chain solutions.  This provides more flexibility, but it's hard.  The integration is really tough because most orgs do not have a clean set of inputs and constraints to pull from.  For example, production or inventory records may arrive late or is regularly revised/adjusted because of errors.  Sending "garbage" into the scheduling engine makes the scheduling, well, "garbage".

Author: giladl
Content: Hi @Daniel Pomeranz long time 😋 There 3 general category of solution in this space. Algorithmic APS (use math to solve), Discrete Event Simulation tailored to do APS (like Simio), and now emerging AI/ML based algorithms either custom or tools (there are a few startups).

Author: bright_hummingbird_31342
Content: Long story short:  scheduling is hard.  It's a specialized field in itself.  Most orgs trivialize it and subject their precious working capital to the limits of under resourced teams and spreadsheets.

Author: giladl
Content: Yep, and spreadsheets by far is the most prevalent APS tool in our industry and main others. This points to the fact that the most effective method to do scheduling is to use "Human Intelligence".

Author: gtwirth
Content: Most APSs can read from spreadsheets (and other sources) and incorporate whatever logic the production scheduler uses to create their schedule. The main problem capturing all the reasoning that the production scheduler uses to create the schedule.    It is hard to express everything logically.   This is where ML can assist.  That said, you should always have a manual override mechanism to give the production scheduler a means to override the APS logic / ML decision to gain their acceptance.

Author: jon.forbord
Content: This is why I like to use OPC UA on the edge, and publish to mqtt. I get the control I want from OPC, and the autodiscovery, pub sub etc from mqtt. Done and done! OPC UA (DA) is even fairly prominent in edge equipment as compared to mqtt or sparkplug!

- I am thinking of proposing an MES solution for them
- Thinking of doing this using Sepasoft OEE Downtime and Track & Trace

Any other recommendation? Looking for an option where we can test out the features or build a PoC with?

Author: jpmoniz
Content: I would suggest you understand what problems they have and why they are going after an MES  I would assume they have some sort of requirements document generated to be short listing products.  If you can get into that conversation then you can turn the conversation to strategy.  You would want to see if they are thinking strategically or are they just solution focused.  The goal is always to show how the right strategy can provide value to the problems they know about and the future problems they come up with when enabled with the right infrastructure.  That conversation can go well if they are open and know what they don't know.  It could go the other way if they are focused on singular goals or biased on the immediate problem they are trying to solve.  You will know that once you feel them out and have the right conversations.  I wouldnt be talking about products but about their problems and how a certain architecture solves said problem and enables future problems/growth.

Content: The weaknesses of OEE are well documented. And failure to include metrics such as safety, energy, and on time delivery will lead to poor outcomes.

Author: rickbullotta
Content: It’s a dead end actually. 😈 Very few companies can actually track it accurately l, particularly quality. It’s mostly a misleading KPI. Track availability and performance if you can do so accurately, but I’d bet that the vast majority of OEE implementations are inaccurate by about 10% or so.

Author: hobbes1069
Content: More likely worse, I would be happy with a +/- 5% accuracy. It's enough to tell me if I'm winning or losing.

Author: d_leblanc
Content: We actually removed OEE from our standard reports and only provide it if requested. It was very misleading and caused more issues then it was worth. Performance we do accurately, Quality we were only tracking reject from a machine.. availability was pointless to try as people get moved around and no one updates the system

Author: ctown_kyle
Content: I always like to go after availability first if possible. I actually cut our shift change time in half just by reporting when the first part was made at the beginning of each shift. It wasn't until then that the supervisors realized the 15 minute shift change actually took about 30 minutes on average.

Author: rickbullotta
Content: Sometimes, but usually not at the necessary granularity, and some causes are not automatically detectable. Also, I do not like the way most companies “punish” a work center with reduced availability numbers even when the cause is upstream or downstream - that intensely bothers me.

Author: nickn5549
Content: SQCDP can be simplified in the first phase as QDE (Quality, Delivery, Effectiveness) and covers Quality = Cumulative Yield, Yield; Delivery = Line Throughput, Output Linearity, Manufacturing Lead Time, Raw Material Inventory,  WIP, Bonepile; Effectiveness = Labour Productivity, OEE, Overtime, Absenteeism, Skills and competency, Lost time from accidents.

Author: d_leblanc
Content: we are very good at tracking availability, utilization of the machine. the issue is comparing it to planned time...  we can plan breaks, lunch, tool changes but that is generally as far as it goes and it is a set time that never changes. Then you have supervisors getting the operators to take staggered breaks so certain machines run all the time and other machines the operators were taken from now have more time not running or people get shifted around. Production does their own thing and different depending on whos running the show that shift.

Author: rickbullotta
Content: If I machine is starved because of an upstream issue or blocked because of a downstream issue, how do you handle it?  Most OEE implementations count it against the work center but assign the reason code appropriately.  That's silly, IMO. It's not the work center's fault.

Author: hobbes1069
Content: Utilization yes, availability typically no. You need the operator to tell you why the equipment isn't available in most cases, some reasons you may be able to intuit based on other signals.

Author: d_leblanc
Content: That is the issue with OEE and why I am personally against it. Your best machine can have the worst OEE because of conditions not related to the equipment itself and points people in the wrong direction. We generally do not use OEE at all in most of our facilities. We do everything in JPH and do constraint analysis. We can make informed decisions and work on the bottleneck machine/operation, make improvements and move onto the next one.

Author: vikanchira

I take @RickBullotta and @Daniel LeBlanc point though. Will try other methods and compare. I have 2 cases now and would be interested in reviewing.🥸

Author: rickbullotta

Author: vikanchira
Content: Less than 5% of manufacturers know what OEE is in Thailand. So... 🤣

Author: giladl
Content: You may want to keep that way 😉

Author: sparkylarks
Content:
I'm going to jump in a defend OEE. and then leave the office and get coffee for a while.

Pros
- Is is widely used so people know what it is
- It is easy to calculate even from little data.
- It can help to highlight issues quickly and lead to quick wins.

ways to make it better
-OEE is based on the standards, and cannot be redefined by reallocating machines or calling safety meetings.
- you need to include capturing downtime, Performance and Waste issues, and here only ask the operator for what is observable, not the root cause


to @RickBullotta and @Daniel LeBlanc 's point,. 
If Rick is on Machine 1 and I am on Machine 2 and I cannot run my machine because I am waiting for stock from Machine 1. 
Then the downtime is applied to my machine, and the reason was  "Rick didn't have his work done". We can then put in measure to schedule in a way there there is a buffer of stock to reduce the downtime on Machine 2.

If the pieces from Machine 1 are not good enough quality and need to be rejected or reworked, then I like to reject, and apply the waste to Machine 1.

In both those cases, I now have a metric showing red and the data collected to allow me understand the root cause and fix it.

with Customers do often calculate another measure sometimes called ME 'Machine Efficiency' , or EE 'Equipment Effeciencey' and the idea here is to allow the operator see how close there were to perfect. In that case, stock not available, would not  count against performance. Or if changeover was within the plan, or where the target speed for that product is less than the machine max speed then that would not affect performance.


But I think a lot of the criticism for OEE is because people try to use it to rate operators performance and that is not a good use of OEE.
It's like putting a sock on your hands to keep warm and complaining hat you can't tie your shoes.

Author: rickbullotta
Content: “Widely used” isn’t necessarily a positive.  Opioids are widely used too. “Easy to calculate” either, since it’s very rarely accurate. And a couple hours on the shop floor watching and asking questions will “highlight issues quickly”, probably better. Cheers.

Author: sparkylarks
Content:
a couple hours on the floor watching and asking questions, wont come close to adding the value that tracking OEE will.
That is a nonsense statement. It is not repeatable, systematic, or transferrable across machines or sites.

Author: sparkylarks
Content:
and how do you measure improvement. ?
Measuring yourself every day on a uncalibrated scales, is a much better approach to losing weight than not weighting your self and asking people how do you look and do they think you are losing weight

So even if you don't use OEE you still need a measure to track. and if you are measuring Availability Performance,. do you not look a quality or yield in some fashioin, Surely you can't ignore it.

Author: sparkylarks
Content:
And as an anecdotal example, Last month I was on site, I asked the operator about the Machine speed, 72 piecs per minute. he said any faster on that product would lead to higher defects. Machien running at max so??

After shift changeover, new operators, made some tweaks and upped the speed to 85pieces per minute, waste was lower.

Author: sparkylarks
Content: Widely used, means that it is a know quantity that people are familiar with and can gain acceptance of pretty quickly. that allows improvements to be made without needed people to get familiar with a new metric

Author: sparkylarks
Content:
how does Jobs per hour work? 

In the case of issues outside the control of the machine e.g. my machine is starved of material by an upstream process, how does the JPH approach show the issue is with the upstream machine
Basically I don't understand how JPH prevents "Your best machine can have the worst JPH because of conditions not related to the equipment itself.

Also  My latest project I have some jobs that take 1 hour and some that take  days.
I am looking at one job which is a 1 million job order and was started before Christmas.
It is running at 350 pieces per minute. Scheduled Duration is 9.1 days
do I need to normalise some how. Or am I comparing to a predicated Jobs per hour?
If from 2 to 3 PM I am running part of a 1 million piece run and with a target rate 150 pieces per minute. 
Do I have compare my actual .012JPH to my target .009 JPH?

Author: rickbullotta
Content: You know you’re pushing a rope trying to convince me. 😈 I’m all for tracking the constituent completes IF you can track them accurately, which is a giant IF.  And we will strongly disagree on the value of Gemba walks.

Author: rickbullotta
Content: That anecdote supports EXACTLY what I'm saying - your discussion with the second operator led to insights.  All the OEE tracking in the world wouldn't likely have achieved that same result.

Author: rickbullotta
Content: Also, it's VERY rare that defects are caught "in real time" and charged to the correct work center - usually caught downstream or offline.  Some industries can do inline test, but only a small fraction can do 100% testing.  It's kinda like the availability issue - it incorrectly/inaccurately punishes or rewards the wrong work center.

Author: sparkylarks
Content:
I know I'm pushing a rope. And I am all for Gemba walks, but once we have the data.
And I want to start my Gemba on the consistently lowest OEE machine. In a plant with 100 machines, some 20 years old and some 6 months old. I want to have some metric to start on the lowest 10% of performers and work my way up.
Maybe a poor performer is an old machine and there is no quick win, ok, i'll move on

But the bit that I really struggle with is 
If you track the constituents why not multiply them.
if you have 2 machines with A Q  and P of   65 , 70  and 90 and 65,  80 and 60 which one would you recommend needs further investigation. 

The current project, all the waste goes into a Bin, and that is on a scales and we calculate the number of pieces, and it seams to be about 1% accurate when I test it.
I appreciate that it is not always so accurate on other facilities. And I am showing over 200kg of paper being wasted on the current Job. 
I want to tackle that.
but even if it is +- 10% over a month that will probably even out. Or there is a deficiency in the measurement method so it always read low in one direction.
So I still see use in an inaccurate measurement.

If I don't measure waste, to me It is like assuming no waste.
So if I measure and have 20% waste, and it inaccurate by 30% so waste is actually 14, or 26 % that is still way way better than not tracking it.

Author: sparkylarks
Content:
My OEE tracking would show the increase in the OEE across the shift for the same Product and the same Job.
And without the tracking of the performance metric I need luck , or a lot of walks to highlight the issues.

Author: rickbullotta
Content: Regarding multiplying APQ, I think that the resultant stat is too opaque.  It also fallaciously assumes equivalent negative impact on profitability/margin from all three components.  I did a talk at a MESA conference a few years ago showing how this wasn't the case, and how higher OEE could lead to lower margin in some cases.  My summary is simple: track what is relevant and track what you can measure accurately, and go beyond OEE to include safety, energy, and delivery performance.  That we can all agree on, right?  Cheers Mark.  I'm really not trying to be a d*ck here.  Just encouraging going beyond OEE.

Author: sparkylarks
Content:
Going Beyond OEE, I 100% agree with.
But to me I do OEE first. then go Beyond it.

And I get the point that OEE can be too opaque, and if you follow it blindly you can do stupid things.
But is it not the same of any measurement or KPI.

And I understand that normally  AQP of  70 70 90 is not the same as 70 90 70 . I would look at the 70% quality first.
But that is from years of experience across industries,  and the understanding that a scrapping 20% more product has higher costs than running 20% slower for a lot of industries,

And a way to convert my AQP to a cost impact would be better.
And that is what I am working to with Clients, but we don't have the data for that yet.
So I'll start with OEE, then look at Schedule Adherence.

Author: r.pop
Content:
OEE by itself does nothing. It's all in how your organization is set up to act on the data provided. People get too caught up in the target's of OEE and forget that the purpose is to just get better. More throughput, Less Scrap, Less downtime...When measured correctly, these can all be beneficial data points. Ultimately though, it comes down to the business's ability to act on that data. 

Whenever we deliver an OEE solution, we deliver with a Policy Deployment guideline, that also instructs the customer on what they should do with the data that comes from the OEE system. Just measuring it does nothing.

Author: technicality
Content:
Definetely agree on requiring AQP separately as well. Actually I don't think I've ever looked at a dashboard/dataset containing only OEE. The very first thing you need to do is check AQP to compare & contrast in time, between lines, etc. (or maybe TEEP and underlying numbers first?).

And likely people will have some idea where there problems are. Having some somewhat reliable stats that can corroborate or disprove that helps the decisions along. Just hope you can have a grown up discussion with the stakeholders and not get hung op on arguing about the validity of the numbers. If they can be factually shown to be incorrect (actual machine data helps), sure, but otherwise just pick a problem (remember to optimize at the constraint) and start solving?

Author: geoffnunan
Content: The KPI i'd love to be able to manage is the % of maintenance budget spent on resolving the top 5 solveable issues. In 28 years talking with operations teams around the world, i've only ever seen 1 site that had it, and they ran 20% higher OEE than other similar plants in the same business.

Author: kevinhibbins
Content: Yes! Measures such as OEE are essentially a measure of the success (or otherwise) of an underlying bona fide continuous improvement program or equivalent, and if there is none then measuring anything has a much lower probability of doing anything better!

Author: kevinhibbins
Content: Re OEE, of course it (and its parts) can be used to add value, but it needs to be done consistently, without manipulation, with the right contextualization, interrogated & consumed appropriately, and of course form part of a wider KPI analysis regime that can drive a business forward. I note, that under standard terms, a line could run at 100% OEE and be highly unprofitable. Other metrics such as Utilisation, Labour, Energy, etc should be included.

Author: vikanchira
Content: We all need a starting point. I also like to start with A, P, Q then OEE, then beyond. Removing OEE altogether doesn't make sense for me but I am also looking for alternatives and other matrices.

Author: Deleted User
Content:
[I slightly followed the long OEE thread] 
We used Vorne OEE at my first job. Not even close to being accurate (especially because quality was always 100% LOL) but still provided an immense benefit. Allowed us to deep dive into unplanned stop reasons, leading us to create a better TPM standards and ultimately a very nice PM rebuild schedule.

We were also self taught engineers (fresh EE/ME graduates with no engineering leadership) the Vorne content alone taught us so much about this industry and eventually led us to ask more questions about OEE metrics which ultimately lead us to this YouTube channel back in 2018.

We would even create diagrams, documents, forms, and trainings to teach all other maintenance and operators, based on our Vorne/4.0 industry content learnings.
In the end, the people were the greatest challenge. Many laughed at us and straight up told us they'll never take our suggestions or fill out our forms lol. 
That's when we learned it needs to come from leadership, we gave up and looked for a better career that takes industry 4.0 seriously lol

But, due to this I am still a big advocate on OEE and free online learning content. Imo, it's not necessarily about the specific KPI, protocol, tech stacks, Lean certs, or large document processes. These are all tools, and there can be value added from any of them depending on the environment and how you apply them.
 It's about the people, the mindset, and the leadership.

Author: technicality
Content:
Right, but time is included in the A cost (times $XX per hour). If one wants to split that up into waiting and working time to help you understand where the time goes, hopefully the data is there for you (maybe task time is written in CMMS right beside the parts cost?).

It really depends on the plant/site challenges, I guess in this story it must've been expensive repairs. Of course many repairs can be viewed as 'delayed maintenance' so same spare goes in regardless of corrective or preventative. 
Unless it is a huge crash with collatoral damage, or things like overnight(ing) fees need to be paid.

By the time you get into these kind of blended use cases one's hopefully moving along nicely in terms of using data to improve, right?

Start simple I will say. What is your problem? Lets find some data. Do you have none? Lets start making some. If your problem is planning adherence, lets make it facts. If your sub problem is availability issues, lets make those facts. etc. etc.

Easier said than done, but once some trust is there a lot is possible with little data. Just getting to it is the next challenge...

Author: kevinhibbins
Content: Thank you @SebastienAuclair for your synopsis, I enjoyed reading it. Just checking, have you been on the red wines? Hope so because then I look forward even more to discussing! Seriously though, sounds like we cover a similar career spectrum. I graduated electrical engineering in 1993 and quickly became responsible for a highly automated 24x7 manufacturing plant as process control engineer, so I guess I was I3.0 born and to be honest it's where I learnt a LOT. I believe what has happened since is the proliferation of technology that has somewhat out-paced human advance. We've gone through various "laws" such as Moore / Kryder / Neven etc, but what it means in layman's terms is that technical capability has exceeded functional human capacity to absorb it, in general. Humans are now bedazzled by buzzword bingo which leads to analysis paralysis and the like. I think if we, as a technical community, stripped the message back to be more outcomes focused then the technology / capability will come along for the ride, rather than the opposite.

Author: kevinhibbins
Content: And of course don't forget the law of diffusion of innovation, which I think is even more prescient today.

Author: r.pop
Content: When I lead this effort for a large Tier 1 Auto OEM, we tied our Ignition OEE system to our e-maint CMMS. We had a range of faults that we determined as "Critical" or "Significant". If one of those faults occurred 3 times in a row, or 5 times in an hour, it automatically called an API in our e-maint system to assign a workorder to a technician to examine what was happening.

Author: r.pop
Content: We saw in increase of uptime of about 10% with that system in place. And if you've ever been in an Automotive plant, you'll know that 10% is $$$$

Author: hiptopjones
Content: I really like that electrification comparison.  Electrification is a fairly abstract concept (like data), even if the manifestation is physical.  Common electrification infrastructure was necessary to get the most value.  If electrification was approached as point-solutions, then the very specific infrastructure developed for each solution would not have made future solutions easier or even possible, and would not have been compatible with existing solutions.  Today, everyone in a geo region operates on a common electrical standard, and we take that interop for granted every day.  There are many, many examples of this (roads, telephones, etc.)  To help businesses navigate the snake oil, there needs to be a language to place DX in context like that.  Unfortunately, there is no broadly accepted standard yet to organize efforts around, which makes it every vendor for themselves today.  Education is the only way out of that, and that flywheel takes time.

Author: technicality

Author: ctown_kyle
Content: Exactly. I worked at a place where the campus was over 100 acres. I recommending putting in a "waiting on Maintenance" downtime reason that the operators could select once maintenance was notified and then the maintenance personnel would select the actual problem (press, conveyor, robot, etc.) when they started troubleshooting. Looking back on it, outside of major breakdowns there was always a large amount of downtime due to not having the right people at the equipment, like waiting on maintenance, waiting on supervisors, waiting on Quality sign-off.

Author: r.pop
Content: Makes a lot of sense. Also a good method to follow if you can't capture accurate downtime data from a machine. Sometimes if we could only get "running/not running" we would enable that feature as well. Allow a qualified person to enter the downtime reason that occured during that "not running" state. A lot of times it was "waiting on parts"

Author: d_leblanc
Content: I dont do enough in Siemens for it to be worth my time and dont really know the structure of it. I believe there are a lot of different files you need to create/modify but not 100% sure.  I have a code generator that writes complete Allen Bradley PLC programs as an XML import file. I store a lot of the chunks of code in SQL database with "tags" (unique text) that I can replace with code that is unique to the program. I also have large chunks of XML containing standard logic and AOIs in separate XML files. my code generator is build in python, it will connect to a DB in the facility the program is for and pull info about the line, then connect to the code gen central DB which stores all the code snippets. at the end it will read all of the larger XML files into string and stitch everything back into 1 XML file with all the program logic and 1 csv with all of the tags (easier to create the tags as a tag import then in XML).  I dont know how tia openness works but with AB, I can take a blank program, save as XML and that gives me the XML to create an empty project. then as you add programs, routines, hardware in the I/O tree etc, I keep inspecting the XML to see the format of each aspect of the program. If you can do this in TIA Openness, it will help you identify how to write all the parts of the project

Author: sparkylarks
Content:
Great article but  I have an issue with the idea that the 2nd revolution is all about electrification. 
yes electrification is part of Industry 2.0 but so was
Iron and Steel, Bicycles, rubber, Automobiles, Rail, Telecommunications, Steam turbines

The Third Industrial Revolutions encompasses the Transistor and the Internet.

I do think that Electrification is a Great analogy for the digitalisation of manufacturing, but I do think that given the wide swath of the previous Industrial revolutions, this one seams a bit narrow, and it certainly seams a bit premature to move to the 5th revolution already.

I think when historians look back, at the 4th industrial revolution it will look at a lot more than Digitalisation, and include things AI and 3D Printing, and will include the likes of predictive maintenance, but may even include as much as connected supply chains, computerisation of services from the ATM to the AI broker I will talk to on the phone, and might even look to include ecommerce and brand fragmentation and localisation.

Author: sparkylarks
Content:
I do not fully understand the question.
Maybe if I clarify what I was saying.

I think the definition of the 4th Industrial revolution is to me small given the breadth of the previous revolution's. And to give an example Looking at the Third Industrial revolutions, it was about much more than electrification and includes, Steam rail travel ,steam engines, bicycles

That doesn't mean I am saying that there is no 4th Industrial Revolutions( I an probably mentally differentiate this from I4.o  which is a German Industry/Govt marketing term).

But I am saying I think when historians look back they will encompass more than just DX of manufacturing. I am not sure I can predict what they will include

I think that to Digitally Transform a company it takes "transformative Leadership" and by that I mean a commitment from leadership in terms of resources and permission to innovate and even fail, in order to become a company that has access to the data it need in real time. 

I don't personally like to use data company because to me that is a company that sells data. A company that uses steel to make knives is a knife company , not a steel company. so using data really well to me doesn't make a company a data company. Maybe I am wrong in this and I'll change my mind in the future.

Author: jon.forbord
Content: From a historical perspective there really ever was just one Industrial Revolution. But saying we’re in a fourth one is still an effective way to say that there’s a train leaving the station soon, and you better get onboard if you don’t wanna get left behind.. 😅

Author: giladl
Content: Rather than classify the changes by technology we can look at what it did for society, ie the outcome. Every one of the revolutions (step changes) caused a monumental change in how we work, think and use technology. More importantly it brought a step change in productivity, I like to phrase it as "order of magnitude" productivity increase. This is a fact for the first 3 industrial revolutions, the 4th where we are now, is still not clear and will only be clear if it does the same to our industry. We will only know if it was a revolution after it happened. The problem is that if you and your company wait for that you will have missed out with dire consequences. So embrace the change and focus on the outcomes.

Author: bright_hummingbird_31342
Content:
There is a certain reputation and stigma around management consulting that I can't refute.  But, regarding Deloitte, I think some people would be surprised.  

Years ago, I used to think of Deloitte as the firm that botched Oracle implementations.  It was hard to imagine how someone could take bad products and bad commercial practices and make them even worse.  Perhaps that was the norm in ERP space in the past, but there's much more to Deloitte than what meets the eye today.

Many would be blown away by some of the stuff they quietly work on related to Industry 4.0, UNS, OT, cybersecurity, etc.  It's technology-centered, open-architecture, vendor-agnostic, and client-focused.  They push the tech many of us discuss on this server to a scale and scope few have.  I would not write them off as some dinosaur company dabbling in industrial automation.

Author: nickn5549
Content: Value Stream Mapping (VSM) or Materials and Information Flow Analysis (MIFA) is a lean manufacturing thingy that consists of all the actions required to bring a product or service through the flow from raw materials or information (data package) to the delivery to your customer. A VSM perspective means that you look at the big picture, not just the individual processes or tasks. The goal is to optimise the whole not the individual components. What do you have in mind when you say VSM in the context of DT?

Author: carson3949
Content: is it part of the DT or MES ?

Author: nickn5549
Content: It's a separate beast part of lean manufacturing methodology.

Author: sparkylarks
Content:
@carson3949 @NickN 
To me Value stream mapping is really valuable and ensure that you can understand and communicate the process to others, i.e. integrators etc.

It can be really really valuable in a a DT, or even MES implementation, but because most companies don't use them it can become very difficult to justify the time and cost, if they are not already created.

They are a bit like Functional Logic Drawings, or well maintained panel drawings.

But if you have a set of value stream maps I would say it can give you about a 1.3x acceleration in Time.

What it will really save is all the small changes that need to be made during UAT, where it turns out the communication of the process to the integrator was not up to scratch.

Author: sparkylarks
Content:
I am not sure we are meanind he same thing when we say a VSM.

To me it is a document that describes the process in a similar way.

the value is that if you hire me to automate you process, be that a production or business process, I need to first understand it.

that can be very difficult, and a Value Stream map really helps with that.

To me it is the same as ig you want to to do some mechanical work in a Plant, it is much easier for me to understand the existing plant if you have a P&ID, 
or if you want me to add components to a panel. If you have drawing for the panel , it is much faster for me to define what work needs to be done.
Or if you want me to modify a PLC can you can send me over drawings of the Logic,

Content:
It does. 
what food or Beverage and I can give an example

But where it becomes particularly useful, is in the non core process. like staging, or quality, i.e. what happens when quality check fails.


I suppose Technically I am referring to Process mapping, rather than VSM, but I would defend that in two ways 
1- It is still important to understand the flow of materials, especialy if you are looking at traceability. Think tracking product batches in a dairy, how do you know where the cream and skim milk goes?
 2- VSM is big picture and you end up with a bunch of processes as boxes, you need to dig in ad look at the process.
i.e. in a Dairy and when a pasteuriser, going out of temp range, what happens,

Author: ted.garrison
Content: Interesting they put OEE on those VSM diagrams.  I find VSM's to be very beneficial - normally in pointing out how few people that should know the process, actually know the process.  But I can't see how OEE would actually be a beneficial datapoint for it.  If they instead had the APQ values, then maybe - but even still, those are showing how you're not meeting the process, not how poor the process actually is.  The idea of the VSM is to find all the places in the process where you're doing stuff that ADDS NO VALUE, and get rid of it if it's not required for some other reason (regulation, etc.)

Author: ted.garrison
Content: once you get the VSM activity completed, then you can start diving more into the "why aren't we actually getting that cycle time.  Why aren't we meeting the leadtime"

But even a quick VSM could be very useful...just walk the flow from beginning to the end, helps you see operations - helps to visualise the production flow, allows you to see waste in the system, provides framework for conversations, demonstrates interaction between information and material flows, ....

Author: icecream06388

Author: walker.reynolds
Content:
I am prepping for a call and was asked to read this post.  I apologize for missing this when it was originally posted.

The answer to your question is many-fold.  But there are two points that jump out at me that we should highlight.

1. You are definitely approaching the question from the perspective that ALL legacy orgs will find the answer.  This is a fundamental mistake most in our industry make (OEMs, End-Users, SIs et al).  The fact is, during transformative times, only a fraction survive without bankruptcy and/or M&A.  The number, based on a longitudinal analysis of Industry 2 and Industry 3, is 1 in 12.  1 in 12 are your audience and will find the answer.  One of the major reasons we see so much 'noise', buzz-words, fuzzy definitions is because OEMs are trying to sell to 12 in 12.  They are taking guidance from all customers -- even those who have no idea what DX actually is.  This is where you see people attribute terms to outcomes that are unrelated (calling a proprietary, deterministic integration 'open' or calling the digitization of a report 'digital transformation')

Become digitally fluent so you can't be confused by the noise and then focus on the 1 in 12 (they are the examples for the 11 in 12 to follow)

2. A principle I don't talk about often but is very important is The Shirky Principle.  Groups try to preserve the problem to which they are the solution.  It is in OEMs best interest to muddy the waters, confuse, hijack, misappropriate, obfuscate what DX and I4 are,  to preserve what they have in the market.  Legacy OEMs are most guilty but there are plenty of start-ups who do the same.  OEMs are actively trying to preserve the problem (barrier to entry for conversion of digital data into information in service automating business decisions while plugging into a digital supply chain) because they make money off of being the solution.

Focus on the relationship between digital strategy, open and edge driven architectures and transformative leadership -- and ignore the noise.

Author: vaughnturner
Content: @icecream06388 you can always go to the #questions channel. It's for all questions, regardless of topic.

Author: walker.reynolds
Content:
Deloitte doesn't have a technical problem they have a business model problem.  Their incentive structure is to go deep and stay long (super expensive) while preserving their strategic commercial partnerships with vendors (recommend less than optimal).  That is the key reason they do far more harm than good.

I agree with you -- they have a lot of cool stuff going on behind the scenes but its behind the scenes for a reason and that isn't going to change.

There is no vendor we replace more in DX  than Deloitte.

Author: walker.reynolds
Content: TCP/IP won the protocol wars in 1998 -- that is the disruption, from that moment forward, the result was the automation of business decisions.

Author: jeff.rankinen
Content: Is there a name for the related problem of managers wanting to preserve their fake, pencil-whipped KPI's to maintain their performance bonuses?

Author: jeff.rankinen
Content:
How about KPI Kabuki? 
from Gemini: KPI Kabuki: This option uses a play on words, referencing the Japanese theatrical form "kabuki" which is known for its elaborate costumes and stylized movements. It implies that the manager's performance is more about showmanship than substance.

Author: zeratall
Content:
Jeff, I absolutely think there are managers that in their own self interest (career growth) act that way, but I think they are the exception not the rule.  I think we need to be careful around the communication of I4.0 and the increase in transparency, like all things DT, culture transformation is very important. If we start implying people are acting malicious, that is a quick way to lose support and actually provoke people to act out against the digital transformation efforts. 

Most managers are not malicious, they just don't have the access to data, Because of this, they have had to make assumptions or simplifications for their calculations, at scale when every mfg area manager does this, it reduces confidence in the KPIs and they can't be used for comparison. Obviously we get more standardization and confidence in the data when the KPIs are automated. The automation often makes managers nervous because KPIs they were once responsible for change overnight and tell a different story.

 If we want to win over the work force, we need to be sensitive in how we communicate the increased transparency, it should be forward facing and not a blame game.

Author: jeff.rankinen
Content: Agreed. Best to assume unethical managers are the exception not the rule. Great point!

Author: sparkylarks
Content:
I was going to make that very point.
Most people are tyring to help solve problems, that included the Big consultants, the Big vendors, the small start ups.
And one observations I always like to remember is that people will avoid looking too critically at things, if that will disrupt, how they put a roof over their family, feed their kids send their kids to college, have a nice car.......

and if an extra bonus allows me do something special for my wife, then I will look to maximise the areas that my bonus depends on.

Compound that with human beings 
    tendency to repeat what has worked before,
    tendency to be proud of why that have built from their efforts.
    tendency to defend when they are being attacked. It is hard to Trusting your self when all men doubt you is actual easy, making allowance for their doubting too is much much  harder.

I think I understand why people might be resistant to change, especially if they feel they are doing well( i.e. their speed is still high and they have not noticed they have stopped accelerating)

I think those here who lead DX and help advise those who lead DX have a duty to learn how to convince those who are sceptical and not just get rid of them. For all I hear about resistance to change and people not looking forwards, I have never come across someone who doesn't get on board when some slows down and explain to them and addresses their concerns.

Author: sparkylarks
Content:
The best way to prepare for the 5th Industrial revolution, is to be as advanced as possible in the 4th Revolution
If you did not automate your manufacturing in the 3rd revolution, automating your Business process is much harder
If you did not electrify your plants in the 2nd revolutions( and put in assembly lines etc) it is very very hard to Automate your manufacturing.
If you did not move from a cottage centralised hand based manufacturing to a industrial machine based system ,it is very hard to electrify your production

Author: chris.demers
Content: Those of you who have been involved in really successful digital transformation initiatives or know of them what does the org chart typically look like? Is it a dedicated digital transformation team? Do they report up through the business or IT side? How do they work with the sites, do the sites own the infrastructure and applications after?

Author: hobbes1069
Content: I can't say (yet) 🙂 But it's been a long journey over the last few years working with and making friends in IT. Some of the teams are now on our side and excited about doing something new. That being said, we're a pretty big legacy company so I'm not surprised it's taken this long to get some momentum.

Author: ctown_kyle
Content:
I wouldn't say I was a part of a "really successful" initiative but my biggest success was kind-of on accident when our C-suite rolled out a digital transformation initiative (very vague) and then gave no instructions or targets whatsoever. other than "complete ___ number of projects". We completed projects at the site level with no involvement from corporate. We simply had to report our results up through our management. So we used the corporate push to get buy-in from the shop floor. I left this job but one of my colleagues still works there on a digital transformation team. He reports up through IT, travels to the sites, and owns the applications. Most sites don't have in-house Automation resources so sometimes he's training contractors when he travels to the sites.

Alternatively, my current company recently started a digital transformation team with an IT Sponsor, Corporate Sponsor, Project Manager, etc. We've spent 4 hours trying to determine what the goals of the team should be. Right now, I'm fighting them because they want to standardize our PLC hardware across sites. We're international and we don't have more than 1 plant in any country so I'm not sure how that's going to work. I told them we need to determine our goals and focus on data standardization not specifically hardware.

Author: sparkylarks
Content:
I think having OT and IT working together is key.
It can be two people working as a nucleus to build the team around or it can be larger.
I find that perhaps approaching IT with "We want to Digitally transform, but we really need your help in understanding the modern ways to approach this"
I have found the best way to get buy in is, ask for help, because that person has insight and skills you need, and tell them so. 

And it sounds like you have that hurdle started, the other advice I would give, is smaller and faster project phases.
I say this alot but If you do 1 machine first, using Node red and Grafana, you will in a few weeks have something working but also have learned so many of the integration problem you will face. Even if you discard all the code and move with another platform it is worth it.

Or at least the technical leads should be building a hobby test system.

But under no circumstances try to do multiple functionality enhancements across multiple plants at the same time.

Author: vaughnturner
Content:
It's the first step in the right direction. Especially if your team and organization are behind it. 

* Educate
* Digital Strategy
* Current State
* Desired Future State
* MTR (Minimum Technical Requirements)
* Suggested Architecture
* Suggested PoC
* Implement
* Learn
* Adjust
* Repeat 

This is the way we've found the most success for not only our clients, but also within our organizations.

Content: Does anyone know of any maturity models for production scheduling?

Author: zack.scriven
Content: great question! Can you elaborate what the requirements would be?

Author: youri.regnaud
Content: The idea is to help the business project itself from "Excel" scheduling to advanced or even partially autonomous scheduling. Clarify key stages such as digitization, integration of OT data, evolution of decision-making between man and machine, etc. I have a few ideas, but I'd be interested in any sources of inspiration. Small detail it is scheduling in discrete environment on workshops mainly machining polishing and manual assembly.

Author: zack.scriven
Content: i'd maybe look into how Sepa Soft MES Modules function and reverse engineer it. I think are many  considerations such as: are you scheduling a set amount of time for a production run? or are you scheduling a desired production goal? etc.

Author: zack.scriven
Content: The equipment scheduler component in ignition is actualy quite usefull too. They give you all the SQL Queries you need to drive that component.

Author: nickn5549
Content: I moved my workplace from 'Excel' and whiteboards to a web-based scheduling system that I developed. The first advantage you get, regardless of which system you choose is improved visibility and transparency. And then, if the system is good enough and you can connect it to ERP, MES, CMMS, Shift Monitoring Systems, etc the results will blow your mind... you get increased participation in scheduling from experienced people from your organisation who otherwise would have stayed aside minding their job (as per job description). It is powerful to give people access to information, responsibility and power to decide on things they know, even if some are outside of their  'job description'.

Author: gtwirth
Content: I am from Simio. We have a deep understanding of production scheduling.  We sell a production scheduling application for complex manufacturing environments that includes the scheduling of machines, employees, materials, and other assets.   Since we are built on simulation technology, we can closely model your manufacturing environment.  We use data sources such as the UNS to get real-time data and monitor events that automatically trigger rescheduling.  If you would like more details, plesee let me know.
