Author: youri.regnaud
Content: I would be interested to know how you can exploit a full ISA-95 model available as an event (MQTT, AMQP, ...) or GraphQL API. In other words, Time To Value, where all historical and real-time industrial data is available via advanced protocols.

Author: ted.garrison
Content:
It depends on what the scope is.  For something like Simio, we had a team from the Mfg Eng group review and decide.  Wasn't necessarily the team I would have put together, but that wasn't my call.  For something that just my team uses, my team (the whole 4 of us) decide.

We also have to get IT (security, etc) and Legal (licensing) to review and approve, but for most mainstream stuff, that's not terribly hard.

Author: zack.scriven
Content: Ah that makes sense! Thanks for sharing 💯

Author: gtwirth
Content: The tables in the Simio Scheduling Examples are based on the ISA 95 standard.  That said, the tables are easily configurable to match the schema of the source system.  We have an MQTT connector that can subscribe to and publish messages.  We also have a WebAPI (HTTP) connector.    Is it possible to get to your GraphQL API data via HTTP POST?  If so, we can transform the result into one or more tables.  Our Simio data connector API is flexible.   If there is a .NET library for an advance protocol, a data connector for that protocol can be created easily.  There are number of example of data connectors on our Simio GitHub.

Author: sammysevens777
Content:
We've discussed maturity trackers / readiness checklists, but are there any "tests" to evaluate if your infrastructure is "I4.0 ready"

I wonder if it's use case based, e.g.:
- how does an equipment maintenance trigger transactions to procure replacement hardware from a vendor
- how is machine data used to improve performance over time
- how long does it take for a new piece of equipment to connect to the factory network and provide data to <CLOUD> repo?

Very superficial - but wonder if this is something that others have discussed/explored?

Author: durinwinter
Content: So we developed this as well as have organizations conduct the following thought exercise

Author: durinwinter
Content: Collect all the information you would about your system if you were dead set on changing the vendor. So whatever your PLC is. What would you need to know about what it's running and how it's connected to change vendors. For your network equipment. What if you were going to swap vendors. Same with SCADA. Same with everything. The point is not to evaluate the competitive offerings. The point is to capture your system information as though you were absolutely going to. If your organization can't do that or won't, then you probably can't really do I4.0 and whoever it was in your organization that stopped that process is the reason why.

Author: durinwinter
Content: Or whatever structural reason why you can't actually conduct that exercise is the reason why

Author: durinwinter
Content:
The unfortunate reality is that it's far less about what is true about your system than it is your companies culture. What causes a failure in digital transformation is almost always some internal company dynamic. 

A good example of this is I see a lot of companies spend months arguing over which cloud they will use. But if you can use terraform and Kubernetes it doesn't even matter.  

And no PLC is so arcane that it should matter. 

So it's mostly about company attitudes and a willingness to train/cross train. Dynamics about IT/OT infighting, and executives who avoid decisions and push leadership down to people based off of only their intuition about "who is right"

Author: zeratall
Content: Or worse executives push their own agenda without any or against the input from the technical team.

Author: durinwinter
Content: It's unfortunately the single most important metric. We had to develop an entire adoption framework to help orgs through this issue.

Author: durinwinter
Content: Because you can't make it meaningful and stick if the executives are bad actors in this regard.

Author: durinwinter
Content: If Controls people really wanted to design a system and transform an organization. They would go to college for psychology and power dynamics and use them to control the decision making the same way that staffers ultimately run congressm

Author: sparkylarks
Content:
I think theses are the right questions you need to ask, but there is not one answer. 
It is a bit like are Vertically or horizontally integrated company the best approach.

in Sports, it defiantly makes sense to have teams made up of all diverse skill sets that are correct for the position.

but in organisation with no set limit on the number of members it becomes a different question.

There is a famous story my father used to tell, of when an outsider became CEO in a insurance company, and looked at the Actuarial group and thought, why are the smartest people in the company all in the one group and one room, and split them up and put them into different teams.

the Actuaries hated it and could not function well at all.

in your last picture, you can certainly take that approach, but you need to forma Pseudo-team of the app developers so they can share issues and solutions as well.

Maersk did that well, I was part of the Automation Team, but had weekly Meetings with the OT architect group, and a bi weekly with the entire Architecture group


and that I think is the correct approach for DT.
you should have a lot of different sprints, some developing new functionality, some expanding existing functionality to new lines, some starting on new plants.

and in that case the sprint team, needs to have the skill sets it needs. and if I am a python coder on that team I want to be reporting to the person I deliver to, the sprint lead.

But I need to be in a group of DT/OT Python Coders, and a larger group of all the Coders in the org perhaps.

Author: yasirtuncer
Content:
The ones who wrote (Siemens, SAP, McKinsey, TUVSUD) never really did a complete transformation that's why SIRI is a tool for consultancy not for implementation teams. To cover the gaps an assessor with implementation experience should conduct to reap the benefits of SIRI. The prioritization matrix leaves you half way you need to build MTR, roadmap items, and use-cases based on your experience. 

I did 40+ assessments to SMEs, and multi-billion multi-nationals and argue that with a consultancy hat including DTMA questions, you can become a rainmaker for most manufacturers. If I were to re-write SIRI methodology I would include all Organization dimensions as prioritized dimensions because it is the dominant factor for a successful transformation

It should not be one or the other, I think the backbone questions should be from DTMA and details of the 10 pillars should be included in SIRI dimensions but the prioritization should be based on costs structure, company KPIs, benchmark to peers. The roadmap should include use cases for pilot, long-term as well as the UNS architecture with MTR details for the company. 

All of those should start with organizational pillars: Strategy, Workforce learning & development, leadership competency and inter- intra- collaboration dimensions. All successful companies I have seen had these in place

Author: ctown_kyle
Content: There have been many examples on the Youtube channel (the first one that comes to mind is the bread company that solicits customer feedback via a QR code on their products in exchange for a discount) but I'll share one from one of my own interests, professional sports. With more and more professional sports entering into contracts with streaming services there is a lot more data available on viewer demographics. This allows streaming companies to tailor their advertising to appeal more to that specific audience and also push to acquire or create similar content. It's no surprise that Amazon was one of the first to lean heavily into streaming live sports. They paid $11 Billion for Thursday night football and it's basically a loss leader just to get customers using their service and of course to get their data (which Amazon can use 100 different ways I'm sure). The NBA's contract (2nd largest only behind the NFL) is about to expire so there's a bidding war going on right now. It will be interesting to see how it ends up.

Author: sparkylarks
Content:
@Zack Scriven 

I agree with the concept of Data becoming a resource for a company.
But is a commodity classified by having the same value to all people. so if I swap my barrel of WTI for your WTI then it is the same value.

But my companies data should be more valuable to me, than it is to you.
and I can certainly use my data more effectively than I can use your data.

Author: zack.scriven
Content: There was a company who had a special process and approach to running a photography studio business. Well the owner had created a coaching / licensing model and was teaching 100+ other studio owners around the world how to implement their system and was making $500k/year from that business. Well Hormozi suggested they shut it down completely and just expand the model in-house because it would be more productive that way. Each store would generate $2m/year and only cost a few hundred grand to get off the ground. They were selling the model for $25k or something. Now instead of $25k per store they make $500k per store. And open a new one every month.

Author: sparkylarks
Content:
As a framework I would say;

Set your Digital Strategy
Inventory your Current State
Set your Minimum Technical Requirements
Decide a Proof of Concept.

Build the POC with the MING stack.

Then with the knowledge from all of that, you can look at Platforms and make an informed decision.

I see that the single platform approch works in the middle of scale. Very small and very large systems will be composed of lots of different solutions.

Ignition works well, because as you scale up it can go from being the single solution, to a node in the Eco System.

Author: jeff_flow
Content: I use an app called Merlin from Cornell University (https://merlin.allaboutbirds.org/) to identify birds by sight or by song. It's completely free and is extremely powerful. I can simply turn on my mic and it will identify any birds it hears in my backyard. The data is then shared from all users (along with location, time of day, etc) back to Cornell which is using it to track migratory birds and identify new patterns in bird behavior. Pretty slick right?

Author: sparkylarks
Content:
Just finished this , hope it helps
1- Set your Strategy
2- Inventory the business
3- Set Minimum Technological requirements, (and a model Architecture)
4 -Decide and execute a Proof of Concept and in doing so 
    Connect, Collect, Store, Visualise, Analyse, Spot Patterns , Report and Solve those problems
  then keep repeating

There is a Step 0, to Learn enough, but given you have found yourself here, I'll guess you have that.

Author: _dyland
Content: Find the low hanging fruit for a proof of concept. Start small so that you can refactor and replace early on.

Author: _dyland
Content: A lot of times this is easier when everything is on paper and spreadsheets. Existing solutions often come with technical debt.

Author: _dyland
Content: The data exists somewhere, the sensor may need to be picked up, or the PLC networked but if there is even a clipboard being filled out, someone already knows where the data is. I usually find the guys filling out the forms or the spreadsheets and follow the trail from there. Do they look at a dial or a gauge, an HMI, or just guess at a random number? Once the base is built, then some real detective work comes in to find the solutions to the problems that have yet to be identified.

Author: sparkylarks
Content:
Good advice and @safa saib if you take the paper form, you can start by just putting the form into a tablet, and pushing the data from the tablet, though it is still collected manually, you can then start to automatically collect the data. 

It is sometimes a good real world approach, to put the Paper on Glass, and then say, oout of theses 20 pieces of information how many can I collect easily, it might be 17. Start there and get the win, and then you can decide to dig in and find the data, or decide you don;t need it, or sometimes keep doing some collection manually.

If you have an injection moulding machine with a HMI, there is probably a PLC in there,
Can you connect to the HMI, or PLC.
PLC-> Node-Red -> MQTT Broker -> TimescaleDB
Now your have Connected, Collected, Stored Data,
Use Node Red to Contextualise the data and structure it well.
Connect Grafana to the Timescale DB and Visualise and Analyse the system

Author: sparkylarks
Content:
The issue I would see with this is there is likely to be a lot of effort before seeing any benefits.
having all you PLC's on one network is important but it does not solve any problem anyone is having.

I really would recommend a simple proof of concept, that solves someone's in your organisation problems.
In doing so you are likely to  bring one or two PLC's onto the new network, Create a small UNS where the PLC and other data is published and the other nodes subscribe to it. 
you probably will create some MES functionality and start collecting data that you can use in Analytics and ML later.

Author: ted.garrison
Content: Digitization/Digitalization (same in my opinion) are just taking paper and making it digital.  If you take some form you fill out and stick in a drawer, and turn it into an excel doc that you file somewhere and never touch - you've digitalized it.  But whoopdee-doo..   You're still not DOING anything with that data.     When you start then connecting that data to other data, so you can learn from it - then you're beginning digital transformation..

Author: vaughnturner
Content:
Digitization: This is the process of converting information from a physical format into a digital one. For example, scanning a paper document into a digital file or converting analog data into digital data formats. Digitization makes information easier to store, access, and share, but does not fundamentally change how the business operates.

Digitalization: This is the use of digital technologies and digitized data to impact how work gets done, transform how customers and companies engage and interact. It's about the use of digital information to simplify and enhance processes. Digitalization implies a change in operations and can lead to improvements in efficiency and effectiveness. It often involves automation of routine tasks and the integration of digital technology into existing business processes.

Each of these stages builds upon the last. Digitization creates the digital data necessary for digitalization, which enables improvements and efficiencies in processes. Digital transformation, however, is about leveraging these advancements to fundamentally change how a business operates and delivers value to its customers.

Author: zack.scriven

Author: vaughnturner
Content:
A gateway primarily serves as a bridge between different networks, handling protocol translations and data format conversions to facilitate communication across diverse systems. 

Middleware is software that acts as an intermediary layer between applications, managing and facilitating communication, data exchange, and services beyond what the operating system provides.

Author: wissemtahraoui_16562
Content: how do you realise that is a legacy facility  i mean what are the criteria

Author: vaughnturner
Content:
Good question, here are some key indicators your facility is a legacy or Industry 3.0 facility: 

**1. Automation and Control Systems:**
**Discrete Automation: **Relies on stand-alone, discrete automation systems rather than integrated, flexible, and adaptive systems.
**Limited PLC/SCADA Use: **Uses Programmable Logic Controllers (PLCs) and Supervisory Control and Data Acquisition (SCADA) systems primarily for basic control and monitoring, without advanced data analytics or connectivity.
Manual Processes: Many processes are still manually operated or manually initiated, with limited automation.

2. Data and Connectivity:
**Isolated Systems:** Machines and systems are isolated with minimal or no connectivity, leading to data silos.
**Limited Data Utilization: **Data is collected manually or not collected at all, with little use of real-time data for decision-making.
Lack of IIoT Devices: Few or no Industrial Internet of Things (IIoT) devices are deployed to gather and transmit data from machines and processes.

3. Manufacturing Execution Systems (MES):
**Basic MES or None: **Either no MES in place or a very basic MES that does not integrate with other systems for holistic production management.
**Manual Reporting:** Production and maintenance reports are generated manually, often with spreadsheets or paper records.

4. IT and OT Integration:
**Separated IT and OT:** Information Technology (IT) and Operational Technology (OT) systems operate independently with little or no integration.
**Lack of Unified Namespace:** No unified namespace for comprehensive and coherent data representation across the facility.

5. Maintenance Strategies:
**Reactive Maintenance: **Maintenance is predominantly reactive rather than predictive or proactive, leading to higher downtime and inefficiencies.
**Minimal Predictive Analytics:** Little to no use of predictive maintenance tools or analytics to foresee and mitigate potential equipment failures.

6. Operational Flexibility:
**Rigid Production Lines:** Production lines are rigid and inflexible, designed for mass production of limited product types with long changeover times.
**Limited Customization:** Inability to easily customize or personalize products to meet specific customer demands.

7. Workforce Skills:
**Traditional Skillsets:** Workforce is primarily skilled in traditional manufacturing and maintenance techniques, with limited training in digital technologies and data analytics.
**Resistance to Change:** Potential resistance to adopting new technologies and processes due to lack of understanding or fear of disruption.

8. Customer and Supply Chain Integration:
**Limited Customer Interaction: **Minimal integration with customers for real-time order tracking, customization, and feedback.
Disconnected Supply Chain: Supply chain operations are not synchronized in real-time, leading to inefficiencies and delays.

Author: vaughnturner
Content: **To be fair this is almost 90% of all manufacturers in some shape or fashion.**

Author: brianiac832670
Content: Besides the Business Connector module, what are the common ways to connect SAP to MES?

Author: bright_hummingbird_31342
Content:
SAP is not just one thing.  It's many applications, many versions, etc.  There are integration avenues including http, database, and files.  Since you mentioned Sepasoft Business Connector, presumably Ignition is present.  It's possible to interface with APIs through scripting.  The SUDS library comes in handy for SOAP-based endpoints.

Other options include:
-Some, more sophisticated MES solutions have an HTTP client and their own integration capabilities
-SAP has their own full-stack integration solutions
-There exists third-party middleware solutions that can transact between MES and SAP endpoints
-GSI / consultancies have developed their own point-solutions ("accelerators") for integrating with SAP

Author: bright_hummingbird_31342
Content:
This is somewhat of a popular topic.  I think there is some misunderstanding of SAP is.  Some solution providers will market that they have SAP integrations, but trivialize or omit the details of what it takes to make that actually work.

SAP is not another OT node that produces/consumes telemetry data.  It's not integrated the same way Ignition, Canary, MING, etc are.  It's not simply a matter finding the right interface adapter.  There is an impedance mismatch between it and OT nodes.  "SAP" is an IT endpoint that will have specific requirements that are a function of how it was implemented.

Think less about the interface and think more about the use case.  A successful integration will be oriented around the what purpose, what message, what logic, what SAP module, etc.  Once those things are identified, determining the interface is more straightforward.

Author: mariano.beracochea
Content: Wouldnt that be a 3.0 approach? that seems like every new  use case is like a new project

Author: zack.scriven
Content: https://tenor.com/view/perfect-popcorn-michael-jackson-gif-26271837

Author: bright_hummingbird_31342
Content:
Could you be more specific on what is 3.0 approach?

An integration can definitely be reused or scaled. I’m referring to using use cases as a methodology to define an outcome and work back through the technology. Industrial controls professionals sometimes assume that ERP systems are another thing that produces and consumes tags. They’re a completely different beast.

SAP is not a SCADA system. It does not just replicate a collection of telemetry data points. It will have specific transactions for specific purposes. These transactions will have specific payloads and specific logic.

By choosing an outcome like line change overs, processing inventory, inspection records, etc, it allows one to better focus and understand the transactions involved. By learning this, one can build integrations that can be generalized and can be scaled.

Author: wissemtahraoui_16562
Content: how can i convince my manager that digital transformation can solve the production problems

Author: _dyland
Content:
Without any details...

Start by asking yourself the following questions. 

-1- What are the problems that the people working in and around production are facing?

-2- How can we solve those problems?

-3- Are these the problems we as a business really need to solve right now? Why and Why not?

-4-  What tools can we use to solve those problems?

-5- How do we implement these solutions?

Only after you yourself have these answers, should you proceed with the next step...

If you still can't convince them, and you know that it will work. Then don't convince them, just show them. 

If you need to, start by solving one of your own, or your Manager's problems. Find the low hanging fruit and go from there.

A UNS wont solve your problems. The UNS will enable you to solve them.

Not knowing your exact scenario or your manager, not many people here will have a concrete answer for you. But since you have identified the first problem, Overproduction and Defects, the next question to ask is what do you need to solve it.

Author: _dyland
Content: Once we know the current state, Where the objective and production data are, then we can identify the tools used to retrieve it, from there, how to implement it, and after that you will have a solution to a problem. Once you have a solution, you can convince your manager to implement it.

Author: _dyland
Content:
So the question is - How do you inform the operators of the objective?

If they already know the production count, they just need to know the objective. Right?

What is stopping the lead from telling the operators the objective? It sounds like that would solve a lot of the problems.

We can go further, automating this exchange of information and implementing notifications, maybe a dashboard that shows the progress. 

If we want to digitize this, you will need access to the production data, and the objective.

Maybe the first step is to show the value in sharing information with the operators, before even mentioning digital transformation?

Author: wissemtahraoui_16562
Content: how could i digitize the exchange

Author: _dyland
Content:
That depends on what the machine is and what access you have to it. Based on what I know from this conversation, to digitize this exchange, you will have:

2 sources of data, the scheduling department and the machine

2 Consumers of the data, the operators and the lead.

If we are using a UNS:

You need to **Connect, Collect, Store, Analyze, and Visualize.** the data.

**Connect,** to the sources, the Scheduling Department and the Machine. 

**Collect,** the data from those sources into a Unified Namespace.

**Store .**this data in a way you can easily retrieve later.

**Analyze, **the data to create meaningful information.

**Visualize, **that information in a way that brings value to the consumer.

Author: _dyland
Content:
I was writing up a response but it got too long... and i veered off course a bit...  so I posted it as a Linkdln article. 

https://www.linkedin.com/pulse/tension-teamwork-digital-transformation-story-dylan-dufresne-cykzc/

But the short version that i intended to write and didn't is that the tools and technologies will change. So start by identifying the needs and the culture. and move from there.

This includes the operators, the management, the IT team, engineering, maintenance, admin staff... anyone and everyone in the organization. Implementing the tools and technologies will often require a level of technical aptitude so it is often about finding the right people who can help.

Sensors, PLCs, Robots, Ignition, MQTT, HighByte, Node Red, SQL - these are all tools that can be used to solve problems but are useless if the problems have not been identified. 

Sometime the answer is to just tell 2 people to talk to each other...

Author: _dyland

Author: sparkylarks
Content:
as @Dylan said it is a great start and I recommend that you build it and see how it goes, you will learn a lot more doing that asking questions here

So tips I would give based on experience, And theses are based on Issues I have run into , so they may not be relevant for you at all.

how many machines have you in total? I would put in an "Area" Level, if there are a lot of machines. 
Personally even if there are only a few machines I put in a "Production" area

is BMS the organisation name, or the Building Management system.?
if it is the Building Management System, and you have a PLC at the Machine for that, I would put structure as 
- Enterprise->Production->Machine 14118-> BMS

Personally I don't like putting the PLC in, because if I have sensor on Machine 1, it might be wired to Machine 2 or to an area level PLC. I have seen this a lot with things added in after the machine is installed like labellers or barcode sensors. That said I often have an Topic called/ Ent/Plant/Area/PLC/Raw data. and map all the signals from the PLC to that point , and then parse and publish them to the UNS part of my Broker

Are the CMMS and ERP and Work order system, Enterprise level? If they are plant level I would put them in below the Plant.
( that is why I like at least one Area) I do classify big Systems for the Plant as an Area

Author: matthiasmax
Content:
The mentioned frameworks make up a very small part of a holistic solution.

Not sure I get the question right. But I‘d say they are not easily exchangeable once put into place.

Sure they all follow a similar rule (they are component based using almost identical synthax). 

But I usually go a more standard way and recommend using web components for example which is an open standard and has grown over the years.

Last but not least the „framework“ term is used slightly more concrete for frontend „libraries“ in web dev land.

Author: matthiasmax
Content:
That‘s great.

Did you come up with that or is this an „official“ definition of UNS?

Author: _dyland
Content: "Connect, collect, store, analyze, visualize" is a pretty common phrase around the UNS.  It defines a method for getting started in a fairly simple way. The specifics were some assumptions for the use case and  needs that were being discussed.

Author: matthiasmax
Content: Makes sense. Focus on one area at a time. Pick the right tool for the job in each area and compose this "chain" together to form a solution.

Author: _dyland
Content:
Especially as things are getting started. Momentum is everything, and the most important thing is that we get started.

Though I would say less one area at a time and more one problem at a time. Identifying the needs and solving them in scalable and extensible ways to form that "chain" of solutions.

So even before "Connect, Collect, Store" is to inventory the business, meet the people, and  identify their needs. From there we can learn the priorities and find out what to connect, collect, and store.

Author: b.goode
Content:
in some of Walker's youtube content he recommends building a "technology stack, not a software stack." I'm interested in understanding if there's good consensus here on those terms, and where there isn't, what the differences are.

protocols like MQTT, TCP/IP, OPC UA, probably fit in "tech stack" for most or all people, but what else would they include in tech stack, and where do they draw the line between tech and software stacks?

AVEVA PI, mosquitto, oracle databases probably fit in "software stack" for most or all people (or do they? i assume so?).

javascript frameworks was just the first thing that popped in my mind. what about languages, like Java? what about particular language libraries? let's say you're doing some web socket stuff with IXWebSocket (a C++ library). WebSocket is a protocol, but where would you place particular WebSocket libraries like IXWebSocket or Socket.io?

probably minutiae for some people, but I'm curious. appreciate any thoughts

Author: sparkylarks
Content:
My integration of this is.

With a technology stack I can remove any part of the stack and replace it with an equivalent.
so, I migrate from Node-Red calculating my OEE, to Ignition ,  and nothing else is affected, any other nodes reading the AQP or OEE doesn't even notice  
replace my Hive MQ broker with EMQX , and relatively quickly be back up and running, 


If I have a software stack that does not happen. I replace my Node Red with Ignition and any other nodes that are using OEE need to have new connections created to communicate with Ignition.

Author: og_grendyl
Content: Leave the distributed devices alone, and change the IP of the servers.  You can spin up the new one and do your prep and testing, then just change the IP address of the old one to something that isn't used, change the IP of the new one to what the old IP was, and all the devices should reconnect to it smoothly.  You could just turn the old one off, but I always change it's IP first just in case it needs to be brought back online for some reason.

Author: giladl
Content: Augmented Lean is a concept that intends to bring Lean into the digital age. As such it is a component of digital transformation and means that digital technologies should inherently support operational excellence/Lean/continuous improvement however you like to call it.  It is one key element that needs to be considered in the digital transformation strategy. It is also a way to sift through the barrage of marketing by technology companies. If a technology, among a few other critical things, does not inherently support continuous improvement or lean then its probably not part of the new paradigm.

Author: zack.scriven
Content: That is not a possibility at the time unfortunately.

Author: og_grendyl
Content: Lean and kaizen are strategies or approaches that utilize technologies and other tools to achieve improvements in your business, so I'm struggling to conceptualize how a technology can inherently support or not support lean or kaizen.  Could you explain in a little more depth what you mean by that?

Author: giladl
Content: Its not necessarily features that make this possible but a fundamental shift in how its used and implemented. The technology needs to support an iterative bottom-up adoption (design, deployment, implementation, integration, etc). Lean and continuous improvement is a bottom up method to change, one step at a time, one problem at a time. Most traditional technology solution require a top-down design everything first - then implement approach and then, once its in any changes take a significant effort and risk. So digital technology has to not only allow but be a catalyst to these cycle of improvement and change. In a way its the merging of Agile, from the software domain, and Continuous Improvement which I believe are the same fundamental concept. You can read more here https://www.giladlconsulting.com/2023/06/4-questions-to-guide-you-towards-true.html and here https://www.giladlconsulting.com/2019/04/the-genius-of-toyota-production-system.html

Author: dapomeranz
Content: @giladl @Grendyl I see Augmented Lean as the complete integration of technology into a physical operation **to create process definition and data quality**. It only works now that modern software platforms enable operational applications to be hyper customized and easily iterated upon. Previously, operations had to interact with digital systems as an afterthought. Now, applications are the core definition of process and the hub through which quality and all lean implementations are maintained, enforced, and measured.

Author: dapomeranz
Content: Over and over again I see the amount of time wasted due to businesses considering "quality" to be only for QA and QC roles. Through these MES and adjacent systems, we have the opportunity to bring process quality to the forefront of every operation-- and make in a way that isn't a PITA. This creates all the typical benefits of Quality that Deming and Toyota have always advocated for, but also the modern benefit of capturing live and consistent data for visibility, traceability, and other continuous improvement analysis .

Content:
Follow the Process.
- Set the Strategy
- Inventory the business
- Set the MTR
- Define the POC  ( I always push for 1 function on 1 machine)

In ERP transformation, consultants usually listen to your process and apply it to the software. However, if there are situations that need to be physically improved, especially on the production side, they may not be very helpful. They try to transfer your vision to the product. Therefore, I see the benefit in preparing beforehand or getting consultancy from the right source.

Author: flowurpatch
Content:
This is sooo many companies.  Taking an inventory of all the tools, systems, processes that are in place now is a great start.

If you can replace even one spreadsheet, or even one part of one spreadsheet, but do it in a way that focuses on showing key folks how the new tool will make some part of their job easier, that will go a long way to getting buy in from your customers so you can help them more.  It's really important to take the time to find the right first piece to work through, but also don't worry about finding the perfect first piece.  Find a problem that they need solved.  It may be one they built a spreadsheet for and have gotten used to the friction of using their current, significantly inferior tools.

Author: bachan1868_11442
Content: @Walker Reynolds In order to speed things up in manufacturing, because it seems to be going kinda slow, do manufacturing companies that want to survive the next 10 years need a CDTO? (Chief Digital Transformation Office or Officer)?  And what would that job description look like?  How about this: The Chief Digital Transformation Officer (CDTO) for the manufacturing vertical is responsible for leading and executing the company’s digital transformation strategy to drive innovation, efficiency, and competitive advantage. This role involves overseeing the integration of digital technologies across manufacturing operations and Information technology (Yes! above the COO and CTO and CIO!), enhancing processes through data analytics, automation, and IoT, and fostering a culture of digital innovation. The CDTO will collaborate with senior leaders to identify digital opportunities, implement cutting-edge solutions, and ensure alignment with business objectives. Key responsibilities include managing digital projects, ensuring seamless technology adoption, optimizing the supply chain, and enhancing customer experiences. The ideal candidate will possess a deep understanding of digital technologies, a strong track record of leading digital initiatives in manufacturing, and excellent strategic, leadership, and communication skills.

Author: vaughnturner
Content:
Hi Michelle, great question, here is the reply from Walker.

[10:29 AM] Walker Reynolds
The role is CDO (Chief Digital Officer).  Orgs can be successful two ways.  

1. CIO and CDO are one role that, in conjunction, leads the creation and execution of the Digital Strategy by driving IT as a service organization tasked with enabling Digital Transformation

2. CDO and CIO are separate roles where CDO is responsible for operations and infrastructure around DT, and CIO is responsible for converting the data into value for the organization — including making data a commodity for sale.

Operational execution is achieved through the org, led by a DT team until the org reaches digital maturity, upon which time DT is part of the culture.

He has an org chart I can share if you're interested.

Author: thooor9411
Content:
Hello all,

can somebody help me understand something here since my lack of experience in the field and on UNS but i am learning. lets say you have a company with 3-5 plants that you want to digital transform and you want to have technology driven solutions so you want to build an uns architecture but you also need an MES bc of etc... now you can maybe start with MING stack or maybe use Ignition as IIOT platform and then expand with time adding highbyte or hivemq etc.. you get the idea:)
So lets say you are the driver, the manager that is driving this and you probably have all these big players like rockwell, siemens etc selling you their solutions that probably are expensive and locking you to their ecosystem but you want to build an open, edge driven, technology based architecture.
- Do you need a team of maybe 2-4 plp that will build and maintain and drive the above instead of paying consultancy firm proposing you off the shelf solution or high cost engeering one?
-  Are you building your own MES solution with this iiot platform or you buy a solution and connect to the eco system? in this case you want to have enterprize MES so maybe building is too costly but also you need to maintain it?
- what is more preferred storing all your data on-prem or using cloud to store all your data?
- do you employ an integrator to guide you and help you during this journey as you cant drive it alone and how to avoid these one that are selling you expensive off the shelf soltions?
- how do you enable worker of the future like Walker said. do you give access to UNS to different users in you company and let them develop solutions which you can integrate into the eco system?
- what is the timeline until you have architecture in place, structured data coming in and you can start solving your business problems, maybe even using AI and ML?
- how do you avoid setting up costly strategy and avoid being stuck with solutions/softwares that don not allow you to scale and be agile.

Author: hobbes1069
Content:
A lot to unpack here... 
1. A smallish team may be able to maintain what's put in place but you need a much bigger team to start with (at least for 3-5 plants) if you want to get anywhere quickly. Here's where a good I4.0 integrator can help by giving you horsepower to start and help you avoid some technical debt.
2. You certainly could roll your own MES from scratch but then you need an even bigger team. Better to start with a platform like Ignition, FactoryStudio, or Tulip, and build on top of it.
3. Only your organization can answer that question. One answer could be "both". My company is "Cloud First" and we're a Tulip house.
4. Better if you do... We didn't and it's taken us about 5 years to really get embedded in out plants. Very slow growth at first but now starting to accellerate. 
5. Most people should have at least `Read only` access to the UNS. You may be required to restrict access to sensative data though.
6. With a good integrator you're probably at least 2 years before you see AI/ML solutions but that can vary a lot by industry/maturity.
7. Get a good integrator that's already learned those lessons or try stuff and fail quickly so you can move on.

Author: sparkylarks
Content:
You need an internal team of 2 to 4 people.

Don't use consultants. Use Integrators who have built something similar to what you want and make sure they are problem orientated.

( I consult but I am not a consultant)

Do the up front work first.
Strategy. Inventory the business. Model architecture. MTR.

Define a proof of concept. Solve it.
Solve more problems on the same machine. Roll out to more machines.
Roll out to more plants.

In relation to platform cost. I like to start cheap or free and add more expensive nodes as I scale. Start with MING if needed. Or Ignition/Framework.
You can probably solve 18 months of problems without encouraging too much technical debt, and then move to more expensive ones.

I default to on prem( especially for storage) and then move data  to cloud when it is needed there to solve a problem that has been identified.

I would employ an integrator.
Or there are quite a few small Integrators here who consult. But if you have a preferred integrator you want to build, I would bring in a consulting system architect to help get started ( the can also help with the pre-work).

The worker should have tools with access to the data in the UNS. What that looks like is very specific to you company.

Architecture in place 4 to 6 months. But it keeps growing.
AI and ML. 18 to 24 months minimum

Make sure your MTR and model architecture allow any component to be replaced with minimum impact to other nodes.

Author: sparkylarks
Content:
As a Integrator/consultant, I would give this advice.
Go with the partner that 
1 - you trust
2 - is always trying new things
3 - Want's to deliver a solution to you and finish, i.e. not sell you a service for 20 years
4 - Happy to do lots of small projects and are not looking for a single multimillion dollar project.

Author: thooor9411
Content: So how are small integrators able to compete with big industrial companies in this space? Why customers go after big companies is because credibility and delivery even at bigger cost.

Author: _dyland
Content:
Better service, tailored solutions, better attitude, word of mouth, you golfed or had a beer with the right person, better service, more agility in scheduling, close proximity (ties into support), really there are a lot of reasons. When you are the little guy you have to get creative sometimes but the differentiators are there.


This is just off the top of my head but as a small integrator these are all real world examples that I have seen first hand.

Author: _dyland
Content:
At the end of the day it's not about the size of the integrator but in their reputation. The Integrator with the reputation for successful and innovative projects will win in the end. 

The big players typically grow out of their innovative projects phase in favor of lower risk canned products. That's typically my in.

Author: zeratall
Content: Dylan is spot on imho from my own experience.

Author: _dyland
Content: The 2 biggest clients of my career both came as a direct result of a larger incumbent (considered the gold standard in their respective verticals) offering a proprietary solution without providing the source code. That combined with slow support got us in the door. From there we had to learn the industry, the client, the people, and their problems real quick. Because once you're in the door you have to deliver... If you're not solving problems they will go right back to the incumbent.

Author: _dyland
Content: And don't get a reputation for being the budget option... That's when you only get the 💩 jobs that the big boys don't want.

Author: sparkylarks
Content:
Why do people go to small bakers  - Better product
Why do people go to small Accountants/Lawyers ... - Better Service.

IF you look at how I have gotten business.
- first customer rang people I had worked for before one needed some work done, and then another job and another job form him.
- Second customer came from someone on this discord looking for an Architect
- Third  customer was a friend of the first guy who rang him looking for someone with siemens PLC experience
- Fourth customer was someone I worked with previously who is staff at an end use and had an opportunity outside that and needed help.
Few more opportunities in the ether, 
 - I was introduced to a nearby Engineer looking to leave a bigger company
 - I met a small ERP/software house that is 5 miles up the road that need help exploiting some manufacturing content.

But to take what @Dylan DuFresne says and when the big companies don't deliver or mess up., if you can solve problems and provide value then people will typically stay customers

Author: sparkylarks
Content:
I think from being both the customer and the integrator I would say.
Big integrators( or software vendors) , you have to tell them what you want and how you want it.
Smaller integrators tell you what the possibilities are, what you need, and how you need to do it.

Author: sparkylarks
Content:
Yes, but if you big integrator delivers you crud to start with, then you rollout crud.
Get the small Integrator for the pilot and get the big company for the rollout.

Author: zeratall
Content:
Let me offer a slightly different perspective (end user/architect) . I prefer working with smaller integrators. Mostly because as Walker has mentioned, different partnership models make all the difference. Large SI organizations often focus solely on providing an engineering service—they develop a solution, assist with deployment, and that's it. Rarely do they care about training or helping the contracted organization become self-sufficient.

But on average I find smaller SIs are  more flexible, open to ideas, and truly become partners through knowledge sharing. We've put large SIs on contract, specifying training and knowledge sharing in the SOW, but they consistently underperform in that department imho.

I see re-skilling as a major issue over the next 5-10 years (already is in a lot of ways). Especially for a large enterprise who need to retain some expertise.

Hey folks! I created a chatbot that mitigates the issue of sending large tokens to openAI. It does two things to achieve this:

Author: stephenbryant_89711
Content:
I've spoken to small ones who just don't see the need (no vision?), and are probably scared that a transformation will be hugely expensive.  That means they're not making use of the data they already generate.  I'm in Germany, BTW.

@Vincent Thavonekham, FactoVia wrote about France, but what he describes is certainly not unique to France - I've seen the same here.  It's also not limited to small companies either.  If you're an external integrator, it's really difficult to get any traction as long as they think they know what they're doing.

It looks like those that are pragmatic and willing to listen will transform and thrive - helped by the fact that their competitors don't.  It really is a repeat of I3.0, and the main reason is that people are still people and behave much the same.  The wrong managers are in charge.  While you and I can't change that, financial reality will hit them sooner or later and we will see changes in the landscape.

True story: a mid-sized German company set up a new "smart factory" abroad, over the last year or two - where work orders are being printed out on paper and typed in, and there's still heavy reliance on manual assembly (ie: it's not very automated at all).  I can't tell whether it's stupidity or whether they're lying to themselves, but it's certainly not smart.  I estimate their DTMA score to be under 40 too.  The question is not whether they'll survive, but how long they have left.

Author: nickn5549
Content: I feel better now, here, Down Under. I'm not alone in this....there are many.....

Author: milanhurban
Content:
I've been in meetings and on site with many customers over the last 4 years in Austria and the CEE region. There's a huge variety in the digital maturity of companies. From purely paper-based production to companies with their own software development teams, creating custom (and often quite impressive) solutions for their problems on the shop floor and beyond.

When presenting our (Siemens) portfolio, sometimes you get blank stares, and sometimes it's the best thing since sliced bread, like when the customer was already looking for a platform to run their Docker containers on in production. Who you talk to makes a huge difference, sometimes you can convince a higher-up, sometimes there's a capable person in the OT with a problem they need solving. It's almost never IT, and OT and IT are often openly at war with each other. But small, young "digital competence" teams or spin-offs of larger companies can be very open and useful.

One major shift is how very different this is to the I3.0 business model of "selling grey boxes" that many of my older colleagues are used to. You can sell someone another PLC or I/O card, they know what it's for. You cannot just sell someone an edge device, it doesn't mean anything. The vast majority of the time, there is no clear digital strategy, everything is ad-hoc and the entire topic is extremely consulting- and support-heavy.

The bigger manufacturing players usually do have their shit together in terms of IT infrastructure and understand what we can offer, but there it often just takes forever, months or years, to get anywhere. E.g. someone at some point set a standard for how Kubernetes deployments are to be done and nothing can be changed about that...

But to be honest, reading posts from others here and on the web, it seems like all these things are universal.

Author: enriquec_58034
Content:
For people like us, working with technology, your example is unbelievable @Stephen Bryant . I simply cannot understand how that can happen.
But there may be other reasons for a mid-size company for doing what they do, especially considering that digitalization in a greenfield site is  easier than in a brownfield site. 

I think behind this behavior there is one thing: fear. 
Fear to change. 

Are these companies usually run by people older than 50 or 60?
Fear to change in most people at that age is VERY hard to handle, no matter how good the tech you show them is.

Author: IIoT#4707
Content: GG @Enrique C, you just advanced to level 1!

Author: enriquec_58034
Content:
The main problem with helping a site with ad-hoc solutions is that what you offer will never be as functionally effective as what they have built themselves. That’s because what they have is their solution, specifically designed to address their unique issues.

I encountered this problem while assisting a power generation company in overhauling their renewable energy park management system. They had control sites in Oporto and Houston. In Houston, they had an in-house tool involving no fewer than 30 Excel files. It was incredibly difficult to convince them to move away from it and adopt a commercial solution

Author: stephenbryant_89711
Content:
> Are these companies usually run by people older than 50 or 60?
The company in my story is.  To be fair, it's attitude not age that makes the difference.  Elon has worked (and slept!) on the factory floor.  I'm pretty sure none of the top 2 levels of management in my story's company has done either - certainly not in the last decade.

I have noticed lots of companies realising they need to do something, but they're poking around in the dark, a bit lost.  Admitting you need help is not easy, and many will no doubt feel like that's same as admitting failure.  It isn't, but I think fear is involved here too.  The problem is certainly non-technical in nature.

Author: milanhurban
Content: It's also a very vulnerable position to be in. Even if you recognize you're not able to do it yourself and have to place trust in a third party, how can you be sure they know what they're doing and aren't just trying to rip you off? Who do you trust, the tech conglomerate, the one-man-show open-source fan, the consulting firm? References help here, but those have to come from successful projects in the first place, so someone has to take the leap first.

Author: sparkylarks
Content:
But surely you know someone , who knows someone?

but I look at it like building a building.
you start with an architect, and find one you trust or vibe with, look at wht they have done before.
The Architect, put together a plan that suits you and together you go out and look at people who can build it.

Take baby steps, look at what others are doing, go on some tours of other factories to see what they did.

but to build a Smart Factory that runs on lots of paper, that's nonsense.

Author: tomasvojtek
Content: From my experience, the vast majority of manufacturing companies run on two solutions: 1. MES (Microsoft Excel Solution) 2. FPS ( fucking paper solution). And in mid-size companies, everything is about cost savings. If your solution can cut people (whole person), then you might have a chance. if you just save some time but no hard saving is doable in a few months, then it is a very hard sell, and only progressive-thinking companies will adopt it. So if you can save a person 1 hour a day, but they still have to pay the salary, then it's going to be very hard to sell something because this is not cost-cutting but cost addition. And lastly, this is also connected to average wages, some solutions are easy to sell in Germany, but hard in Romania or Poland, because is cheaper to just pay someone to do it on paper than to digitize.

Author: tomasvojtek
Content: That is a very good analogy. Unfortunately, I have not seen many real "architects" that actually can produce value. What I saw are overpriced presentations and workshops on the topics by consultants who have no clue what they are talking about and with 0 conversions to reality.

Author: sparkylarks
Content:
Saving 1 hour a day, 
- that is a 12.5% increase in the amount of product each person creates in a day
- So you can now sell 12.5% more stuff, at no increased labour cost and possible a low energy cost increase

Or send people home an hour early, pay them the same and save the electricity costs.

but in most cases, you will have an overtime bill, where you can save. so assuming 10 and hour, and time an a half for over time, the wage bill to produce the same goes from 95 to 80. that is a 15% saving on wages. plus the reduction in electricity because you can turn off the lights.

Author: tomasvojtek
Content: I absolutely understand the logic and agree with you. Unfortunately, I was not able to sell anything with this reasoning. Maybe I'm just a bad salesman. For instance, in the CEE region, white-collar people can be mandated to work unpaid overtime for up to 150 hours a year. If the company is not overreaching, it has 0 monetary impact on them. You can argue with the well-being and turnover of people... But my experience is that they just don't care. But this can be different from region to region therefore, disclaimer: it is my experience, and it is not universal. But I saw it in multiple countries in Europe and North and South America.

Author: sparkylarks
Content:
That is because companies are paying 100k+ for a consultant to tell them, here are all the problem that you told me you have.
and very often the consultant doesn't give any actionable advice.

And I think that kills the whole process.

and Architects who can produce value, are both
 - busy
- likely to be high on the Dunning Kruger curve and so don't tell the worlds about the value they can add

Author: zeratall
Content: Hahaha, “busy” hits the nail on the head with that one!

Author: t.vesa
Content:
I would like to chime in with my two uneducated cents here, without a day of experience in the SI field:
Driving the business off a cliff and ending up closing because you failed the digital initiative—now that's also a change and should raise fear in executives on a much more primal level, like the cold, sweaty, sleepless-night type of shit, seriously. And I'm saying this not just to be a dick, but to dig a bit deeper into the problem, and I think this should be communicated as it is. Obviously, there's much that goes into it to demonstrate the important aspects, and I do not advocate for rudeness—far from it. But I believe eventually anyone smart enough for you to even be willing to work for will understand this anyways and appreciate the candid approach because they've seen a hundred guys who just want the sale and don’t have the solution that's needed. Basically, there's pain ahead, but you choose the flavor.

they do not understand what Digital Transformations is, or how to adapt any plans to specific companies.

Author: nickn5549
Content: I have been through it as the 'architect of change'. You have to keep at it, and one day, C-Suites will realise that people are suddenly more efficient and you can do more with less. Or you run and find somebody that really needs your help. In my case, I stayed and pushed uphill, until suddenly, the whole thing was the jewel of the entire factory. The eye-opener, ironically, was the attention and praise from outside (customers, suppliers) before the top management realised the value. Of course, in the meantime, the end-users (shopfloor, engineering, quality) were happily using the new system(s), and only TOP C 'class' was oblivious to it...

Author: georgemoshakis
Content: I don't really know if the following is for digital transformation or for the edge but i will try here. The very first step that we have all learned on this community we need to take for digital transformation apart from the education is to collect data. nobody argues i want to believe about that. We all or the majority here that have visit even couple of factories know that legacy systems or even systems like 5 or 10 years before which by the way for manufacturing are considered brand new, are all over the place and we are calling to collect data from those systems. from my experience there are two ways forward. One, we say the customer that you need to contact the machine oem and tell him that we want to extract all data in an opc ua or what ever we choose. second way forward, no worries we will go into the plc ourselves and we will extract the data. Now apparently the first way is the preferable one since we are talking that any organisation call us in, is mature and most likely serious enough with their data that's why he call us in first place. From my experience in the filed is that once the customer call the oem the exact that moment we lost the ball to keep the proof of concept or what ever project we have undertake on track. Suddenly the ball is on how busy the oem is, how quickly he can do the job and so on so forth. if we choose the second way forward then we put the customer instead of a piece of mind state, shifts to an anxious state, having thoughts like can they really do it, what if they do something and then I have problems on the machine and the list of thoughts goes on. I would love to hear from the experts on this community how they handle this, since we are talking for the very first step any proof of concept requires right ?

Author: enriquec_58034
Content:
From the answers, I see 4 barriers to implement digital transformation projects in manufacturing companies:

1) Low awareness > CEOs see digital transformation as too risk (difficult, expensive and a mess) so:
- Some ignore the issue, lacking vision and unaware of the consequences
- Some make superficial changes, but fail to address the elephant in the room

2) Trust > Helping them is difficult, because:
- Some find hard to recognize they need help
- If they seek for help, they do not know who to trust

3) 2 ways to solve the problem that neither works
- Consultant: listened by the CEO, but short on delivering actionable solutions
- Architect: the opposite

4) Main driver to get buy-in: demonstrate MEANINGFUL cost savings. It is all about cost reduction

Note: Transversal issue to all manufacturers. No matter size or region

Some observations (purely from my experience):
- I agree, although surprised to see no differences between companies in different regions and sizes (ie. many Swiss companies are family companies, in which management is more long term focused vs public companies)
- Little can be done about Low awareness. The majority of companies will see the consequences when it is too late
- A viable solution would be a person with both consulting and tech skills. If it is a firm it should be small. The incentives of a consulting firm and its clients become more misaligned as the former grows
- Obtain meaningful cost savings in a short period of time is very difficult

Author: sammysevens777
Content:
machines and oem are a little broad in your post.

heres what that means:
- communication interfaces differ oem to oem
- some adopt standards, some make their one, and many publish apis
- depending on your machine, reviewing the oems communication interfsces will likely lead you to a lot of material with code / commands etc. to extract data
- if not, yes contact the oem....
- tapping into an existing plc is also a good option, so long as you separate code you add to capture data from main functions....however, if youre concerned your data extraction could hinder machine performance, reevaluate how you ate interfacjng with the machine...communication should not impede performance

in most cases work with the oem, a lot of their code is also not as "good" as what majot players ptovide, so ultimately you may need tp work woth them and in that case, who better than the machine maker?

Author: georgemoshakis
Content:
Thank you for your email, but it seems we're addressing different topics. My concern isn’t about OEMs or related issues. From both a commercial and project progression standpoint, relying solely on each OEM to handle tasks independently isn’t advisable—in my experience, this approach can lead to complications and unsecure delivery times from system integrator. This results to unsecure revenue streams and everytihing associated with. 

Attempting to make adjustments ourselves within their PLCs, no matter the level of expertise, simply isn’t feasible. Major clients like Coca-Cola, Kellogg's or Nestle are unlikely to permit direct access to any of their machines in the plant from a small system integrator. Unless you have a different experience but from 25years of building sites all around the globe, each one time we have tried to go as such, customer was uncomfortable. And I mean with customers we have built them the entire factory and they trust us 100%. 

If anyone can discuss a more cohesive approach that aligns with these constraints, I'm open to hear it.

Author: sohyun926735
Content: Hi Folks, i have a projects to build an energy analytics dashboard to customer. Normally they will need to have which kind of analytics for the energy dashboard?

Author: sparkylarks
Content:
Electrical Energy or including Gas, steam etc.

Generally you need to have the instantaneous rate i.e. kW.

But the kWh is more important. Showing the energy used in the past  x hour/days etc

Author: geoffnunan
Content:
I would say it depends on the customer.
Most of the companies I work with are not just interested in energy consumption, but energy consumption in context.
They want to be able to answer questions like:
- do different machines use different amounts of energy to product the same product?
- if not, it the difference significant enough to justify changing the equipment to more efficient equipment?
- do different crews or shifts operate the machine in a more energy efficient manner? If so, how?
It's easy to reduce energy consumption. Just turn the factory off.
What is interesting is 'Specific Energy Consumption' which is the amount of energy used to produce a specific quantity of output.

Author: rickbullotta
Content: Also analyzing by product/SKU and by production state (idle, run, changeover) can be very insightful particularly when heat is the primary energy driver.  Scheduling and sequencing changes can make a big difference in costs.

Author: _dyland
Content:
Some of the highest ROI projects I have done have been to reduce energy consumption while keeping up or increasing production rates and quality.

Reducing the amount of Gas used by Dryers, Systems that filter and allow water to be reused, reducing inrush current on large motors, transferring heat from effluent - to name a few.

Author: _dyland
Content: Not all of these had fancy dashboards, but a dashboard could have reduced the amount of time it took to identify the issues, identify the root cause, calculate the ROI, and prove the ROI on the backend.

Author: nickjephcott_88228
Content: Would love to get everyone’s view as to where they think PLM sits within the single infra stack. Currently we have Cloud at the top and then ERP, MES, SCADA, PLC/HMI and then the sensors that sit at the very bottom.

Author: nickjephcott_88228
Content:
The following is an analogy I got from Google Gemini: Imagine building a house.

PLM: The architect's blueprints, specifying the design, materials, and construction process.

ERP: The contractor's plan for managing resources, budget, and timelines.

MES: The foreman overseeing the day-to-day construction activities.

SCADA/PLC: The tools and machinery used by the construction workers.

The blueprint (PLM) guides the entire project, even though the architect doesn't directly operate the tools (SCADA/PLC).

Author: nickn5549
Content: We place PLM at Level 4, adjacent to ERP, because of its strategic level (deals with product design and lifecycle management, more aligned with enterprise-level planning , focused on long-term product development) and its relationship with ERP (supports high-level business decision-making, manages product information across the entire lifecycle, shares enterprise-level strategic perspective).

Author: evjakec
Content: Agreed. Level 4.

Author: rickbullotta
Content: Really depends on the industry of course. In aerospace and defense, the loop from the shop floor to PLM is usually tight.  As you head towards the continuous process end of the spectrum, PLM almost becomes irrelevant.

I think Cloud relates more to infrastructure whare as the Level 1 to 4 of the pyramid relate more to the functionality.

that is another are of confusion in that MES and MOM software can operate at multiple level, or an ERP can have some MOM functionality

Author: .killnine
Content:
I think what this is called is 'Agency'. 

I come from a very large enterprise organization where everyone had their silo they were expected to work in. I rose quickly in the organization because I was able to cross those silos, and was eager to learn about related areas of the business. (It's also important to note I had a supervisor who encouraged that). 

Eventually, though, almost my whole team ended up moving on to new organizations because people felt like, despite being a highly digitally-literate manufacturer, they didn't have the control of their destiny like they wanted. Projects and deadlines would, seemingly arbritrarily, come down from on high. Politics would pit managers (and their teams) against one another to where a team would complete a project just to see it dismantled by another team. It was organized, but almost to a weaponized degree. I really liked the organization for the most part, but that was the most demoralizing.

I ended up moving on as well and am at a manufacturer in the same industry, but at the _very beginning_ of their journey. Most everything was paper or, potentially an excel spreadsheet. They were pretty good at it, but hitting the limit of what they could make work.

As a one-man show, I've helped (and been enabled by management) completely replace the network infrastructure across our plants, replace legacy accounting system with a cloud-based solution allowing for remote work, implemented a temporary off-the-shelf ERP to build a culture of digital literacy in the org and greatly speed up the ability for the business to see the flow of material into and out of the plant. And now we're onto making use of data that's 'locked' behind the InTouch/Wonderware/PLCs of our equipment.

Culture does, indeed, a lot to do with the agency I have in the organization.

Author: evjakec

What about thoughts on having a technical only staff that self manages vs traditional models with program\project managers, business analysts, etc. it would seem engineers also get frustrated for having to respond to people that are not their boss and question what value they bring to the team. The alternative is that they need more soft skills and will have to produce reports of progress and be more customer facing. Can it work, or would you rather have focused time on engineering tasks only?

Author: _dyland
Content:
The right people should be in the right seats. 

I would run fast from any company that only consisted of self managing engineers... 

A successful team takes all types. The skillset needed to build a thing is very different from the one needed to sell it, to dream it, to coordinate it, and to keep everything moving in the same direction in the name of a common goal.

Author: _dyland
Content: The thing that most technical people are missing - and to tie it back to the theme of why digital transformation fails - is a lack of understanding of the bigger picture.

Author: zack.scriven
Content: prioritizing

Author: evjakec

Author: _dyland

Author: _dyland

Author: evjakec

Author: _dyland

Author: _dyland

Author: _dyland
Content: A team of engineers building an MES syatem - sure. but not a team that intends to drive systemic transformation of a manufacturing buisness.

Author: evjakec

Author: _dyland
Content: There is a difference in the personnel required to map the business and work with the c-suite then there is to implement a specific solution.

Author: _dyland
Content: I should add, that while I push against a bottom up approach driven exclusively by engineers, I also push back against a top down approach driven by consultants.

Author: _dyland
Content: Not to sound like a broken record, but it takes all types.

Author: _dyland
Content: We need more awareness in the bottom up approach as well as more technical aptitude and experiance in the top down one.

Author: _dyland
Content: AND not OR.

Author: dustin0101
Content: It's been a struggle to find a solution to get our PLCs connected to the network. The site doesn't want to install a dedicated OT network, and IT has not been very willing to collaborate to find a workaround. I started at this position about a year and a half ago and somehow convinced leadership to get me an Ignition license but we only have it connected to one production line. If I were able to connect the other PLCs to the network, I could move the deployment to our server.

Author: joshuastover
Content: The beast that is IT doing IT things...

Author: ted.garrison
Content: Just layer OT onto the IT Network.  Create OT Vlans and put those PLCs on that Vlan.    Doesn't require any additional switches (assuming there are enough free ports) or other infrastructure.    THat's how we do it.

Author: dustin0101
Content: This is the route I am taking, but IT still controls all the Vlan segmentation 😬

Author: sparkylarks
Content:
You can also look at just adding PLC's onto the IT network. Many have dual NICs. The other NIC can be used for the machine network.

But @Ted Garrison is 💯 correct. There should be a VLAN for each line/machine, and then use of manages switches to limit unwanted traffic.

Author: dustin0101
Content: Already tried that, IT won't let me put PLCs on the IT network. My Ignition deployment is set up in a similar fashion, basically just running on a dual NIC PC plugged into the local PLC network and wifi connected to our company wide network. This actually isn't in compliance with IT policy either though.

Author: ted.garrison
Content: Ours does as well.  But they have created some for us that we "own" and control the IPs on.  So we don't have to go to them everytime we need to setup something new.

Author: dustin0101
Content: Nice, I'll check and see if they'll let me do something like that.

Author: sparkylarks
Content:
There are a few ways where you can essentially have " firebreak" devices( not sure if that is the right term)
But essentially put a device that connects to your OT Equipment in the plant floor, and publish it directly to the Cloud and deal with it there.
Even if instead of the cloud you send it to you on prem servers the principle still holds. the Siemens CC716 does this.

But fundamentally that is using a hammer to bash in a screw instead of getting a screw driver.

Here I think you really need to sit down with IT and say. 
This is what I need to do, Tell me how you want me to do it.\

The best approach depends on you, the IT team and the dynamic between them. I have seen owners and Plant managers, tear into IT because they were being problems. And it works.

I tend not to take that approach, I often take the butter them up approach and ask for their help in ensuring we get this right. 

If they do not know the best approach, there are a lot of great people on this server who can tell them the best approach.

Author: schwabendaddler
Content: Sorry in advance if this is a dumb question but I thought some might have been in a similar situation and have some advice for me or are in a higher job position to give their point of view. So I work in a quality lab checking incoming an outgoing parts with manual and computer aided measuring equipment at a local automotive supplier. Their digital transformation is rather slow. Outside of my job duties in my spare time I do c# coding. To make my life easier at work I started to develop a software at home which collects and shows data from the machines in a way that exactly matches my preferred workflow and is not readily available by third party or the device manufacturers. Over the months I spend quite a lot of time on coding and more and more featurers got added. Now several people from department lead to plant manager saw what is possible and want to use it as well all over the plant. I feel a little bit of dilemma. On one hand it feels nice to get recognized for the work I did and I am happy to help coworkers and the company. On the other hand I feel like it would be nice to get somehow compensated for the time I used in my spare time before handing over software and source files also knowing additional mandatory work will be added in future because other people are involved. Is it expected by a company that in a case like this all I do and create for work is automatically owned by them because I am an employee and should always act in best interest for company with or without money involved ? Do you guys who develop digital transformation applications for your company have a different mindset (When working on an idea outside of paid hours) ?

Author: jpmac.s

Author: lemonaid8
Content: If there's a chance other companies could use your software, i'd say spin it as a SAAS and offer your employer a lifetime contract for free. An easier choice can be asking your employer to take your software and spin it as their own product, but you get a good chunk of equity. I've seen both routes in my software engineering domain and they're both possible and smart. If you don't want to get into any of this, then ofcourse use it for a promotion and salary bump, maybe a better contract. Just remember a lot of great products were built exactly this way, so congratulations!

Author: .stopple
Content: Anyone in here work for an OEM or deal with OEMs frequently? Looking to connect and get your take on data collection and monitoring from an OEM perspective. Thanks!

Author: stephenbryant_89711
Content: What sort of OEM are you after?

Author: r.pop
Content: I’ve done both. If it’s Automotive just pack it up and move on to the next job.

Author: .stopple
Content: Preferably automation or packaging machines or similar large industrial equipment

Author: _dyland
Content:
I usually run into two types of OEM, 

One doesn't care about data, they already sold the machine - or they can sell it to another party that doesn't care... Aka, too bad, no data, go.into the PLC and find the tags ourselves.

The other loves data, they especially love your data, and are happy to charge you a few to access their web portal that allows you to see your data. Need that data locally, too bad, it's a proprietary protocol they built... But at least they have a $10,000 gateway they will sell you, but only if their techs come out for a week to install and configure it. Basically, this type becomes, pay the fee and get the gateway, pay the fee and scrape their website, or sit there for a month with Wireshark and figure it out. 

Sometimes, not often but sometimes, we run into a third that is excited about data but has never been asked to do It before or didn't know they could... These guys will work with us and help identify what is needed to best access the data. 

99.99% of the time it's a major pain.

Author: _dyland
Content: I prefer brownfield when dealing with OEM equipment, especially if the OEM has been out of the picture for a few years, at least then there is no political battle with them ... It's just get in and figure it out.

Author: .stopple
Content: Thanks for the insights. I didn't know there were so many that did proprietary or that actively prevent the standard PLC protocols to have others access the data through OPC UA, modbus, etc. Do you prefer the figure it out approach over having an OEM that already has the important data ready to go and accessible? Assuming they make it accessible in a friendly way (fair price and not web scraping or similar).

Author: _dyland
Content:
I would prefer they make it accessible over a common protocol (Even Native PLC Tags / Addresses is fine). Most of the ones on the PLC side don't necessarily lock it down, they just have heavily standardized and messy code that often has entire sections abandoned or unused... it makes reverse engineering it a challenge - Not too hard but rarely in the budget of the end user... 

If the data is clean, structured, and meaningfully addressed / named - than it shouldn't be hard for the end user to pick up with any SCADA, IIoT Platform, or gateway appliance. It is sad that it is viewed as an add on and not a minimum requirement... Most places I got I try and convince the client to write it in their spec but they rarely do... often times they feel like it would prevent them from getting the most effective machine.

Its a catch 22 - OEMs wont do it until enough customers demand it and customers wont demand it because they need hte machines for production.

Author: _dyland
Content: It is the complied and propriatory ones I really take issue with - they should be exposing the data in some way or another - hell, im happy with a well documented Modbus TCP table... that should say a lot right there.

Author: .stopple
Content: This is all very helpful. If you're open to it maybe I'll ping you in a few days after I get a chance to solidify my thoughts on what I have in mind and what you've said here. Thanks!

Spell out everything in detail. Don't expect anyone has the same idea if what a base acceptable product is. Like redundant IOservers 5 million dollar MES in System Platform/AvevaMES.
