It helps that they know you are solving it too and happy to pay for it.


Be very deliberate

Author: vaughnturner
Content:
Derek, here's a couple of examples: 

Example Digital Strategy Statements
 
"We use accurate, unified, digital data and information to drive decision making, quickly, and in real-time. [Business case for why we are a digital company goes here]"
 
"We use accurate, unified, digital data and information to drive decision making, quickly, and in real-time. 
We leverage an infrastructure that treats all producers and consumers of data and information as nodes in an ecosystem that interact with one another through a Unified Namespace. [Business case for why we are a digital company goes here]"

Author: hobbes1069
Content: Third sentence, “All implementations will be consistent with our digital strategy and meet our minimum technical requirements.”

Author: sparkylarks
Content:
I think it is very easy to create a generic Digital strategy, but for me the Strategy should focus on why, 
of course it is it dive improvements, make decisions faster, become a data drive company. 

That is like saying I want to exercise more so I feel better and lose weight, but the why is more important,
 
I want to lose some weight so I look better while dating
I want to be stronger so I pick up my kids for longer,   
I want to reduce injuries, so I'll be able to pick up my grand kids.

So when setting a digital Strategy, is it to lower the cost of production, is it to manage to keep up with Quality requirements,  is it to allow you to scale.  but like our reasons for keeping fit change, so too do our reasons for Digital Transformation, and so too should our strategy.

So @Vaughn Turner  I humbly suggest a small tweak

**WHY:** [Business case for why we are a digital company goes here]"
**WHAT:** "We use accurate, unified, digital data and information to drive decision making, quickly, and in real-time. 
**HOW:** We leverage an infrastructure that treats all producers and consumers of data and information as nodes in an ecosystem that interact with one another through a Unified Namespace.

Author: theph85
Content: That the tech part is not the hardest. Getting humans onboard is. Always start there, talk to them a lot, highlight what *everyone* gains, etc.

Author: sparkylarks
Content:
I think that happens when Digital Transformation is given to people who are good with Tech and bad with people, or more interested in things than people. Lets call them Engineers.

It can equally fail if you have people who are good with people and bad with Tech, or at least more interested in people than things,

Author: farid1623
Content:
In my case, I got everyone on board through different tailored pitches.  

For the COO and operations it's straightforward - getting accurate downtime, OEE, and Frontline communication tools is enough.    

For IT, it was explaining that this was an inevitability - and that if we own the process they can take their time in putting the correct guard rails in place.  If we wait, and our future owners / consultants / etc. decide digital transformation is needed, they will go with integrators, and IT will be forced to support them on a time crunch.  And if God forbid they decide on Redzone we will have to manage Apple products...

For the CFO it's explaining the $ saved by building in house, and the benefits for inventory management when the ERP is fully integrated with operations via the MES.

Author: evjakec
Content: If anyone needs another data point, many are speaking about this, Siemens in their CES keynote for example. The knowledge in factories is dwindling fast. If you’re not on digital platforms with good processes in  place, then you’re introducing risk. Average tenure was 20 years just 5 years ago. Now they estimate that’s down to 3. I’ve seen a few examples where companies have had to hire back retirees on short term contracts just to get the info they never wrote down. So that cost of doing nothing should be considered as well.

Author: hisma
Content: Love this, mirrors my thoughts that I made in the business case channel. Customers want to know "what do I gain by implementing a UNS", rather than vague claims like "future proofs your production" or "a single source of truth".  Neither of those statements paints a clear picture of what a customer stands to gain when the job is done. Paint a picture so compelling that making the move is a no brainer. That picture will probably require understanding that companies pain points and how UNS solves them.

Author: jcthibaudet
Content: Hi! In which training module (mastermind? Mentorship?) does Walker cover the writing of a digital transformation strategy? I have just started the journey and I would think that this is the one of 1st element covered in details but I can't find it.. Thank you!

Author: hobbes1069
Content:
Not sure of the module but I can give you the gist. It should be a 3 sentence statement on why YOUR company wants to digitally transform. For that reason it’s hyper specific to your company so you really have to develop it.

Each of the statements should be more specific than the previous.

It can take a lot of effort / iteration to come up with the digital strategy and then you have to live by it. It could mean choosing a more expensive solution that meets your minimum technical requirements.

If it feels wrong then you need to re-evaluate your digital strategy

Author: _dyland
Content: Emphasis on the WHY. I usually have to ask five or six times before we ever get to the real reason. A few of the earlier answers can help fill in the narrative too.

Author: jcthibaudet

Author: mandeepsidhu2001_96284
Content:
The company I work for, Schneider Electric are starting a digital transformation with Thames Water. Probably the largest private water utility in Europe. 

We and TW have seen many Projects fail, we're determined this will be a success. 

We spent 2 days we hosted 20 of their company in our fancy central London offices, mainly operational but also had OT, data and smart departments in the room. We had heads, above whom is the c-suite. 

Half of day 1 we did the Insights colour profile exercise so we know how to talk to each other.
The other half of day 1 and half of day 2 we listened.
The last bit of day 2 we replayed what we learned and our high level next steps based on what we were hearing.
Tempting as it was, we never went into solution mode.

We came up with this:
Change management and people driven from day 1
Cyber and data governance all the way through 
Establish an exec sponsor, cross discipline steering committee and working groups in a pyramid feeding insight and decision upward . 
Establish a product name, branding and communication plan. 
Start activities Targeting delivery of  a minimum viable product for a model Office 
Define the 5 year programme 

Any thoughts or inputs?

Author: codepoet80
Content: Build the information model *before* you start building the software architecture

Author: rickbullotta
Content: Problem is that nowadays you usually already have somewhere between 2 and 200 information models already.

Author: geoffnunan
Content:
I don't follow.
Surely your software architecture should be agnostic to the information model??

Author: codepoet80
Content:
teams get hung up on which software to use. until you know what you're doing and why, that exercise is premature.
I should have said:
1) start with the business use-cases -- what problems are you trying to solve
2) then define the information model that can help solve those problems
3) then figure out if you have connectivity to the data to fulfill that model
4) where you don't, go get that (which may be software)
5) finally, plumb the movement of the data to the business-problem-solving layer with software

Author: codepoet80
Content: to rick's point, if you already have 2-200 models, step 0 is rationalization and harmonization.

Author: zeratall
Content:
People like to focus on #3/5 instead of #2, imho #2 is the magic sauce for unlocking value. I always reference or use the term semantic interoperability. To me that is the true challenge with integration and today I see a lot of models that are semantically incorrect and have a lot of smells. (Which is a combination of modeling expertise by those doing the modeling, but also in the modeling tools, aka modeling tools that can support and capture nuances, this is where something like @GeoffNunan/Rhize really excels imho)

Imho The focus should be **__less __**of (but still a design consideration) around what @js  has coined "Integration (Protocol) Glue aka how do I get this tool to talk to this tool" and **__more __**on "How do I relate these two different forms of data (I.e. timeseries data, to unstructured (or relational, transactional, etc)  data in a way that people understand, that is easy to consume, and is appropriate (i.e. not making assumptions on concrete objects where properties don't apply or are appropriate).

Author: zeratall
Content:
Also an underlying theme/point your hinting on that I advocate all the time as an architect. Architecture should be focused on requirements/use cases and remain generic AS LONG AS YOU CAN. At some point in the design cycle you will need to make down selections on design patterns, frameworks, libraries, etc. But at soon as you do, you start to impose constraints on the design that may make compromises. Starting at the requirements/use cases ensures you define what is important so that when you do make those compromises you know where your priorites are, and what things are appropriate to compromise on. If you don't start there, you will find the architecture might start make compromises in areas that are not appropriate. 

Architecture is always about pro/cons, and a good architect knows how to identify priorities, and chose design patterns in such a way that the final design meets/excels in the areas that are important for the user, and makes compromises in areas that aren't mission critical.

Author: mrwinechit
Content:
In alignment with the ISA-95 standard, we are currently assessing two approaches for implementing a smart factory solution. The first approach utilizes vNode for factory-floor data acquisition integrated with GE Vernova as the MES platform. The second approach involves developing a fully customized solution using Python, Django, Flask, Hadoop, and Apache Spark.

From a manufacturing company’s perspective, which of these approaches would be more practical and scalable in terms of performance, integration capability, and long-term maintainability?

Author: geoffnunan
Content:
There is a 3rd option. Use an ISA95 compliant Headless MES platform that saves you from the pain and suffering of Hadoop and Spark, but still gives you the flexibility of building your own UI using python and flask.
Dm me if you would like to know more.

Author: sim_sam3
Content:
Cognite is a neat imagining of a cloud-first industrial data fabric. Bunch of IDM and IDO features in one package. A UNS can theoretically help to create and facilitate that fabric, tho as I understand it, interaction deeply into the machine network is often an important feature, and this isn’t as “directly” possible right now if the UNS is implemented as an indeterministic message broker.  

When you consider the power of creating metadata catalogs to add additional context to schemas to aid queries and enhance the knowledge graph, and if folks can blend UNS with certain fabric expectations, we’ll really be cooking with gas.

Author: slamber12
Content: What kind of tools have been useful for metadata catalogs? I’m just using a SQL DB right now but I’m afraid we will quickly outgrow it

Author: IIoT#4707
Content: GG @Slamber, you just advanced to level 2!

Author: sim_sam3
Content:
There are a lot of fantastic alternatives to SQL, and folks have been storing metadata for a long time.

Wonderware InSQL stores records in binary files and metadata in SQL Server - really performant in and out and drove a lot of nice “historian” functions on top of store.

Modern systems would probably use light noSQL DB for objects and just a separate noSQL instance for metadata. Could monkey with those concepts for scale and performance tho.

Author: geoffnunan
Content:
We work with the DeltaV opc ua servers at Moderna. 
The biggest difficulty is getting the high-availability design right. DeltaV just use 2 opcau servers, but they are not synced, so the same message could have different timestamps depending on which of the 2 servers you subscribe to.

We did manage to get the EBR generation time down from 25minutes to 8 seconds though.

Author: sim_sam3
Content:
There’s ton that UA can do - it’s a massive specification that solves for many problems (some debate about its attempt to solve too many) and extensibility is foundational. But implementations vary quite a bit. Many just follow simple hierarchical data access server patterns. 

Oh and the link is an academic paper maybe 10 years ago that talks about its qualities as a graph server.

Author: bright_hummingbird_31342
Content:
For these historian backfill scenarios in continuous or batch industries, it’s more the latter. Some will elect to replicate everything and others will elect to replicate what’s needed for downstream data products supporting enterprise-level use cases. Infrequently capturing the changes of metadata and frequently capturing the value changes. With buffering and snowpipe streaming, ingestion is pretty efficient. The real cost with something like Snowflake is the compute on query-side. There is quite a bit of optimization that can be done using dynamic tables and views.

At the end of the day, it’s not going to be used for something like PI Vision where a process engineer is going to trend an instrumentation value to monitor and control the process. It’s used for more analytical and exploratory purposes. The downstream data products are often blended with other data (e.g., weather, customer demand, supplier data).

Does anyone already perform Simplification / Standardization phase on their process across multiples sites  (Pharma/F&B) before moving to an digitalization phase?

Author: sim_sam3
Content: Palantir.. Cognite.. they need to watch out, paradigms shifting. Well done Flow team!!

Author: evjakec
Content: Sanofi did this for their MES rollout. They presented it at the Siemens show. Wish it was available online. After review, they found they could only standardize 70% and used a building block approach so they could offer flexibility to the sites. They did find they could cut scope from their original recipes as well to simplify. I asked about adoption challenges and it was a minor issue because they had executive support. They built the templates, and then would go on site for “booster weeks” where they would deploy these templates. Sorry for the high level response, but it seemed to work for them. They had a need to accelerate as more sites transitioned and they were able to do that.

Author: craig101_58718
Content: Hi guys apologies I am new to this what is the average price of an MES system please

Author: sparkylarks
Content:
How long is a piece of String.

It really depends on what you want the MES to do, how big your organisation is and what planforms you already have and what platform you want to add.

you can get started for 10''s of thousands, building one or two functions on a few machines but you could be talking millions too

Author: craig101_58718
Content: would you buy of the shelf or build your own ??

Author: evjakec
Content: The range is wide but 75k USD for a small factory, minimal users (<50) up to 500k for large factories. That would be annual licensing. Of course development time for the initial deployment would depend on your scope. Plan for 1.5-2x the license cost for rollout. That assumes a standard vendor. If you get into the platform space, things change.

Author: sparkylarks
Content:
Because I build MES functions as a living I tend to lean towards Build.

But realistically if you build a MES on a platform like Ignition, or you buy and configure GE Proficy for example there is still a lot of customisation needed and the man-hours needed is not massively different.

And it very much depends on what you mean by a MES , what functions are you looking to get, and how quickly.

There are "Buy" solutions I would certainly use and configure to my needs, and "Build" solution I would not touch with a barge pole


But at this point I would always say the first steps are.
1 define your strategy 
2 Inventory your business and tech
3 define you Minimum Technical requirements
4 Define your Model Architecture.

At that point you are starting to think about solutions and in a really informed place to decide if build or buy is correct for your organisation.

Then you can look at your POC

Author: craig101_58718
Content: Thanks Jake that was helpful

Author: craig101_58718
Content: Thanks Mark when you say you build functions could you be a little more specific please

Author: sparkylarks
Content:
If you approach MES as a software I think you are setting your self up for failure.

I think if you focus on the functionality you want at that MES layer and look to see how you can implement that functioning you may find that some functionality is done in the ERP and some in your SCADA , so you need a lighter MES software to fill the gaps.

So if you engage with my company, we would look to do the front end study work and the look at what functions you want , maybe performance analysis, maybe scheduling, maybe Work order tracking etc.

And the we look to build out that functionality on the most appropriate platform or platforms

Author: sparkylarks
Content:
Depends on the Size of the Org, and the industry  you are in .
I love Node -Red but it is very limited for a full MES
for small Single Plant, FrameWorX, Ignition or Aveva are all very good,, I prefer FrameworX but all three are pretty broad platforms you can build of and integrate well into other systems.and you can certainly get a great solution for the core MES functions, and integrate specialised tools if needed for some of the other functions

for Larger organisation it really depends on what you want to achieve, for what I call a full suite MES I really like GE Proficy, Aveva MES not too bad if you already in that wheel house. They will cover off all the possible functions really. Ther are others but I have no experience with them at all.

If you are looking at Larger Enterprise solutions , the Traditional MES  might not be right. and you are looking  Litmus, Tulip,  Highbyte  Maersto Hub, Flow
